fields.headline: Somewhere for later
fields.trailText: Iceland | Spain | Peru | US | Southern Africa | Botswana | Armenia | Australia | US and Caribbean cruise
fields.body:
Europe

Iceland: Short Breaks Direct (0870 789 3338) is offering two nights' B&B at the Hotel Reykjavik for £341pp including return flights from Heathrow.

Spain: Watch the Barcelona Grand Prix on a four-night break with British Airways Holidays (0870 24 24 243) from £649pp. The package includes return scheduled flights from Gatwick to Barcelona on April 27, four nights' B&B at the three-star Hotel Lleo, transfers, Grand Prix tickets for April 28 and 29.

South America

Peru: Trips Worldwide (0117 987 2626, www.tripsworld-wide.co.uk ) is offering 14-day trips to Peru throughout the summer. Prices start at £2,247pp, including flights, accommodation, internal transfers and local guides.

North America

US: From June to August, Bon Voyage (0800 3163008, www.bon-voyage.co.uk) is offering five nights for the price of four in the four-star National hotel on Miami South Beach. The price, £587pp, includes return flights from Gatwick and room-only accommodation.

Africa

Southern Africa: Join the Friends of the Royal Observatory to see the eclipse on June 21in Zambia, combined with visits to two private game reserves in South Africa, Thorny Bush and Mala Mala. Departing Heathrow on June 19, returning June, the cost is £2,500. Temple World (020 8940 4114).

Botswana: A 10-day safari at Chobe National Park, departing Heathrow on April 10, costs £2,695pp from Cox and Kings (020-7873 5000), including full-board accommodation.

Australia: An 11-day-Round-Australia holiday from Airline Network (0800 727747, www.netflights.com) costs £1,299pp including international and internal flights with Gulf Air, departing from Heathrow. Includes a harbour cruise in Sydney and accommodation.

Atlantic: Save £1,220 on the brochure price of an 18-night Easter cruise from MSC (020-7637 2525) departing April 11 from Port Everglades, Florida and calling at San Juan, St Croix, Antigua, Guadaloupe, Funchal, Cadiz, Barcelona and Genoa. Prices start at £999, including flights, transfers, port and airport taxes, plus all on-board meals and entertainment.

fields.headline: Notes from a small resort
fields.standfirst: Once a year, the quiet seaside town of Pesaro comes alive to celebrate its favourite son. Michael McNay reports
fields.trailText: Once a year, the quiet seaside town of Pesaro comes alive to celebrate its favourite son. Michael McNay reports
fields.body:
Pesaro has streets named after Dante, Leonardo, Raphael and Michelangelo, a Viale Mascagni and a more important Viale Guissepe Verdi. But the one that really counts is part of the main drag between the station and the beach, the Via Rossini, where the great composer was born on February 29, 1792.

He lived to be 76, but by the age of 37 he had retired from the theatre having by then composed dozens of operas: enough to float a Rossini industry in Pesaro.

Every August, this small seaside resort holds a festival, meticulously re-staging the great operas - The Barber of Seville, Tancredi, La Cenerentola, The Thieving Magpie, William Tell - and the forgotten works, or those which, if remembered at all, are remembered for an overture here, a catchy aria there. There is a Rossini Foundation in town, devoted to scholarly research into all the doings of the master and to meticulously poring over the scores and correcting errors.

Last year, the festival productions were The Silken Ladder, The Siege of Corinth, and, the big one, La Cenerentola. This year's productions are La Gazzetta, La Donna del Lago and Le Nozze di Teti, e di Pelleo.

Pesaro about the size of Wells or Ripon and, surprisingly for Italy, is quieter than either. You can still jump into a Fiat and play the daily sport of picking off a pedestrian or two, but only on the roads encircling the town. Otherwise, the way to go is by pushbike or on foot.

That way, however fraught you are after arriving by jet from Heathrow and train from Bologna through castle-topped hills like the landscape in Giovanni Bellini's so-called Pala di Pesaro, it is not long before the pernicious charm of Italy, in EM Forster's phrase, takes hold.

It does not, mind you, necessarily take hold of everyone. One evening, in a trattoria by the sea, a tourist who evidently has not slipped into the local ways and culture comes in and picks out a table. After a full 30 seconds, he calls for service, "Hey, you." Failing to gain instant attention, he stands up, hooks a hand under the rim of the table, upends it, and stalks out. The waiters shrug, wave their arms a little, sweep up the broken glass, lay the table again. A couple of carabinieri arrive and take desultory notes, depart, and life goes on.

The following day, I am having lunch in the Bar El Cid. From the menu I pick - what else? - a Rossini. It has tomato on the pizza base with rococo whorls of mozzarella in 6/4 time. Just as I am about to fill my mouth, a flood of the citizenry sweeps in from the pavement, filling every inch of standing room. Simultaneously, the TV is switched on for the start of the Hungarian Grand Prix. Michael Schumacher is in pole position in his scarlet Ferrari, but Mika Hakkinen squeezes by on the first bend and the bar erupts with anguished cries of "Aieee! Madonna!" and slapped foreheads.

A boorish tourist is a rare episode; but Formula One is life itself, and an intimation of death. Seconds later, the fans have melted into the town and I raise a slice of Rossini to my mouth.

The serious seaside crowds go to Rimini a little to the north, but here in Pesaro there is a stretch of beach swept and combed each morning and planted with sun parasols. The streets and piazzas are lined with fragrant juniper trees. A gaily painted merry-go-round looks like something in a child's pop-up book; there is the usual clusters of lithe brown young Italian males in skimpy bathing slips negligently stroking their crotches; and lissom seven-eighths naked girls disdainfully not noticing.

You enter the post office in the Piazza del Popolo through a gothic facade flanked by saints leaning assertively out of their niches (it was originally a church); and an arcaded ducal palace built for the Sforzas, another of those glittering, sinister, warlike, civilised and debauched Renaissance families. The wooden ceiling in the great hall of their palazzo was theatrically painted with heraldic devices by the local artist who also built the stately if run-down range of buildings flanking the south of the piazza. All in a day's work in this place and that time.

Theatricality is the genius of the city, and the ongoing masterpiece is undoubtedly the annual Rossini Festival. The commune is proud of its prolific son, and they do him proud, with productions in the lovely little 18th-century Teatro Rossini, in the theatre of the Rossini Foundation, and in the Palafestival, an unlovely sports hall which, however,adapts spectacularly well to the demands of modern theatre technology.

Back at Heathrow next day, I slot Cenerentola into the car's CD player, final scene. Cinderella's silvery notes fill the space moving round the M25 with apprehension of joys to come. But then, at home, I turn to Guardian Sport. The fickle scarlet Ferrari had stayed in second place. Nine points to Hakkinen. Aieee! Madonna!

The practicals

Opera specialist JMB Travel Consultants (01905 830099, www.jmb-travel.co.uk) organises two- and three-night breaks to this year's Rossini Festival (August 10-24) from £627pp, including return schedule British Airways flights from Heathrow to Bologna, three- or four-star B&B accommodation and two best-category opera tickets.

fields.trailText: Los Angeles | Hong Kong | New York | Sydney/Brisbane | Paris | Amsterdam | Barbados | Delhi | Cairo | Christchurch | Eurostar
fields.body:

Los Angeles: £247

KLM from Manchester via Amsterdam. Must be booked by March 19. Valid for departures until April 5. Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum one month. Going Places Direct (0161-908 7967).

Hong Kong: £359

Air France from Heathrow, London City, Birmingham, Manchester, Newcastle, Edinburgh, Glasgow or Southampton, via Paris. Valid for departures until March 14. Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum one month. Quest Travel (0870 4445552).

Air India from Heathrow. Must be booked by March 31. Valid for departures until March 31. Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum one year. Lunn Poly Direct (0870 3334400).

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Countryside crisis
fields.body:
Countryside crisis

The cancellation of holidays in British country hotels and cottages continues in the wake of the foot and mouth disease crisis. Earlier this week, ministers met tourism representatives who are concerned that the disease may jeopardise an industry that, in England alone, employs 380,000 people. Total spending by visitors to the English countryside amounts to £12bn a year, according to the English Tourism Council. Advice remains not to walk in the countryside and to check with the local tourist board.

High fliers

Low-cost airlines are winning over customers, and charter services and short-haul scheduled airlines are losing out, according to a survey of the best and worst airlines by Holiday Which? Air New Zealand was the overall winner, but easyJet made it into the top group. Other highly-rated operators included Emirates and SAS. At the foot of the table were Air Europa and Sabre.

Cleaner Guernsey

Guernsey has the cleanest beaches in the British Isles, according to a survey by the Marine Conservation Society. The report surveyed 150 beaches and recorded the lowest levels of litter and the lowest density of sewage-related debris on Guernsey. For general information on Guernsey, call 01481 723552 (www.guernseytouristboard.com).

Euro explained

Lloyds TSB has published a free practical guide to the single European currency, Keeping You Posted About the Euro, available at their branches.

North and south

Quest Travel has launched a new brochure, The Americas, combining North and South America. For a copy, call 0870 4445552.

Virgin Canadian

On June 12, Virgin Atlantic is starting a daily scheduled service to Toronto from Gatwick from £347 return. Tel: 01293 747747 (www.virgin.com).

Midland America

British Midland starts its flights from Manchester to Washington DC on April 30 with a return fare of £274 and to Chicago on May 21 with a fare of £315. Tel 0870 6070555.

A dog's life

Dogs accompanying guests to the San Marino Hotel in Palm Springs, California, will now be offered the luxury treatment, including accupressure massage, fur cuts and creative grooming to make overweight dogs look thinner. Tel 001 800 6761214.

fields.headline: Harley street
fields.standfirst: It's the only way if you want to ride the American dream. Author Tom Cunliffe heads west on a Harley-Davidson
fields.trailText: It's the only way if you want to ride the American dream. Author Tom Cunliffe heads west on a Harley-Davidson
fields.body:
I walked into the wall of heat outside the air-conditioned diner and promptly burned my hand on the bars of my bike. Ahead, the land dropped away to Kansas and the Great Plains; behind lay half of America. The thermometer on the clapboard shack read 101F. It was going to be a tough afternoon.

Gingerly, I eased into my broad, black saddle, pausing to glance at Roz as my butt equalised with the frying-pan temperature. It hurt my eyes to look at her primrose-and-buckskin Harley. Against all apparent reason, she was slipping her arms into her armoured riding leathers. I wished she'd let the air flow over her instead, but I knew she wouldn't. She'd heard about tyres ripping off trucks on the rough back roads and sending scantily-clad riders on a fast slide across the gravel. Roz had decided she'd rather boil than bleed.

Cross Kansas and Nebraska as quickly as you can, because they're boring, appeared to be the received wisdom. Hit Colorado and Montana to see something worth the trip. I didn't know whether to believe this or not as we rolled down the 50-mile slope on to the gently undulating prairie, but by sundown I knew that our advisers had missed the point. Maybe it was because they drove cars.

Secure in an automobile, the traveller is insulated from the cruel climate of the plains by air conditioning, a comfy seat, the radio and his windscreen. The roads may run straight from horizon to heat-blurred horizon, but the motorcyclist's heightened perception demands awareness of every bump and crack under his spinning spokes. Grain silos glimmer like ghosts, wavering in the distance while cattle lazing in ancient buffalo wallows flash by close at hand. To comprehend the perspective puts a British-raised mind at full stretch.

Every so often, as we plugged on towards Dodge City, a truck would wobble into view three miles or more ahead. First, it was a smudge of colour several feet above the road, dancing on the heat. It might drop out of sight behind the next dip. Then, suddenly massive, with its turbos screaming, it would be on us, swaying as it ripped by. A wall of hot air threatened to hurl the quarter-ton motorbikes off the road, the blast so thick you can feel it: diesel exhaust, grit and grasshoppers.

It was partly the names that sent Roz and I on this pilgrimage to the heart of the US: Cheyenne, Santa Fé and Flagstaff have called me since boyhood. They are the breath of classic Western movies, the Transcontinental Railroad and Route 66, the very seeds of romance. Now it was leading us 12,000 miles from one small town to the next, into country and communities that grew wilder as we headed west.

"Nice bikes, guys. Where you folks from?" The young rancher filling up at the only gas station in Tryon, Nebraska, favoured the standard opening. This is a travelling nation. Americans are born on the road. They will move house more than twice as many times as their British equivalents.

"England? You don't say. You got time to come and meet the wife?"

Two hours later, we sat down to lunch in a modern, low-roofed ranch house, joining hands around the table with our host, Kirk, his wife, their two young children and his father - the old man's grandfather had been the first to settle the land. As we gave thanks for our daily bread, I realised that saying grace is not unusual around here. A summer hailstorm can wipe out a whole crop in 15 minutes. Kirk's wife opened a freezer the size of a wardrobe and produced three lumps of ice like tennis balls that had bounced off the family car that spring. Later, she showed me the car's roof. It might have been walloped by a hammer.

The following day, we all trucked 90 bullocks to market in North Platte after Grandad had rounded them up. He looked for all the world like John Wayne, except that he rode a Yamaha trail bike instead of a horse.

This open-handedness to travellers wraps around you like a blanket in rural America. Perhaps it's the novelty of a new face among people who live miles apart, but I prefer to think it dates from pre-TV times when casual visiting was an art form. We'd encountered it before in West Virginia, where we'd been rescued from the death throes of a hurricane. Sitting on the step of the local store-owner's cabin, we drank home-distilled whiskey and listened to stories from the proprietor and his family. Everyone on that lamplit porch could have earned a good living on the after-dinner speaking circuit. Tales of running moonshine to the Carolinas in all-American cars pursued by tobacco-chewing Feds vied with yarns of not-so-wily hunters trapped up trees with giant racoons scratching and biting them.

In between staying with new friends, Roz and I slept under canvas or in motels. Camping offered great sunsets and occasionally adventure, particularly when we side-stepped the official sites to brave the wilderness. It also took us closer to snakes and bears than we sometimes cared for, so we bought a night indoors when we could. Surprisingly, it was the motels that produced the characters.

Our budget kept us at the downmarket end of town, where ridiculously cheap deals were available. Better set-up travellers might have been enjoying firmer beds, extra towels and quieter air conditioning, but they were missing out on human interest. You don't meet itinerant harvesters with a life history like a Johnnie Cash song at the Holiday Inn. Nor do you come across a treasure hunter down to his last buck heading out for Wyoming to prospect a Pony Express station once sacked by the Sioux.

Worst of all, we'd have missed the craggy Vietnam veteran who muscled his ancient Harley into Medicine Lodge out of the most spectacular deluge. With him was a Missouri teacher on a big yellow Honda. It rained six inches that night, and twisters stalked the prairie. As we sheltered behind the thin walls, the Vietnam vet recounted how that morning they had ridden over the snowy passes of Colorado: the teacher had to be in front of her class the next day or lose her job. They roared out into the rain before breakfast with 500 miles still to go. Roz and I had three months to find our way to San Francisco and back. Feeling vaguely guilty, we switched on The Weather Channel, brewed up on our tiny stove, lay in late and dreamed of California.

There are many ways to travel America, but for the full experience, try throwing your leg over a bike. You'll understand the awesome heat, the bugs, the sheer scale of everything, while the unique motorcycle mix of vulnerability and raw power will never fail to fascinate the locals. Americans love Harley-Davidsons. Ride one westwards and you won't be alone for long.

Way to go

Organising a motorcycle tour in the US can be accomplished in three ways:

Ship your own bike: From Southampton via Wallenius Lines to Baltimore costs £390 ride-on, ride-off, one-way, including UK port charges and Customs. You will have to pay locally in the US for port and Customs (around $100). Call Dockside Freight Services (02380 336644). Claridon Shipping (01375 656100) will arrange everything, including crating your bike for maximum safety. Three-week return freight to Sturgis, South Dakota, costs £750 plus riding insurance.

Hiring: various websites, including www.denverharleyrentals.com and Western States Motorcycle Rentals, www.members.aol.com/_ht_a/azmcrent. Hiring costs around $800 per week ($550 for a 1200 Sportster), but there are a number of extras, including state tax and always two levels of insurance, of which you are well advised to choose "the full monty". Up to $1,500 deposit.

Buying and selling in the US: Far cheaper than renting, but make sure you can insure it.

United States on the Road is published by Insight Guides at £17.99.

fields.trailText: It sounds like the ultimate in luxury - being chauffeured between palatial hotels in the land of princes. Pas Paschali enjoys the view from an Ambassador's windows
fields.body:
Forget what you've read. Travelling around India doesn't necessarily mean having to take the backpacking-on-a-budget route. Nor does it have to be the all-inclusive, pricey package. Those who've dreamed of visiting the land of maharajas may be encouraged to learn that there's a third way: the customised package. In other words, travel independently but let someone else do all the legwork.

A customised package means you choose your itinerary, your accommodation and your means of transport. For me and my travelling companion, this was a 17-day tour of Rajasthan, staying in the most spectacular palaces and castles, with a chauffeur to ferry us around.

Our original intention was indeed to go the backpacking route, relying on the Indian rail system and seeking out accommodation on arrival at each town. As we jetted off to Delhi, all we had booked for our three-week holiday was a couple of nights in the Lonely Planet-recommended Hotel 55. The rest was to be left to spontaneity.

But on our very first day in Delhi, we walked right into a scam - there's one operating on every street corner for the unwary tourist - prompting us to change our plan. We were looking for the tourist information office, and were ushered into a building displaying the sign "Tourist Information" on the right street. But it turned out to be a travel agent; we only realised this afterwards, when we noticed several places claiming to be the official tourist information office.

Nevertheless, it was the travel agent who first gave us the idea to devise our own package. He told us train travel was far from glamorous, and, on the more popular routes, we wouldn't get our first choice of trains. Rajasthan is a big place and some journeys can take 12 hours, so travelling in anything less than a first-class sleeper would mean arriving exhausted and irritable - and possibly minus our rucksacks.

Had we thought of a chauffeur-driven car instead? We were quoted a price of £475, which seemed reasonable for a 17-day itinerary, inclusive of all fuel and taxes.

We were only doing a small part of India, but we wanted to see the "real India", and we wanted to do it exhaustively. My biggest anxiety was not seeing it all, due to inadequate planning or inconvenient train timetables. Yet we were rather indignant at having fallen prey to a con trick. So we decided to get a quote from a reputable agent.

Off we went to Cox & Kings ("seeing travellers around India since 1758") and they undercut the first quote by £75. In a burst of confident enthusiasm, and more than a little relief, we handed over our sketched-out itinerary, listing our choice of hotels (we pushed the boat out here), and left all the arrangements with them. At the end of the day, they had sorted it all out: a cream 1961 Ambassador car was due to pick us up from our hotel the following morning and transport us to the land of princes, Rajasthan.

We had complete mobility, all hotels booked for us, an official guide laid on at each destination, entry to all the sights, plus the chauffeur's accommodation, fuel and taxes paid for up front. All for £800 each.

It went like a dream. On our driving days, we set off in the cool of the morning, at 8am, travelled for between four to six hours, including a stop at some landmark temple, palace or fort en route, arriving at our hotel some time between noon and 2pm. Six hours in a car is not as bad as it sounds. The view from the window was endlessly fascinating, even in the desert: dusty villages, hilltop forts, wildlife, the fluorescent saris of Rajasthani women, garishly-customised lorries, camel carts, painted cows. And we made stops wherever we wanted. By train, we would have missed the 15th-century temples at Ranakpur and the beautifully-preserved ghost town of Fatehpur Sikri, the ertswhile capital of the Mughal empire.

We stayed in the most exquisite hotels - often in the maharaja's palace complex. When the maharaja's palace was beyond our means, we stayed in the home of a family member of the maharaja, but on those occasions we ended up with the best room. And to satisfy our curiosity about the grander, more expensive palace in town, we booked ourselves in for dinner, thus allowing us to snoop around.

We did a vast anticlockwise circuit out of Delhi. Our first stop was the village of Mandawa, in the Shakawati region renowned for its ornate "havelis", or mansions, built by wealthy merchants in the 19th century. Inside and out, the walls are illustrated with maharajas on elephant-back or more up-to-date transport, such as motor cars or the Wright Brothers' plane. The owners were keen to demonstrate that they were keeping up with the latest developments in the west. We stayed in the spectacular Mandawa Castle, with its labyrinthine staircases and battlements, and that evening dined under the stars in its vast candlelit garden courtyard.

The next day we headed for Bikaner, a desert town in the north, with its magnificent fort and, in an outlying village, the infamous "rat temple". The rats that scurry everywhere are believed to be reincarnations of a holy woman, and are therefore sacred. We stayed at the Gajner Palace, an ornate 19th-century, red sandstone edifice on a lake, set in its own nature reserve.

We continued deeper into the Thar desert until we reached the golden city of Jaisalmer, near the Pakistan border. Built from yellow sandstone, it's a pure Arabian Nights fantasy. It's also the camel capital of Rajasthan; everyone takes a camel safari here, and we were no exception. Our hotel, the Himmatgarh Palace, on a hill outside of town, afforded us a great view of the walled city rising dramatically out of the desert plain like a mirage.

In Jodhpur, the Brahmins first painted their houses blue to differentiate themselves from the lower castes. Then everyone followed suit; now Jodhpur is known as the blue city. It has the most imposing mountain-top fort and the teeming Sardar bazaar, where we bought saffron, nutmeg and masala spices for our "chai". Our modest abode, the Ajit Bhawan, built by the maharaja for his younger brother, lies in the shadow of the grandiose Umaid Bhawan, possibly the most expensive hotel in India, where suites cost up to £700 a night.

Not to be outdone by other cities, Udaipur has appointed itself the "marble city", a tranquil oasis with beautiful lakeside palaces. The Lake Palace Hotel, the one that appears to float on the lake, was used for a James Bond film location. Alas, it's now popularly known as the Octopussy Hotel, and the film gets shown every night somewhere in town. We dined there one evening, picked up by the palace boat at sunset, though we stayed in the Shiv Niwas Palace, neighbours of the maharana (a rank even higher than maharaja).

From one lakeside location to another: to Pushkar, top place of pilgrimage for Hindus, its sacred lake surrounded by temples, with steps, or "ghats", leading down to the water's edge. A respite from sightseeing, there was little to do here except sit on the palm terrace of the Pushkar Palace and gaze out on to the lake, watch people bathe, and listen to the drums and chanting drifting across the water from the temples opposite.

The capital of Rajasthan, Jaipur, is the pink city. Built from red sandstone in the 18th century, this rectangular walled city was designed on a grid - remarkable for its time. Though our hotel, the Alsisar Haveli, enjoyed a busy city-centre location, it was remarkably tranquil in its lush garden setting. One of the attractions of Jaipur is the magnificent Amber Fort, nestling in the mountains high above the city. Most tourists complete the climb by elephant, but we were sated with our camel ride of a few days previous. Besides, there's no shade on an elephant in 35-degree heat.

It's quite fair to say that Agra is the most polluted of cities, but it is home to that wonder of the world, the Taj Mahal. It has, however, become a victim of its own success: queues form for a picture on the "Diana seat". The government takes advantage of its popularity: rickshaws, taxis and guides were going on strike that weekend, protesting at the doubling of entrance charges to R1,000 - more than £15. No longer in Rajasthan, alas, and heritage hotels being thin on the ground, we chose the Plaza on the basis of its proximity to the Taj - a mere 10-minute walk away.

We got back to Delhi in time for Diwali, the festival of lights honouring the goddess of prosperity, Lakshmi. It's the Hindu equivalent of Christmas - all tinsel garlands, fairy lights, an exchange of presents and sweetmeats - with the bonus of fireworks. That day, we roamed the narrow, dusty streets and the maze of bazaars, each one with its own speciality: silks, spices, homeware, electrical goods, tailoring.

Seventeen days previously, we had started out from New Delhi, the heart of which is the Lutyens-designed Connaught Place - a circular park circumscribed by a vast colonnade of white stucco buildings. We ended our tour in Old Delhi, just north of the new town, and on our last night stayed at the Oberoi Maidens, an elegant colonial building from where, coincidentally, Lutyens had planned his New Delhi. The circle was complete.

Way to go

Our customised itinerary cost £800pp through Cox & Kings, Delhi (011 332 0067). Although we didn't get a breakdown of costs, if we allow £400 as quoted for the driver, his accommodation and fuel, £60 for six city guides, and £60 for entrance fees, our accommodation worked out at an average of £32 each a night, including breakfast. Not bad considering that the most expensive hotel we stayed in was advertising its rooms at £90 a night, plus "luxury tax" (which can add up to 23% to the bill), and the cheapest hotel at £45 per night, plus tax.

We flew BA for £500, bought through Trailfinders (020-7628 7628). To book the same tailor-made tour through Cox & Kings in London (020-7873 5006) would cost £1,790pp, including international flights, chauffer-driven car and based on room-only twin share accommodation.

Cox & Kings also offers a 17-day group tour of Rajasthan, called Forts & Palaces of Rajputana, visiting Delhi, Gwalior, Agra, Jaipur, Bikaner, Jaisalmer, Manvar, Jodhpur, Rohet, Udaipur and Mumbai. Prices start from £1,495 per person, including international flights, twin share accommodation, meals as per the itinerary and transfers.

There are, of course, plenty of other agents in Delhi able to organise such a trip, including Abercrombie & Kent (011 643 6207), Sita World Travel (011 331 1133) or Travel Corporation of India (011 331 5834).

The obligatory six-month multiple-entry visa to India costs £20. You can download the application form from www.hcilondon.org, then apply by mail or in person (8.30am-noon) to the High Commission of India, India House, Aldwych, London WC2B 4NA.

We stayed at the Gajner Palace, an ornate 19th-century, red sandstone edifice on a lake, set in its own nature reserve. We continued deeper into the Thar desert until we reached the golden city of Jaisalmer, near the Pakistan border. Built from yellow sandstone, it's a pure Arabian Nights fantasy. It's also the camel capital of Rajasthan; everyone takes a camel safari here, and we were no exception. Our hotel, the Himmatgarh Palace, on a hill outside of town, afforded us a great view of the walled city rising dramatically out of the desert plain like a mirage. In Jodhpur, the Brahmins first painted their houses blue to differentiate themselves from the lower castes. Then everyone followed suit; now Jodhpur is known as the blue city. It has the most imposing mountain-top fort and the teeming Sardar bazaar, where we bought saffron, nutmeg and masala spices for our "chai". Our modest abode, the Ajit Bhawan, built by the maharaja for his younger brother, lies in the shadow of the grandiose Umaid Bhawan, possibly the most expensive hotel in India, where suites cost up to £700 a night. Not to be outdone by other cities, Udaipur has appointed itself the "marble city", a tranquil oasis with beautiful lakeside palaces. The Lake Palace Hotel, the one that appears to float on the lake, was used for a James Bond film location. Alas, it's now popularly known as the Octopussy Hotel, and the film gets shown every night somewhere in town. We dined there one evening, picked up by the palace boat at sunset, though we stayed in the Shiv Niwas Palace, neighbours of the maharana (a rank even higher than maharaja). From one lakeside location to another: to Pushkar, top place of pilgrimage for Hindus, its sacred lake surrounded by temples, with steps, or "ghats", leading down to the water's edge. A respite from sightseeing, there was little to do here except sit on the palm terrace of the Pushkar Palace and gaze out on to the lake, watch people bathe, and listen to the drums and chanting drifting across the water from the temples opposite. The capital of Rajasthan, Jaipur, is the pink city. Built from red sandstone in the 18th century, this rectangular walled city was designed on a grid - remarkable for its time. Though our hotel, the Alsisar Haveli, enjoyed a busy city-centre location, it was remarkably tranquil in its lush garden setting. One of the attractions of Jaipur is the magnificent Amber Fort, nestling in the mountains high above the city. Most tourists complete the climb by elephant, but we were sated with our camel ride of a few days previous. Besides, there's no shade on an elephant in 35-degree heat. It's quite fair to say that Agra is the most polluted of cities, but it is home to that wonder of the world, the Taj Mahal. It has, however, become a victim of its own success: queues form for a picture on the "Diana seat". The government takes advantage of its popularity: rickshaws, taxis and guides were going on strike that weekend, protesting at the doubling of entrance charges to R1,000 - more than £15. No longer in Rajasthan, alas, and heritage hotels being thin on the ground, we chose the Plaza on the basis of its proximity to the Taj - a mere 10-minute walk away. We got back to Delhi in time for Diwali, the festival of lights honouring the goddess of prosperity, Lakshmi. It's the Hindu equivalent of Christmas - all tinsel garlands, fairy lights, an exchange of presents and sweetmeats - with the bonus of fireworks. That day, we roamed the narrow, dusty streets and the maze of bazaars, each one with its own speciality: silks, spices, homeware, electrical goods, tailoring. Seventeen days previously, we had started out from New Delhi, the heart of which is the Lutyens-designed Connaught Place - a circular park circumscribed by a vast colonnade of white stucco buildings. We ended our tour in Old Delhi, just north of the new town, and on our last night stayed at the Oberoi Maidens, an elegant colonial building from where, coincidentally, Lutyens had planned his New Delhi. The circle was complete. Way to go Our customised itinerary cost £800pp through Cox & Kings, Delhi (011 332 0067). Although we didn't get a breakdown of costs, if we allow £400 as quoted for the driver, his accommodation and fuel, £60 for six city guides, and £60 for entrance fees, our accommodation worked out at an average of £32 each a night, including breakfast. Not bad considering that the most expensive hotel we stayed in was advertising its rooms at £90 a night, plus "luxury tax" (which can add up to 23% to the bill), and the cheapest hotel at £45 per night, plus tax. We flew BA for £500, bought through Trailfinders (020-7628 7628). To book the same tailor-made tour through Cox & Kings in London (020-7873 5006) would cost £1,790pp, including international flights, chauffer-driven car and based on room-only twin share accommodation. Cox & Kings also offers a 17-day group tour of Rajasthan, called Forts & Palaces of Rajputana, visiting Delhi, Gwalior, Agra, Jaipur, Bikaner, Jaisalmer, Manvar, Jodhpur, Rohet, Udaipur and Mumbai. Prices start from £1,495 per person, including international flights, twin share accommodation, meals as per the itinerary and transfers. There are, of course, plenty of other agents in Delhi able to organise such a trip, including Abercrombie & Kent (011 643 6207), Sita World Travel (011 331 1133) or Travel Corporation of India (011 331 5834). The obligatory six-month multiple-entry visa to India costs £20. You can download the application form from www.hcilondon.org, then apply by mail or in person (8.30am-noon) to the High Commission of India, India House, Aldwych, London WC2B 4NA. fields.headline: Orient Express of the north
fields.standfirst: Helen Carter is given the five-star treatment on a day trip from Manchester
fields.trailText: Helen Carter is given the five-star treatment on a day trip from Manchester.
fields.body:
As the train pulled out of Manchester Victoria, a passenger turned to his wife and said: "You'd have to be mad not to enjoy this."

This was no ordinary train journey, a long way from the usual experience of commuting in dirty, overcrowded carriages with overpriced inedible food. On a balmy summer Wednesday morning, they had joined 250 other passengers on the inaugural journey of the Northern Belle, which sets out to recapture the elegance of the great dining cars of the 1920s and 30s.

Orient Express has refurbished its six maroon, cream and gold carriages at a cost of around £500,000 each. The seats are more like a favourite armchair. Tables are shrouded in white linen with specially-designed china, gleaming silver cutlery and flowers.

Within a few minutes of leaving, even though it was only 10am, we were being served champagne by stewards, whose uniforms match the livery of each of the carriages.

Brunch followed swiftly as we glided through the Yorkshire countryside - buck's fizz, fruit cocktail and scrambled eggs wrapped in smoked salmon piled on a crumpet with a claw and hollandaise sauce.

We caused a stir as we passed through Doncaster, Leeds, York and Newark. Trainspotters were out in force on the platforms with video cameras and notebooks.

After stopping at Grantham for a tour of Belvoir Castle, it was time for lunch. Chilled strawberry and champagne soup was followed by guinea fowl in port and meringue with blueberries, raspberries and pistachio cream. A pair of a capella singers serenaded the diners and a magician performed tricks as the stewards coolly served the cheese and coffee around him.

"I wish all train travel could be like this," said Brookside actor Karen Drury, who was one of the passengers: "It is great that there is nobody shouting at you and telling you that you have the wrong type of ticket. It is the little luxurious touches that make all the difference." And a four-hour trip costs less than a first-class journey from Manchester to London.

Way to go

The Northern Belle (reservations 0161-831 7900, e-mail northern-belle@orient-express.com) departs from Liverpool, Manchester Victoria and York. Excursions start at £115pp for a four-hour journey including lunch or dinner. Weekend breaks to Paris with two nights' accommodation cost £750.

fields.headline: The first round
fields.standfirst: While most Dubliners are still fast asleep, Dea Birkett has explored the city by bike and is relaxing with a dawn pint of Guinness
fields.trailText: While most Dubliners are still fast asleep, Dea Birkett has explored the city by bike and is relaxing with a dawn pint of Guinness
fields.body:
It's not yet eight in the morning, and I'm having my first glass of Guinness. I've already been up almost three hours, toured through the backstreets where no curtain was yet drawn, trespassed on building sites before the foreman arrived, crossed the Liffey twice, toured Dublin Castle, and had a very hearty breakfast. Now my confused body clock was telling me that I was ready to down the first drink of the day.

This day had begun far too early, at 5.30am, when we'd arranged to meet up with Damien O'Tuama, bike enthusiast and erstwhile cycling campaigner, who takes the foolish, the masochistic and the odd insomniac on a leisurely pedal around Dublin as the light rises over the Liffey. Now we were near the end of our tour, and my fellow travellers were saddled out and pedal pushed. Other drinkers in Slattery's, the early morning bar, had not seen their beds for even longer than me. Some had been up all night, coming straight from the clubs, and it showed.

You certainly see a different Dublin on a dawn bike tour. Absolutely nothing listed as a must-see in your guidebook is open. You cannot visit the Book of Kells, the Guinness Hopstore, the James Joyce Centre or Kilmainham Gaol. None of them open until 9.30am, hours after we were up.

Nor can you go inside Dublin Castle (opens 10am), and stroll through the state apartments and chapel royal. Yet you can see the heart of government as few tourists ever do. We cycled past the security guard at the Castle gate with a royal wave, whizzed around the courtyard, and leant our Raleigh Pioneers up against a wall sitting on grass that, just a few hours later, tourists would be prevented from sitting on. The half moon was still hovering over the 13th-century Record Tower.

We were like a travelling show, the tall flags on the back of our bikes flapping, and such a rare sight at this unearthly hour, that everyone greeted us with a laugh. No one is worried about a small gaggle of early morning cyclists. We could have got in anywhere.

The drawbacks of setting the alarm clock so early were soon outweighed by the benefits of seeing a city literally in a light few people have seen. We experienced a Dublin still yawning, emerging from the night. Only the tramps were beginning to turn, woken by the early sun lighting the shelter of the shop doorways. There were few long shadows like ours on the streets. There was just the odd person staggering about, trying to find their way home, as if the capital were inhabited by members of Monty Python's Ministry of Silly Walks. Taxis ferried the last clubbers, and first buses carried office cleaners and construction workers. Only the pigeons scattered for us, and then reluctantly.

Without traffic jams and Dublin's prolific crowds to contend with, your mental map of the city shifts. We rode three abreast up O'Connell Street, the city's main thoroughfare. The quietness let other sounds and senses seep in. By the time we reached the 24-hour Guinness brewery, my sense of smell was so heightened that the aroma in the surrounding air was enough to make me feel already drunk.

Just a couple of hundred yards away, the patients of St Patrick's psychiatric hospital, founded in 1745 from money bequeathed by Jonathon Swift, author of Gulliver's Travels, hadn't yet been given their breakfast. Most of the early inmates were alcoholics - incarcerated right next door to what was once the world's biggest brewery. An ambulance siren from several miles away pierced the empty air.

By the time we reach the Dublin Corporation Victorian Fruit Market, I was so sensually heightened I felt as if I was being assaulted by the scent from the flowers. The grinding of the forklift trucks was so piercing it was almost painful.

Markets are men's business, from very young boys to very old codgers. Fresh faced and pimply young bucks pushed trolleys piled with paper sacks of Irish tatties. Their dads arranged the cabbages. Most of the fruit and vegetables eaten by the Irish nation pass through the Victorian Fruit Market.

At least we were in tune with this place. Breakfast at 8am was the market traders' equivalent of lunchtime, when they had the main meal of the day. The menu at Paddy's Place (opens 6am), the market café, has survived a decade onslaught of nouvelle cuisine and sun-dried tomato products unscathed. It offers black pudding, white pudding, rashers and anything else that is saturated in animal fat. It was delicious, washed down by watery tea or milky coffee. By the time we left, several pounds heavier, Paddy's Place was already beginning to close.

It must have burned up at least 10 calories of my double fried egg to reach Slattery's in Capel Street, Dublin's notorious traditional early house. There were bouncers on the door from seven in the morning - it was that kind of place. There was standing room only inside, and you're never out of close bodily contact with other drinkers - nurses working late shifts, clubbers who need a pint before they go to bed, and some of the market lads without their dads.

Soon, you're not only inevitably pressed up against but also in deep semi-coherent conversation with someone. Cruelly, pub mirrors lined the old bar so it was difficult not to be caught out by your own reflection at a time when none of us were looking our best. The girl with her pelvic bone protruding into my back whispered hoarsely in my ear that she hadn't made it home from the night before, then added, "The drummer from Thin Lizzy plays upstairs some nights." It was a very diverse crowd with only one thing in common: Everyone was drunk. And remember; it wasn't yet nine in the morning.

We rode in a flock back over the Liffey, belting out Molly Malone. Damien was eloquent on the benefits of being an early morning cyclist. "You can potter up a certain street if you see something interesting," he said. "You couldn't ask a coach driver - 'Hey, hang on a minute, I just want to look up there.' You can be part of everything on a bike."

Back at our hotel, late risers were stumbling down to breakfast. I felt sorry for them. The best part of the day had already passed. And they hadn't even had their first Guinness.

Way to go

Dublin at Dawn bike tours can be booked through Dublin Bike Tours (00 353 1 6790899, fax 00 353 1 679 6504, www.connect.ie/dublinbiketours. Tours cost from £15pp, including bike, tour guide and insurance. Student and family rates available.

Slattery's in Capel Street is not currently open at 6am. For an early Guinness, try Hughes Pub in Chancery St (00 3531 8726 540).

webTitle: Holiday Insurance: Avoid getting tripped up on your travels

fields.headline: Avoid getting tripped up on your travels
fields.trailText: Fifty per cent of people buy insurance from the organisation where they booked their holiday. But travel agents and tour operators charge way over the odds, according to the latest Holiday Which? report.
fields.body:
Planning your next holiday? Travel insurance is a must, but don't get ripped off. How much you pay depends as much on where you get it from, as how much of a risk you are.

Fifty per cent of people buy insurance from the organisation where they booked their holiday. But travel agents and tour operators charge way over the odds, according to the latest Holiday Which? report. For example, cover for a two-week holiday in Europe with Going Places costs £40.65, whereas TravelPlan Direct is four times cheaper, charging only £10 to cover a two-week holiday in Europe. "Be prepared to shop around for holiday insurance which can deliver real savings," says Patricia Yates, editor of Holiday Which?

Specialist travel insurance providers consistently offer better deals than those offered by the high street travel agents. Independent travel agents offer slightly better value policies than the high street chains, but the survey says that these are charging double those listed in our best buy table on page 35.

And don't rely on free travel insurance, often offered as a perk by credit card companies. Many of the cards only offer travel accident insurance, which is not as comprehensive as proper travel insurance. A recent Jobs and Money survey on gold credit and debit cards' multi-trip travel insurance found the cards only offer 31 days' cover, whereas standalone insurance policies cover you for up to 60 days. Charge cards can also offer better deals.

On average, people take four months planning their holiday and less than 30 minutes finding their travel insurance. And a quarter of people who buy travel insurance do not take their policy away on holiday with them, while the majority of people who buy travel insurance are unsure of how to make a claim if an incident should arise.

The Post Office's Travel Insurance Survey found that 20% of British holiday makers do not take out travel insurance. Of those who buy insurance, 42% admit they never read the small print.

There are various ways to reduce the cost of your insurance. Opting out of baggage and belongings cover can save you up to 30%. This is worth considering if you have an an all risks homes content insurance policy which covers your possessions outside the home.

Additionally, if you are travelling in Europe, you are entitled to free or cheaper emergency medical treatment if you carry an E111 form. However, they do not replace travel insurance and can be cumbersome to use.

fields.headline: Ski tips
fields.trailText: 10.03.03 Independent skiers eyeing a late escape to Italy could take advantage of some new deals from Alitalia (0870 5448259). The airline is offering flights from Gatwick to Venice and Turin for £99 and £129 respectively.
fields.body:
Independent skiers eyeing a late escape to Italy could take advantage of some new deals from Alitalia (0870 5448259). The airline is offering flights from Gatwick to Venice and Turin for £99 and £129 respectively. They must be booked by March 23, tickets must be bought at least three days before departure and you have to stay at least one Saturday night. Last date for travel to Turin is March 31, Venice until June 30, well beyond the end of the season. However, it is not available during the fortnight covering Easter (April 6-22).

Better conditions following recent snowfall have persuaded Inghams (020-8780 4433, www.inghams.com) to extend its season by a week in the Austrian resorts of Söll, Niederau and Westendorf. Last departures will now be on March 24. Seven-night half-board deals, with flights from Gatwick, cost £429, £329 and £326 in the three resorts respectively. The firm is also offering a week in the Alberta resort of Lake Louise for £399. Departure is from Gatwick on April 4 and the price, which does not include meals, is based on four people sharing a room at the Lake Louise Inn.

Snow conditions at Colorado's Winter Park should stay good for Easter. North American holiday specialist Ski Independence (0870 5550555) can still offer chalet deals there from £679 a week, based on two sharing a room. It includes flights to Denver with United Airlines, minibus transfers, breakfast and meals on six of seven evenings.

webTitle: Adam Buxton: MiniDisc player | Camcorder | G3 laptop and DVD player

fields.headline: Adam Buxton never travels without...
fields.trailText: MiniDisc player | Camcorder | G3 laptop and DVD player
fields.body:
A necessity: A MiniDisc player. This is accompanied by a sad little British Airways washbag that contains no fewer than 20 compilations I have invariably wasted a good two weeks constructing prior to departure, so that no wonderful or miserable travel moment will go by without its own special soundtrack.

A lucky charm: I won't set foot on a plane without my camcorder. In the unlikely event of an emergency, I would whip it out and start filming the onboard grimness as we descend, thus guaranteeing my loved ones a wad of cash from all the news shows once it's been recovered from my little black box. This may sound macabre, but my theory is that nothing interesting ever happens when my camcorder is around, so as long as it's there, I should be sorted.

A luxury: My G3 laptop and DVD player. Before leaving, I go to the Cinema Store and load up with a pile of cinematic effluent to while away the inevitable hours of delay or night time bus journeys that wait for me. For sunbathing, I like to listen to the informative commentaries that accompany my favourite films. "So that's how The Hollow Man's dazzling special effects were achieved!" I think to myself as the sunburn takes hold.

If only: I'd take a personal transporter device as seen in Star Trek: The Next Generation. Let's face it, foreign climes are great, but unless you're a pop star and get to travel first class everywhere, getting there is absolutely horrible.

 The new series of The Adam and Joe Show is on E4 at 10pm on Wednesdays.

fields.headline: Carriage returns
fields.standfirst: Emily Barr takes a trip on the Trans-Siberian Express, and finds that the greatest train journey in the world lives up to expectations
fields.trailText: Emily Barr takes a trip on the Trans-Siberian Express, and finds that the greatest train journey in the world lives up to expectations.
fields.body:
We boarded the train in Moscow as the sun was setting. Our cabin was a vision of faded grandeur: heavy mirrors, old light fittings and kitsch landscape prints. Charlotte and I sat on our beds and shared a beer as we watched Moscow slipping away. This was to be our home for the next four nights. The greatest train journey in the world was, so far, living up to expectations.

"Hi guys," said a hearty New Zealander from the next-door cabin. "I'm Rachel." Her friend appeared. "And I'm Rachel," she added. The Rachels were going to be our companions all the way through to Beijing. Luckily, we liked them.

We had the luxury of a two-berth cabin, and a carriage attendant who vacuumed and dusted every day and made sure we were back on board in time when the train stopped. On the first night, we puzzled over how to get any water from the taps, and ended up brushing our teeth in mineral water. We later discovered that there is a piece of metal poking down behind the tap, and that this has to be pushed up, an eccentric method of supplying water, but it worked.

This was proper train travel. Railtrack wasn't involved, the timetable was gospel, and, if there were any leaves on the line, they didn't pose a problem. We drifted off to sleep chugging through western Russia, and woke up still chugging through western Russia. Outside, smoke curled from the chimneys of little houses surrounded by birch trees.

We sat, with the Rachels, in the restaurant car, in which the food is always provided by the country you're in at the time, resulting in meagre rations in Mongolia and multi-coursed feasts in China. We drank Baltika beer. We read books. At the stations, we got out to stretch our legs.

During this first and longest stretch of 5,191km, between Moscow and Siberia, we moved officially from Europe into Asia. We saw the underwhelming Ural mountains, and passed within 375 miles of the Tungunska River, where a massive explosion occurred in 1908. This has been variously blamed on an atomic spaceship, a mini-black hole and an asteroid collision.

We settled into a peaceful train life, broken only by an occasional vigorous walk round a platform in a remote town, smiling at local people whose lives we could barely begin to imagine. Between us, the passengers drank the bar dry of Baltika 3, the normal lager, and had to move on to Baltika 9, which is more like a spirit. We made plenty of friends after that.

Then suddenly, we were in Irkutsk, the self-styled "Paris of Eastern Siberia". We had crossed five time zones in four days, resulting in the unusual phenomenon of train lag.

The boulevards may feel slightly Parisian, but there is no escaping the fact that this is Russia. Imposing Stalinist edifices cast their shadows over white Orthodox churches with golden onion domes. Lenin stood with a raised hand in a square. "He wants a taxi", a local explained.

Charlotte and I looked at the monument to the completion of the railway, admired a bust of Yuri Gagarin, nodded curtly to some hideous art in the museum, and decided we needed to sit down.

"What do you think that means?" Charlotte asked, pointing to a piece of paper on a park bench. "It can't be anything important," I decided. Unfortunately, it meant "wet paint" and those trousers stayed in Siberia.

From Irkutsk, it's not much more than an hour's drive through snowy birch forests to Listvyanka, a village on the shores of Lake Baikal. From the moment we walked into Rita's house, and saw her table laden down with our second breakfast, we knew we were somewhere special.

Lake Baikal glimmered in the sunlight at the end of the street. The air was crystal clear, the sky deep blue. We walked on the shores, caught a boat, and vowed to come back for longer.

We discovered that Siberian loos are at the end of the garden, even though it is minus 30 degrees centigrade on winter nights. Stranger still, they don't have showers or baths, but saunas. Charlotte and I were sent into the sauna together, and instructed to hit each other with birch twigs.

Rita's table creaked under the weight of her gorgeous food four times a day. "I like it when tourists eat a lot," she told us pointedly, looking at our leftovers. We talked to her, through Lida, our guide, about communism and capitalism, about Chechnya and the Russian soul. We wanted to live with her forever.

Our last night in Listvyanka was Orthodox Easter. Before midnight mass, we nipped out for a drink in the Baikal bar by the lake. "We'll just have one vodka," we told each other, sensibly. By the time we staggered to the church, chatting amiably to everyone, we had consumed more alcohol units than my doctor believes I drink in a week, and had learned lots more Russian.

The train onward to Mongolia served as a drying-out clinic. The Rachels spent the entire day lying prostate and clutching their heads. When we pulled in to Ulan Baatar, the platform was heaving with people. They had come to buy from the traders whose boxes clogged the whole train as it crossed Siberia, and which suddenly vanished as soon as we reached customs.

The final train, which took us to China, stopped, considerately, at a station situated within the Great Wall, so we could take photos. That left two days in Beijing before we flew home. The whole trip lasted just over two weeks, and we came back feeling that we'd been away for months.

Way to go

Bridge the World (0870 444 7474, www.bridgetheworld.com) organises a 15-day Trans-Siberian trip for £1,263pp for departures until June 30.

The price includes 14 nights' accommodation, including two nights in Moscow (three-star hotel or family), village stay in Baikal, an overnight stay with a family in Irkutsk and two nights at a Mongolian Ger Camp on the Steppe.

The price also includes all train travel (second class/four berth), flights from London Heathrow to Moscow and Beijing to London, plus various meals and excursions.

· Emily Barr's novel Backpack is published by Headline at £5.99

Travel special

No particular place to go? Whether it's rafting in Sweden or riding in a covered wagon in Wyoming, travelling is not just the dull bit at the beginning and end of your holiday. Jonathan Futrell finds the best options

Auto pilot It sounds like the ultimate in luxury - being chauffeured between palatial hotels in India, the land of princes. Pas Paschali enjoys the view from an Ambassador's windows

Way to go Travel editor Charles Burgess attempts to gain a full motorbike licence in six days from scratch, on an all-American dream bike through a course at Rider's Edge in Builth Wells

Harley street It's the only way if you want to ride the American dream. Author Tom Cunliffe heads west on a Harley-Davidson

Northern Belle Helen Carter is given the five-star treatment on a day trip from Manchester

The first round While most Dubliners are still fast asleep, Dea Birkett has explored the city by bike and is relaxing with a dawn pint of Guinness

fields.headline: Website of the week
fields.standfirst: Epaths
fields.trailText: Epaths
fields.body:
E-paths? That's right. When the European Ramblers Association was founded in the heady days of 1969, they decided to create a series of long distance footpaths that would criss-cross the continent. Some of their plans seemed a little over-optimistic at the time - Gibraltar to the Ukraine, for example - but many were fulfilled.

Just how long are they? Very long indeed. E3, the Black Sea-Iberia route, is 7,200km. The relatively modest Atlantic-Adriatic route (or Brittany to Venice) is 3,000km.

And how many people have actually tackled one? Who knows? The site outlines the routes and suggests suitable guidebooks and webpages to help you plan the journey. But as it points out, few walkers attempt an entire route, and the information in a single guidebook would quickly become outdated - and, of course, it would have to be translated into all the languages of the EU.

Sounds like a perfect excuse for some pan-European web funding. I want to be able to walk these paths alongside my European brethren. I have to warn you that the chosen routes can be rather eccentric. E5 stipulates a walk from Verona to Venice; but there has never been a path between the two, so you'll have to catch a train.

fields.headline: The hard stuff
fields.standfirst: Martin Bell continues his guide to basic technique with an introduction to icy surfaces
fields.trailText: Martin Bell continues his guide to basic technique with an introduction to icy surfaces
fields.body:
"Why has nature put this terrible surface here to scare me?" is the reaction of most intermediate skiers when confronted with ice. It may seem that skis were designed to handle snow, whereas ice-skates are implements better suited to coping with ice. But with the right technique (and ski preparation), a pair of planks can help you deal with the slippery stuff just as well as any skates.

It's important to realise that there are different grades of ice. If the surface is rock-hard, but has a matt, rather than a shiny texture, it is usually possible to get a fair amount of grip, given some astute angling of the body, and a sharp enough pair of edges. Most recreational skiers would call this "ice", but racers, who are used to dealing with hard surfaces, refer to this type of snow as "hard and grippy".

On the other hand, if the surface is beginning to show a shiny appearance, then we can truly begin to talk about ice proper. And if it starts to get noticeably darker than the snow around it, it becomes a case of the dreaded "blue ice".

Ice is not created instantly. It evolves from snow under certain conditions. When snow crystals originally fall from the sky, they pile together loosely, because of their spiky shapes. This is the cause of the lovely "fluffy" texture of fresh powder snow. As skiers and piste-bashers scrape over the snow, day after day, they gradually break down the crystals, and the snow particles start to pack together more compactly - this usually produces snow of the "hard and grippy" variety.

As long as the air stays cold, this is as bad as things get. But if the snow starts to melt, due to warm sunshine or rain, the amount of water between the particles increases. While it stays warm, the snow will be soft, heavy and slushy. But once the temperature drops, usually because of a clear, cold night, the water freezes, and binds the snow particles together in a solid layer. The wetter the snow during the afternoon, the worse the ice will be the next morning. The direction of each slope, relative to the sun, can make a huge difference to this "melt/freeze cycle" effect. In the northern hemisphere, south-facing slopes will always suffer the worst.

So now we know how it's formed, but how do you ski it? If the ice merely occurs in patches, the best tactic is to look ahead, and try to turn on the areas of loose snow. But it's important to maintain a good traverse position, angling your knees and hips towards the uphill side, to keep your skis tilted on to their uphill edges. Keep your upper body facing downhill and leaning out over your downhill ski. As long as your skis are carving (ie tracking along their edges rather than skidding sideways), and they're tilted over on to a sufficient angle, they'll be able to slice across almost anything.

It's a different kettle of fish, if you have to deal with a solid sheet of ice, such as you may find on a clear April morning on the lower slopes. The key is to increase the pressure on to your edge as you progress around the turn. Extra downward pressure will help your ski to grip, just as the "downforce" on Formula One cars helps them to stay on track around bends. You need to increase that pressure during each turn, by gradually sinking into a lower and lower position to counteract the centrifugal and gravitational forces which build up towards the end of each turn - they're trying to stop you finishing off your turn, because they're always pulling you down the hill.

The lower, more aggressive position will undoubtedly be more tiring; that's why racers, who almost always race on ice, have to be incredibly strong and fit. But it will give you more control. You'll also need to keep your feet wider apart, for better balance, and to give yourself room to angle your outside knee inwards to achieve that extreme edge angle with the outside ski.

If the terrain is flat enough, you'll want to be carving your entire turns. But pure carving will not kill off any speed; on steeper slopes you'll have to be content with pivoting your skis around in a controlled skid, and getting them to carve the traverses at the end of each turn, providing a stable base from which to initiate the next turn.

And never, ever put any weight on your inside ski. Almost all the pressure should be acting through the outside ski, around each turn. That means that if your outside ski skids, your inside ski will be there to "save" you. If you habitually turn on your inside ski, once it skids you'll have nowhere to go but on your backside.

Good ski preparation will also help. Most expert skiers rate the quality of their edge preparation as more important than base waxing, when it comes to enjoying their turns. Keep your edges sharp, either by regular servicing, or ideally by learning to file them yourself. If you really want extra grip, try "bevelling" them; that means filing them into an 88-degree angle instead of 90. This may not sound much, but it makes an appreciable difference; racers always bevel their skis.

Whenever you're confronted with ice, you must be more aggressive. Think about dominating it, driving that ski edge into it, rather than letting it dominate you. And if all else fails, get a pair of ice skates!

 Martin Bell is running ski courses for intermediate skiers this summer in Vail and Breckenridge, Colorado. For more information, call 001 970 845 5710 or visit: www.unmissable.com

But pure carving will not kill off any speed; on steeper slopes you'll have to be content with pivoting your skis around in a controlled skid, and getting them to carve the traverses at the end of each turn, providing a stable base from which to initiate the next turn. And never, ever put any weight on your inside ski. Almost all the pressure should be acting through the outside ski, around each turn. That means that if your outside ski skids, your inside ski will be there to "save" you. If you habitually turn on your inside ski, once it skids you'll have nowhere to go but on your backside. Good ski preparation will also help. Most expert skiers rate the quality of their edge preparation as more important than base waxing, when it comes to enjoying their turns. Keep your edges sharp, either by regular servicing, or ideally by learning to file them yourself. If you really want extra grip, try "bevelling" them; that means filing them into an 88-degree angle instead of 90. This may not sound much, but it makes an appreciable difference; racers always bevel their skis. Whenever you're confronted with ice, you must be more aggressive. Think about dominating it, driving that ski edge into it, rather than letting it dominate you. And if all else fails, get a pair of ice skates!  Martin Bell is running ski courses for intermediate skiers this summer in Vail and Breckenridge, Colorado. fields.headline: Ask a fellow traveller
fields.trailText: Elizabeth Hopkins wants to know where a fairly weak swimmer can go snorkelling over coral from the beach rather than from a boat
fields.body:
Elizabeth Hopkins wants to know where a fairly weak swimmer can go snorkelling over coral from the beach rather than from a boat.

It would be hard to find anywhere better than the Coral View Resort in Pulau Besar, Perhentian Islands, Malaysia. The coral stacks right off the shore support literally hundreds of varieties of fish and an amazing range of animals from turtles to giant clams and even black-tipped reef sharks (totally safe, honest, but guaranteed to cause palpitations on first viewing).

The islands are off the north-east coast of Malaysia and a 20-minute speed boat ride from close to Kota Bharu, and easily accessible from Kuala Lumpar or Singapore.

The Coral View Resort costs about £15 per night for ensuite air-conditioned chalets and has the best food, the best coral, excellent rooms, great staff... and flying foxes. But remember that the islands are "dry", so if you want an evening bevvy, take your duty frees with you.

And before you go, you should buy or borrow a mask, snorkel and flippers from a div ing shop here in the UK - you can hire them on the island, but you'll want to be in the water for so long that the hire charges will work out more than the cost of purchase.

Vicki May

We went to the Red Sea resort of Sharm-El-Sheikh over Christmas for exactly the reasons you describe. The beach was sandy and gently sloped with no strong currents (unlike the Maldives) - perfect for children and unconfident swimmers. There were living coral reefs within a few feet of the beach, teeming with fish.

Tim Ford

We found the snorkelling in Hawaiian island of Kauai was actually better from the beach than from a boat. Our favourite spot was Ke'e Beach, which is enclosed by coral apart from a narrow channel. You could swim among shoals of 3ft fish without getting out of your depth.

Martin Thomas

This week's question:

My friend and I would like to go on holiday somewhere we can learn photography. Our non-photographic husbands would like to come with us and spend their days hill walking. Any suggestions?

Jane Cooper

fields.trailText: Hever Castle | Tower of London | Contemporary Art Fair, Glasgow | Bath Literature Festival | Chelsea Antiques Fair | Typical Men, Nottingham | Scottish Motorcycle Show | Film and TV Locations Map
fields.body:
Flowery Hever

At Hever Castle's Spring Flower Week, castle gardeners will be showing visitors around the main spring flower areas and discuss gardening topics.

 March 12-18.11am-5pm. £6.30/ £4.20/£16.80. Hever Castle and Gardens, Hever, Edenbridge, Kent (01732 865 224).

Tower tours

Learn more about Anne Boleyn, Henry VIII, Mary and Elizabeth as guides dressed in 16th-century costume bring the secrets of the Tudor Tower to life.

 Sat, Sun.£11/£7.30. The Tower of London, Tower Hill, London (020- 7680 9004).

Art international

A touring show of contemporary art featuring more than 26 international artists, Mirror's Edge includes work from Raymond Petitbon, Hiroshi Sugimoto and Steve McQueen and artists from Africa, Asia and Latin America.

 Until April 15. Free. Tue-Sun, noon- 8pm. Tramway, 25 Albert Drive, Glasgow (0141-422 2023).

Literary lions

The theme of this year's Bath Literature Festival is Words and Music, and its final days feature readings by Barbara Trapedo and Sebastian Faulks as well as performances by John Mortimer and Quentin Blake, the first ever children's laureate.

 Until March 11. Various venues. 01225 463362 www.bathlitfest.org.uk

Antique prices

Have your cheque book ready as antiques from the past 500 years go on sale at the Chelsea Antiques Fair, with prices from £50 to £50,000.

 March 16-25. Mon- Fri, 11am-8pm; Sat, 11am-7pm; Sunday 11am-5pm. £5. Chelsea Old Town Hall, Kings Road, London (01444 482514).

First-class male

Typical Men is an exhibition of atypical images of the male body by an assortment of contemporary photographers featuring big names such as John Coplans and Robert Mapplethorpe.

 Until April 22. Djanogly Art Gallery, Arts Centre, The University of Nottingham, University Park, Nottingham (0115 951 5791).

Leaders of the pack

The Scottish Motorcycle Show features stunt riding, live bands and vintage classic displays.

 March 10, 11. 9am-5pm. £12/£6. Royal Highland Centre, Ingliston, Edinburgh (0131-333 3036)

It happened here

Movie buffs can pick up the new film and TV map of South West England with details of over 80 locations featured in a wide variety of productions including Straw Dogs, The French Lieutenant's Woman and A Hard Day's Night.

 Available from local tourist information centres or www.visitbritain.com/moviemap

fields.headline: Way to go
fields.trailText: Travel editor Charles Burgess attempts to gain a full motorbike licence in six days from scratch, on an all-American dream bike through a course at Rider's Edge in Builth Wells
fields.body:
It is an exhilarating and frightening moment when you sit astride a Harley-Davidson, hear the throaty roar of the engine and wonder, as you push the throttle past 40mph, whether you will be blown off the bike. The exhilaration continues as you go past 50 and 60, and your terror rises with the speed. Then a curve appears and you have a moment when you forget how the brakes work before your instructor buzzes in your ear and talks you gently through it.

Ten minutes later, and we are turning off the A470 between Rhayader and Llangurig to the caravan that houses Marie's Roadside Café. We amble in, order tea and bacon-and-egg sandwiches with brown sauce, take off our leathers and relax. We have a chat with the other two customers about bikes as they stick their faces outside to admire my Harley Sportster and Toby's Fat Boy. The conversation, about doubles and triples and torque, is unintelligible to me, but for the first time I feel like a biker.

Until earlier that week, I had been a lapsed 47-year-old scooter commuter. Now I was attempting to gain a full motorbike licence in six days from scratch on an all-American dream bike through a course at Rider's Edge in Builth Wells.

It was not easy and, for a lot of the time, extremely hard work, as from 9.30am until 4.30pm we learned the rudimentary rules of the road. It is much more tiring than learning to drive a car and by the end of an hour of going around Llandrindod Wells, practising hill starts, u-turns and concentrating hard on staying upright and alive, we were physically and mentally knackered.

The first two days were spent gaining a certificate of basic training (CBT), which allows you to drive a small bike with L plates on a public road, or allows you out with an instructor on a bike of 250cc-plus. Rider's Edge is based in the grounds of the Royal Welsh Show at Builth Wells, so driving around the private roads on a small bike was a perfect way to learn the basics. And when it rained, we could always practise in some of the big animal sheds built for the agricultural show.

After two days, with a bit of experience out on the real roads, an instructor giving instructions through an ear-piece, all three of us on the course gained our CBT. Then we were on to the big ones - those chrome monsters of cinematic folklore to males of my generation.

They are heavy, especially at first, but after weaving in and out of cones and stopping and starting and doing it all over again and again, we were out on the road. The scenery of mid-Wales, around the Brecon Beacons, makes a wonderful backdrop for riding, although concentration means you do not see as much of it as you would like. The push to drill in the rudiments in town, and get miles under our belts in the country was relentless.

We spent our evenings in the Griffin Inn, just down the beautiful Wye Valley from Builth Wells. Lovely beer and country cooking of local produce helped make it a welcome place to stay.

But it could not prevent us from feeling nervous as our test, in nearby Llandridod Wells, approached. I was not alone in not sleeping a wink the night before. At that stage, it felt anything like a holiday.

But I passed the test and felt brilliant (and if I had failed, Rider's Edge would have given free lessons until a pass was achieved). And riding the bike felt wonderful - if still a little frightening.

The practicals

Rider's Edge (01982 551331) runs a five-day course, with the sixth day for your test, for £1,098. This includes use of this year's Harley-Davidsons, leathers, gloves and helmets (but not boots), picnic lunches, B&B, and dinners at the Griffin Inn or similar. Upgrade to five-star accommodation at Llangeod Hall is £195 per night.

To find your nearest Harley-Davidson dealer, call: 01280 700101, or visit www.harley-davidson.co.uk

webTitle: A Lady with a Squirrel and a Starling, Holbein (c. 1526-8)

fields.headline: A Lady with a Squirrel and a Starling, Holbein (c. 1526-8)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Hans Holbein the Younger (1497/8-1543), the son of a German painter, who worked in Basle, Switzerland, on portraits and decorative and religious commissions, before his relationship with the Renaissance humanist Erasmus made him an international star. In 1523 Holbein painted Erasmus, who recommended him to his friend Thomas More. From 1526 to 1528 Holbein worked in London, painting More and other courtiers. "Your painter, my dear Erasmus, is a wonderful artist," More wrote.

Holbein returned to Britain in 1532 as court painter to Henry VIII. He portrayed potential wives, designed Anne Boleyn's jewellery, and painted the definitive images of Henry. Holbein died in London, probably of plague.

Subject: On stylistic grounds, and judging by the English style of her clothes, it is believed this courtly lady was painted during Holbein's first visit to London, but her identity is unknown. The starling and squirrel could refer to a family coat of arms, but none has been traced. Even more intriguingly, her hat is similar to one worn by Thomas More's stepdaughter, Margaret Griggs, in a Holbein drawing in the Royal Collection, but the two portraits don't look alike at all.

Distinguishing features: This woman could not be more powerfully embodied. The sense of three-dimensional space is so precise it's almost as if it were modelled by computer, and you could move around to see her from the other side. Her face is not glamorised, but she's appealing in her individuality. Holbein makes her reserved, yet she has humour and eccentricity, playing with her squirrel, which, after all, was safer than catching the eye of Henry VIII.

Holbein's art is both sophisticated and primitive. For all the subtlety of his technique, perfect grasp of perspective and humanist learning, he has something raw about him. It comes out in his English portraits, perhaps because those who commissioned them were not as versed in art as continental patrons. They wanted something simple - a "counterfeit" of themselves.

This painting has the obsessive verisimilitude of a waxwork, except it is infused with life. Holbein plays on stillness and motion, contrasting the static severity of the woman's pose with the antics of her pets. He creates a portrait as serious as a funerary sculpture and as colourful as a tapestry. You can see why people might want to identify this woman as More's stepdaughter - her clothes are plain, redolent of religiosity. But Holbein suggests her warmth through the animals. In contrast to her visible consciousness of the painter, they seem relaxed. The squirrel sits on her arm, happily chewing a nut, and the starling, too, is perky.

Even the leaves of the vine are hypnotically detailed. Yet, having established the vine and animals with meticulous realism, Holbein adds an abstract blue background, a luxurious colour that sets off the composition like a velvet cushion on which a gold ring might rest.

Inspirations and influences: Holbein's portraiture is part of a northern European preoccupation with the depiction of the person that includes Dürer's portraits and the works of his father, Hans Holbein the Elder, who trained him. He imported this tradition to Britain and established the portrait as the British art par excellence, his ability to evoke character echoed by painters as diverse as Hogarth and Gainsborough.

Where is it? The National Gallery, London WC2 (020-7747 2885).
