webTitle: Who lost their heart in St Kitts?

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... St Kitts
fields.standfirst: Courtney Pine
fields.trailText: Why: My wife is from St Kitts, so we go there quite a lot with our four kids. We go to a little village called Otley, which I love for its peacefulness. It doesn't have a big-city feel and the people are very warm and welcoming. They treat everyone like family.
fields.body:
Why: My wife is from St Kitts, so we go there quite a lot with our four kids. We go to a little village called Otley, which I love for its peacefulness. It doesn't have a big-city feel and the people are very warm and welcoming. They treat everyone like family.

The best thing: Otley seems to be the best kept secret in the Caribbean. It has a wonderful relaxed atmosphere and is relatively undeveloped as nobody else seems to know about it. There are no guys hassling you to buy things on the beach, so its actually possible to have a real holiday.

My perfect day: Lounging around with my Mac Powerbook and saxaphone close by. I love writing music while I am there as the whole island provides so much inspiration. Just relaxing and enjoying the tranquility, the tempo of life, the atmosphere and the fresh food.

My advice: After chilling on the beach, take a day trip on the ferry to nearby Nevis. There is a really nice seafood restaurant called Fisherman's Wharf in the capital Basseterre.

How do I get there? BA (0845 7733377) offers a fare to Antigua and on to St Kitts with Liat from £566pp return, valid from April 14 to June 30.

 Courtney Pine's new single, Love and Affection, was released this week.

fields.standfirst: Whether it's rafting in Sweden or  riding in a  covered wagon in Wyoming, travelling is not  just the dull bit at the beginning and end of  your holiday. Jonathan Futrell finds the best  options
fields.trailText: Whether it's rafting in Sweden or riding in a covered wagon in Wyoming, travelling is not just the dull bit at the beginning and end of your holiday. Jonathan Futrell finds the best options
fields.body:
Travel special articles

Auto pilot It sounds like the ultimate in luxury - being chauffeured between palatial hotels in India, the land of princes. Pas Paschali enjoys the view from an Ambassador's windows

Carriage returns Emily Barr takes a trip through Russia on the Trans-Siberian Express, and finds that the greatest train journey in the world lives up to expectations

Way to go Travel editor Charles Burgess attempts to gain a full motorbike licence in six days from scratch, on an all-American dream bike through a course at Rider's Edge in Builth Wells

Harley street It's the only way if you want to ride the American dream. Author Tom Cunliffe heads west on a Harley-Davidson

Northern Belle Helen Carter is given the five-star treatment on a day trip from Manchester

The first round While most Dubliners are still fast asleep, Dea Birkett has explored the city by bike and is relaxing with a dawn pint of Guinness

Train

Canada

All Canada Travel & Holidays (01502 585825, www.all-canada.com) organises six-day tours on the Royal Canadian Pacific from May 10 to October 4) rumbling through the wilderness between Alberta and the wonderfully named Head-Smashed-In-Buffalo-Jump. Prices start at £3,369, based on two people sharing, including all meals, connections and motor coach excursions with a tour guide. Return flights between Heathrow and Calgary start at around £533.

India

The Palace on Wheels leaves Delhi any Wednesday during the Indian winter (September-April) and heads for the sun-baked plains and palaces of Rajastan. Passengers stay in twin-bedroomed en-suite compartments furnished in the richly-traditional Rajput style. The eight- night package with Greaves Travel (020-7487 9111) costs from £2,725 including BA flights, connections and all meals, and visits the Pink City of Jaipur, Chittorgarh, Udaipur, Ranthambhor National Park, Jaisalmer, Jodhpur and Agra.

South Africa

The shamelessly luxurious five-star Blue Train takes 24 hours to travel between Cape Town and Pretoria as part of the seven-night Secret Cape itinerary from African Odyssey's (01242 224482, www.africanodyssey.co.uk). Passengers have their own butler and dine on oysters, crayfish and game. The Blue Train can be combined with a six-night privately-guided tour of the Cape, staying at five-star hotels and including all meals. Prices start at £2,019, including return flights and transfers.

Africa

The Southern Cross Safari from Discover The World (01737 218802, www.discover-the-world.co.uk) takes in six African countries: Zimbabwe, Botswana, Zambia, South Africa, Mozambique and Swaziland. The train rolls through the night arriv ing each morning at a new destination and, with a safari bus on board, guests spend the days sightseeing. Sights include Victoria Falls, Kruger National Parks and the Matobi Hills. The tours run between May and October with prices starting at £2,081 (based on two sharing), and includes return flights, transfer, 16 nights' half-board accommodation, excursions and guides.

Ffestiniog Travel (01766 512340) specialise in organising train travel anywhere around the world

Boat

China

Regent Holidays (0117 921 1711, www.regent-holidays.co.uk) has a 10-night cruise down the Yangtse, including several excursions - Nanjing, Three Gorges Dam and Suzhou, the Venice of China - starting at Shanghai and culminating at Chongquing. Prices start at £1,780 (excluding flights) and include three-star hotel accommodation at the start and finish of the cruise, all meals on board and tour guides.

Scotland

Cruise the Caledonian Canal from Inverness to the foothills of Ben Nevis, passing the forested slopes of the Great Glen and some of the Highland's loveliest lochs, including Loch Lochy, Loch Oich and Loch Ness. During late spring and early summer, it stays light until after 11pm. Boating specialists Hoseasons (01502 501 010, www.hoseasons.co.uk) has a range of boats for hire with a typical price for a family of five, for one week from May 5, starting at £438.

The Danube

Cruise along the Danube, starting in Budapest and ending in Munich, stopping off en route for three operas. JMB Travel (01905 830099, www.jmb-travel.co.uk has three seven-day opera cruises scheduled for 2001, the first of which ups anchor on April 14. The itinerary is Cavalleria Rusticana/Pagliacciin Budapest, William Tell in Vienna and Lucia di Lam mermoor in Munich. Prices start at £1,495 and include return flights, transfers, full board on the cruise, one night's B&B in Munich and best category seats for each opera.

Sweden

International Adventure (01767 650 312) organises six-day rafting voyages down the Klaralven River, in Varmland, central Sweden, which start with you building your own raft. This usually takes between four and six hours, with expert tuition provided. Nights are either spent on board or beneath canvas on the river bank. Packages start at £391pp (based on four sharing) and includes Newcastle -to-Kristiansand ferry crossings with DFDS Seaways for a car and passengers, equipment and six days' rafting.

Portugal

All the port stored in the warehouses lining both banks of the Douro River in Oporto is carried down the valley on port wine barges. It's a slow meandering journey from Pinhao through steep sided valleys lined with vineyards to Portugal's baroque northern capital.

Mundi Color (020-7828 6021) has eight-day, seven-night cruises on the Douro starting at £1,110 based on two sharing. The price includes flights to Oporto, full-board accommodation in twin cabins and all transfers.

Persian Gulf

The eight-day Arabian Seatrek in Oman fom Explore Worldwide (01252 760 100) includes a three-day cruise on the dhow. The holiday begins with a walking tour of Old Dubai before heading, via Sharjah, to the east coast - with a stop at the Emirate of Fujairah. The seatrek explores the coastline of Musandam, stopping off at isolated villages and bays ending in Khasab, followed by a 4WD journey into the interior. The trip, with departures between February-April and October-December costs from £895pp, including scheduled flights, transfers, all transportation, some meals (full board on the dhow), seven-nights' accommodation and a guide.

Motorbike

Pyrenees

The Midi-Pyrenees Tourist Office (c/o French Holiday Service: 020-7355 4747) organises motorcycle tours taking in many of the rarely-explored hilltop villages of the Languedoc, in south-west France in the foothills of the Pyrenees. Prices start at £336pp per week, excluding travel to and from the Languedoc for a rider and pillion on board Honda CB500 bikes, on a preplanned route, with accommodation in two- and three-star hotels. Great Escape Tours (01492 535556) also organise trips in France.

Rocky Mountains

Ride across British Columbia on a 900cc Triumph Trophy staying in four- and five-star hotels en route, thus eating and sleeping in style.

Rocky Mountain Motorcycle Tours (www.rockymtnmoto.com, e-mail mike@rockymtnmoto.com) is based in the ski resort of Whistler, about three hours drive from Vancouver. The rides are long and punishing, sometimes close to 300 miles a day, and they're taken at a fairly brisk pace. Too fast for anyone without real motorcycle experience. But it's a slick operation with all your luggage, and a spare bike, carried on a support vehicle that is seldom more that 30 minutes away.

Try the four-day, five-night Coast to Kootenanys tour or the breathtaking Best of Western Canada trip that takes 10 days passing through Nelson, Jasper National Park and The Icefields Parkway glacier. Prices start at £1,050, with an additional £350 for a pillion passenger and include everything except flights to and from Vancouver. There is a surcharge of £170 for single people.

Mobile home

Tasmania

Hundreds of miles of empty roads run through a temperate rain forest, past deserted white-sand beaches and on to the Tasman Peninsula with some of the highest cliffs in Australia. A seven-day self-drive tour encompasses the entire state - roughly the size of Ireland - with a population of less that half a million. The wildlife includes the Tasmanian devil, echidna (imagine an egg-laying hedgehog), platypus, possum, wallabies and paddymelon (a type of small kangaroo). Autorent Hertz (00 613 6391 8677) has a range of camper vans starting at £530 for a family for one week, including unlimited mileage and insurance.

Arizona

Cheap fuel, more than 80 travel parks, and sunshine all year round make Arizona ideal for exploring with a mobile home from the snow capped mountains of Flagstaff to the Grand Canyon, and from the red rocks of Sedona to the Sonoran desert. A popular route takes in Route 66, passing the Wigwam Motel (free standing cement tepees), the Petrified Forest and the Museum Club with its line-dancing school. Recreational vehicles (RVs in US jargon) can be hired from either Phoenix or Tucson from around US $110 per day. For details, visit www.cruiseamerica.com.

County Kerry

If you're not in a hurry, and like your Guinness poured very slowly, try touring Ireland's County Kerry and the Dingle Peninsula with a traditional horse-drawn caravan. They sleep up to five people in single bunks and have basic cooking facilities. Slattery's (0800 515 900, e-mail ireland@slatterys.com) has a range of caravan holidays. A week costs from £229pp, based on two sharing, including ferry or flight.

Wyoming

For the genuine western experience how about a wagon train holiday? Off The Beaten Track (www.huntinfo.com/ww/) offers six-day, five-night treks through the Bridger-Teton-National Forest for $865 (adult), $765 (children under 14) including transportation to and from Jackson and all meals.

Cycling

Cycling from place to place without having to take your own luggage, stopping off for lunch and feeling virtuous by the end of the day, can be a joy. Many companies are now organising this. The Chain Gang (020-7323 1730/www.thechaingang.co.uk) runs a week-long guided cycle tour round the Dordogne for £630 including insurance, plus £180 for travel via Eurostar.

East Anglia is flat enough and empty enough to be a great place to cycle. Suffolk Cycle Breaks (01449 721555, www.cyclebreaks.co.uk) offers a variety of tours with bike hire, route planning, luggage transportation and good back up. Their two-day Castle and Vineyard Tour starts at £132, including stays in Needham Market and Framlingham.

Saddle Skedaddle (0191 2651110, www.skedaddle.co.uk) operate cycling holidays in the UK and Europe and throughout the world including North America, Patagonia and India.

Bike Tours (01225 310859, www.biketours.co.uk) is organising a three-week Land's End to John O'Groats tour, starting July 28 for £990.

Walking

Discover a landscape on foot at your own pace and you are likely to take it all in. A walking holiday from one village to another also allows you to discover the local culture, so make sure that you stay in small, family-run hotels that offer genuine hospitality and good food.

Choose a specialist tour operator that offers a wide range of walks from riverside strolls in southern France to high mountain hikes in some of Europe's grandest scenery. There is no need to be weighed down with a heavy rucksack, because the good operators will arrange for your luggage to be waiting for you at your next hotel. They provide detailed walking notes and maps too which means that you can travel with your partner or friends, rather than with an organised group.

Inntravel (01653 629010 www.inntravel.co.uk) offers 41 independent walks for all levels of walkers from hotel to hotel. A week's walking around the southern most tip of Spain, through Moorish towns along to Cape Trafalgar costs from £679pp.

fields.headline: She's behind you...
fields.standfirst: Luke Skywalker had Darth Vader for a dad. Poor Tony Blair has Maggie Thatcher in his attic
fields.trailText: Luke Skywalker had Darth Vader for a dad. Poor Tony Blair has Maggie Thatcher in his attic.
fields.body:
Yesterday it was revealed that dozens of Tory candidates have been arranging photos of themselves shaking hands with Lady Thatcher. The story came to light after a number of merchant bankers were suddenly rushed to casualty with broken fingers. Conservative hopefuls are rejecting offers to pose next to William Hague and are choosing instead to associate themselves with the Tory leader before last while John Major, wearing his best suit, sits sadly by the phone wondering if anyone's going to call. With the Conservatives being perceived as extreme and out of touch, these candidates have decided that what they need now is to be seen with the Iron Lady. It's like Rosemary West calling Myra Hindley as a character witness.

It's incredible that after all these years Mrs T continues to have such a grip over the Conservative imagination. They cannot forget the way her career ended in tragedy. Indeed it did; she became prime minister for 11 years. For the dwindling band of diehard Tory activists, Lady Thatcher is the King Over the Water and they cling to the belief that she could walk over it at any time to return her rightful place as party leader and PM. They have a political heroine addiction, they crave her smack of firm government; they're desperate to escape back to that simple, separate reality and feel that quick rush they'd get from another Thatcher outburst on Europe.

Meanwhile for senior Conservatives, Lady Thatcher is the mad old lady in the attic, an embarrassing senile relation who needs to be kept under lock and key. Last week, on the anniversary of the Gulf war, she infuriated Major by claiming that if she'd remained in power, the allied forces would have carried on into Baghdad and removed Saddam Hussein. Yes, she was always overruling American presidents on military operations. It's good to hear her come out with this nonsense just to be reminded how completely loony, awful, self-deceiving and wrong she always was. Another recent contribution to the national debate was the suggestion that single mothers should be placed inside religious institutions to be taught traditional values. Maybe she could get Cecil Parkinson to set the scheme up.

Terrible though it is to admit it, in a strange way I sort of miss her. Because she was the embodiment of all evil, there was a certainty to life that isn't there anymore. In the film Alien, when the creature has its limbs locked round John Hurt's face and is forcing its tentacles down his throat, he could at least be sure of what the problem was at that particular moment. So it was when Maggie was PM.

And now there is a whole generation of voters who do not even know who she is. Recently I gave a talk to a group of sixth formers which was littered with references to "Thatcher" and most of them thought I was talking about Ben Thatcher who plays for Tottenham Hotspur. But loathe her or hate her, her political legacy is still undeniable. Just as Luke Skywalker discovers that he is the son of Darth Vader, and Buzz Lightyear's father is the evil Emperor Zorg, so Tony Blair is the political offspring of the Iron Lady. He may be the antithesis of her bigoted, confrontational xenophobia but without Thatcher, Prime Minister Blair would not exist. Her destruction of the labour movement gave rise to New Labour which her Conservative successors now find so unassailable. Early on in his premiership, Tony Blair shocked many Labour supporters by inviting her round to Downing Street to ask her advice on one or two things. Apparently she said you have to give it one long flush and then another quick flush immediately afterwards.

For Labour today, her continued presence is a useful reminder of how the poison that emanated from Downing Street dictated the atmosphere of the whole country back in the mean-spirited 80s. For Hague the problem of the mad old lady in the attic is a slightly trickier one. I can see only one way forward for him.

Next year sees the 20th anniversary of the Falklands war, and to commemorate this Hague should arrange a lecture tour of Argentina for Britain's former dictator. He can then pretend to be shocked and alarmed when she is arrested in Buenos Aires and detained for crimes against humanity. General Pinochet will visit her and express concern that she is being made to stand trial with her health failing her so suddenly. If William really wants to rub salt into the wounds he could even appoint Lord Lamont to organise a campaign for her release.

But until someone does the decent thing and puts a stake through her heart, the Conservative party will never be able to move forward. Even then they'll probably keep searching for the nearest thing to the original. If George W Bush can follow in his father's footsteps, then shouldn't they be finding safe Tory seats for Carol and Mark? No, I shouldn't suggest it, not even in jest.

Next year sees the 20th anniversary of the Falklands war, and to commemorate this Hague should arrange a lecture tour of Argentina for Britain's former dictator. He can then pretend to be shocked and alarmed when she is arrested in Buenos Aires and detained for crimes against humanity. General Pinochet will visit her and express concern that she is being made to stand trial with her health failing her so suddenly. If William really wants to rub salt into the wounds he could even appoint Lord Lamont to organise a campaign for her release. But until someone does the decent thing and puts a stake through her heart, the Conservative party will never be able to move forward. Even then they'll probably keep searching for the nearest thing to the original. If George W Bush can follow in his father's footsteps, then shouldn't they be finding safe Tory seats for Carol and Mark? No, I shouldn't suggest it, not even in jest. comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Vaz in the clear over Hinduja passports

fields.headline: Vaz in the clear over Hinduja passports
fields.standfirst:
Report says there was no improper relationship

Special report: Mandelson
fields.trailText: Keith Vaz, the minister for Europe whose political future was in Sir Anthony Hammond's hands after allegations that he had passed secret information to the Hinduja brothers, was in the clear last night.
fields.body:
Keith Vaz, the minister for Europe whose political future was in Sir Anthony Hammond's hands after allegations that he had passed secret information to the Hinduja brothers, was in the clear last night. The report found there was "nothing improper" in his contacts with the Home Office or his activities within the Foreign Office.

Mr Vaz, who on Monday faces the publication of a separate inquiry by the standards and privileges committee into charges relating to constituency matters, welcomed the report's findings. "I am pleased with the conclusions that he has reached. He makes clear that he has found nothing improper in relation to me."

In the wake of Peter Mandelson's resignation, the Europe minister faced increasingly serious allegations which some of his friends felt were racist in their inspiration. He was accused of using his position at the Foreign Office to pass sensitive information to the Hindujas about avoiding extradition to India to face questioning over the Bofors bribery allegations.

He was also accused of putting pressure on the Home Office to grant the Hindujas citizenship and of signing letters to Mr Mandelson and Tony Blair which had been drafted by the Hinduja brothers.

The Hammond report - which comments on Mr Vaz's "open and frank" response to questions - specifically rules out any involvement by him in the Hinduja brothers attempts to avoid extradition.

Sir Anthony says that Mr Vaz as a leading member of the Asian community, had an unusual role which involved him representing people who were not his constituents. He came to know the Hindujas well and first wrote to the Home Office about their naturalisation applications in 1993 after they had been rejected because they spent too much time out of the country.

His interest was not only in their naturalisation applications. He also became involved in a millennium project they were backing in Peterborough which Mr Vaz suggested as an idea for the dome itself in a letter to Mr Mandelson, then dome minister.

On the charge that Mr Vaz "topped and tailed" letters drafted by the Hindujas, Sir Anthony accepted Mr Vaz's explanation that if it happened it was in relation to the millennium project and would have been done by a member of his staff. "I do not regard this as a matter of any great significance," Sir Anthony reports.

Mr Vaz still has to face the findings of a second inquiry into his conduct as a backbench MP by the privileges committee. Mr Vaz is said to have accepted two donations in the early 1990s, each of under £500, for his constituency from a City solicitor Sarosh Zaiwalla who reportedly told the Guardian that he had no idea he had been recommended for an honour by Mr Vaz.

The Vaz case may be a footnote to the Mandelson affair but it raises wider issues. Some members of the Asian community feel there is a need for more formal representation of their interests - something along the lines of the Jewish Board of Deputies. They argue that it could ease the pressure on people like Mr Vaz.

fields.headline: Mr Not-so-clean
fields.standfirst:
The report on Mandelson seeks to cover up the real scandal of his behaviour

Special report: Mandelson
fields.trailText: The report on Mandelson seeks to cover up the real scandal of his behaviour.
fields.body:
Shortly before the Hammond report into the "dome cash-for-passports" scandal was published, political journalists were told Downing Street was concerned most over what it would say about the secret intelligence reports on Mr Hinduja, that lucky Indian millionaire now clutching his official maroon document following Mr Mandelson and Mr Straw's "helpful" efforts on his behalf.

Tony Blair need not have worried, if he really ever did. For the Home Office's own former chief lawyer has an answer, however implausible, to every uncomfortable incident he feels he has to record.

Unsurprisingly, Hammond concedes there was indeed "intelligence material" about the controversial and high-profile Indian businessmen brothers at the centre of allegations of corruption in a major arms deal. Disturbingly, he concedes that this MI6 intelligence which he acknowledges to be relevant, mysteriously escaped the attention of the Home Office, the agency responsible for granting citizenship.

Yet, astonishingly, he finishes up by suggesting that even if it had not, it would not have made any difference.

Downing Street is, of course, right to fear the MI6 material. Despite Hammond's staggeringly complacent comments, it goes to the heart of the really crucial outstanding issue - the allegation that Mandelson is still lying in the impression he gives about what he knew at relevant times of those major bribery accusations against the Hindujas, while he was merrily taking their dome money and commending their passport applications.

The MI6 files also raise serious questions about the judgment of senior cabinet ministers, all of whom also regularly receive intelligence reports. Hammond conveniently ignores this.

With the masterfully calculated insouciance of someone well-versed in Whitehall culture, he says the Secret Intelligence Service - MI6 - accumulated "a certain amount of intelligence" on the Hindujas which it would "not be appropriate" to describe in detail. He concedes the material did "raise the possibility" that the Hindujas had been involved in "dubious practices" in some cases amounting to "illegal activities".

Yet none of this intelligence was passed to the Home Office. Why not? Because it was collected "in response to a request in a different context", says Hammond. Only beneath the surface does his report hint at another explanation - the Hinduja brothers were becoming so important to the dome project that both Home Office officials and Mandelson either ignored or played down possible MI5 and MI6 concerns .

MI5, explains Hammond, is concerned only with Britain's "national security" and allegations of corruption in India by prominent businessmen seeking British citizenship had nothing to do with that. But wouldn't the MI6 intelligence have been relevant to the test of "being of good character" enshrined in the British nationality act?

Certainly, says Hammond. Indeed, he goes further. Since it was such an "important and sensitive" question, the home secretary would have had to be consulted if the Home Office had ever seen the files. But it does not matter - the intelligence would "probably" not have made any difference because of its "speculative and inconclusive nature".

This is another artful choice of phrase. Hammond knows perfectly well MI6 reports never contain "conclusions" as such - they simply provide information, sometimes with references to the reliability of sources, for ministers to act on. This was the mistake made by Ann Widdecombe in January when, in an attempt to embarrass the government, she asked Hammond to investigate claims that MI6 advised that SP Hinduja's application for British nationality should be blocked.

Asked by Andrew Marr, the BBC's political editor in January whether he was aware of the Bofors case when he was inquiring about the Hindujas' British citizenship, Mandelson replied: "I didn't have any knowledge of that, no. All I know is that they volunteered to assist in the underwriting of the costs of that zone in the dome."

But Hammond himself now admits these intelligence reports were seen by Mandelson in October or November 1998, and that he went ahead regardless with the acceptance of £1m of Hinduja sponsorship money. Mandelson recklessly decided to discount the danger of adverse publicity if the truth came out.

Behind the scenes another department, the Foreign Office, was, like MI6, under no illusions. In 1996, Caroline Elmes of the FO's south Asian department, told Andrew Walmsley, director of the Home Office's nationality division, about the Indian government's criminal investigation into the Bofors arms deal - a scandal which had featured prominently in media there for more than a decade. "Given the activism of the Indian courts," she warned, "it is conceivable that the case could come alight."

She gave a warning in language remarkably strong for the FO that "at the very least the Hinduja brothers can be said to have sailed close to the wind in building their business empire".

Ministers, as the Scott report into the "arms-to-Iraq" affair so amply demonstrated, seem to have little time for intelligence reports. In its latest annual report, the parliamentary intelligence and security committee noted that the cabinet committee on the intelligence services had not met since 1995.

Yet of course ministers did not in fact need any secret intelligence to know what the Hindujas were up to. Indian investigators became increasingly convinced that the brothers' request for British passports was linked to charges being drawn up there, and so would have concluded any assiduous reader of the newspapers.

The Hindujas were becoming notorious, as ministers in Britain feted them and they feted ministers. In November 1999, they invited the Blairs to a glittering Diwali party in London - in the conspicuous absence of senior diplomats from the Indian high commission.

None the less, when Mandelson last year personally approached Straw about yet a third Hinduja brother, Prakash, who wanted British citizenship, an official in the home secretary's private office emailed Walmsley saying the family business could benefit "UK interests" and Straw would like the case to be dealt with "helpfully".

Hammond asked the home secretary what he mean by "helpfully". It meant he wanted it dealt with "properly, as was his approach to all cases", Hammond records Straw's reply. "If it was right, within the rules, to exercise discretion in this case, then the Home Office should look to do so."

These knaves clearly think we're fools.

webTitle: Myners' code might crack age old problem

fields.headline: Myners' code might crack age old problem
fields.standfirst: Pensions review starts a debate that could result in us all enjoying a more secure old age
fields.trailText: Pensions review starts a debate that could result in us all enjoying a more secure old age.
fields.body:
This week's subject is pensions. Pause. Are you still with me? For many of us, the most important investment decisions of our lives are those relating to our pension funds. Yet we devote little time to understanding them, let alone influencing them.

The pensions industry is a perennial candidate for the booby prize in plain English awards and, faced with complex financial structures cloaked in opaque language, it is little wonder we let tomorrow look after itself.

Let me commend to you then the review of institutional investment published this week, at the Treasury's behest, by Paul Myners. Its author, apart from being chairman of Guardian Media Group, is a doyen of the British investment industry and his insider's view of the way pension assets are invested is a welcome demystification. It is salutary to be confronted with many of the absurdities and inefficiencies ingrained in the system.

For as long as I can remember, fund managers have acknowledged that the targets they are set by the trustees of pension funds are inefficient - typically to perform better than their rivals, rather than to produce a specified investment return.

In their more candid moments, the best managers have been aware that these inefficient targets encourage them to follow the herd. The rewards for just beating the opposition are as great as those for trouncing them - and if you try to trounce them you run the risk of spectacular failure and the career gallows.

Myners tackles these issues head-on. He recommends that pension funds adopt a code of best practice. His belief is that the code's conditions would ensure better informed, more appropriate investment decisions by trustees and fund managers.

It is a laudable aim. But within days, the backlash has begun. The review has been criticised on many counts. There are those who consider the proposed code unworkable or unnecessary and others who voice disappointment that the review was not more radical.

It may be that Myners is reaping the typical whistleblower's reward. The fund management industry is a very profitable one and, as Myners points out, is regarded as one of Britain's successes. As European pension assets continue their gradual shift from bonds to equities, British fund management expertise will be a growing export.

It is difficult to have much sympathy for those voicing disapproval at Myners' recommendations. I say this with some care, for the fund management community is Old Mutual Securities' core customer base. However, the review fails to analyse the costs of effecting the suggested changes. These could be substantial.

Myners wants the actuarial consultants who advise pension trustees to provide better-informed advice on asset allocation and - by extension - fund manager selection. He concedes that the profitability of the consultants is not great, so their charges must increase if they are to improve their advice.

Another recommendation is that pension trustees receive better training and better support from their sponsoring companies. More of them, Myners believes, should be paid for their services.

The review also takes a tilt at the profitability of the fund managers and the brokers they turn to for investment advice and to execute their transactions on the stock market. Myners would like the cost of trading commissions to be borne by the fund management groups rather than by the pension funds they manage. He expects fund managers to adopt a more activist approach to resolving problems within poorly performing companies they have invested in. Oh, and he'd like a greater proportion of fund assets devoted to unquoted companies.

Threat to commissions

All of this costs time and money. The review cites a study by consultants Watson Wyatt that estimates the average annual cost of running a £200m pension fund to be a mere 0.47%, just over half of which accrues to the investment manager.

Myners' code might lead to some redistribution of this sum - less to brokers and fund managers, more to trustees and consultants - but the overall cost will have to rise. So the new system had better deliver improved performance.

The threat to commissions is an intriguing one. There has been an uneasy debate between brokers and fund managers about commissions for some years. Discussions revolve around two points: the dual role of brokers' analysts who serve corporate financiers as well as investors; and the returns to market makers for employing risk capital to facilitate fund managers' trades.

Here the Myners review could prove cathartic. Fund managers should employ more of their own analysts. Brokers should employ fewer, and these should be tied more unambiguously to corporate finance departments. Commissions should disappear for any trades in big, liquid shares where market making competition is intense. They should remain healthy in more obscure shares where the broker has provided analytical input unavailable to the fund manager in-house.

Overall, this might make for a marginally more comfortable retirement for those of you who have struggled through to these final words.

Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities

Myners would like the cost of trading commissions to be borne by the fund management groups rather than by the pension funds they manage. He expects fund managers to adopt a more activist approach to resolving problems within poorly performing companies they have invested in. Oh, and he'd like a greater proportion of fund assets devoted to unquoted companies. Threat to commissions All of this costs time and money. The review cites a study by consultants Watson Wyatt that estimates the average annual cost of running a £200m pension fund to be a mere 0.47%, just over half of which accrues to the investment manager. Myners' code might lead to some redistribution of this sum - less to brokers and fund managers, more to trustees and consultants - but the overall cost will have to rise. So the new system had better deliver improved performance. The threat to commissions is an intriguing one. There has been an uneasy debate between brokers and fund managers about commissions for some years. Discussions revolve around two points: the dual role of brokers' analysts who serve corporate financiers as well as investors; and the returns to market makers for employing risk capital to facilitate fund managers' trades. Here the Myners review could prove cathartic. Fund managers should employ more of their own analysts. Brokers should employ fewer, and these should be tied more unambiguously to corporate finance departments. Commissions should disappear for any trades in big, liquid shares where market making competition is intense. They should remain healthy in more obscure shares where the broker has provided analytical input unavailable to the fund manager in-house. Overall, this might make for a marginally more comfortable retirement for those of you who have struggled through to these final words. Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities edmondw@omsecurities.co.uk

fields.headline: Chill reaches Britain
fields.standfirst: Factory output falls
fields.trailText: Factory output falls
fields.body:
Britain's hi-tech manufacturing base felt the first chill winds of the global economic slowdown in January, government figures revealed yesterday.

A 4.8% slump in demand for electrical and optical goods sent output from factories tumbling at its fastest rate for three and half years in January, according to the office for national statistics. Manufacturing contracted by nearly 1% over the month, the largest fall since August 1997.

City analysts warned that yesterday's figures could be the first signs that the slowdown in the world economy has reached British shores.

"This is clearly the sector most obviously vulnerable to the current global slowdown," said Danny Gabay, UK economist with JP Morgan.

"Our view is that the manufacturing sector will be in recession by the middle of the year," said John Butler, UK economist with HSBC Markets.

"The one sector that is remaining robust is the durable goods industry, which is more heavily related to domestic demand."

Any faltering in the "new" economy would be disastrous for manufacturing. Hi-tech firms were the driving force behind its growth last year, expanding output by 13% while old-economy sectors such as chemical and metals languished.

Industry is already in recession, according to independent analysts at the National Institute of Economic and Social Research. Its latest forecasts show industrial production contracted by 0.6% in the three months to February, while the economy as a whole grew by just 0.3%.

The Bank of England's monetary policy committee left borrowing costs unchanged this week. Analysts said yesterday's unexpected slump in manufacturing would strengthen the hand of those committee members arguing for further rate cuts.

ONS statisticians said they had reduced forecasts of trend growth in manufacturing from 2% to 1.5%.

webTitle: Tories eclipsed as Sun denounces asylum stance

fields.headline: Tories eclipsed as Sun denounces asylum stance
fields.trailText: The Sun's implicit line - one that will cause the government no problems at all - is that the euro is a matter for the Labour government, the British people, and probably the Sun as well, while the Tories have made themselves irrelevant.
fields.body:
Was there a hint early in the week that the Sun was up to something? The biggest seller of the daily Eurosceptic newspaper trio - the Mail and the Telegraph are the others - suddenly devoted not one page but eight to a special deal for its readers. "£9.50 holidays to Europe" read the huge headline on the front page of the supplement.

Was this a less than subtle ploy to convince any wavering Sun readers how awful Europe really was, by sending them to see it for themselves? Surely it could not be that the Sun was abandoning its passionate anti-Euro stance?

By midweek the paper was further softening its line, with a leading article attacking "Hague's error", the Tory leader's speech warning of Britain becoming a "foreign country" if Labour won another term.

The asylum issue, said the Sun with new-found moderation, was "a complicated one". Mr Hague had allowed his speech writer to "flirt with extremism ... it left a nasty taste in the mouth. We have seen how another great country - America - can be built by 'foreigners'."

And the next day, after the budget, the Sun came out, earlier than it had before the last general election, endorsing Labour for the coming one. Even their influential political editor, Trevor Kavanagh, consistently anti-European and anti-euro, was adopting the paper's anti-Tory stance. "The Tory leader," he wrote, "is convinced wavering voters feel the same way as him about the euro and bogus asylum seekers."

But the speech allowed for another interpretation, and an opportunity for Mr Hague's critics, both Labour and Tory, to accuse him of veiled racism. Kavanagh concluded that the Tories were preparing "not to govern, but to spend much, much longer on the opposition benches."

It was thus a week of great significance for the government. With the Sun onside, the already gift-wrapped Labour victory now has bows on the parcel.

Not that we should assume that the Sun has abandoned its "save our pound" stance. Its bold line on asylum should not be taken to mean it is wavering on the euro, a subject it more or less avoided in its week of declaring for Labour.

It is, in a sense, taking a Gordon Brown position. The election comes first, and is one thing; the euro, and the possible referendum, is quite another, and lies ahead.

The Sun's implicit line - one that will cause the government no problems at all - is that the euro is a matter for the Labour government, the British people, and probably the Sun as well, while the Tories have made themselves irrelevant.

Mr Hague's speech can thus be seen as having a direct effect on the euro debate by fusing it, or indeed confusing it, with the asylum debate. The Sun, consistently sensitive to the gut instincts of its readership, felt bound to draw a line separating the issues.

The Daily Mail and the Telegraph carry on however. The Mail achieved another first this week by managing to get the message on to its Money Mail pages.

Fed up with paying tax? Blame it on the French, read the headline across a double-page pre-budget spread, charting the history of taxation in Britain.

It also gave prominence to comments from the outgoing Nato supreme commander, General Wesley Clark, that the proposed European rapid reaction force would "split the transatlantic alliance".

The Mail gave a page to Roger Scruton, the right-wing polemicist, to celebrate Britishness. "The asylum racket," he wrote, "has alerted the British people to the fact that their government will neither defend them from invasion, nor ask for proof of loyalty to the crown of England from those who settle here."

But the overwhelming press sentiment of the week was of unease about the language used by Mr Hague.

As the Times, which tends to steer a middle way on the euro, put it: "Mr Hague has knowingly raised the political stakes. In so doing he has voluntarily engaged in his own European integration. Much of the continental right is flirting with blood and soil in a strident opposition to outsiders ... Mr Hague said on Sunday that 'British people are not narrow nationalists. They are not xenophobes'. That is precisely why they will not stampede to politicians who seem to be playing the race card from the bottom of the deck."

By intentionally or otherwise identifying the Euro-sceptic position with views many potential Eurosceptics find unpalatable, Mr Hague has helped the euro supporters, as a reading of this week's press makes clear. It will turn out to have been a significant week for the euro.

 Peter Cole is professor of journalism at Sheffield University

webTitle: The feud dividing Mandelson and Campbell

fields.headline: Masters of the political black arts go to war
fields.standfirst:
A betrayed friendship is at the heart of the feud dividing Labour's best strategists

Special report: Mandelson
fields.trailText: A betrayed friendship is at the heart of the feud dividing Labour's best strategists.
fields.body:
Peter blames Alastair who blames Peter. The Svengali of Spin and the Sultan of Spin are deploying their black arts against not the Tories but each other and this is politics as soap opera: a Downing Street tale of broken friendship, betrayal and revenge that would not be out of place on BBC1 or ITV.

Peter Mandelson and Alastair Campbell are now bitter enemies after one of the most spectacular Westminster falling-outs in living memory. The former Northern Ireland secretary may insist publicly that he has been undisgraced a second time but this feud promises to run and run.

"The private view of senior ministers is that Mandelson is dead," said a source close to the heart of government. "A question to be decided is the precise manner of his passing."

The source says he has no chance of rising from the grave: "He isn't coming back as a minister and he will not be allowed anywhere near the election campaign in Millbank. This is final."

Labour may be on course for a second election triumph but the Tories can at least look forward to the spectacle of an undignified family feud. The week has been dominated in public by the last Budget before polling day, but in private Downing Street has been preoccupied by the Hammond report.

Tony Blair and Mr Campbell have been at odds over how to handle its findings. The prime minister has rejected the advice of his official spokesman, effectively gagging him in the hope of keeping Mr Mandelson quiet in the future.

"He [Blair] has indulged Mandelson at a substantial cost to himself as well as others," said a government aide. "Alastair is fuming."

Mr Mandelson has been "spinning like a top" to prepare the ground for the report's publication. The Hartlepool MP has visited the offices of every national newspaper at least once to declare that he was the victim of a terrible miscarriage of justice.

Early last month, he was discovered to be talking to the Labour-hating Daily Mail and Daily Telegraph on the day of a keynote speech by Mr Blair, triggering headlines that he hoped to be made a European commissioner.

It sparked a furious row and since, Mr Mandelson has gone to great lengths to cover his tracks and has insisted that his comments must be completely off the record.

Yet Mr Campbell and others are convinced that Mr Mandelson has been responsible for the series of leaks to the media predicting that he would be exonerated by the Hammond inquiry.

The Mandelson camp, primarily consisting of author Robert Harris and the man himself, is admittedly very much smaller than the Campbell clan, which has been actively briefing people about Mr Mandelson's culpability and Mr Campbell's own innocence in the affair.

Since an explosive diatribe against Mr Mandelson made to the Sunday lobby shortly after the resignation, Mr Campbell has been more circumspect. "His line is that Peter has proved why he had to go by his petulance and unstable behaviour since," said a tabloid journalist who has spoken to the press secretary. "Alastair knows what has been going on because the people who Peter speaks to tell him and he reads it in the papers."

Mr Campbell left yesterday's regular briefing to Westminster journalists to his civil service deputy, Godric Smith, rather than face the press.

The rift is a remarkable transformation in a friendship which dates back to before the 1987 election, when Mr Mandelson was Labour's director of communications and Mr Campbell was a journalist.

Mr Campbell opposed his friend's swift return to the cabinet after his first downfall over the £373,000 cheap home loan from Geoffrey Robinson.

Relations between the pair have been strained since and Mr Campbell believes that Mr Mandelson's second shaming vindicates his position. Mr Mandelson believes the Hammond inquiry vindicates his.

Two men who were once the best of friends now appear not to be even friends at all.

webTitle: Mandelson: How the storm blew up

fields.headline: Sultan v Svengali
fields.standfirst:
How the storm blew up

Special report: Mandelson
fields.trailText: How the storm blew up.
fields.body:
Friday January 19

Liberal Democrat MP Norman Baker receives a written Home Office answer on applications for British passports by the Hinduja brothers. Barbara Roche confirms that Mandelson inquired about how an application might be viewed

Sunday January 21

In the Observer Peter Mandelson is quoted as saying that the Hinduja matter was dealt with by his private secretary

Monday January 22

Alistair Campbell tells journalists that when the Hindujas asked Mandelson "to endorse or support any application, he refused perfectly properly". In the Commons Chris Smith dismisses calls for an inquiry

Tuesday January 23

Alistair Campbell tells a lobby briefing that Mandelson had made the phone call and he had been wrong to say otherwise. Mandelson, when asked how he had forgotten the call, tells Channel 4 News that he was not asked about a call until today

Wednesday January 24

Mandelson is ordered to No 10. After much speculation, he resigns

Wednesday January 31

Mandelson calls in a firm of lawyers to represent him in the Hammond inquiry

Friday March 9

Hammond report published. It concludes that nobody did anything wrong

webTitle: Hammond report: No evidence of improper dealings

fields.headline: No evidence of improper dealings
fields.standfirst:
In the muddle, statements were made on the basis of evidence which turned out to be incomplete

Special report: Mandelson
fields.trailText: In the muddle, statements were made on the basis of evidence which turned out to be incomplete.
fields.body:
Edited extracts from the Hammond report

The reputations of individuals depend, to some extent, on the conclusions which I have been called upon to reach, although not to the extent of involving questions of criminal conduct, as did the Profumo affair.

I have ... had regard to the fact that, in the case of events which occurred in 1998, ie more than two and a half years ago, recollections are hazy and it would not be surprising if accounts of different individuals are not wholly consistent with each other.

I have not interviewed any of the Hinduja brothers. Their position is well known from their public statements.

There are four brothers named Hinduja; these include Gopichand (known as GP), Srichand (SP) and Prakash (PP). They are international businessmen with extensive interests in India and in other countries including the United Kingdom.

My main conclusions are as follows:

The applications for naturalisation of GP Hinduja and SP Hinduja were handled properly. No improper pressure was brought to bear by any minister.

The inquiries made on behalf of Prakash Hinduja were handled properly by all concerned.

Keith Vaz made representations on behalf of both SP and GP, but these were in the context of many other immigration and nationality cases in which he made representations.

Mr Mandelson or his officials made or passed on inquiries on behalf of SP and Prakash. It is likely that Mr Mandelson spoke directly to [Mike] O'Brien [in relation to SP]. Mr Mandelson's belief that he had not had a telephone conversation with Mr O'Brien was honestly held.

Mr Mandelson did not make representations on behalf of either SP or Prakash.

There is no evidence of any improper relationship between him and the Hindujas or of any connection between his contacts between them over the sponsorship of the Millennium Dome and their efforts to obtain naturalisation.

There was intelligence material about the Hinduja brothers, but this was not drawn to the attention of the Home Office and it probably would not have affected the outcome of the naturalisation applications if it had been.

In some respects, the processing of the naturalisation applications by the Home Office could have been improved, but systems are now in place which address these issues.

Record keeping in the private offices involved ... was, in some respects, unsatisfactory, and there is a need to address this issue and that of the monitoring of telephone calls.

GP Hinduja

An initial application [for naturalisation as a British citizen] was received from GP Hinduja on February 21 1990. This was apparently sent to the then home secretary, Kenneth Baker, and forwarded to the nationality department.

He had entered the UK in 1982 and had obtained indefinite leave to remain here on July 18 1985.

The normal checks were made with the police and security service, which were negative. In view of the fact that investigations were being carried out in India into alleged corruption relating to the award of an army contract to the Swedish firm Bofors, inquiries were made of the Foreign Office (FCO) and the security service was contacted again. The security service response was again negative.

The FCO suggested that his application should be treated in the same way as any other application; as long as he remained under suspicion and investigation in India, it would cause considerable difficulty with the Indian government if his application was given special treatment.

In 1991 a submission was put forward ... recommending refusal of his application on the grounds, first, that he appeared not to meet the unwaivable requirements of being "in" the UK on the date on which the five-year application period began; and secondly, on the basis that, because of the Bofors allegations it would be difficult to satisfy the requirement of being of "good character".

There was also some doubt about whether he had genuinely "thrown in his lot" with the UK.

Mr Hinduja was told only that his application was refused on the grounds of his failure to comply with the residence requirements.

Between 1993 and 1996 inquiries ... were made on behalf of the Hindujas by a number of people including Edward Heath, Sir Jay Gohel, Keith Vaz, Dame Angela Rumbold [MP] and Lord Feldman.

On March 3 1997 a second application was received from GP. It seems that Andrew Walmsley [director of the Home Office nationality division] decided that in view of the high profile of the Hinduja brothers and of the political sensitivities, it would be better to wait until after the election before going to ministers about making a decision.

On July 3 1997, Mr Walmsley put forward a submission to Mr O'Brien recommending that the application be granted. If Mr Walmsley had checked again with the FCO before submitting this minute he would have discovered that there had been a major and (in India) well-publicised development in the Bofors investigation in January 1997 when the Indian authorities had received important information from the Swiss authorities which they had been seeking since 1990.

Naturalisation was granted to Mr Hinduja in November 1997. The application was, in my view, handled properly by officials and ministers.

SP Hinduja

SP Hinduja, the eldest brother, first applied for naturalisation on February 21 1990. In April 1991, SP was informed that his application had been refused. The letter only mentioned SP's excess absences and made no mention of any doubts about Mr Hinduja meeting the "good character" requirement. I am satisfied the case was dealt with properly.

Because of the events which led to the resignation of Mr Mandelson, much attention has been focused on the issue of whether a personal telephone conversation took place between Mr Mandelson and Mr O'Brien in June or July 1998. In view of this, I have decided that I must deal with this issue in some detail, although I have concluded that in itself the issue is relatively insignificant.

When I interviewed Mr O'Brien he told me he was certain he had had a personal telephone conversation with Mr Mandelson about a naturalisation matter concerning SP at the end of June or beginning of July. Mr Mandelson said firmly that he did not remember the call.

Mr O'Brien said that his assistant private secretary in 1998, Matthew Laxton, had sent an email about SP's interest in naturalisation to Mr Walmsley on July 2 1998. This email had clearly been written as a result of some form of contact from Mr Mandelson or his office.

Mr O'Brien told me that Mr Mandelson had explained that Mr Hinduja was a prominent man in the Asian business community who had applied for citizenship and been refused. Mr Mandelson had told Mr O'Brien that Mr Hinduja would not want to make a further application if there was little chance of success.

Mr O'Brien was clear that Mr Mandelson had not made any representations on behalf of SP but had tried to establish the government's policy in this area so he could relay the details back to SP. Mr Mandelson had specifically said that he was not asking Mr O'Brien to grant naturalisation.

Although Mr O'Brien had known Mr Mandelson for some time, he did not often get telephone calls from him. This was one of the reasons why he remembered the call.

Mr Mandelson told me that he did not remember how the issue had been raised with him by either SP or GP. He did not remember any correspondence on this subject at that time and said he thought that the issue might have been raised informally at a meeting he had had with the Hindujas about some other matters.

Mr Mandelson categorically denies that there was ever any link made by the Hindujas between the funding of the dome and the question of naturalisation.

According to Mr Mandelson, one or both of the Hindujas had asked about a relaxation of government policy in relation to citizenship and whether it would have any bearing on SP's wish to become a UK citizen. Mr Mandelson told the Hindujas that he did not know the answer but would find out.

The alleged telephone call resurfaced in 2000-2001 as the result of a written parliamentary question by Norman Baker MP which was due for answer on December 18 2000. [It asked what representations had been made on behalf of GP and SP's citizenship applications by Mr Mandelson and Mr Vaz]

Mr Mandelson told me that he had been keen to deal with the question and get it answered as soon as possible. The reason why Mr Mandelson queried why it was necessary to mention him at all in the answer was first, because the Norman Baker question had asked about representations and Mr Mandelson had not made any representations. He had not expressed support or endorsement. Second, at this stage of his limited involvement in this matter, no application had been made by SP Hinduja.

Mr Straw's recollection is that Mr Mandelson approached him in the lobby and initiated a conversation about the Norman Baker question. Mr Straw explained that he remembered this discussion because Mr Mandelson had said, more than once, that he did not see why he should be mentioned in the answer. Mr Straw told Mr Mandelson that Mr O'Brien had a clear recollection of having had a conversation with Mr Mandelson about SP Hinduja in 1998. Mr Straw recalled that Mr Mandelson's reaction was along the lines of "Did I?"

There is a difference of view between the Home Office and Northern Ireland Office about whether, in December 2000 or January 2001, Mr Mandelson had acknowledged a telephone call with Mr O'Brien and told his private office that this had been "private". If such a claim were true it would, of course, seriously undermine Mr Mandelson's contention that his dealings with Mr O'Brien's office were done entirely through his private office.

Mr Straw's assistant private secretary Jane Fowler said that during the course of a discussion with Mr Mandelson's private secretary Sarah Todd, Ms Todd said she had spoken to Mr Mandelson and he had acknowledged that his conversation with Mr O'Brien had been "private" and so he did not want this conversation mentioned in the reply to the parliamentary question.

Ms Todd told me that she did not remember using the words private or confidential.

Mr Mandelson told me that as, at that point, he had not acknowledged that a telephone conversation with Mr O'Brien had actually taken place, he was not likely to suggest that such a call would have been private. I am unable to come to a clear view as to whether the words "private or confidential" were ever used in this context.

The question from Norman Baker was answered on Thursday January 18 2001. The following Sunday, the Observer carried a story with the headline "Mandelson helped dome backer's passport bid". The Observer reported Mr Mandelson's statement: "To the limited extent I was involved in this matter I was always sensitive to the proprieties. The matter was dealt with by my private secretary. At no time did I support or endorse this application for citizenship."

This statement was to play a significant part in the rest of the week's events, particularly when later in the week, when Mr Mandelson thought that there was some documentary evidence to support the existence of the telephone call, he had acquiesced in the view that a call had taken place.

Despite the paucity of written records, the hazy and inconclusive recollections of many of those involved and the inconsistencies in the various accounts, although I cannot reach a view with any certainty, the best conclusion which I feel able to reach is that a personal telephone conversation involving Mr O'Brien and Mr Mandelson took place.

I have also concluded that there were a number of contacts between the then ministers' private offices and that it is likely that Mr Mandelson spoke personally to [Matthew] Laxton [O'Brien's then assistant private secretary].

All this was clearly a muddle. Events moved very quickly and definitive statements about what had happened in 1998 were made on the basis of evidence which turned out to be incomplete.

fields.headline: Prince to attack education system
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The Prince of Wales is expected to attack the "failed education system" which leaves too many deprived children without qualifications during a visit to a young people's homelessness charity next week.
fields.body:
The Prince of Wales is expected to attack the "failed education system" which leaves too many deprived children without qualifications during a visit to a young people's homelessness charity next week.

The criticism will coincide with events marking the 25th anniversary of the foundation of the Prince's Trust, set up in spring 1976, which has helped nearly 450,000 disadvantaged young adults to set up their own businesses or develop employment skills and engage in community projects.

Some of the trust's initiatives, such as its out of school learning programme, have been taken over by the government, but the prince's words will reflect disappointment that politicians have not done more to help inner city teenagers.

He is understood to be alarmed that up to 70% of young adults leave care with no qualifications.

The speech will be made during a visit to Centrepoint, the homelessness charity in the Elephant and Castle, south London, on Tuesday. The charity's patron was once the late Diana, Princess of Wales, and Nick Felton, a former director, was one of those consulted about setting up the trust.

The prince's words - though couched in non-partisan terms - would represent a cooling of his previously warm endorsement of the government's youth initiatives.

Although the speech was still in draft last night, advisers believe that its message will not be diluted.

Tom Shebbeare, chief executive of the Prince's Trust, said: "Organisations such as Centrepoint are now funded on such a marginal basis that they are almost teetering on the edge of collapse."

webTitle: Councillors guilty of UK's biggest electoral fraud

fields.headline: Councillors guilty of UK's biggest electoral fraud
fields.trailText: Two local councillors were facing imprisonment last night after being found guilty of orchestrating Britain's biggest vote rigging scandal.
fields.body:
Two local councillors were facing imprisonment last night after being found guilty of orchestrating Britain's biggest vote rigging scandal.

Isaac Lieberman, 29, and Zev Liebowitz, 36, both councillors in Hackney, east London, were convicted of forgery and conspiracy at Wood Green crown court. Lieberman, a school administrator and Liberal Democrat councillor, and Liebowitz, a childcare worker and Conservative councillor, worked together fraudulently to boost the number of proxy voters to ensure Lieberman was elected in the 1998 council elections.

The pair tricked people into proxy support for the Liberal Democrats, created non-existent voters at a derelict property, and added the names of under-18s and non-British citizens to the electoral roll without their knowledge. Liebowitz also registered his brother as two separate voters.

The electoral fraud resulted in a 2,000% increase in the number of proxy votes and may have cost Labour overall control of the council.

The 1998 election saw 241 proxy votes cast, up from 12 at the 1994 election. The court heard that there was a real possibility that the will of the people was not fairly represented. Labour won 29 seats, and the Liberal Democrats and Tories 31 each.

Liebowitz, who despite being a Tory, was motivated by a desire to see his friend elected, conspired with Lieberman to boost the number of Liberal Democrat votes by a variety of means.

The two month trial heard that several pensioners were tricked into signing away proxy votes by the pair, who visited them and told them they were collecting signatures for a petition about refuse collection.

Seven non-existent voters were created, with their address given as a derelict house. A police raid at Lieberman's home uncovered a copy of the electoral roll with the words "Seven votes in the bag" written next to the address.

Some 88 votes were apparently cast by students at a Talmudical college despite many of the students being under voting age or non-UK citizens. Eighty-four of the students at the Mesifta College, which has only 30 beds, cast their votes for the Liberal Democrats, the court heard.

One local man turned up at a polling station to find his vote had already been cast, while a 17 year old appeared on the register as eligible to vote.

"This is not about the odd bit of cheating. The effect may have been to deprive Hackney of the council the electorate truly voted for," said John Bevan QC, prosecuting.

Detective Inspector Robert Garratt of the Metropolitan police, who led the investigation, said: "It is certainly the largest attempt to subvert the democratic process that I am aware of ... There were certainly enough votes garnered by unlawful means to substantially improve Lieberman's chances of success."

Earlier during the trial Lieberman was found not guilty on the judge's directions of one of the conspiracy counts and a forgery allegation, while Leibowitz was acquitted of three forgery charges.

A third defendant, college caretaker Chananya Gross, 22, from Clapton, east London, who only faced one conspiracy count, was acquitted after putting forward a "good faith and honest mistakes" defence.

Two others, who cannot be named for legal reasons, may face a retrial after the jury failed to reach verdicts against them. Lieberman and Liebowitz were granted bail and will be sentenced on April 6.

webTitle: Call to lift bar on Catholic monarch

fields.headline: Call to lift bar on Catholic monarch
fields.trailText: The ban on Roman Catholics succeeding to the British throne is discriminatory and should be changed, Lord Williams of Mostyn, the attorney general, said yesterday.
fields.body:
The ban on Roman Catholics succeeding to the British throne is discriminatory and should be changed, Lord Williams of Mostyn, the attorney general, said yesterday.

The 1701 Act of Settlement prohibits the heir to the throne becoming Catholic before ascending the throne or marrying a Catholic, but does not rule out marriage to a member of any other faith.

Lord Williams said the act was outdated. "I don't like any form of discrimination," he said in an interview with the Daily Telegraph. "My personal view is that there shouldn't be any such bar."

Under current legislation the monarch is the supreme governor of the Church of England, and no Catholic could sit on the throne unless the church was disestablished.

Lord Williams said he would welcome any discussion of the subject. "It's healthy to have a debate about this in a community which now has many different faiths in it," he said.

Lord Williams also said the monarchy was long overdue for reform.

He said he did not want to replace it with a republic, but believed the Act of Succession should be amended to allow royal daughters equal rights to succession.

This would not affect the Prince of Wales or Prince William because it would take years to implement, he said.

Opposition to the Act of Succession has grown in recent years, with lawyers claiming it conflicted with the Human Rights Act.

fields.bodyText: The ban on Roman Catholics succeeding to the British throne is discriminatory and should be changed, Lord Williams of Mostyn, the attorney general, said yesterday. The 1701 Act of Settlement prohibits the heir to the throne becoming Catholic before ascending the throne or marrying a Catholic, but does not rule out marriage to a member of any other faith. Lord Williams said the act was outdated. "I don't like any form of discrimination," he said in an interview with the Daily Telegraph. "My personal view is that there shouldn't be any such bar." Under current legislation the monarch is the supreme governor of the Church of England, and no Catholic could sit on the throne unless the church was disestablished. Lord Williams said he would welcome any discussion of the subject. "It's healthy to have a debate about this in a community which now has many different faiths in it," he said. Lord Williams also said the monarchy was long overdue for reform. He said he did not want to replace it with a republic, but believed the Act of Succession should be amended to allow royal daughters equal rights to succession. This would not affect the Prince of Wales or Prince William because it would take years to implement, he said. fields.headline: Braced for a little local difficulty
fields.standfirst:
Hartlepool could present a new challenge

Special report: Mandelson
fields.trailText: From the splendour of an official residence across the Irish Sea and all the trappings of high office, Peter Mandelson yesterday struck out on a more lowly political course, maintaining that his future now lay with the parochial and not the national.
fields.body:
Hillsborough one week; Hutton Road the next. From the splendour of an official residence across the Irish Sea and all the trappings of high office, Peter Mandelson yesterday struck out on a more lowly political course, maintaining that his future now lay with the parochial and not the national. A few people believed him.

So, in the fading Victorian grandeur of Hutton Road and his other home in the better end of an old steel and shipbuilding town, the former Northern Ireland secretary insisted: "It will be Hartlepool first from now on. I'm not going to lose my voice in politics but I am going on being a first-class constituency MP."

His visit to a struggling north-east constituency, which at times has taken a back seat to wider ambitions, was given a "Peter returns to the grassroots" billing. Schoolchildren bursting past special branch minders thrust autograph books in his face, pensioners clasped his hand, some cheered and some jeered.

Mr Mandelson cruised effortlessly through school and hospital visits and private constituency business, after a shaky start.

Outside his home he read out his 300-odd word statement grimly and ended by saying: "I intend to concentrate on winning back the full trust of my Hartlepool constituents and serving in Parliament for another term. For reasons I hope people will understand, I do not desire a return to government. There are more ways to serve New Labour and fulfil our ambitions for the country. This I intend to do." He refused to elaborate.

Trust? It was the first admission that he had a fight on his hands to retain a once solid Labour seat (majority 17,000) now regarded by Labour's hierarchy as more marginal since the party lost control of the local council last May, and the intervention of a populist local Tory, Gus Robinson the builder, with the added irritation of Arthur Scargill, the miner's union president, standing for the small Socialist Labour Party he created.

Throughout the day, Peter Mandelson's tactic was clear: emphasise the local, avoid most of the national media and be kind to the excellent local paper the Hartlepool Mail.

On Thursday night he phoned its deputy editor, to say he would speak to them exclusively.

"I feel slightly drained but happy that the whole thing is behind me," he told the paper. "It has been, I would say, a searing experience. I feel bruised, but I would like to thank the people who have supported me. This town has been strong ... my job now is to restore people's confidence in me."

webTitle: The Budget: Children are the biggest winners.

fields.headline: Children are the biggest winners
fields.standfirst: Families with youngsters were helped most this year, but don't throw away your contraception just yet, writes Tony Levene
fields.trailText: Families with youngsters were helped most this year, but don't throw away your contraception just yet, writes Tony Levene.
fields.body:
Families with children were the biggest recipients of recently married Gordon Brown's generosity. There are increases in direct financial help for those with children - whether lone parents or couples. And there are greater benefits for women having babies.

But anyone tempted to follow the advice of one tabloid, which dubbed this a "breed for Britain Budget", should take care. Many of the benefit improvements will not kick in for 12 months or even two years. Babies conceived now in a spirit of Budget euphoria will not qualify.

Some gains are limited to the less well-off or barred for the wealthiest. And most are not paid out automatically. Parents have to apply - and that could involve means testing and form filling.

Here's our guide to what's on offer, when it will be paid and, most importantly, how to ensure you get what is due.

Maternity Pay: Statutory Maternity Pay (SMP) is a non-means-tested benefit paid to those about to have a baby or who have just had a baby. They must earn enough to be in the National Insurance net, although there is no minimum NI contribution.

It is currently set at £60.20 a week and is due to rise to £75 a week in April 2002 and £100 a year after that. From April 2003, the payments will be made for 26 weeks instead of the current 18 weeks.

These amounts are paid direct by employers, who can then reclaim a proportion. They are minimum levels - many women will receive more, thanks to contractual obligations. These may not necessarily be increased in the same proportion.

Women who have paid past National Insurance contributions but who do not qualify for SMP can claim Maternity Allowance at the same rate. Ask for form MA1 at a local benefits agency if this applies to you.

Paternity leave: Fathers will get two weeks' paid leave on the same basis as SMP from April 2003. It will be paid by employers, who will be free to offer more generous arrangements.

Paid Adoption Leave: To be paid at the same rate as SMP.

Sure Start Maternity Grant: This means-tested lump sum benefit applies to some 215,000 low income families a year. It will be increased from £300 to £500 in April 2002. The pre-Budget report last autumn abolished the £500 savings limit for applicants. Details from the benefits agency.

Children's Tax Credit: Starting in April, parents of children aged up to 16 will receive £10 a week via paypackets providing they complete an Inland Revenue form which they can get from their local tax office. The sum will be paid irrespective of the number of children and will be tapered so that higher paid parents will not receive the credit.

Families where one or both parents earn up to £32,000 will receive the full credit; those where the higher or only earner has an annual salary of £32,000 to £40,000 will receive lower amounts, while those earning more will receive nothing. From April 2002, the higher earnings level rises to £50,000. Helpline: 0845-300-1036.

Baby Bonus: This is an extension of Children's Tax Credit. It will be paid on a similar basis to CTC, to parents of children born after April 5, 2002, for the first year of the child's life. They will receive an additional £10 a week tax credit - making £20 in all - paid through the PAYE system by their employer, provided they have sufficient earnings. Most new parents with earnings will be able to apply via an Inland Revenue form.

Working Families Tax Credit: This is a means-tested benefit to top up the wages of low paid workers with children, administered by the Inland Revenue's tax credit office. The basic credit goes up from £53.15 to £54 next month and by a further £5 a week on June 1. WFTC claimants should get a minimum £225 a week. Claim on form WFTC1 from benefits agencies. Helpline: 0845-605-5000

Childcare Tax Credit: This is part of Working Families Tax Credit and cannot be claimed on its own. From June, the limit that can be claimed for childcare by qualifying families goes up from £100 a week to £135 for those with one child needing care and from £150 to £200 for those with more than one child.

Child Benefit: A non-means-tested amount which is currently paid at the same rate to all families with children regardless of income or hours worked. It goes up from £15 to £15.50 for the first or only child and from £10 to £10.35 for subsequent children. Claim on form CH2 for the first child; CH497 for subsequent children.

VAT: There is no VAT payable on clothes or shoes for children. But the definition of a child size has stayed unchanged since the 50s; children now grow faster and mature earlier. New rules will attempt to distinguish between clothes aimed at older children and those aimed at adults, reducing costs. There will be separate rules for boys and girls. Small women and men who can fit into child sizes will also benefit.

The Low Incomes Tax Reform Group welcomed the £78 a year increase in Children's Tax Credit over the previously announced rate. But it has "fundamental concerns about how the credit will operate in practice".

It says: "The interaction between this credit and the Working Families Tax Credit means many of those encouraged to take up by the WFTC will find the CTC is reduced to a mere £234 a year instead of the full £520.

"Calling both a tax credit is difficult to follow for most people, while dealing with CTC through tax codings is bound to lead to confusion."
