webTitle: Head teacher wins right to fair hearing

fields.headline: Head teacher wins right to fair hearing
fields.trailText: Marjorie Evans, the Monmouthshire head teacher cleared on appeal of slapping a 10-year-old pupil, yesterday won the right to a fair displinary hearing after a high court judge ruled that her employer had not followed proper rules and procedures.
fields.body:
Marjorie Evans, the Monmouthshire head teacher cleared on appeal of slapping a 10-year-old pupil, yesterday won the right to a fair displinary hearing after a high court judge ruled that her employer had not followed proper rules and procedures.

But Mrs Justice Bracewell also found that Mrs Evans was lawfully suspended after further allegations of pupil mistreatment were made against her and should not return to St Mary's junior school in Caldicot, south Wales, until after the three day hearing next week. The outcome of the hearing, before the school governors, will determine if and when the 56-year-old teacher can return to work.

At the high court in Cardiff, the National Union of Teachers, on behalf of Mrs Evans, had accused education officials of having a "pig-headed attitude" over her return to work. It said Monmouthshire council and the school governors had ignored proper disciplinary procedures.

In her ruling yesterday, Mrs Justice Bracewell said: "Mrs Evans faces very serious allegations but she has been presented with three versions (of disciplinary proceedings) inconsistent with one another and none applicable with disciplining a head teacher."

Mrs Evans has been suspended on full pay for 18 months after being accused of slapping a special needs pupil. She was convicted of assault in July, but cleared on appeal in September. The suspension remained in place because police were investigating further claims of mistreatment. But in October the crown prosecution service said it would be taking no further action.

fields.headline: Snow show
fields.trailText: 10.03.03 Warm conditions have taken their toll on most of Europe, while heavy snow in America and Canada is improving already great conditions.
fields.body:
Warm conditions have taken their toll on most of Europe, while heavy snow in America and Canada is improving already great conditions.

Austria

Rain and high temperatures have caused some deterioration in the snow quality. Kitzbuhel (***) and St Anton (***) have wet snow on the lower slopes.

France

Wet/slushy snow in many resorts. Tignes (****) and Les Arcs (****) have great skiing on piste but off piste is to be avoided due to high avalanche risks.

Switzerland

Klosters (****) and Saas Fee (****) have some of the best skiing in Europe.

Italy

Still very good although some lower slopes are becoming worn. Madonna di Campiglio (***) has had recent rain.

Andorra

Generally adequate but the snow is becoming wet and heavy in many areas.

US

Snow is still falling in Stowe (*****) and Killington (*****). Conditions should be great for Easter.

Canada

Still very good throughout. Big White (****) has lovely powder off piste and good groomed snow on the slopes.

Liz Russell, The Ski Club of Great Britain

No snowflakes = a serious lack of snow - no lifts open. * = poor snow conditions, very few lifts open. ** = conditions reasonable, some slopes in poor condition.*** = plenty of good skiing. **** = good conditions. ***** = fantastic on and off piste.

fields.headline: Netjetters
fields.trailText: This week, for the first time, our travelling trio have all ended up in the same country, Australia - although from what they get up to, you'd never guess it.
fields.body:
This week, for the first time, our travelling trio have all ended up in the same country, Australia - although from what they get up to, you'd never guess it. Sam heads for Uluru and hits on an unusual method of combating the heat, Sue negotiates jumping crocodiles and leeches during her visit to Kakadu National Park and Milly clocks up an impressive 17-hour shift at her hotel job - officially her longest ever day.

Sue in Darwin: "Next day, we were up at 6am and into Kakadu, many parts of which are flooded and inaccessible. We went up to Nourlangie Rock to see the Aboriginal rock paintings, then on to Gubara for a 6km walk which ended with a lovely swim at a waterfall.

"There were 11 of us on the tour, all youngsters apart from me and an older Danish couple - a different type of traveller from those I had been used to meeting on the rest of my trip. These people were mostly just working, travelling or partying around Australia and New Zealand (there can't be many young people left in Ireland - they're all here). They all happily did the walks in an assortment of skirts, bikini tops and flip-flops, but they were good fun and full of questions and enthusiasm for all we saw.

"In the evening we played 'two truths and a lie', where you each make three statements, and everyone else has to guess which was the lie. Few got mine right: I was once kissed by Paul McCartney/I once went out with a boy called Bertie Clack/I once played cricket for Sussex Junior Ladies.

"The next day involved more walking, stunning waterfalls and swimming in the Gimbat area. The most impressive waterfall was the Motorcar Falls. This area could only be reached by a four-wheel-drive, as a couple of the roads were flooded and partially washed away. Several people tumbled out of their seats as we rock'n'rolled our way through - exciting stuff."

Sam in Alice Springs: "We were headed for the Olgas when I suddenly realised that I had dropped my hat. This was not good news. It would be madness to go out in the sun without some sort of protection. Clearly I would have to improvise. A little later, tourists getting off the other buses were treated to the sight of an odd-looking character coming down from the hills. Was it Yasser Arafat on holiday? Lawrence of Arabia, perhaps? No, it was me with a tea towel round my head. It actually worked quite well: I could put my head under the tap and soak the cloth to keep myself cool.

"This was the first time I had encountered the sort of heat that could kill you. There were plenty of stories about people expiring among the rocks because they hadn't taken enough water with them. Dave made sure we were all carrying plenty - at least a couple of litres each - when we ventured out. Back at the campsite, I slept out under the stars - partly for the experience and partly to get away from the extremely poisonous redback spider that was sharing my tent."

Milly in Sydney: "I managed to get away at 1.15am, which meant I'd had a 17-hour working day, which is pretty impressive. More impressive was how I managed to stay in the pub for four hours after that (to celebrate still being alive). I returned home tired, less than sober, and over 24 hours later than I'd left. I think that day is going to take some beating."

Milly in Sydney: "I managed to get away at 1.15am, which meant I'd had a 17-hour working day, which is pretty impressive. More impressive was how I managed to stay in the pub for four hours after that (to celebrate still being alive). I returned home tired, less than sober, and over 24 hours later than I'd left. I think that day is going to take some beating."

fields.headline: Hollywood's moguls
fields.standfirst: Idaho is not usually associated with glamour, but the Sun Valley Ski Resort has been pulling in stars since the 30s.  Alf Alderson follows the leads of Errol Flynn, Clint Eastwood and Arnold Schwarzenegger
fields.trailText: Idaho is not usually associated with glamour, but the Sun Valley Ski Resort has been pulling in stars since the 30s. Alf Alderson follows the leads of Errol Flynn, Clint Eastwood and Arnold Schwarzenegger
fields.body:
Sixty-six years ago, skier Count Felix Schaffgotsch of Austria wandered among the mountains of Idaho and pinpointed the peaks above the unknown sheep-farming town of Ketchum as being the perfect location for the first ski resort in the US. One year later, in December 1936, Sun Valley Ski Resort had been christened by the marketing men and was built and open for business with a chairlift - based on a hoist used for hauling bananas into ship's holds - ready to take punters up Dollar Mountain.

The resort was the brainchild of Averell Harriman, president of Union Pacific Railroad, who had employed Schaffgotsch to search out the ideal spot for a ski resort in the northwest, which would attract more passengers on to his trains. However, because of the remote and unknown location of Sun Valley, Harriman needed to get his expensive new baby into the public spotlight, and it was Hollywood that supplied the extra push.

By inviting stars such as Clark Gable and Errol Flynn to the resort's opening party, Harriman ensured that Sun Valley hit the headlines before the first skis had even schussed across the snow, and the stars have continued to patronise Sun Valley's elegant ski lodges and slopes ever since.

Indeed, Hollywood has come en masse to Sun Valley on several occasions. Among the numerous movies filmed here or in the nearby Sawtooth Mountains were How to Marry a Millionaire and Bus Stop, starring Marilyn Monroe in the 50s, and Clint Eastwood's Pale Rider in 1985. It also did the place no harm that Ernest Hemingway wrote much of For Whom the Bell Tolls while staying at Sun Valley Resort Hotel, and even his suicide in Ketchum in 1961 brought more publicity to the area.

Today, Clint Eastwood, Bruce Willis, Demi Moore, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Tom Hanks and Jamie Lee Curtis are just a few of the screen icons who own property in Sun Valley. Which, among other things, means that it is also one of the most expensive ski resorts in the US. A common complaint is the cost of lift passes (around £37 a day), but when conditions are right, you may get some of the best skiing on the continent and, whatever the conditions on the mountain, you can enjoy the luxury mountain lodges.

It can be a little disconcerting to walk into River Run or Warm Springs lodges at the base of the ski runs, or Seattle Ridge Lodge high up on the mountain, and find yourself clomping across deep pile carpets in snow-encrusted ski boots, dumping soggy hats and gloves on elegant heavy wooden dining tables, or applying sun cream inside marble-clad "rest rooms" that could grace any five-star hotel. But that's how you attract millionaires, which is a large part of what Sun Valley is about.

Another major plus of the resort is that even in a winter like this one, when snow levels have been around 50% down, Sun Valley has the biggest man-made snow-making system in the world, covering 645 acres.

Most of the ski action takes place on 9,150ft Bald Mountain, directly above Ketchum. The first lift didn't open here until 1939; today there are 14, with runs catering to all abilities. However, it's worth noting that the mountain's constant steep pitch can result in a lot of runs being "under-graded" - this is the first place I've skied where some of the green runs have moguls, and many blues would be graded black(ish) at most other resorts (bear in mind that there are no reds in the US).

"Baldy" stands out as a huge bulge of rock above the surrounding landscape, and you can follow the sun around its three faces throughout the day. You also get magnificent views of the wild, remote mountain ranges of central Idaho to the north and the wide Snake River Plain to the south.

Sun Valley's original ski hill, Dollar Mountain, is tiny in comparison - only 6,638ft high, it's located a couple of miles east of Ketchum, looking down on the Grand Dame of 1936, Sun Valley Resort Hotel. It shows how much things have changed that the mountain which once attracted Hollywood greats is now regarded almost exclusively as a beginner's area.

In addition to some of the best downhill skiing in the US, that isn't all the place is about. There are more than 200km of cross-country ski trails along the Wood River Valley, which runs beneath Bald Mountain, snowshoe trails on both Bald and Dollar mountains, ice skating on indoor and outdoor rinks at Sun Valley Resort, and if money is no object, Sun Valley Heli Ski can get you out into perfect powder country. And when you finally want to take the strain off your legs, you can hand it over to sled dogs who will haul you into the surrounding hills for anything from one hour to overnight trips.

Then again, if you've invested in a multi-day ski pass, you'll probably want to get value for money and ski as much as possible. And since this is Sun Valley, you may even end up sharing a lift with one of your favourite movie stars.

Getting there

Ski The American Dream (0208 5521201) offers one-week room-only packages at the Sun Valley Resort Hotel for £895, based on two adults sharing and including flights via Salt Lake City and transfers.

Accommodation

There is no real budget accommodation available in the Sun Valley area. Sun Valley Resort Hotel (+1 208 622 4111) is the original, still very elegant lodge, with rooms costing from $109-$1,000 a night, while Sun Valley's Elkhorn Resort (208 622 4511) is well placed for accessing Dollar Mountain, and has rooms from $128 - $299 a night.

In Ketchum, and ideal for Bald Mountain, River Street Inn (208 726 3611) is one of the most attractive B&Bs in Idaho, with rooms from $140-$195 per night.

Passes Downhill: A one-day ski pass costs $59, a six-days-out- of-seven pass will set you back $336. Check out www.sunvalley.com for more details.

Cross-country: Sun Valley Nordic Center (208 622 2250, www.sunvalley.com) has trail passes for $12. Skis and shoes can be rented for around $30 per day.

Heliskiing: Sun Valley Heli Ski has access to 750 square miles of back country terrain, with various deals from a day to a week's skiing. Call 208 622 3108, or visit www.destinationnw.com/svhelisk

Ice skating: Sun Valley Ice Rink, admission $8, skate rental $3.25. Contact Sun Valley Resort (208 622 2196, www.sunvalley.com).

Dog sledding: trips vary from 90-minute rides to overnight excursions, with prices from $85-$350 per person. Call Sun Valley Sled Dog Adventures (208 823 4600, www.sunvalleyplace.com/sleddog/mush.html).

Snowshoeing: in Sun Valley, contact Sun Valley Nordic Center (208 622 2250, www.sunvalley.com).

A $15 lift ticket allows access to snowshoe trails on Bald Mountain, and snowshoe rental is around $30 per day, contact Ski-Tek, 191 Sun Valley Rd (208 736 7503 www.ski-tek.com).

Also, 25 miles north of Sun Valley is Galena Lodge (208 726 4010) which has some excellent snowshoe trails in the Sawtooth Mountains, accessible for only $3 per day.

webTitle: Ros Taylor rounds up the best websites for surf fanatics.

fields.headline: Netting the surf
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor rounds up the best websites for surf fanatics.
fields.body:
Quite why looking at web pages was ever compared to surfing a wave is unclear, but there is certainly no shortage of sites devoted to the sport. I've concentrated mostly on British sites here, but both the Adventure Sports Directory (see below) and the index at About Surfing are useful if you want to head for Hawaii, California, Australia or another surfing hub.

Some sites ask you to bear in mind that many beach footpaths are currently closed because of the foot and mouth epidemic.

UK Surf Index

The Index calls itself the "one-stop portal site for all UK surfing", which is no exaggeration; schools, surfing shops, contests, online magazines, classifieds, weather and webcams are all covered, as well as a very active bulletin board.

British Surfing Association

Adult membership costs £23. The BSA site is a pale imitation of the UK Surf Index, although a members-only section is promised.

Surfing Vancouver Island

Even if you're not thinking of a trip to Canada, this site is worth visiting if you're a novice, want to read up about boards or surfing terminology or how wave height is predicted. Enthusiasts will also enjoy Neil Borecky's "Sick Days Compared to Swell Height" graph and similar outpourings.

Adventure Sports Directory

Choose Surfing from the activity index and click on the world map for a list of local surfing schools. An intelligent idea, well executed.

Sharkbait

A Brighton-based site with lively reports from the south coast, wetsuits and boards for sale and local beach and accommodation information.

Surf Newquay

Everything you could possibly want to know about the surfing capital of the south-west, with some glorious photography.

Your Environment
Type in the first two letters of the postcode of the place where you want to surf, and a map will appear indicating the quality of the bathing water.

Surf 98

Cornwall beach profiles, forecasts and a page devoted to some of the dolphins spotted by surfers in the south-west.

webTitle: Councillors guilty of UK's biggest electoral fraud

fields.headline: Councillors guilty of UK's biggest electoral fraud
fields.trailText: Two local councillors were facing imprisonment last night after being found guilty of orchestrating Britain's biggest vote rigging scandal.
fields.body:
Two local councillors were facing imprisonment last night after being found guilty of orchestrating Britain's biggest vote rigging scandal.

Isaac Lieberman, 29, and Zev Liebowitz, 36, both councillors in Hackney, east London, were convicted of forgery and conspiracy at Wood Green crown court. Lieberman, a school administrator and Liberal Democrat councillor, and Liebowitz, a childcare worker and Conservative councillor, worked together fraudulently to boost the number of proxy voters to ensure Lieberman was elected in the 1998 council elections.

The pair tricked people into proxy support for the Liberal Democrats, created non-existent voters at a derelict property, and added the names of under-18s and non-British citizens to the electoral roll without their knowledge. Liebowitz also registered his brother as two separate voters.

The electoral fraud resulted in a 2,000% increase in the number of proxy votes and may have cost Labour overall control of the council.

The 1998 election saw 241 proxy votes cast, up from 12 at the 1994 election. The court heard that there was a real possibility that the will of the people was not fairly represented. Labour won 29 seats, and the Liberal Democrats and Tories 31 each.

Liebowitz, who despite being a Tory, was motivated by a desire to see his friend elected, conspired with Lieberman to boost the number of Liberal Democrat votes by a variety of means.

The two month trial heard that several pensioners were tricked into signing away proxy votes by the pair, who visited them and told them they were collecting signatures for a petition about refuse collection.

Seven non-existent voters were created, with their address given as a derelict house. A police raid at Lieberman's home uncovered a copy of the electoral roll with the words "Seven votes in the bag" written next to the address.

Some 88 votes were apparently cast by students at a Talmudical college despite many of the students being under voting age or non-UK citizens. Eighty-four of the students at the Mesifta College, which has only 30 beds, cast their votes for the Liberal Democrats, the court heard.

One local man turned up at a polling station to find his vote had already been cast, while a 17 year old appeared on the register as eligible to vote.

"This is not about the odd bit of cheating. The effect may have been to deprive Hackney of the council the electorate truly voted for," said John Bevan QC, prosecuting.

Detective Inspector Robert Garratt of the Metropolitan police, who led the investigation, said: "It is certainly the largest attempt to subvert the democratic process that I am aware of ... There were certainly enough votes garnered by unlawful means to substantially improve Lieberman's chances of success."

Earlier during the trial Lieberman was found not guilty on the judge's directions of one of the conspiracy counts and a forgery allegation, while Leibowitz was acquitted of three forgery charges.

A third defendant, college caretaker Chananya Gross, 22, from Clapton, east London, who only faced one conspiracy count, was acquitted after putting forward a "good faith and honest mistakes" defence.

Two others, who cannot be named for legal reasons, may face a retrial after the jury failed to reach verdicts against them. Lieberman and Liebowitz were granted bail and will be sentenced on April 6.

fields.headline: Soldier, scholar, socialite
fields.standfirst:
Academic Charles Boxer was recently accused here of betraying
fellow army officers in the second world war. Historian Dauril
Alden , whose biography of Boxer is published next month, sets the
record straight
fields.body:
Born on March 8 1904 at Sandown on the Isle of Wight, Charles Boxer was the son of a British officer who was wounded while serving with Kitchener at Atbara and died while leading his men over the top in France in 1915. Charles Boxer was educated at Wellington and Sandhurst. The navy rejected him because of deficient eyesight and he joined the army in 1923. He enrolled in the Lincolns, following in the footsteps of his late father and his elder brother, Myles. In 1930 Boxer was assigned to Japan as a language officer, that is, a language student and military observer. During the next three years he studied language intensively and shared the stoic existence of Japanese military units with whom he lived. He also became proficient in kendo, the Japanese form of fencing. He travelled widely in the orient and bought many books, a practice he continued into his late 80s. After a two-year stint in Britain, mostly in the intelligence section of the war office, Boxer was posted to Hong Kong, where he arrived in 1937 and remained until 1945.

Between 1937 and 1941, Boxer, promoted from captain to major, became one of the key members of the Far East Combined Bureau, a British intelligence organisation that extended from Shanghai to Singapore. By 1940, most of its Hong Kong office had been transferred to Singapore, leaving Boxer as the army's chief intelligence officer in the colony. His performance was later evaluated by Major-General GE Grimsdale. From 1939 until 1945 Grimsdale headed British army intelligence successively in Hong Kong, Singapore, and Chungking. He played a key role in the creation of the FECB and remained one of its staunch supporters. The two travelled together on trips to war-torn China. Grimsdale declared Boxer to be "a very capable intelligence staff officer, with a quick and accurate mind and a fluent pen. I could not have wanted a better or more congenial assistant".

Boxer was, like most other prominent figures in the colony, socially very active. But he was often away. After the Japanese army occupied Canton and territory adjacent to the Kowloon mainland, Boxer frequently visited the new commandants in order to ascertain Japanese intentions. He also made several extended trips to remote parts of China. In Chungking he negotiated directly with Chiang Kai-shek to establish a Sino-British secret radio corps to monitor Japanese overflights. He regularly ferried to Macao, where he combined business (sharing intelligence with the Portuguese governor) with pleasure (archival research and conviviality). He returned to Japan on several occasions. His last pre-war visit came in mid-1939, on honeymoon following his marriage to Ursula Norah Anstice Tulloch.

Later he became deeply worried about the state of Anglo-Japanese relations. In a masterful report sent to the war office and senior officials throughout government, he warned that "at present there could be no greater error than to assume, as is so often done, that Japan's military machine is too bogged down in China to prevent it being turned against us in the event of our becoming involved in a war in Europe". Though the war office and the foreign office took little note of Boxer's warning, events proved him to have been prescient.

During the early morning of December 8 1941, Major Boxer was in an underground post in Victoria, where he regularly monitored Japanese radio news broadcasts. Suddenly he heard, and promptly reported to his base commander, the fateful coded words that announced the beginning of the Pacific war. Following the collapse of the defence of the mainland, Boxer was one of the staff officers who greeted the retreating 2 Royal Scots as they landed on Victoria and directed them to their new defensive assignments. On two occasions (December 13 and 17 1941) he met with Japanese delegations demanding the colony's surrender, demands adamantly refused by its governor, Sir Mark Young. To the shock and dismay of suspicious observers, Boxer courteously conveyed the governor's responses in fluent Japanese accompanied by bows and salutes, in accordance with customary Japanese protocol.

On December 20, as Japanese forces were threatening the south perimeter highway connecting the Aberdeen naval station with Stanley Peninsula, Boxer went to Repulse Bay Hotel, where casualties and refugees ware confined under close attack. Discovering that a company of the 2/14 Punjab regiment had become leaderless while trying to regain high ground near the hotel, he tried to rally the men but was shot in the back by a sniper. He was not discovered for hours. He was taken to a nearby hospital and placed in its morgue. It was assumed he would not recover but he came round. After months of hospitalisation and only partial recovery of his damaged left arm, Boxer was transferred in October 1942 to Kowloon, where he was confined with his fellow officers to the Argyle Street camp.

There he became a contributor to a barracks magazine, Within, one of several publications the PoWs produced to divert the prisoners' attention from the depressing war reports that the Japanese disseminated in their official paper, the Hong Kong News. B y the early months of 1943 the fortunes of war in the Pacific were clearly changing, and the Japanese authorities in Hong Kong were becoming increasingly worried. The results were bloody crackdowns. First in Stanley camp, where most of the remaining western civilians were interned, and then in the three major PoW camps, Argyle Street. Shamshuipo and Ma Tau Chung. What most troubled the Japanese was the possibility of a mass breakout and that is precisely what the BAAG, the Sino-British underground in the Chinese mainland, tried to promote through surreptitiously delivered messages. Boxer was certainly involved in the planning of such a breakout at Argyle but he had absolutely no responsibility for its premature exposure which resulted in the arrest, torture and execution of the future recipients of posthumous George medals: Mateen Ahmed Ansari, Douglas Ford, Dolly Gray and Lance Newnham.

In every PoW camp in the Far East there was a contest to control prisoners' minds. The Japanese wanted to withhold all news concerning their own setbacks, while inmate leaders were anxious to build morale by disclosing Allied victories. For a brief time, from June until late September 1943, a secret short-wave radio receiver (not a transmitter, as stated in the Saturday Review article of February 24) functioned in the Argyle Street camp, enabling Boxer and his fellow officers to accomplish their objective. At least five men, including Boxer, Commanders Douglas HS Craven and Rex Young, and Lt Herbert Charles Dixon, the radio's constructor, knew where it was hidden. But an informer - a sixth person, and certainly not Boxer, for Craven and Young would have said so in their memoirs if it had been - disclosed its existence.

After the Japanese found it, Boxer and the others were arrested, interrogated, and sentenced to five years of hard labour. Thereafter, Boxer was confined with his fellow officers to two grim barracks, halls B and C, of Stanley Prison. They remained there from October 1943 until June 1945, when they were transferred to a Canton penitentiary. I have visited hall B and can attest to the depressing conditions throughout the prison. There is ample testimony that during his long months of solitary and later shared confinement, Charles Boxer earned the admiration of his fellow inmates. After the war, Ralph Goodwin, a remarkable camp escaper, contacted many of Boxer's prison companions in the course of writing one of his books. Goodwin wrote that they "never ceased to marvel at the amazing fortitude and calmness of spirit that characterised his behaviour throughout their long incarceration", adding that they remained grateful to him for his intervention with Japanese commandants in both prisons to alleviate their distress.

Much the same testimony appears in the text of the government's first offer of an MBE to Boxer. Following liberation in August 1945, Boxer returned to duty in Hong Kong. For two frenetic months he undertook several tasks: one was to identify prospective Japanese war criminals and to assist in their roundup; a second was to discover the graves of the recipients of the four George medals and to arrange for their removal to Britain.

According to one United States official in Hong Kong who saw him frequently, Boxer "was truly the only man in Hong Kong with spark and drive and a passionate urge to get on with the job. [He] worked like a beaver". A third task was to recover his missing library; a fourth was to determine whether his mistress, Emily Hahn, still wished to marry him.

Charles Boxer was educated at Wellington and Sandhurst. The navy rejected him because of deficient eyesight and he joined the army in 1923. He enrolled in the Lincolns, following in the footsteps of his late father and his elder brother, Myles. In 1930 Boxer was assigned to Japan as a language officer, that is, a language student and military observer. During the next three years he studied language intensively and shared the stoic existence of Japanese military units with whom he lived. He also became proficient in kendo, the Japanese form of fencing. He travelled widely in the orient and bought many books, a practice he continued into his late 80s. After a two-year stint in Britain, mostly in the intelligence section of the war office, Boxer was posted to Hong Kong, where he arrived in 1937 and remained until 1945. Between 1937 and 1941, Boxer, promoted from captain to major, became one of the key members of the Far East Combined Bureau, a British intelligence organisation that extended from Shanghai to Singapore. By 1940, most of its Hong Kong office had been transferred to Singapore, leaving Boxer as the army's chief intelligence officer in the colony. Grimsdale declared Boxer to be "a very capable intelligence staff officer, with a quick and accurate mind and a fluent pen. I could not have wanted a better or more congenial assistant". Though the war office and the foreign office took little note of Boxer's warning, events proved him to have been prescient. Suddenly he heard, and promptly reported to his base commander, the fateful coded words that announced the beginning of the Pacific war. Following the collapse of the defence of the mainland, Boxer was one of the staff officers who greeted the retreating 2 Royal Scots as they landed on Victoria and directed them to their new defensive assignments. Shamshuipo and Ma Tau Chung. fields.headline: I think I'm turning Japanese
fields.standfirst: David Mitchell's second novel number9dream is flawed but stylish, finds  Steven Poole
fields.trailText: David Mitchell's second novel number9dream is flawed but stylish, finds Steven Poole
fields.body:
number9dream
David Mitchell
422pp, Sceptre, £10
Buy it at a discount at BOL

David Mitchell's first novel, Ghostwritten , was one of the most highly praised fiction debuts of recent times, and with unusual justice. It was impressive mainly for its imaginative range - a globetrotting series of first-person narratives that included a Japanese Aum cult member on the run after the Tokyo subway nerve-gas attack, an Irish nuclear physicist and a disembodied consciousness searching for its birth-story in Mongolia.

Despite its enormous ambition, however, it left some wondering how much of a novel it was. Each section was linked to its fellows only by fleeting, marginal appearances of characters from other sections; rather than any overarching narrative structure, the effect was one of spectral patterns interleaved, ripples interpenetrating in a pond. The reader was eventually given leave to suppose that the entire novel had been compiled by the sky-surfing, satellite-hopping electronic consciousness of its penultimate chapter. True to its title, Ghostwritten was a dazzling performance of authorial absence.

Number9dream is at first glance more traditional in its architecture, sticking mainly with one narrator. Eiji Miyake is a 20-year-old Japanese student, newly arrived in Tokyo to search for his missing father. Absent fathers are traditional bait for metaphysical quests, and Eiji's real quest, it turns out, is to come to terms with a tragedy buried in the past; intercut throughout the novel are idyllic scenes from his childhood.

Eiji rents a capsule room above a video shop, falls in love with a pianist's perfect neck, and gets mixed up in the deliciously creative violence of Yakuza turf wars. Alternating the modes of sadistic action movie, detective story, cyberpunk thriller and gentle romance, the external action of the novel is always engaging. But such is Mitchell's beautifully precise style that he can make inaction just as pleasurable, as Eiji lies alone on his bed, smoking cigarettes and watching the neon clock across the street count down the hours until dawn. The prose bespeaks a kind of observational rapture that offers the smell of Tokyo streets or even the movements of a cockroach as tiny, cherishable shards.

Mitchell also adores larger-scale formal tricks, which are not always convincingly integrated with his subject matter. The book opens with a faintly irritating section entitled "Panopticon", named for the law firm where Eiji believes he will find clues to his father's identity. The reader is wrong-footed numerous times, as each elaborate attempt on the Panopticon fortress is revealed to be a figment of Eiji's nerve-shredded imagination. The third section, "Video Games", makes only a half-hearted attempt to mime the sensual action of the electronic arts; in its romp through Yakuza-owned hostess clubs, it quickly comes to resemble a seedy teen-buddy movie.

It is the fifth section, however, that grates most. Entitled "Study of Tales", it sees Eiji hiding out in a writer's house and reading the fables she has left on her desk. With their hero Goatwriter, who is obsessed with finding the "truly untold tale", they are written in an insufferably fey, sing-song rhyming prose, and it becomes painfully apparent, among the superfluity of pages devoted to this arch nonsense, that we are witnessing a fable about fiction itself. "A hoochy-koochy hooker honked. 'Stories never filled my belly!'" Such wastebasket-fodder is symptomatic of Mitchell's greatest fault: he explains too much. The book's lovely oneiric textures seem mocked and polluted by this clunking defence of making stuff up.

Far more successful, because less overt, are the enjoyably arrogant dabs of intertextuality: one character and one secret facility from Ghostwritten wink tangentially into life here too, and contribute a pianissimo counterpoint to Mitchell's leitmotif. His guiding thesis is a comfortingly simple one: everything is somehow interconnected, even if we don't know why. This theme is most obviously celebrated in the novel's obsessive numerology. As though it were intended as a cyborg updating of the medieval dream poem Pearl , number9dream is everywhere infected with viral nines. Partly because of this suspicious arithmetic, it becomes possible to suppose that the entire action of the novel may have been a dream; Mitchell's greatest feat is to suggest this without making the reader feel cheated.

It is at the climax that we are also reminded of Mitchell's great literary debt. Eiji dreams he meets John Lennon, who wrote a song called "#9dream". "'#9dream' is a descendant of 'Norwegian Wood'," Lennon tells Eiji. Similarly, number9dream is heavily influenced by the Japanese novelist Haruki Murakami, whose most famous book (in Japan) is Norwegian Wood . As in Norwegian Wood , a woman very close to the narrator writes letters to him from a mental institution. And just as Murakami's The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle (which, it is hinted, Eiji has half-read) includes a harrowing nested narration of events during the second world war, so number9dream offers pages from the diary of a Japanese torpedo pilot on a suicide mission to sink American shipping.

It may be, however, that Murakami is a dangerous model, in the same way that Nabokov has claimed so many lesser talents as victims. Mitchell's attempt to borrow historical pathos misfires, while he simulates the gossamer naivety of Murakami's characters - especially in his curiously asexual central romance - without ever quite managing, as the Japanese novelist does, to make them resonate. Murakami conjures a tone of great poetic melancholy out of deceptively simple materials. It is a tone that Mitchell has not quite matched here, but he is clearly a writer of such rare imaginative energy that in the future he will doubtless create a world entirely his own.

webTitle: Anti-obesity drug given licence for NHS use

fields.headline: Anti-obesity drug given licence for NHS use
fields.trailText: A new drug for obesity which prevents fat from being absorbed by the body was approved for use in the NHS yesterday, but strictly limited to those whose weight is a serious medical problem.
fields.body:
A new drug for obesity which prevents fat from being absorbed by the body was approved for use in the NHS yesterday, but strictly limited to those whose weight is a serious medical problem.

Orlistat (brand name Xenical) is the first anti-obesity drug that does not work by suppressing the appetite. It has been hailed as potentially one of a new breed of lifestyle drugs. Weight reduction, like conquering social shyness and ending impotence, can be seen in the context of quality of life rather than serious damage to health.

The decision that the NHS should pay for orlistat, announced by the national institute for clinical excellence (Nice), came with conditions to make sure that only those whose health and in some cases life is threatened by their weight will get it.

The patient must also show they are committed to losing weight and keeping it off by shedding at least 2.5kg in the previous month through ordinary diet and exercise.

The tablets are not a miracle cure. They have to be used in conjunction with dieting and exercise and offer their own rather unpleasant incentive to cut down on fat intake. They work by reducing the capacity of the body to absorb fat. Any surplus passes straight through the gut and is excreted with some urgency.

Most patients will not be prescribed orlistat for longer than a year and none should have it longer than two years, Nice says. They will only be allowed to stay on the pills if they manage to lose at least 5% of their body weight every three months.

Peter Littlejohns, clinical director of Nice, said: "Doctors and patients need to work together to manage this condition and today's guidance provides advice on the contribution which orlistat can make."

The Nice decision is partly a response to the worrying in crease in obesity in the UK, which looks set to follow the pattern in the United States. Some 11,000 seriously overweight people are likely to be prescribed the pills, at a cost to the NHS of £12m a year. Even this represents savings on the bill for treating medical conditions which can be a consequence of obesity over many years.

Ian Campbell, chairman of the National Obesity Forum, said: "The decision underlines the importance of treating obesity and the overweight - an epidemic that is having an alarming impact on our nation's health - before it is too late.

"By treating obesity and overweight we can reduce the burden of disease linked to obesity, such as coronary heart disease and diabetes."

Around 61% of British men and 52% of women are thought to be overweight, while 16% and 18% respectively are clinically obese and therefore likely to have damaged health. As in the US, children seem to be following in the fatness trend. A survey found that in the last 10 years there has been a sharp increase in the numbers who are overweight, customarily put down to junk food, and too much television and computer game-playing.

The national audit office said recently that the inactivity and overeating, which causes obesity, were killing 31,000 people prematurely a year. In 10 years, it said in a report, the UK could catch the US, where a quarter of the population is obese.

Orlistat will only be given to those with a body/mass index of over 30 kg/m2 or 28 kg/m2 if they have a serious illness such as diabetes or high blood pressure. Body mass index is the person's weight in kilograms divided by their height in metres squared. A BMI of 20 to 25 is normal, 25 to 30 is overweight and more than 30 is obese. A man of about 5ft 10in weighing more than 15 stone or a woman of 5ft 6in and 13.5 stone would be regarded as obese.

Latest economic revival package is immediately overshadowed by rumours that Japan's prime minister will step down

Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: Latest economic revival package is immediately overshadowed by rumours that Japan's prime minister will step down.
fields.body:
Japan's ruling coalition attempted to breathe life back into the nation's economy yesterday, but its efforts were overshadowed by rumours that prime minister Yoshiro Mori will announce his resignation today.

The Liberal Democratic Party, which has held power for all but one of the past 46 years, and its two allies announced an emergency package to boost share prices, increase liquidity in the property market and redenominate the yen.

It was billed as a shift away from the government's attempt to spend its way out of a 10-year economic slump, but investors and analysts said it was too little too late. The announcement made barely a ripple on the currency markets, where the yen hit an 18-month low on Thursday.

"We proposed this emergency economic package after concluding that it would be very difficult to restore the economy to stable growth just by implementing the budget for the next year", said Shizuka Kamei, the ultra-conservative LDP policy chief.

The package was undermined by being presented to Mr Mori, whose 6% approval rating makes him one of the most unpopular leaders in the country's history.

Mr Mori is seen as part of the old guard, clumsily repeating anachronistic right-wing comments about the war and the emperor, and professing ignorance about the economy and information technology.

He has been twice linked to yakuza gangsters and scandals have claimed the resignations of three of his ministers.

Since he took the helm last April the economy has slipped into reverse. Tokyo stocks have lost 40% of their value and the yen has declined by 15% against the dollar.

Japan faces a cocktail of deflation, record unemployment, the world's biggest public debt, renewed fears of bank instability, and nose-diving stock and property prices.

At the heart of the rescue package was a plan to revitalise the stock market, where the Nikkei index hovers close to a 15-year low.

The ruling parties said they would introduce tax breaks to encourage individual investors back into the stock market and boost property sales. The plan seeks to channel more of the huge pool of postal savings into stock investments. It also proposes the establishment of a private-sector fund to buy up stockholdings owned by banks weighed down by ¥30 trillion (£176bn) in non-performing loans.

With an upper house election due in July, the coalition tried to shift some of the blame for the slump on the Bank of Japan's decision to end its zero-interest rate policy last August. The emergency package includes a call for the central bank to restore the "money-for-nothing" policy and establish a price stability target. This has been opposed by the bank's governor, Masaru Hayami, who insists the government's efforts should focus on structural reforms.

Financial authorities also appeared to be divided over the currency. Many in the ruling party favour a weaker yen, which would help exporters and reduce deflationary pressures by raising the cost of imports. Mr Hayami and economics minister Taro Aso said this was undesirable.

The growing leadership vacuum was also highlighted by reversals and contradictory statements on policy by senior government officials, making it far from clear whether the rescue plan would be implemented.

Finance minister Kiichi Miyazawa apologised for saying the previous day that Japan's finances were very close to collapse. "My choice of words was inappropriate," the 81-year-old told parliament. "The overall economy remains on a recovery track though the pace is very slow."

Economics minister Taro Aso was more pessimistic: "The economy is not in a state where one can be optimistic."

webTitle: Japanese are now a 'don't spend' force

fields.headline: Japanese are now a 'don't spend' force
fields.standfirst: Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: It was not so long ago that Japan aspired to be "No 1". So why has this once dynamic country become so muddled and disillusioned, drifting along under governments that persist in trying to cure the country's ills with the same ineffective remedies?
fields.body:
It was not so long ago that Japan aspired to be "No 1". The phrase, the title of a well known book, reflected a time when a puzzled and more than slightly frightened world studied Japanese strategy and style for clues on how to cope with the country's astonishing economic success.

An equally puzzled world is now asking why a once dynamic Japan has become so muddled and disillusioned, drifting along under governments that persist in trying to cure the country's ills with the same ineffective remedies.

It is not that Japan does not remain a formidable economic power. Still very much a manufacturing giant, it has huge export surpluses, massive foreign exchange reserves, and tremendous stockpiled personal savings. It may not have quite the technical edge it once had over rivals like the US but it still leads in many fields; by 2002, for example, Japan is expected to have 370,000 industrial robots, as against America's 120,000 and Britain's 12,000.

The key lies in those personal savings, which are both a potential asset and a symptom of the lack of confidence of ordinary Japanese in the political and economic system. Put simply, the Japanese will not spend or invest their personal reserves and prefer to put what they have by for a rainy day.

The government is in hock, ironically, precisely because citizens will not spend. It tried to jack up demand by expensive public works programmes, but stimulus package after stimulus package in the years since the stock market crash of 1990 sent Japan into the doldrums have failed in their purpose.

The economic problem is part of a broader dilemma for Japan. More and more it seems as if the formula that made the country so succesful was a momentary one, reflecting a balance that could not be maintained for long. Economically, Japan combined the world-beating efficiency of its leading firms with the cushioned inefficiency of its domestic market.

Socially it managed to keep old forms of solidarity and old ideas of duty and proper behaviour in being even as modernisation bore down on traditional ways. The strain always showed in the bizarre breakdowns of individuals and the cultish excesses of certain groups, phenomena which go back a long way in Japanese history.

These days the Japanese are not sure they recognise themselves in their own young, whom they sometimes refer to as "space aliens". They worry mightily over a spate of schoolboy killings and over the emergence of gangs like the bosozuku, bikers who stage sometimes lethal battles in the streets.

Japanese caution is shown not only in a reluctance to spend but also in a reluctance to have children. The birthrate is dropping, and, at present rates, Japan's population will be down to 100m from the present 127m by 2050. Twenty six million Japanese today are over 65, which presents yet another problem.

If the country had had stronger political leadership during recent years, the vicious circle of insecurity leading to more insecurity might have been broken. But the Liberal Democratic Party, in power except for one short break ever since normal politics began after the second world war, is a factionalised organisation accustomed to compromise and internal bargaining, and deferential both to the business class and the bureaucracy.

Reformers like Koichi Kato, who led a sort of rebellion last year, have not fared well. The prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, has lost some of his better ministers after corruption scandals, and has himself been spectacularly inept. Probably his final misjudgement as prime minister was to continue his game of golf after being told of the sinking of the Japanese school ship by a US submarine.

That was compounded when it was discovered that his membership dues for the club, an astonishing £200,000, had been paid by a businessman friend. It is this combination of misfortune, misjudgement and sleaze that seem to many Japanese to characterise their life in the new century. Mori will not last much longer. But it looks as if Japan's troubles will.

fields.headline: Hotel Barcelona, Exeter
fields.trailText: Our bed was kingsize, firm and smothered in crisp white cotton sheets and soft pillows. Perfect for lazy breakfasts and late afternoon lounging.
fields.body:
Address: Magdalen Street, Exeter, Devon EX2 4HY. Tel: 01392 281000.

Fax: 01392 281001.

Web address: www.hotelbarcelona-uk.com

First impressions: Former Victorian eye hospital in soft red Devon stone. Once inside the Grade II listed building, all institutional associations dissipate thanks to funky 1950s decor - including original Castiglionni floor lamps, Miles Davis sketches and luxuriant sofas.

What are the rooms like? Ours was large, airy and relaxing, with light streaming through four 15ft sash windows. Dark wood floor and furniture complements autumnal colours of sumptuous bed and curtains. Tea- and coffee-making facilities, TV and video, and CD system.

The bed test: Kingsize, firm and smothered in crisp white cotton sheets and soft pillows. Perfect for lazy breakfasts and late afternoon lounging.

Bathroom test: White, immaculate and modern, with a forceful shower, toiletries and huge towels.

The restaurant: Café Paradiso serves simple, yet impressive, Mediterranean-style food, using local, predominantly organic, produce. Pizzas are cooked in a woodburning oven and local fish charred in front of you on a brushwood grill. Antipasti £6, pizzas £6.50-£9.50, dense chocolate pudding £5.50.

What is there to see within walking distance? Exeter's shops, Norman cathedral and picturesque cathedral close Alternatively, chill out in Kino, the hotel's "theatre-style nightclub offering cabaret and dinner".

And nearby? The coast is less than half an hours' drive away, the dramatic, rolling tors of Dartmoor less than an hour.

How much a night? Until the end of March, two people can spend two nights for £159, including continental breakfast, entry to the club Kino, and one dinner. From the end of March, the price rises to £199.

fields.headline: Keep the faith, reap the net profits
fields.standfirst: Interview: Gerald Levin , chief executive officer, AOL-Time Warner
fields.trailText: Interview: Gerald Levin , chief executive officer, AOL-Time Warner
fields.body:
Gerald Levin is a man on a mission of biblical proportions. In his early 20s, as a student of religious literature, he thought seriously about becoming a rabbi.

Today, at the age of 61 and as head of the world's largest media company, he is preaching a message of a very different kind. His mantra is the promotion of the newly created $130bn (£89bn) AOL-Time Warner, a media group that he believes has the power, literally, to change the world.

It is an organisation that marries new media with old, has content and distribution arms across five continents, claims 130m paying subscribers and strikes fear into the hearts of competitors.

And as far as Mr Levin is concerned it has only just got going. "We want to be the most valuable and most respected company of any kind anywhere in the world within five years," he says.

"We're trying to make a difference in the world and there is a missionary zeal in this company. I like to see AOL-Time Warner as a laboratory for innovation and an agent for change."

Had Mr Levin not taken an unsolicited call from AOL boss Steve Case 18 months ago, he would probably still be doing the rounds on Wall Street merely trying to convince investors that Time Warner would eventually "get the internet" and would not lose ground as technology forced different mediums to converge.

"Steve came on the phone and said simply 'Let's put the companies together and you can be CEO'. I said maybe we ought to have dinner because I was really unsure any of it would work. We had dinner, spent the entire time talking about values, world views and ideas and that's when it came clear to me that perhaps we should try and do it."

Substance behind vision

The proposed merger was announced in January last year, turning the media world upside down and seeing the bold marriage of the internet and content described as "deal of the century".

Mr Case, who is chairman of the enlarged group, took the plaudits that day but those who believed that AOL Time Warner would be his show underestimate Mr Levin. Some 20 years Mr Case's senior, and a veteran of several multi-billion dollar takeovers, Mr Levin is the substance behind the vision.

Uncomfortable in the media spotlight and a slight, greying figure, he has often been characterised as cold and distant. Former colleagues have said he is intellectual but lacks charisma.

In an industry where the big players are larger than life and often domineering characters such as Rupert Murdoch, Barry Diller and Sumner Redstone, Mr Levin can come across as almost dreary.

Yet when the quiet mogul of US media speaks, people listen. Critics warn that the combination of Mr Levin, Mr Case and the Ted Turner as vice chairman could lead to a case of too many cooks spoiling the broth.

Mr Case says the individuals are vital to serving up a feast of content and technology that spans the US's largest internet service provider, Netscape, Time magazine, Warner Records, Time Warner Cable, HBO, Fortune, Sports Illustrated and the Warner Brothers film studio.

The merger was sealed just six weeks after intense regulatory scrutiny but analysts are already starting to question whether it can deliver on the aggressive targets it first outlined.

A year has passed since the technology laden Nasdaq market toppled from its peak. Shares in technology and media companies show little sign of recovering their former highs.

The advertising market is weakening, as popular internet portal Yahoo! warned earlier in the week, and these days it is the leaders of established media firms making the telephone calls. They are offering to put the dot.coms out of their misery.

Yet Mr Levin is resolutely sticking to the hymn sheet and refuses to budge from the ambitious target of revenues of $40bn in 2001.

"I agree that most mergers fail to deliver on their promises but in this case we have a position, assets and people that are so profound and we're talking about growth rates that are so significant that we're looking at something that will be a one-of-a-kind company."

He says the fees the company generates from AOL subscriptions and pay-TV sub sidiaries such as HBO should keep revenue levels stable.

Observers say Mr Levin faces an uphill task integrating what are perceived to be two very different work cultures that developed at AOL and Time Warner.

"In a way we're fortunate, because in the year and a day that it took us to close this deal we spent a lot of time talking about the same values and the same subscription formats and I feel very comfortable that we have very committed people."

A large part of that commitment is to changing the world. "Making a difference is very important to the the kind of people who have been attracted to this company. There is a sense of destiny here and the job is not just about a pay cheque.

"We have an obligation to participate in the formation of public policy and its not just because we affect people around the world or that the internet is a global medium. I really think companies have the resources and the skill to do so.

"Frankly, there is a lack of leadership in the public sector and education. There's no conflict with the financial interests of shareholders because if you've got committed people who really believe in the mission of the company then their performance is going to reflect that.

"Henry Luce, the founder of Time Inc, put in his will that the company should be operated not only in the interest of shareholders but in the public interest. We've taken that as a rubric for our company.

"This is going to be a completely new kind of media company simply because when you blend in the internet activities with the advanced media you saw at Time Warner you create something entirely new."

Desire to develop

That Mr Case is seen as the AOL-Time Warner front man will not surprise Mr Levin. He is used to being written off and has made a habit of proving his detractors wrong. Ever since he took over as chief executive of Time Warner in 1992, rivals started to whisper that Mr Levin would not be in the job for long.

Instead he has built a reputation as one of the industry's shrewdest operators and greatest survivors. In 1997 he even had to overcome the personal tragedy of losing his youngest son Jonathan, a teacher who was shot dead by one of his pupils.

Born in Philadelphia and twice married, Mr Levin joined Time in 1972 after a year working for the International Basic Economy Corporation in Tehran.

For all Mr Levin's talk of AOL-Time Warner's plans for world domination, only 20% of its revenues come from outside the US. It is something he plans to address quickly and he was in Britain earlier this week on a profile-raising trip that involved speaking to business leaders at an event organised by the London Business School. "Europe is central to us and is at the top of our list in terms of our strategy and desire to develop."

While Mr Levin was in London, speculation on Wall Street centred on his long-term future and whether he plans to retire - but with a rare smile he describes his new role as "about as good as it gets".

Expect him to keep the faith a while longer.

The CV

Born: Born in Philadelphia on May 6, 1939

Education: Graduated from Haverford College - where he studied theology - in 1960. Three years later, he gained a law degree at the University of Pennsylvania

Family: Three children from first marriage to Carol. One son Jonathan was murdered in 1997. Two children from second marriage to Barbara

Career: Started as an attorney in New York City. Worked for Development and Resources, international investment company, and served for a year in Iran.

Joined Time in 1972 when HBO was in developmental stage.

Became vice-chairman in 1988.

Engineered merger with Ross Warner in 1990 and became CEO of Time Warner in 1992.

Acquired CNN in 1996, merged with AOL to form world's biggest media group last year.

Interests: Classical music and religion. On the board of Museum of Jewish Heritage

fields.headline: Who pulls the strings? (part 3)
fields.trailText: Bilderberg members continued to ignore my enquiries through the end of 1999 and into 2000. I continued dutifully to write to Bilderbergers, although I held out no hope of a breakthrough. And then, one Tuesday morning, the phone rang. It was the instantly recognisable voice of a Bilderberg founder member, for 30 years one of their inner circle, their steering committee, a Bilderberg agenda setter, a head-hunter - a secret ruler of the world himself, should you choose to believe the assorted militants I had spent the past five years with. It was Denis Healey.
fields.body:
Bilderberg members continued to ignore my enquiries through the end of 1999 and into 2000. I continued dutifully to write to Bilderbergers, although I held out no hope of a breakthrough. And then, one Tuesday morning, the phone rang. It was the instantly recognisable voice of a Bilderberg founder member, for 30 years one of their inner circle, their steering committee, a Bilderberg agenda setter, a head-hunter - a secret ruler of the world himself, should you choose to believe the assorted militants I had spent the past five years with. It was Denis Healey.

"How can I help you?" he said.

"Well," I said, "would you tell me what happens inside Bilderberg meetings?"

"Okay," he said, cheerfully.

There was a silence.

"Why?" I said. "Nobody else will."

"Because you asked me," he said. Then he added, "I'm an old fart. Come on over."

Once Lord Healey had agreed to talk to me - and I had circulated this information far and wide - other Bilderberg members became amenable, too (albeit on the condition of anonymity). These interviews enabled me to piece together the backstage mechanics of this most secret society.

So this is how it works. A tiny, shoe-string central office in Holland decides each year which country will host the next meeting. Each country has two steering committee members. (The British ones have included Lord Carrington, Denis Healey, Andrew Knight, the one-time editor of The Economist magazine, and Martin Taylor, the ex-CEO of Barclays Bank.)

They say that each country dreads their turn coming around, for they have to raise enough money to book an entire five-star hotel for four days (plus meals and transport and vast security - every packet of peas is opened and scrutinised, and so on). They call up Bilderberg-friendly global corporations, such as Xerox or Heinz or Fiat or Barclays or Nokia, which donate the hundreds of thousands of pounds needed. They do not accept unsolicited donations from non-Bilderberg corporations.

Nobody can buy their way into a Bilderberg meeting, although many corporations have tried. Then they decide who to invite - who seems to be a "Bilderberg person". The notion of a Bilderberg person hasn't changed since the earliest days, back in 1954, when the group was created by Denis Healey, Joseph Retinger, David Rockefeller and Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands (a former SS officer while he was a student - ironic that a former Nazi, albeit a low-ranking and half-hearted one, would help give birth to an organisation that so many would consider to be evidence of a Jewish conspiracy).

"First off," said a steering committee member to me, "the invited guests must sing for their supper. They can't just sit there like church mice. They are there to speak. I remember when I invited Margaret Thatcher back in '75. She wasn't worldly. Well, she sat there for the first two days and didn't say a thing. People started grumbling. A senator came up to me on the Friday night, Senator Mathias of Maryland. He said, 'This lady you invited, she hasn't said a word. You really ought to say something to her.' So I had a quiet word with her at dinner. She was embarrassed. Well, she obviously thought about it overnight, because the next day she suddenly stood up and launched into a three-minute Thatcher special. I can't remember the topic, but you can imagine. The room was stunned. Here's something for your conspiracy theorists. As a result of that speech, David Rockefeller and Henry Kissinger and the other Americans fell in love with her. They brought her over to America, took her around in limousines, and introduced her to everyone.

"I remember when Clinton came in '91," he added. "Vernon Jordan invited him along. He used it as a one-stop-shop. He went around glad-handing everyone. Nobody thought they were meeting the next president." (Of course, Jim Tucker would contend that they all knew they were meeting the next president - for they huddled together that weekend and decided he would be the next president.) At times, I become nostalgic for when I knew nothing. There are so few mysteries left, and here I am, I presume, relegating Bilderberg to the dingy world of the known. The invited guests are not allowed to bring their wives, girlfriends or - on rarer occasions - their husbands or boyfriends. Their security officers cannot attend the conference and must have dinner in a separate hall. The guests are expressly asked not to give interviews to journalists. Rooms, refreshments, wine and cocktails before dinner are paid for by Bilderberg. Telephone, room service and laundry bills are paid for by the participants. There are two morning sessions and two afternoon sessions, except on the Saturday, when the sessions take place only in the evening so that the Bilderbergers can play golf. The seating plan is in alphabetical order. It is reversed each year. One year Umberto Agnelli, the chairman of Fiat, will sit at the front. The next year, Norbert Zimmermann, chairman of Berndorf, the Austrian cutlery and metalware manufacturer, will take his place. While furiously denying that they secretly ruled the world, my Bilderberg interviewees did admit to me that international affairs had, from time to time, been influenced by these sessions.

I asked for examples, and I was given one: "During the Falklands war, the British government's request for international sanctions against Argentina fell on stony ground. But at a Bilderberg meeting in, I think, Denmark, David Owen stood up and gave the most fiery speech in favour of imposing them. Well, the speech changed a lot of minds. I'm sure that various foreign ministers went back to their respective countries and told their leaders what David Owen had said. And you know what? Sanctions were imposed."

The man who told me this story added,

"I hope that gives you a flavour of what really does go on in Bilderberg meetings."

This is how Denis Healey described a Bilderberg person to me: "To say we were striving for a one-world government is exaggerated, but not wholly unfair. Those of us in Bilderberg felt we couldn't go on forever fighting one another for nothing and killing people and rendering millions homeless. So we felt that a single community throughout the world would be a good thing."

He said, "Bilderberg is a way of bringing together politicians, industrialists, financiers and journalists. Politics should involve people who aren't politicians. We make a point of getting along younger politicians who are obviously rising, to bring them together with financiers and industrialists who offer them wise words. It increases the chance of having a sensible global policy."

"Does going help your career?" I asked.

"Oh yes," he said. Then he added, "Your new understanding of the world will certainly help your career."

"Which sounds like a conspiracy," I said.

"Crap!" said Denis Healey. "Idiocy! Crap! I've never heard such crap! That isn't a conspiracy! That is the world. It is the way things are done. And quite rightly so."

He added, "But I will tell you this. If extremists and leaders of militant groups believe that Bilderberg is out to do them down, then they're right. We are. We are against Islamic fundamentalism, for instance, because it's against democracy."

"Isn't Bilderberg's secrecy against democracy, too?" I asked.

"We aren't secret," he snapped. "We're private. Nobody is going to speak freely if they're going to be quoted by ambitious and prurient journalists like you who think it'll help your career to attack something that you have no knowledge of." I noticed a collection of photo albums on his mantelpiece. Denis Healey has always been a keen amateur photographer, so I asked him if he'd ever taken any pictures inside Bilderberg. "Oh yes," he said. "Lots and lots of photographs." I eyed the albums. Actually seeing the pictures, seeing the set-up, the faces, the mood - that would be something.

"Could I have a look at them?" I asked him. Lord Healey looked down at his lap. He thought about my request. He looked up again. "No," he said. "Fuck off."
