fields.headline: Eating out
fields.standfirst: Matthew Fort finds a few rich pickings among the offerings at a village pub in the Chilterns
fields.trailText: Matthew Fort finds a few rich pickings among the offerings at a village pub in the Chilterns.
fields.body:
'Get changed?! To go to Turville?!!" cried the Aged Parent. "No one gets changed to go to Turville." How true, how very true. People dress down to go to Turville.

Before you get the wrong idea, let me explain. Turville is one of those decorative little villages that speckles the hills and valleys of the Chilterns with the sanctity of good taste. So fastidious are these clusters of flint and red-brick homes that they don't even reek of money, although they represent one of the great concentrations of wealth in the country. They are the rural bolt-holes of computer whizzes, bond dealers and media giants who have made it, and lots of it, for whom a better quality of life begins with the commute back from London. And when they get back, the first thing they do is strip off the pinstripe uniform and dress down to go out for a pint and maybe a spot of dinner at the Bull & Butcher.

It had been an adventure for us getting there, as the whole area appeared to be awash. I had to rely on the AP's local knowledge to steer us from Henley to Turville, as many of the back roads had become gushing water courses as a result of long moribund springs within the hills surging back to life after our recent rains. Luckily, the Bull & Butcher itself seemed immune to watery worries, although not free from earthly ones.

Indeed, there was a faint echo of Basil Fawlty about mine host that evening, being curtly dismissive of occasional visitors such as ourselves, while lavishing attention on the down-dressers at the bar. He seemed slightly overwhelmed by events, and later muttered that it had been an evening of unparalleled horrors. By that time, the AP and I considered ourselves lucky to be getting anything at all, chaos in minor forms having invaded the meeting and greeting, the distribution of menus and the drink orders. However, once I had been quieted with a pint of impeccable Brakspear's Bitter and the AP had settled to the bottle of Vacqueras, things looked up.

You can tell that the pub is in a rich village because it has no music, no electronic games, no theming, no fake and fancy Victorian mirrors and ersatz agricultural knick-knacks. It has real fires, real stone flagstones, real beams, real beer and real food. Here is hot home-smoked pastrami on rye, coarse chicken liver and pork pté, warm salad of scallops and wild mushrooms, grilled sirloin steak with fries and salad, breast of duckling with confit potato, blackcurrant and liquorice sauce, and grilled brochette of tandoori vegetables, bindi bhaji and Bombay potatoes. With the exception of the liquorice in the duckling's sauce and the tandoori vegetables, there isn't anything wildly outré about such dishes, but I think most of us would find something to relate to. The AP related to salad of smoked duck, poached pear and Roquefort and then rump of lamb roasted with garlic, dauphinoise potatoes, pak choi and wild mushrooms; I to terrine of smoked haddock, spinach and potato before calves' liver, pecorino mash, smoked bacon and seasonal veg.

You couldn't fault the portion control. The AP's duck, pear and cheese, generous though the primary ingredients were, was almost invisible among the welter of leaves, beetroot, spring onions and other vegetable storm damage. And thank heavens the terrine was a substantial block, because it was in danger of resembling a lost city of Central America hidden beneath a vast mat of jungle. The terrine itself was a nice idea that might have been nicer if it had been marginally less gelid. Obviously, it had only recently escaped the fridge.

The AP was not impressed by her lamb, which was served on a similarly liberal scale. Nice gravy, she said, but the meat tasted of nothing, and something had gone wrong with the gratin that gave it the texture of melted plastic. She approved the most of the whole roasted head of garlic. However, whoever cooked my liver knew exactly what they were about. It was impeccable: tender velvet within a crisp veneer. The mash was best left alone, but the cabbage and gravy were just the job.

This just left me room for steamed syrup pudding with custard, which, given the speed of its delivery, clearly had not been steamed at the last minute. I suspected microwave magic, but was too polite to say so. Lemon crème brlée ice cream gave the AP more pleasure than the rest of the meal put together: she was very cheered by this classy deal, made with soft meringue, which gave it a disarmingly soft texture.

In the growing company of gastro-pubs, on this showing the Bull & Butcher is one of the foot soldiers, a face in the crowd, characterful certainly, but lacking real class. The bill was £69.05, which included the Vacqueras (a modest wine) at £21 and my beer, so the food damage was a relatively light £46. I say relatively, because were you not so greedy you would do well with two courses. But as we thought that we might well be marooned on the way back, we were grateful for the extra calories

webTitle: Young, single and hitting the net

fields.headline: Young, single and hitting the net
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The typical onine shopper - who braves the net despite the sort of problems which have beset virtual bookshop Amazon, where hackers have been accessing customer credit card details held on line - is single, has a degree and drives a hatchback.
fields.body:
The typical onine shopper - who braves the net despite the sort of problems which have beset virtual bookshop Amazon, where hackers have been accessing customer credit card details held on line - is single, has a degree and drives a hatchback.

Around one in five frequent shoppers, that's people who buy at least once every two months, spends more than £500 annually on the net, and is happy to buy financial services online (39% do so).

The average regular shopper is 34 and earns £29,300. More than 40% have a first degree - one in 10 has a postgraduate qualification - and more than 40% are single. The most popular internet service provider in this country is Freeserve (used by 18% to access the net), followed by BT Surftime, NTL and AOL, all of which are used by 11% of frequents.

The top products for internet purchase are books, music and software. David Brosse, marketing director of MyPoints, a company which awards loyalty points to people who receive and read tar geted advertising by email and which carried out this research, says: "People tend to start with low ticket items such as these, then move on."

The British spend £2.3bn a year on the net, which will rise to £4.4bn by the end of this year, according to Nick Jones, senior analyst at internet consultancy Jupiter MXL. fields.headline: Sixty seconds in: Interior design
fields.standfirst: Murray Jervis, a director of agency Jervis Hegarty Losasso, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.trailText: Murray Jervis, a director of agency Jervis Hegarty Losasso, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.body:
Although we all trained as architects, we've abandoned that medium as too slow, and today we specialise in interiors. As a company, we do a lot of work for the Virgin Group and have just finished designing the interiors of its new fleet of 140mph tilting trains that are due to go into service in 2002. None of us know very much about the engineering side but to be honest, that has probably been an advantage as it has allowed us to approach the project without preconceptions.

We got the job because we had designed Virgin's upper class lounge at Heathrow, the interiors of some its planes and, most recently, the conversion of the Our Price chain of record shops into V.Shops.

While we don't know much about train engineering, we do have a very good understanding of what customers want out of a space. Because the new trains will be competing with plane travel in terms of speed and comfort, we have deliberately designed the train to have an aircraft feel. The whole concept is about speed, so we've incorporated lots of swooping fast lines.

Every good interior design is built upon three cornerstones. It has to communicate the brand - in this case it's Virgin, which isn't hard -it has to fulfil the customer's needs, and it has to be easily implemented with minimum disruption to the customer.

For example, in the new trains we've designed small retail outlets similar to those in petrol stations where travellers will be able to buy papers, magazines, CDs - everything you might want on a journey. We've put TVs in the backs of all the seats and installed an audio system that, again, is similar to those in aircraft.

The V.Shops are a good example of creating a design that can be installed quickly. A lot of the installation was pre-manufactured and held in warehouses ready for fitting at the last minute. We put in intranet terminals that allow customers to view the whole of the Virgin back catalogue - they can buy cars or MP3 players - but most importantly we did it in 40% less time than a traditional shop installation.

Generally, the design process starts with a big meeting at which we thrash out the ideas, and we quickly move on to the computers. We present all our ideas in virtual reality, which is great for the customers as they can see exactly what a design is going to look like at quite an early stage.

Although it's superficially thrilling when the finished work is unveiled, for me it's all about making businesses function better and keeping people in work.

fields.headline: Psycho bosses on the loose
fields.standfirst: Are you in their line of fire?
fields.trailText: Are you in their line of fire?
fields.body:
You'd recognise a psychopath if you were unlucky enough to come across one, wouldn't you? Don't be so sure. The media may portray the psychopath as a crazed serial killer - the stuff of nightmares and horror films - but the reality is chillingly different. Not all psychopaths are violent criminals and fewer still have a desire to eat you for dinner. Many are highly successful businessmen and women, lawyers, academics, politicians, doctors and teachers. Psychopaths wear suits too... in fact, there could be one in your office.

According to a recent news report, an Australian psychiatrist and criminal profiler is planning a series of lectures to show employers how to spot psychopaths at work. University of Sydney psychologist John Clarke believes it's essential that employers learn how to identify psychopaths in order to reduce problems in the workplace.

Clarke says workplace psychopaths have the same psychological make-up as killers. The only difference is that they have the ability to hide their psychopathic tendencies behind the front of a respectable, white-collar job. Employers should beware liars, cheaters, smooth-talkers, people who appear bored, those who change jobs quickly and those who believe they should be higher up in the company; all are potential psychopaths. (Note that recent studies have discovered that 15% of top executives misrepresent their education, and one-third of all CVs contain lies.)

Psychopaths aren't mad: they're sane, rational, often highly intelligent individuals. What separates them from the norm is a series of character traits - among them impulsiveness, egocentricity, lack of empathy and irresponsibility - which make them a highly dangerous and destructive force in society. No-one is certain exactly what causes a person to be

psychopathic, although it is now generally believed that psychopaths are born, not made. As yet, psychopathy can neither be cured nor successfully treated.

Robert Hare, professor of psychology at the University of Vancouver, is considered to be one of the world's foremost experts in the study of psychopathy. He estimates that about 1% of the population are psychopaths. "Psychopaths use superficial charm, manipulation, intimidation, and violence to control others and satisfy their own selfish needs," he says. "They lack conscience and feelings for others, cold-bloodedly take what they want and do as they please, violating social norms and expectations without the slightest guilt or regret."

In the go- getting, ruthless world of modern business, such personal qualities are often valued and encouraged.

The result? A psychopath who stays on the right side of the law can go far, charming and manipulating their way to the top of the career ladder and treading on those in their way. "These individuals are every bit as egocentric, callous and manipulative as the average criminal psychopath," says Robert Hare. "However, their intelligence, family background, social skills and circumstances permit them to construct a facade of normalcy and to get what they want with relative impunity."

Tim Field, author of Bully in Sight , is convinced that the manager whose relentless bullying ruined his career, health and marriage, was a psychopath. After researching thousands of cases of bullying at work, he now believes that 90% of bullying incidents are committed by serial bullies, the majority of whom have psychopathic characteristics. He's currently writing a book about psychopaths in the workplace.

"I estimate that one person in 30, male or female, is a serial bully," he states. "Like the textbook psychopath, serial bullies are emotionally cold, compulsive liars and experts at mimicry and deception. They sail through psychometric tests with flying colours and are masters of the latest workplace jargon, which is sure to impress management. They tend to rise swiftly through the ranks, giving them the ideal position to target those below them.

"While, on the surface, the psychopathic bully might seem to have the organisation's best interests at heart, his only objectives are power, control, domination and subjugation. By the time this is realised, the damage is done. Employers are in denial, even though serial bullying is estimated to cost the taxpayer between £12bn and £30bn per year."

Tim says that in 98% of cases, the serial bully will target one individual, while charming and deceiving everyone else. This individual will be isolated from colleagues, subjected to public humililiation and tormented until they leave or break down. The bully will then move on to the next victim. If they sense that information detrimental to their reputation is being spread, the bully will create conflict between those who are collating this negative information.

In Tim's opinion, female serial bullies are more dangerous than their male counterparts. "They're more devious, more manipulative and will often persuade male colleagues to do their dirty work for them. They're less likely to resort to violence, so less likely to get spotted or cross over into criminal behaviour."

According to Tim, most serial bullies have a Jekyll and Hyde nature: "They are vile, vicious and vindictive in private, but innocent and charming in front of witnesses. No-one can - or wants to - believe this individual has a vindictive nature. Only the current target of the bully's aggression sees both sides. Whilst the Jekyll side is described as 'charming' and convincing enough to deceive personnel, management and a tribunal, the Hyde side is frequently described as 'evil'. Hyde is the real person, Jekyll an act."

Whether or not there are more psychopaths around today is debatable. But Dr Paul Babiak, an industrial-organisational psychologist in New York, believes psychopaths thrive in the current business climate. Speaking at the annual meeting of the American Neuropsychiatric Association, he said the organisational chaos that typifies many of today's rapidly growing, downsizing and merging companies is the ideal environment for the psychopath to achieve success.

So, what should you do if you suspect you are working for, or alongside, a psychopath? There are no easy answers. Work with a psychopath and you'll either unwittingly collude or become a victim. Even Robert Hare admits that he has fallen prey to the charm of psychopaths on several occasions.

Unless you can prove a psychopath has committed fraud or another criminal offence, the law provides little protection. "Current sexual, race and disability discrimination legislation does nothing to deter workplace psychopaths," says Tim Field. "If anything, it just gives them the opportunity to find new ways of expressing their tendencies which aren't covered by law.

"Any perceived 'vulnerability' can be enough to make you a target - even if it's just your need for secure employment. In fact, the majority of people who come to me with accounts of being bullied are popular and good at their jobs. The highest performers are targeted so the bully can take credit for their achievements.

"If you think your manager is a psychopath the only thing I can advise is to get out before the damage is done. The more you recognise them for what they are the more you'll become a target."

webTitle: How to... work with unpleasant colleagues

fields.headline: How to... work with unpleasant colleagues
fields.standfirst: Nip problems in the bud before they blossom into real trouble
fields.trailText: Nip problems in the bud before they blossom into real trouble
fields.body:
Work is a brilliant way to meet and make friends. A recent Industrial Society survey suggests that 33% of us meet new friends at work. However, it's also a brilliant way to meet all kinds of people you'd happily pay to avoid.

And it can get pretty nasty. In one case, colleagues were so resentful about a man's sexist comments that they all accepted invitations to his wedding then didn't show up. In another office, two colleagues fell out when one refused to cover for the other, and ended up communicating only through their managers.

Jane Clarke, author of Office Politics (The Industrial Society), comments: "When colleagues dislike each other, it's incredibly wasteful of everybody's time, leads to lots of misunderstandings and has a terrible impact on the work atmosphere."

The most common reasons why colleagues dislike each other are a clash of personalities, different ways of working, competition, distrust, prejudice or a festering grievance.

Sarah-Louise Taylor, a content provider for a dot.com, knows all about personality clashes. "I'm very opinionated," she states. "So, if someone's really wishy-washy and indecisive, that bothers me. I've heard that if you don't like someone, you should get to know them. But that just gives me more ammunition."

Cathy Walton, an occupational psychologist, points out that "it's important to analyse why you dislike the other person. Otherwise, you can expend an awful lot of negative energy instead of approaching the problem constructively. Ask yourself whether you habitually dislike a particular kind of person. Which issues do you disagree on? Which do you agree on? Is it a lack of trust or have you hurt each other?"

Unwittingly, we're all attracted and repelled by certain types of people and behaviour. By analysing your own behaviour and preferences, you can start to repair a working relationship.

"Someone who's very logical and rational will often think that a fast-acting, results-orientated person is dishonest," says Jane Clarke. "But they just have a different working style. It's a question of understanding the difference, tolerating it and finally exploiting the value of that difference.

"Look at yourself in as objective a way as possible. Think about the upside of the way you work and the downside. So yes, you might be rational and reliable, but you also need to acknowledge that others might perceive you as slow and dogmatic."

Many recent graduates are understandably nervous about appearing confrontational towards someone they dislike. "You spend the first year being worried about falling out with people and what it could do to your future," says Thorkild Larsen, a graphic designer for an advertising agency. "I know I've deliberately played it safe."

It can be a tricky balance between bottling up your feelings and approaching the problem in such a full-on way that you alienate people. If you read up on assertiveness techniques (try Assertiveness at Work by Ken and Kate Back), you'll discover ways to express yourself that don't leave you or others feeling steam-rollered.

"The crucial element that helps you deal with other people is empathy," says Jane Clarke. So, consider whether the other person is acting this way because they feel challenged, competitive or jealous. How might your personality or behaviour be affecting the way they act at work?

She offers the following advice for solving workplace conflict:

Nip trouble in the bud. The longer a dispute continues, the harder it is to resolve.

Use an objective mediator. If you'd like help, why not ask another colleague or a trusted manager to negotiate?

Try not to blame the other person. It's rarely one person's fault; both of you should be prepared to make concessions.

Use role play to rehearse what you want to say and anticipate the other person's responses.

Assume the other person means well. What you view as deliberately obstructive behaviour is more likely to be defensiveness.

Assume you both want to resolve the problem. Animosity is draining for both sides; the other person probably wants to find a solution too.

Finally, here's a radical idea: pretend you like the person. Spend a couple of minutes thinking about their positive qualities. Just imagining you no longer dislike someone can have a powerful effect. And who knows? You may even end up as friends.

If you don't remember anything else...

Remember that you are always going to come across people you dislike, and it will make your working life a great deal easier if you learn to make the most of different personality types.

webTitle: Don't despair: find the right shoulder to cry on

fields.headline: Don't despair: find the right shoulder to cry on
fields.standfirst: Student counselling services that keep you on course
fields.trailText: Student counselling services that keep you on course
fields.body:
Best years of their life is how some people fondly remember their university days, and it isn't difficult to understand why. Living away from home among people your own age, a great sense of freedom, no parents or teachers telling you what to do...

This may be a rose-tinted view of university since campus life has changed dramatically in recent years. The advent of student loans, continual assessment rather than one set of exams at the end of year and the growing pressure to achieve higher standards means university life is much more demanding today.

Because of financial pressures, it's not unknown for students to work 20 hours a week while completing a full time degree. And the freedom to manage your own time comes packaged with a fair amount of responsibility. No one is hassling you to do your assignments or revision but that also means there's no-one to share the blame should you run into trouble.

Managing your finances for the first time can be a particularly rude awakening. Indeed, money problems are one of the most common reasons for students dropping out.

These pressures are contributing to the high levels of anxiety amongst students recorded by a recent survey for the Mental Health Foundation. The study found that 46% of male and 64% of female students were suffering from possible clinical anxiety and 12% of men and 15% of women were at risk of clinical depression.

These statistics do not surprise Michael Burton, head of counselling services at Sussex University. "While students today have more choices, there is also a greater pressure to do well. Fifteen or 20 years ago if students had problems, they could perhaps muddle through. But today that isn't really an option."

However if all this seems a bit gloomy, don't despair. Universities are well aware of the issues faced by students and have developed a range of services to help students who find themselves in difficulty or need help with emotional, financial or study-related problems.

Financial problems
The disappearance of student grants means few students can afford not to work while studying. Many universities recognise this and have employment services which liaise with local organisations who can offer part-time work. Hardship funds are also a source of grants for students in extreme difficulty.

Emotional

Relationship problems, bereavement or depression can all take their toll and jeopardise your studies. All universities have counselling services where students can talk to trained counsellors in confidence. Last year, more than 500 students used Cardiff University's student counselling service.

Studying

Although there is more to university life than studying, getting a good degree is the main point of the exercise. But with some courses containing modules run by different departments, it is quite conceivable that you may have four or five pieces of coursework to hand in with the same deadline.

If you feel that you are not coping or are have deadlines for coursework that you can't meet, there will be help at hand says Jim Parry, dean of students at Leeds University. "At Leeds we have a dean of undergraduate studies who has the power to extend a deadline. If a student finds that they have three or four deadlines at the same time which they can't meet, they need to talk to the dean to try and negotiate extending a deadline. However, they should do this in advance and not leave it to the last minute or wait until the deadline has passed."

Even though many courses are based on continuous assessment, most students still have end of year exams to contend with, but again, universities like the University of Sussex have mechanisms for helping students who find themselves stressed out by revision and exams. "We have a learning support unit which offers information on time management and enables undergraduates to use profiling software to determine what type of learner they are," says Michael Burton.

Using this information undergraduates can change their study patterns to methods which are more productive. Some universities also offer exam anxiety reduction programmes.

Ruth Clarke, communications officer at Leeds University, knows all about the conselling services available to students since she used them herself during her time as an undergraduate. "At Leeds there is a legal advice service for students and I contacted them when I was having problems with my utility bills," she explains.

Living away from home among people your own age, a great sense of freedom, no parents or teachers telling you what to do... This may be a rose-tinted view of university since campus life has changed dramatically in recent years. The advent of student loans, continual assessment rather than one set of exams at the end of year and the growing pressure to achieve higher standards means university life is much more demanding today. Because of financial pressures, it's not unknown for students to work 20 hours a week while completing a full time degree. And the freedom to manage your own time comes packaged with a fair amount of responsibility. No one is hassling you to do your assignments or revision but that also means there's no-one to share the blame should you run into trouble. Managing your finances for the first time can be a particularly rude awakening. Indeed, money problems are one of the most common reasons for students dropping out. These pressures are contributing to the high levels of anxiety amongst students recorded by a recent survey for the Mental Health Foundation. The study found that 46% of male and 64% of female students were suffering from possible clinical anxiety and 12% of men and 15% of women were at risk of clinical depression. Fifteen or 20 years ago if students had problems, they could perhaps muddle through. But today that isn't really an option." However if all this seems a bit gloomy, don't despair. webTitle: Welsh say Robinson is the weakest link

fields.headline: Star may face race charge
fields.trailText: Anne Robinson, host of the Weakest Link, is being investigated by police for her alleged racist remarks against the Welsh on the BBC2 comedy show Room 101, it was revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Anne Robinson, host of the Weakest Link, is being investigated by police for her alleged racist remarks against the Welsh on the BBC2 comedy show Room 101, it was revealed yesterday.

Robinson, 57, told host Paul Merton on Monday she would like to get rid of the Welsh by banishing them to Room 101.

North Wales police confirmed they have received a complaint and have asked the BBC for a tape of the programme. A file will be submitted to the crown prosecution service who will decide if the £2m-a-year TV star is to be charged.

A BBC spokesman said it would cooperate with police.

Welsh civil rights group Cefn said it had complained to police. It was also considering taking out an injunction to prevent the BBC from showing a repeat tomorrow.

The BBC received more than 300 complaints, the broadcasting standards commission more than 200, and the commission for racial equality more than 60.

Robinson said her comments were made in the context of a "fun show".

webTitle: Tories eclipsed as Sun denounces asylum stance

fields.headline: Tories eclipsed as Sun denounces asylum stance
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Tories in opposition
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Was there a hint early in the week that the Sun was up to something? The biggest seller of the daily Eurosceptic newspaper trio - the Mail and the Telegraph are the others - suddenly devoted not one page but eight to a special deal for its readers. "£9.50 holidays to Europe" read the huge headline on the front page of the supplement.
fields.body:
Was there a hint early in the week that the Sun was up to something? The biggest seller of the daily Eurosceptic newspaper trio - the Mail and the Telegraph are the others - suddenly devoted not one page but eight to a special deal for its readers. "£9.50 holidays to Europe" read the huge headline on the front page of the supplement.

Was this a less than subtle ploy to convince any wavering Sun readers how awful Europe really was, by sending them to see it for themselves? Surely it could not be that the Sun was abandoning its passionate anti-Euro stance?

By midweek the paper was further softening its line, with a leading article attacking "Hague's error", the Tory leader's speech warning of Britain becoming a "foreign country" if Labour won another term.

The asylum issue, said the Sun with new-found moderation, was "a complicated one". Mr Hague had allowed his speech writer to "flirt with extremism ... it left a nasty taste in the mouth. We have seen how another great country - America - can be built by 'foreigners'."

And the next day, after the budget, the Sun came out, earlier than it had before the last general election, endorsing Labour for the coming one. Even their influential political editor, Trevor Kavanagh, consistently anti-European and anti-euro, was adopting the paper's anti-Tory stance. "The Tory leader," he wrote, "is convinced wavering voters feel the same way as him about the euro and bogus asylum seekers."

But the speech allowed for another interpretation, and an opportunity for Mr Hague's critics, both Labour and Tory, to accuse him of veiled racism. Kavanagh concluded that the Tories were preparing "not to govern, but to spend much, much longer on the opposition benches."

It was thus a week of great significance for the government. With the Sun onside, the already gift-wrapped Labour victory now has bows on the parcel.

Not that we should assume that the Sun has abandoned its "save our pound" stance. Its bold line on asylum should not be taken to mean it is wavering on the euro, a subject it more or less avoided in its week of declaring for Labour.

It is, in a sense, taking a Gordon Brown position. The election comes first, and is one thing; the euro, and the possible referendum, is quite another, and lies ahead.

The Sun's implicit line - one that will cause the government no problems at all - is that the euro is a matter for the Labour government, the British people, and probably the Sun as well, while the Tories have made themselves irrelevant.

Mr Hague's speech can thus be seen as having a direct effect on the euro debate by fusing it, or indeed confusing it, with the asylum debate. The Sun, consistently sensitive to the gut instincts of its readership, felt bound to draw a line separating the issues.

The Daily Mail and the Telegraph carry on however. The Mail achieved another first this week by managing to get the message on to its Money Mail pages.

Fed up with paying tax? Blame it on the French, read the headline across a double-page pre-budget spread, charting the history of taxation in Britain.

It also gave prominence to comments from the outgoing Nato supreme commander, General Wesley Clark, that the proposed European rapid reaction force would "split the transatlantic alliance".

The Mail gave a page to Roger Scruton, the right-wing polemicist, to celebrate Britishness. "The asylum racket," he wrote, "has alerted the British people to the fact that their government will neither defend them from invasion, nor ask for proof of loyalty to the crown of England from those who settle here."

But the overwhelming press sentiment of the week was of unease about the language used by Mr Hague.

As the Times, which tends to steer a middle way on the euro, put it: "Mr Hague has knowingly raised the political stakes. In so doing he has voluntarily engaged in his own European integration. Much of the continental right is flirting with blood and soil in a strident opposition to outsiders ... Mr Hague said on Sunday that 'British people are not narrow nationalists. They are not xenophobes'. That is precisely why they will not stampede to politicians who seem to be playing the race card from the bottom of the deck."

By intentionally or otherwise identifying the Euro-sceptic position with views many potential Eurosceptics find unpalatable, Mr Hague has helped the euro supporters, as a reading of this week's press makes clear. It will turn out to have been a significant week for the euro.

 Peter Cole is professor of journalism at Sheffield University

webTitle: Stars arrive for start of Celebrity Big Brother

fields.headline: Full house
fields.standfirst:
Stars arrive for start of Celebrity Big Brother

Special report: Big Brother
fields.trailText: Stars arrive for start of Celebrity Big Brother.
fields.body:
Television stars took their final steps of freedom yesterday as they entered their new home for the start of Celebrity Big Brother.

Five of the six volunteers seemed relaxed as they arrived at the purpose-built house, but the frown on the face of Jack Dee, the comedian, suggested he was worried at the prospect of seven days of being locked inside.

The celebrities are taking part in a charity version of the show for Comic Relief which will end next Friday, with cameras monitoring almost every move.

Bystanders gathered to watch television presenter Vanessa Feltz arrive along with former boxing champion Chris Eubank, TV presenter Anthea Turner, Brookside's Claire Sweeney, and Boyzone star Keith Duffy.

Viewers can choose their least favourite star by phone or online at www.comicrelief.com/bigbrother The first eviction will be tonight.

Press Association

fields.headline: I did not lie, I did not deceive, I did not set out to mislead
fields.standfirst:
 But questions remain as muddle at top is exposed  Report reveals decisive role played by Straw

Special report: Mandelson
fields.trailText:
But questions remain as muddle at top is exposed
Report reveals decisive role played by Straw
fields.body:
Tony Blair and his fallen cabinet colleague, Peter Mandelson, last night formed what amounted to a pact against further fallout from the Hinduja passport controversy after the Hammond inquiry's extraordinary conclusion that no one had actually done anything wrong.

But Downing Street's chances of escaping renewed accusations of panic and disloyalty were reduced by the detailed revelations of "muddle" at the top, exposed by Sir Anthony Hammond and by William Hague's determination to exploit the "whole bizarre chain of circumstances" that unexpectedly forced the Northern Ireland secretary out on January 24.

In his 73-page report with 40 pages of annexes Sir Anthony cleared Mr Mandelson and the Foreign Office minister, Keith Vaz, of any attempt to exert corrupt pressure to obtain British passports for two of the three wealthy Hinduja brothers in return for a £1m gift to the Millennium Dome.

He also concluded that the now-famous phone call between Mr Mandelson and the then immigration minister, Mike O'Brien, "probably" did take place - on June 28 1998 - but also Mr Mandelson's insistence (after changing his story ) that it did not. That view was "honestly held," the retired QC stated.

Norman Baker, the Liberal Democrat MP for Lewes whose questions triggered the crisis, called the report less a whitewash than "a greywash" given Sir Anthony's propensity to think the best of all 50 witnesses, including officials who bent rules to obtain the Hindujas passports.

Among his revelations is that, in his efforts to get to the truth, Mr Blair rang Mr Mandelson three times the night before the forced resignation, spurred on by Jack Straw's protest that he had reminded Mr Mandelson twice of the O'Brien phone call.

Though keys facts remain disputed it was the home secretary's determination to impress his version on Mr Blair that emerges as a major factor in No 10's conclusion that Mr Blair could not trust his most trusted intimate, the man he had already been forced to sack once over his covert £374,000 mortgage.

But Mr Mandelson himself was quick to claim exoneration, though he admits he contributed to "a muddle rather than misrepresentation". He told reporters: "Sir Anthony's report establishes that I did not lie, that I did not deceive, that I did not set out to mislead." But he also admitted that - unlike his 1998 resignation - he cannot hope to return to government.

With a bitter election campaign looming that admission will be a relief to No 10, though Mr Mandelson's weakness for publicity may cause difficulties, especially as he will not be welcomed into the Millbank campaign HQ dominated by Gordon Brown's team.

In what amounted to an unstated pact to protect New Labour the prime minister also expressed his delight that Sir Anthony's report cleared Mr Mandelson of any impropriety - as he had always expected, he stressed. Bleakly Mr Blair added: "I hope he will be able to get on with rebuilding his life."

Mr Blair has no plans for his old friend. "It's very unfortunate and very tough. But there's no going back on it," said one senior official.

Speaking in his Hartlepool constituency, where he was shoring up his political base, Mr Mandelson said: "At long last I can put this whole thing behind me and start afresh." He too sounded reluctant to re-open the wounds exposed by Sir Anthony, disputing allegations made against him by ministers and officials, notably Mr Straw's team in the home office.

His lawyer, Jonathan Caplan QC, was more frank. Arguing that Mr Mandelson should not have been sacked before the inquiry he explained: "I think it's fair to say that the prime minister was presented with a version of events which, on closer examination, were not correct." He could win damages for constructive dismissal, Mr Caplan insisted.

Mr Blair, who gave the Scottish Labour party's conference a "fight and win" speech in Inverness yesterday believes the controversy will quickly subside. Mr Mandelson also hopes it will.

But Mr Hague, trailing badly in the polls, put the boot in. He complained: "This whole bizarre chain of circumstances would never have happened at all had the prime minister not re-appointed Peter Mandelson to the cabinet just 10 months after the first occasion when he had to resign in disgrace."

Ann Widdecombe, shadow home secretary, attacked incompetence and cronyism and asked why, if Sir Anthony had found no wrong-doing, Mr Mandelson had been forced out?

Jack Straw's role will be contested, though Sir Richard Wilson, the cabinet secretary, emerges with more credit than critics originally predicted.

Recriminations in the Blair court will also point the finger at the kangaroo court of unelected aides including press secretary, Alastair Campbell, Lord Irvine, the lord chancellor, and chief of staff, Jonathan Powell. On the hastily gathered evidence they believed the Northern Ireland secretary had misled them by not reporting the O'Brien phone call and claiming it was "private".

fields.headline: Pedigree chums
fields.standfirst: Ex-Spinal Tap guitarist Christopher Guest doesn't even need a script to make fake documentaries these days, just a talented cast of actors and canines
fields.trailText: Ex-Spinal Tap guitarist Christopher Guest doesn't even need a script to make fake documentaries these days, just a talented cast of actors and canines
fields.body:
In new faux documentary Best In Show, Harlan Pepper is a slow-witted Southerner with a bloodhound named Hubert. Pepper likes to fish and practice ventriloquism, but he also has another impressive trick: He's fairly decent at naming nuts: "Cashew nut, pistachio nut... red pistachio nut..." pause for reflection... "Macadamia nut." Impressed? You might be when you realize that the scene was improvised by the actor who played Pepper: writer, comedy performer, composer and director Christopher Guest. In fact, every moment in this delightful dog-show satire was ad-libbed on the spot. And how many nuts can you name without a script?

Nuts? [offering him some nuts on the table] You want to name some nuts?

Ah, yes, that was a scary moment. I was driving this camper. And in most movies, actors don't actually drive their cars - they're towed. In this case, we couldn't afford it, so I was actually driving that thing. In a place where I had no idea where I was going. And I decided to do this nut thing. And I realized after a few nuts I didn't know any more nuts.

I'd love to talk about the form of the mocudrama.

I don't like the term, personally. I would say that they are movies done in a documentary style. But I don't like that "mockumentary" or the "rockumentary" thing, because I think maybe it's just too glib or something. I don't have a clever name for them. No one has. If you do, you get a bonus.

But what fascinates you about this form?

I'm fascinated by real-time behaviour. I've tried to make all these analogies to what we're doing, mostly with music. Like jazz - where's the music coming from? They're making it up as they go. Same in these films. This is actor jamming.

The only curse, and I wouldn't even call it a curse, is that I end up with, in this case, close to 60 hours of material to edit down. And yes, lots of it is funny, but there's also a linear story, and if it doesn't service the story, it's out. And I'm very brutal about this at this point.

Some of the actors seem almost scripted, like the inept TV commentator played by Fred Willard.

Fred particularly gets to me, in a way that I really couldn't be in scenes with him in the film, because he'd just get me going. He's truly on another planet - it is astounding. He came in and he did his part all in one day, and there was no dog show going on in front of him - we had it at another time. So he's not even looking at anything. I was laughing so hard that I literally couldn't watch. I was doubled over, tears running down, and as this was happening I was thinking, "You're directing this movie, you might want to watch what's actually going on." And I couldn't. Really, truly couldn't.

webTitle: Salman Rushdie rediscovers the thrill of the cinema

fields.headline: Even by LA standards the cheering was astonishing
fields.standfirst: Salman Rushdie rediscovers the thrill of the cinema
fields.trailText: Although the threat of strike action is hanging over Hollywood, Salman Rushdie remains thrilled by the potential of films from around the world to bring people together, even in Tinsel Town
fields.body:
Without Hollywood, they say, Los Angeles would just be Phoenix with a coastline. This year, as deadlines approach for strikes by actors and writers, LA is facing the possibility of becoming, for a time, exactly such a characterless, movie-less sprawl. Rumours are flying: the studios actually want the strikes, the actors don't, though their representatives are talking tough. And the writers? Well, they're only writers, after all. Talks keep breaking down an inch away from agreement.

Television companies are preparing to flood the schedules with even more reality-TV programming (It's cheap! It's popular! It's not unionised!) to fill the holes created by The Strike.

There's plenty of bad feeling in the air, and a growing sense of inevitability. The shutdown is "going to happen", (which means it either will or it won't).

And in the midst of this uncertainty, the movie community awaits its annual you-love-me- you-really-love-me festival of big-business interests disguised as individual achievements. The lobbying season is over.

The city is no longer being bombarded by "for your consideration" videotapes. Famous rock stars are no longer playing impromptu gigs in old folks' homes in the hope of garnering a few votes for best song from elderly Academicians resident therein. The votes are in. The Oscars are coming.

The movies are LA's culture. At the weekend, big audiences go to the new pictures the way the opera-loving Milanese go to an opening at La Scala.

LA is a city of passionate moviegoers. I haven't seen such enthusiastically participatory audiences anywhere outside the Indian subcontinent. This can get irritating, for example when a big guy with his ass hanging out of his pants moans and groans loudly every time Penelope Cruz appears on screen in All the Pretty Horses ("My God, she's so beautiful! Oh, oh, he's going to fall for her! Unh-unh, here comes trouble!"), or when a five-year-old insistently asks her parents, during the interminable Cast Away, "Mommy, when is the volleyball going to talk?" (Footnote: Wilson the volleyball's performance is the best thing in this leaden movie. Why wasn't Wilson nominated for best supporting actor? It's a scandal.)

Angeleno enthusiasm can, however, also be thrilling. I can't remember ever seeing a western audience react to a new film the way a packed afternoon audience on La Brea responded to Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon. Even by LA's standards, the whooping and cheering was astonishing. The audience knew it was sharing a very special experience - the arrival of a great, classic film - and was simply transported by its brilliance. Anyone who thinks DVDs will someday replace moviegoing should have been there.

Those PC killjoys who have denigrated Crouching Tiger as a piece of latter-day orientalism, a western appropriation of eastern manner and material, would have seen an audience as diverse as America itself: Korean Americans, Chinese Americans,Hispanic Americans, African Americans easily outnumbered any WASP-y orientalists who might have been there enjoying it for the wrong reasons. Akira Kurosawa and Satyajit Ray reached smaller audiences, in their native Japan and India, than the commercial movies of their contemporaries. That doesn't make The Seven Samurai inauthentic, or the trashy products of mainstream Bombay cinema "more Indian" than Ray's masterworks. So, yes, Jackie Chan sells a lot of tickets, and, yes, Crouching Tiger draws on a long tradition of martial-arts movies. But Jackie Chan movies are cardboard fun, and Ang Lee's beautiful, intimate epic is - one would have thought self-evidently - a luminous work of art.

In the context of the Academy awards and the shadow of the strike, the success of Crouching Tiger is especially significant. It is being talked about as the breakthrough movie that has taught Americans to accept subtitled films into the giantcineplexes where the big money is made. And this is why the various players - but the studios above all - may be making a big mistake if they think they can ride out the strike without losing their stranglehold on the market. In the 1960s and early 70s, a flood of great non-American film-makers prised Hollywood's fingers off the cinema's throat for a few years. The result was the golden age of sound cinema, the time of the great films of Kurosawa and Ray, of the French new wave, of Fellini, Antonioni and Visconti, of Wajda, Jancso and Bergman.

Now, once again, world cinema is blossoming, in China, in Iran, in Britain. And it may just be that the mass audience is ready, at long last, to enjoy rather more diversity in its cultural diet. After all, there are plenty of dreadful American films we could all cheer fully do without - the appalling, ultra-rightwing new De Niro vehicle Fifteen Minutes, with its saintly cops and corrupt journalists, is just one such farrago.

The Oscars usually show us how Hollywood sees itself. Ridley Scott's technically brilliant but woodenly scripted Gladiator is the big-studio candidate for honours, just as the latest sentimental Miramax confection, Chocolat, leads the charge of the smaller guys. Comedy comes off badly, as usual - the Coen brothers have to be content with just a screenplay nomination for the wonderful O Brother, Where Art Thou?. There's no nomination for George Clooney's delicious, hairnet- wearing performance in this movie, or indeed for Renée Zellweger's moving, subtle work in the title role of Nurse Betty. But behind all this familiar manoeuvring, the tiger is crouching, the dragon hides.

And if by some chance the one genuinely great movie to have been nominated this year runs away with the big prizes, it may just be the wake-up call that Hollywood needs. When the world's finest film-makers are coming after your audience, it may not be such a smart idea to shut your industry down.

webTitle: Steve Rose on films about nuclear war

fields.headline: A blast from the past
fields.standfirst: Just getting over your nuclear paranoia? Too  bad, says Steve Rose - missile drama Thirteen  Days awakens the old nightmare
fields.trailText: Just getting over your nuclear paranoia? Too bad, says Steve Rose - missile drama Thirteen Days awakens the old nightmare
fields.body:
Despite its glorication of the dove-like Kennedy clan, its tedious running time and its galling self-importance, Cuban-missile-crisis thriller Thirteen Days brings back something that's been absent from our screens for way too long: nuclear paranoia. Yes, that good old-fashioned awareness that we have the capacity to annihilate our planet in an afternoon, which seemed to go out of fashion along with puffball skirts and the iron curtain. You can virtually buy a nuclear warhead on eBay these days, international aggression is a growth industry, despotic rulers a dime a dozen, but you'd never guess this from the movies. After decades of wariness, Hollywood has taken a new line on the bomb: it's a really good thing.

The bomb has always been a tricky subject for Hollywood: the ultimate nightmare but also the ultimate special effect. Back in the cold war era no producer would have dreamed of spicing up a picture with nuclear pyrotechnics, although the thought was obviously always on their minds. In those censorious times, they strained to come up with ways of tapping into that paranoia without mentioning it. Thus we had nuclear mutation causing giant ants, lizards, rabbits and teenagers to take over the world, or we had Body Snatchers, Martians and other aliens laying waste to our cities, or stray planets on a collision course with earth.

Even in the "permissive" 60s and 70s, it was a rare thing to see a nuclear explosion on screen. In these peace-loving times, the industry coyly stuck to close shaves and near misses, such as Sidney Lumet's Fail-Safe - in which the US accidentally orders a nuclear strike on Moscow - or The China Syndrome, whose trouble-at-the-power-station plot prediction came true within a matter of days thanks to the Three Mile Island incident. The only exception to the rule was, as usual, Stanley Kubrick. If there was a new paranoia going around, Kubrick usually got it worse than anyone else, and nuclear war was no exception. In the 60s he had his own desktop nuclear attack simulator, and had collected 70 or 80 books on the subject before deciding to make a film about it. His mordant satire Doctor Strangelove was originally intended to be a serious thriller, but one night, according to co-writer Terry Southern, "he woke up and realised that nuclear war was too outrageous, too fantastic to be treated in any conventional manner." So he ditched the happy ending, blew up the world and laughed all the way to the bunker.

Nuclear paranoia entered its golden age while I was growing up. As a schoolboy in the 80s, I was convinced that a mushroom cloud would blossom on the horizon at any moment, ideally during maths. We'd then spend three weeks living under a door propped against a wall while fire rained and dogs melted outside, and we'd spend the rest of our mutated lives scrabbling for radioactive turnips on the charred wastelands of Surrey. The whole of 80s society seemed to be telling us we weren't going to make it past adolescence: reassuring government advice leaflets called Protect And Survive ("you cannot remove radiation from water by boiling it"); friendly children's books such as Raymond Briggs' When The Wind Blows; and cheerful pop ditties Enola Gay and Two Tribes - particularly that floor-filling "dance mix" sampling nuclear attack instructions.

Worst of all were the films. A whole cycle of worst-case-scenario "entertainment" kicked in, creating some of the most depressing and disturbing movies ever made. First there was Testament, a modestly harrowing saga of nuclear war, with Thirteen Days star Kevin Costner in a minor role. The Day After upped the stakes, subjecting its cast to the unforgiving ravages of anarchy and radioactivity until they were reduced to decomposing zombies, cowering in the rubble of humanity. Just when things couldn't get any worse, the BBC unveiled its docu-drama Threads. Written by Barry "Kes" Hines, Threads was to The Day After what Coronation Street was to Dynasty. The Sheffield setting was depressing enough before the bombs hit, but after a few hours of communal terror, scientifically accurate carnage and women giving birth to mutant babies, the nation was on the verge of mass suicide. The film has effectively been banned by the BBC since 1984 - not that anybody wanted to watch it again.

When these bleak years finally came to an end with collapse of the Soviet Union, the world breathed a sigh of relief - especially movie producers. Now that the threat had evaporated (if not the weapons themselves), the atomic x could be administered to more upbeat action movies without triggering panic. Hollywood learned to stop worrying and love the bomb. Where a nuclear explosion was once the ultimate catastrophe, now it wasn't really that bad after all. In fact, better that it did go off - something for the special effects department to do, as long as there were no consequences. John Woo set one off in Broken Arrow (it's OK, it was underground), Independence Day fired a few at flying saucers (what's a little fallout when there's Martians to deal with?), but dick-waver number one in this category was James Cameron. Before Titanic, he could hardly make a picture without a nuclear element: The Abyss (stolen warhead alert), Aliens (set in a nuclear power station which explodes spectacularly at the climax), Terminator 2 (horrifically realistic visions of "Judgement Day"). Most incredible of all was the action "comedy" True Lies, which employs a mushroom cloud as a photogenic backdrop for Arnie and Jamie Lee Curtis to embrace in front of.

So the war has been won. Movies have finally annihilated the threat of nuclear annihilation. The final step in the "H-bombs are your friends" campaign has been made in recent years - trawling back to the 50s for old sci-fi plots to jazz up, two teams simultaneously rehashed the old When Worlds Collide theme: Armageddon and Deep Impact. No cold war allegory or political dimension this time, just the world versus a meteorite. And how to divert the meteorite and avoid global catastrophe? Nuclear weapons. Likewise John Travolta's sci-fi folly Battlefield Earth. How to eradicate the enslaving aliens? Nuke their home planet. Atomic weapons don't threaten the world, they save it. Nuclear proliferation may be alive in the real world but, according to Hollywood, there's nothing to worry about. Which is why, for all its faults, Thirteen Days is doing something vaguely controversial. Even if its nuclear threat is safely sealed in 1962, the film at least reminds us that there was one, once. Now all we need is someone to remake Threads.

webTitle: The films that stretched cast and crew to breaking point

fields.headline: Shooting pains
fields.standfirst: Treacherous weather, demonic stars, drug-crazed directors. Making movies can be hell. John Patterson zooms in on the films that have stretched cast and crew to breaking point
fields.trailText: Treacherous weather, demonic stars, drug-crazed directors. Making movies can be hell. John Patterson zooms in on the films that have stretched cast and crew to breaking point
fields.body:
When you're sitting in a nice warm movie house watching Enemy At The Gates, spare a thought for the victims. Not the hundreds of thousands of Russians who died defending Stalingrad, nor the even greater number of Germans who died besieging it in a bitter, vicious battle, fought in temperatures that often hit 50 degrees below zero, and which turned every staircase, hallway, rooftop and sewer into a grim, blood-soaked extension of the frontline. Forget about them and think instead of the poor bastards who had to recreate all this misery and squalor for Enemy At The Gates. One can only hope they were well remunerated for their troubles.

"It was minus 15 degrees most days," says Joseph Fiennes of the film's gruelling shoot at the Babelsberg studio near Berlin. "It gave you the tiniest idea of what they must have gone through at Stalingrad - the cold, the lice, and the sheer misery and abhorrent nature of war. The filth and cold seemed to enter our bodies, so that you could shower all day and still not feel clean." Jude Law, last seen living it up in the sun-soaked Adriatic for The Talented Mr Ripley, was more succinct: "It was harrowing."

And likely it was, since the production's length ended up exceeding that of the infamous battle itself. Lacking a river Volga of their own, the film-makers flooded an abandoned mine near the set by pumping 10,000 gallons of water into it daily, turning it into something midway between a frozen mudbath and the seventh circle of hell. Two thousand extras worked their way through 17,000 mud-spattered costumes. The stars all underwent SAS combat training (or the thespian-adapted version thereof) and one gets the feeling they were glad to get home.

Sometimes there's no shortage of ways in which ambitious film projects turn into complete nightmares for the poor creatures trapped on set. Don't believe it? Take the trip yourself.

 Enemy Of The Gates is out on Friday

Titanic

Titanic had it all. First, the pressure to justify a budget that started at $100m, then crept up to $200m. Then there was messianic writer-director James Cameron, who bossed his ship like a combination of Captains Bligh, Ahab and Queeg. The shoot in Mexico lasted more than a year, and accommodations were filled with British actors who sat around for months before they got to deliver their lines. Kate Winslet spent days in heavy period dresses and high heels that made it impossible to stay afloat, making for some hairy moments one day when the dress got caught and held her under water a tad too long. Cameraman Caleb Deschanel quit because "Jim Cameron is like the scene in Spinal Tap when the amps go up to eleven." Cameron calls his onset persona "Mij - the anti-Jim. I don't like myself when I'm Mij." Neither did anyone else.

Apocalypse Now

Production on Apocalypse Now took so long - nearly five years - that bit-part player Harrison Ford, who shot his scenes early on, was a Star Wars superstar by the time Apocalypse was finally released in 1979. The 238-day shoot in the Philippines is justly famous: Coppola, fresh off the second Godfather, was at the height of his fame and living at the outer limits of his ego. By the time he came back from the jungles, after hurricanes had destroyed all his sets, his leading man had had a heart-attack so serious he was given the last rites, the film's finale had been completely capsized by the megalomania of an unbelievably tubby Marlon Brando, the budget had gone from $12m to $31m, and Coppola had convinced both the press and his own wife that he had lost his mind. It's arguable that the arduous, booze- and drug-filled shoot bankrupted his talent as well. Certainly nothing he's made since that comes anywhere near it.

Fitzcarraldo

Werner Herzog is the kind of director you work with if you want life to be all hairy, all the time. He made his first film with stolen cameras, hypnotised his entire crew for Heart Of Glass, released a plague of rats into Delft for Nosferatu, landed a documentary crew on a volcano that was about to rip and once drew a gun on his star Klaus Kinski, screaming: "Act, motherfucker. Act!" Fitzcarraldo was the story of a conventionally Herzogian maniac (Kinski, no surprises) who pulls a steamship over a mountain. Herzog decided he would do the same - with a real boat. And all this after having shot half of the film, lost his entire cast (Mick Jagger, Jason Robards), waited two years and started all over again. "We were cursed," Herzog recalled. There were battles between local Indian tribes, Kinski was monumentally egotistical from start to finish ("he can scream in a way you cannot believe" - Herzog), brain-eating parasites lurked in the water, a plane crash paralysed one of the extras, and another three were injured pulling the tub over the hill. "After a while, even my best friends treated me like someone gone mad," said the director.

Easy Rider

Apocalypse Now demonstrated that the sign of a movie going out of control is having Dennis Hopper somewhere - anywhere - on the set. As one wag said of Easy Rider, "One of the stars was a drunken hippy, one of the writers was an acid-fried biker, and the director was a paranoid control-freak. The bad news was that all three of them were Dennis Hopper." There were no tornadoes or natural disasters on the Easy Rider set, unless you count Hopper, who was given to booze-fuelled tantrums, deep-seated anger, and paranoia that everyone else was trying to rip him off or "fuck with my vision!" If anything, Hopper's next movie title - The Last Movie - proved accurate and he was run out of Hollywood all over again.

The Wild Bunch

Sam Peckinpah never made life easy for himself. On almost every movie he made he got into a suicidal feud with whoever was in charge of production - even his own friends - and The Wild Bunch was no different. In the meantime, he was also engaged in life-or-death struggles with booze, pills, cocaine and a range of durable personal demons. Oh, and he was a terrifying perfectionist. And a genius. None of which explains the amazing loyalty he earned from his casts and crew. For the story of a group of ageing outlaws fading away gracelessly, Peckinpah wanted realistic blood and lots of it. His final gunfight was shot on a set wired up with 10,000 squibs filled with fake blood and chunks of meat - painful for the actors who endured multiple takes - and, as one of the crew claimed, "more ammunition was used in that final battle than in the entire Mexican Revolution - only we were using blanks."

Ryan's Daughter

The film that broke David Lean's over-inflated reputation and kept him out of movie-making for 15 years. Lean had just come off Doctor Zhivago, in which his perfectionism led him to recreate the snow-blanketed Russian Steppe in the Spanish desert. Undeterred by the harrowing length of that shoot, he welcomed the opportunity to be equally obsessive on this, his romance set against the Irish Civil War. Most of the agony was confined to a scene when a shipment of arms is offloaded during a storm. "It took months to do," said cameraman Freddie Francis. "We'd get a storm warning and go down to this bit of coast where those storms come across the Atlantic right on to this beach. The storm would last an hour or two and then die away. So you'd usually get two or three minutes of footage before the storm disappeared. The waves were crashing right on to us, the wind was blowing the sea straight into the camera. We had to chain the camera down to the rocks and everybody was in wet suits. Some people were still blown over. Then we'd work on some other part of the film until we got another storm warning. In fact, when winter arrived and we still needed to shoot summer scenes, the first unit went to South Africa, leaving another unit to complete the storm sequence." Despite all this, Ryan's Daughter was a flop.

Not the hundreds of thousands of Russians who died defending Stalingrad, nor the even greater number of Germans who died besieging it in a bitter, vicious battle, fought in temperatures that often hit 50 degrees below zero, and which turned every staircase, hallway, rooftop and sewer into a grim, blood-soaked extension of the frontline. Forget about them and think instead of the poor bastards who had to recreate all this misery and squalor for Enemy At The Gates. One can only hope they were well remunerated for their troubles. "It was minus 15 degrees most days," says Joseph Fiennes of the film's gruelling shoot at the Babelsberg studio near Berlin. "It gave you the tiniest idea of what they must have gone through at Stalingrad - the cold, the lice, and the sheer misery and abhorrent nature of war. webTitle: Audio: The Truth At Last: My Story by Christine Keeler with Douglas Thompson, read by Honor Blackman

fields.headline: The Truth At Last: My Story by Christine Keeler with Douglas Thompson, read by Honor Blackman
fields.standfirst:
(Macmillan, £8.99, 180 mn)
Buy it at a discount at BOL
Hear an extract
You will need RealPlayer to listen to this clip. You can download it here free
fields.trailText: She was never a prostitute, Keeler protests at the start of this heavily condensed version of her ghosted autobiography. But the call-girl label for her late-teen larks as bare-breasted nightclub dancer and sexy model suited a scapegoat-seeking establishment.
fields.body: Lots of swinging and at least one orgy. She was never a prostitute, though, Keeler protests at the start of this heavily condensed version of her ghosted autobiography. But the call-girl label for her late-teen larks as bare-breasted nightclub dancer and sexy model suited a scapegoat-seeking establishment. Stephen Ward was not a pimp but a Soviet spy who tried to kill her. Lord Denning's Profumo report avoided awkward questions about Ward's connections with MI5 chief Roger Hollis. There's little fresh here for conspiracy wonks, though Keeler's rather pathetic tale does reveal a knack for finding trouble and rotten men. It would have been interesting to hear Keeler read her story, but Honor Blackman is an inspired substitute: a star from the period, who has the perfect smoky brittleness and bitterness of tone.

fields.headline: Gumshoe blues
fields.trailText: Isobel Montgomery looks at When We Were Orphans by Kazuo Ishiguro, The Big House by Helena McEwen, The Clematis Tree by Ann Widdecombe, and The Galosh by Mikhail Zoshchenko
fields.body:
When We Were Orphans
Kazuo Ishiguro
(Faber, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

"You have to look forward in life," says Jennifer, the young ward of Christopher Banks, the narrator of Ishiguro's fifth novel. But Banks, a "celebrated London detective", is possibly Ishiguro's finest embodiment of the backward-looking types he has made his own. Straitjacketed by his Edwardian English upbringing, shell-shocked by the inexplicable disappearance of his parents, he remains forever "Puffin", a nine-year-old boy who plays at detectives with his Japanese friend Akira in the garden of a house in Shanghai. Ishiguro's portrait of this tragic eccentric is bitterly comic yet wholly sympathetic.

The Big House
Helena McEwen
(Bloomsbury, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

This intensely evoked picture of childhood will not appeal to everyone. The world that McEwen depicts - a many-servanted place of nursery teas, gardeners and cooks - is beyond the ken of most of us and a place that some would, instinctively, tear apart. The Big House may be over-privileged, but it is skilfully portrayed as an idyll whose loss Elizabeth and her siblings cannot bear. McEwen has a natural grasp of the sensations and emotions that return us instantly to childhood - the way the familiar becomes nightmarish at the flick of a light switch, the quiet anarchy of childrens' games. Less convincing, though, is the serpent that destroys this paradise.

The Clematis Tree
Ann Widdecombe
(Phoenix, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

She is not the first and will not be the last MP to think fiction-writing a nice sideline to politics, nor will Phoenix be the last publisher to write out a large cheque in the mistaken belief that name alone will repay the advance. Unfortunately - and it only takes someone with the most cursory interest in Widdecombe's biography to work this one out - she is without hinterland. So what we get is not a nice novel about home-counties Mark and Claire coping with a disabled son, among other domestic upsets, but a piece of moralising masquerading as fiction of the most mediocre sort. Just as one might expect from the shadow home secretary.

The Galosh
Mikhail Zoshchenko
(Angel, £9.95)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

For 20 years, Antony Wood's Angel Books has published the lesser-known foreign classics. Giving us the chance to enrich ourselves through Heine, Pessoa, Corneille and Russian writers such as Zoshchenko has been a largely thankless task: unrewarded, as Wood complains, by "anything like adequate review coverage". Reading Zoshchenko's deft satires, the surprise is that his books could have been published under Stalin. Perhaps you needed to be there for the gallows humour to bite, but his vignettes of the pot-holed road to utopia show that Russian literature can be short and sharp.

fields.headline: Children of the evolution
fields.trailText: John Dugdale on Trilobite! by Richard Fortey, and In the Red Corner by John Duncan
fields.body:
Trilobite!
Richard Fortey
(Flamingo, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

By echoing Longitude in his equally forbidding trisyllabic title, Fortey surely invites comparison with John Harrison only to send himself up: few scientists could be less like Dava Sobel's stoical provincial outcast than this clubby Natural History Museum palaeontologist, amazed that he's paid to continue a childhood hobby. Seeking to "invest the trilobite with all the glamour of the dinosaur", Fortey unconvincingly argues that these creatures from 550-250m years ago are transfixing because they were "witnesses to evolution". Utterly irresistible, though, are the dotty, boyish zest and stylistic charm - a compelling plea for the value of scientific obsessionalism.

In the Red Corner
John Duncan
(Yellow Jersey Press, £8)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Backed by promoter Frank Warren, Duncan takes leave from the Guardian to try to convince Cuba's Olympic heavyweight champion Felix Savon that a bout in Havana between him and Mike Tyson would be a lucrative propaganda coup for Fidel Castro. With a deal looking unlikely, he devotes his attention instead to what was originally just a cover story - exploring Cuban boxing before and after Castro's 1961 ban on pro sport, by befriending present-day stars and interviewing past greats. The almost accidental result is a study that does for the island's illustrious fistic tradition what Ry Cooder's Buena Vista Social Club project did for its music.

fields.headline: Ash Wednesday and Tolstoy
fields.trailText:
Remember, man, that thou art dust.

The earl kneels, the ash of the end is written on his

brow....
fields.body:
Ash Wednesday

Remember, man, that thou art dust.

The earl kneels, the ash of the end is written on his

brow.

A captain of ships kneels, to be put in mind of a death

in a far port, or at home, or on a rock of the sea.

And the boy that holds cinders for the priest,

His forehead is smeared,

Who wears a coat of fourteen Aprils.

The lady of Paplay

Thinks, most mornings, she will live forever,

kneeling now

Is touched with the grave-stoor.

The ploughman folds sun-grained hands,

He tilts his face

To the dust drained of warmth and light.

Fisherman, the spindrift

Will wash the ashes from you tomorrow.

Still you remember, between two waves,

St Peter and the fire of his denials.

And the old bishop, 'I know this,

One God-ground deed or thought

Endures, when the circle of diamond-and-gold on my

finger is dust.'

In the kirk of Magnus

Stood a multitude of islanders, death-farers that day,

Hungry, after, for panis angelicus.

And unto dust thou shalt return

Tolstoy

He sits at an oak desk,

The old lordly peasant,

There is fire about his heart.

In the crucible of his heart

The ore is troubled.

He swings a scythe,

In a field, with serfs,

Count Leo Tolstoy,

In the sweat of his brow

He scatters the gold of a

summer.

He is home from the wars,

Sword over hearthstone

set.

Now the greatest war

Is there for a transmutation

(this alchemy?)

Bald Hills, Natasha,

Borodino.

Truth is a clear star.

Men root among husks

and roots.

Clear and simple, the star.

Tolstoy lay on the rack of

age

The star on his forehead.

The heroes of history

Perish in their fires,

Caesar, Napoleon,

Ghengis Khan.

Time, a wind, mingles their

dust

With dust of falcons and

flowers.

Look, the crucible is cold,

Look, the manuscript

Sifts pages across the great oak table,

The sheaves are in the barn.

A book is heavy with jewels

and icons.
