webTitle: Pick of the week: Lenin: A Biography by Robert Service

fields.headline: Lenin: A Biography by Robert Service
fields.standfirst: Monster, weirdo or policy wonk?  Nicholas Lezard  considers Lenin
fields.trailText: Monster, weirdo or policy wonk? Nicholas Lezard considers Lenin: A Biography, by Robert Service
fields.body:
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The fat political biography has an antipodal relationship with the fat literary biography: even if it's dull, it's useful. (Literary and political autobiography are also, for the most part, opposites: the former is an exercise that should be compulsory, while the politician's memoirs are almost invariably mendacious and self-serving.) Robert Service, as a prose stylist, is no Trotsky; but with his bland and strangely exculpatory account of Lenin's life we can finally claim to get some way inside the mind of one of the previous century's more enigmatic dictators (as well as the chance to carry around a large red book with "Lenin" printed on it in big letters, which guarantees the reader a wide berth on public transport).

This is a boiled-down, rejigged version of Service's three-volume political life of Lenin, which was made possible by the opening up of Kremlin archives; until then, biographies of Vladimir Ilyich Ulyanov were thin on the ground and hedged by protocol, dogma or fear. It emerges that the individual perhaps more responsible for the 20th century's shape than any other was not so much a monster as a weirdo - and not even a particularly outlandish weirdo. The ultimate policy wonk (even his death mask appears to be frowning in concentration), he was strict with himself and others. He had frighteningly little time for loafers; or, indeed, for much that distracted him from the business of the Revolution. We may speculate that had his elder brother, a more affable and humane type altogether, not been executed for plotting against the Emperor Alexander III, history would have taken a very different turn.

But there is something tantalisingly human about Lenin. He maintained his bicycle as if it were "a surgical instrument"; he played boisterously with his nephew. He may have been given to grim jokes about what he was going to do to the Mensheviks, but at least he had a sense of humour; and, when he took office in the Kremlin, one of the first things he did was get a cat, which would sleep in his armchair in the certainty that no one would disturb it. One shudders to think of the penalty for doing so.

The book has its flaws and its difficulties. It is not in any sense a walk in the park; but then, it's not Service's fault that Lenin spent so much time wrangling over policy in various socialist congresses. The passages which deal with Lenin's intellectual development - his reliance on a mixture of Marx, Hegel and Aristotle - are among the most interesting. Service goes a little dotty over Inessa Armand, who was probably Lenin's lover for a while ("her nostrils were wonderfully flared"), but the book's chief fault - which, I assume, comes with the territory of being a specialist in Soviet history - is that Service assumes a level of background knowledge the reader may well not possess. The transformation from plotter to ruler seems somehow magical; the picture of how much influence Lenin had before 1917 is unclear, as is the level of oppression in pre-revolutionary Russia (how many political prisoners and exiles were there, for instance?). But it's still surprisingly absorbing, and a lot less creepy than reading about some other dictators I could mention.
fields.bodyText: Buy it at a discount at BOL The fat political biography has an antipodal relationship with the fat literary biography: even if it's dull, it's useful. (Literary and political autobiography are also, for the most part, opposites: the former is an exercise that should be compulsory, while the politician's memoirs are almost invariably mendacious and self-serving.) Robert Service, as a prose stylist, is no Trotsky; but with his bland and strangely exculpatory account of Lenin's life we can finally claim to get some way inside the mind of one of the previous century's more enigmatic dictators (as well as the chance to carry around a large red book with "Lenin" printed on it in big letters, which guarantees the reader a wide berth on public transport). This is a boiled-down, rejigged version of Service's three-volume political life of Lenin, which was made possible by the opening up of Kremlin archives; until then, biographies of Vladimir Ilyich Ulyanov were thin on the ground and hedged by protocol, dogma or fear. It emerges that the individual perhaps more responsible for the 20th century's shape than any other was not so much a monster as a weirdo - and not even a particularly outlandish weirdo. The ultimate policy wonk (even his death mask appears to be frowning in concentration), he was strict with himself and others. He had frighteningly little time for loafers; or, indeed, for much that distracted him from the business of the Revolution. We may speculate that had his elder brother, a more affable and humane type altogether, not been executed for plotting against the Emperor Alexander III, history would have taken a very different turn. But there is something tantalisingly human about Lenin. He maintained his bicycle as if it were "a surgical instrument"; he played boisterously with his nephew. He may have been given to grim jokes about what he was going to do to the Mensheviks, but at least he had a sense of humour; and, when he took office in the Kremlin, one of the first things he did was get a cat, which would sleep in his armchair in the certainty that no one would disturb it. One shudders to think of the penalty for doing so. The book has its flaws and its difficulties. It is not in any sense a walk in the park; but then, it's not Service's fault that Lenin spent so much time wrangling over policy in various socialist congresses. The passages which deal with Lenin's intellectual development - his reliance on a mixture of Marx, Hegel and Aristotle - are among the most interesting. Service goes a little dotty over Inessa Armand, who was probably Lenin's lover for a while ("her nostrils were wonderfully flared"), but the book's chief fault - which, I assume, comes with the territory of being a specialist in Soviet history - is that Service assumes a level of background knowledge the reader may well not possess. webTitle: A life in writing: Kate Atkinson

fields.headline: The fragility of goodness
fields.standfirst: Kate Atkinson tells Alex Clark how she overcame her nerves
fields.trailText: Kate Atkinson tells Alex Clark how she overcame her nerves
fields.body:
When Kate Atkinson won the Whitbread Book of the Year Award in 1995, she was rather less surprised than many of the other guests and assembled media - particularly those grandees and pundits who branded her novel anti-family, feminist nonsense. Behind the Scenes at the Museum had, she reckoned practically, about a one-in-three chance, the other likely contenders being Salman Rushdie and Roy Jenkins. And although she was delighted - and not at all averse to pocketing the £21,000 cheque - the thrill of winning the prize fell somewhat short of a previous and far less glamorous trophy.

In 1988, she won the Woman's Own Short Story Award with the first piece she'd ever sent off anywhere, and "the first thing that was truly not about myself". Learning that she'd won remains one of the best moments of her life; more importantly, it was the point at which she realised she had it in her to become A Writer. Until then, she was much more of a reader. As a child, she devoured her grandmother's encyclopedias - the source of an extensive general knowledge that amazes her daughters - and claims to have read Alice in Wonderland once a week for five years. Since she had no brothers or sisters, books provided both company and vital clues to the nature of the outside world, which seemed a terrifying contrast to the quiet, orderly life of the only child. Temperamentally gloomy and at times beset by indefinable fears, she lost herself in work. "I had phenomenal inner drive," she remarks. "I was very self-reliant in that way, and very puritanical."

As the 1960s unfolded, Atkinson submitted readily to the work ethos of the single-sex Queen Anne Grammar School in York, where her parents ran a medical- and surgical-supplies shop. By the time she left home for Dundee University and an English degree, she was ready to break away, but clueless as to what she might find. "I knew nothing about life," she says, "I didn't even know where Dundee was."

But Dundee, which features heavily in Atkinson's third novel, Emotionally Weird , was to become a significant city. At 21, she married a fellow student and had a child there, and around the same time embarked on a PhD. "I thought doing a doctorate and having a baby would be a good combination. Actually, having a baby isn't a good combination with anything."

But worse than the strain of juggling academia with motherhood was the moment her PhD - on the American short story - was refused at its viva. Atkinson believes interdepartmental politics played their part, and the injustice still rankles. At the time, she retreated into herself; now, she regards it as the making of her. "Your life is made by the failures in it, not the successes," she says. "And I wouldn't have become a writer without failing my doctorate."

It was only after this cataclysm - and the break-up of her marriage - that she began to think about writing fiction, nagged at by a need "to put something of myself down". In her 30s, scraping a living for herself and her two daughters through menial jobs (most famously as a chambermaid) and bits of teaching, she started to jot down odds and ends. It wasn't really writing, she says, but a combination of biography and therapy, a way of "making internal chaos into objective external order".

Atkinson is a striking mixture of alarming self-assurance and nervous fragility. Take, for example, two things that happened shortly after she garnered the Woman's Own award. First, she got an accountant, because she'd decided that "women have to be grown-up about money". Then, when she hit 40, she had a peculiar crisis that resulted in a year-long bout of agoraphobia. Psychiatrists proving useless, she got herself through it by reading vast numbers of books on phobias.

That trauma beaten, Atkinson set to in earnest, and her much-vaunted "overnight success" followed swiftly. She was spotted by an agent, landed herself a book deal and wrote Behind the Scenes in three months. "I never had a qualm about it," she remembers. "I had great confidence in that book." But if the reading public - half a million of them, in this country alone - loved her multi-generational family saga, the media scrum had other ideas.

"With hindsight, I wouldn't have done so many interviews," she says. "I wouldn't have indulged them - most of them were bitches." Considering that she was described in one banner headline as the writer who "rejects marriage and the family, and believes we should live in tribes ruled by women", this response might be viewed as mild.

After Behind the Scenes came Human Croquet , the novel she regards as her darkest and also her best. For Emotionally Weird , subtitled "A Comic Novel", she drew on her childhood Alice obsession to engineer a bravura shaggy-dog story, complete with a migraine-inducing array of typefaces, a riotous campus and a stray canine. It may sound like a lark, but writing it was tough. Atkinson was "so written out" that she threw away her first year's work, and insists that she didn't know what she was doing until the end. Then, "in a vague, mystical way", it all came together.

Atkinson is now working on the screenplay for the TV version of Behind the Scenes . How does the job of adaptation compare with novel-writing? "Well," she admits, "knowing what's going to happen is very boring."

webTitle: Review: Did Things Get Better? by Polly Toynbee and David Walker

fields.headline: Could try harder
fields.standfirst:
Ben Pimlott weighs up New Labour's achievements in Did Things Get Better? by Polly Toynbee and David Walker
Read an extract
fields.trailText: Ben Pimlott weighs up New Labour's achievements in Did Things Get Better? by Polly Toynbee and David Walke
fields.body:
Did Things Get Better? An Audit of Labour's Successes and Failures
Polly Toynbee and David Walker
274pp, Penguin, £6.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Does Tony Blair deserve to win the next election? The question is a difficult - if slightly academic - one. Few people doubt that he is going to win, probably with a more than adequate majority, or that the coming contest will set new records for political tedium. Nobody - as far as I know - seriously thinks that William Hague would do a better job. The only issue is whether the current prime minister has earned his victory, or whether it is just another plum dropping into his astonishingly charmed lap.

Apotheosis, or a senescent last throw before Labour's catastrophic implosion? The authors of this excellent, highly readable Baedeker examine the government's policy choices on every conceivable topic from GM crops to biological weapons, and weigh them on the scales. Their approach is to combine objectivity - setting New Labour's own claims as their yardstick - and their own social-democratic passion. Applying these tests, they give a verdict that falls in the middle. New Labour gets a beta-query-plus for effort and earnestness. But it could try harder. Is this harsh, or over-generous? In political style, New Labour has sought to present a brazen image, rejecting past puritanism. In terms of content, however, the new era has so far failed to dazzle.

Over the last century, the party's fortunes have been mixed: six of Labour's nine election wins produced either minority governments or wafer-thin margins. Only three resulted in Labour governments confident of a full term. As the authors of this book show, New Labour in 1997 doesn't begin to compare for sheer audacity with the 1945 Attlee administration, which established Beveridge's welfare state, stuffed the doctors' mouths with gold to found the NHS, gave independence to India and founded Nato and the IMF in its spare time. Nor does it rival the much-criticised Harold Wilson government of the 1960s, which failed to tackle the economy but still found resources to revolutionise education and the courage to preside over a series of key legal changes (on hanging, divorce, censorship, abortion, homosexuality) that created a more civilised society.

By contrast, the Blair administration has been prosaic in the context of plenty. Toynbee and Walker label one of their chapters "It's The Economy, Clever", reversing a Clinton slogan to remind us that it has been the best of times. Blair cannot use the economy as an excuse for actions not taken. Attlee and Wilson were beleaguered by financial problems. In the 1940s, Chancellor Hugh Dalton likened a run on the pound to "watching a child bleed to death and being unable to stop it"; in the 1960s, Chancellor Callaghan wept as he saw Britain's reserves draining away. Gordon Brown has inherited a sounder base than any predecessor since before the first world war. When Attlee's Britain fell short of a socialist utopia or Wilson abandoned his National Plan, it was possible to blame foreign speculators. Blair has no such alibi. If ever there was a government with the wherewithal to transform British society, it has surely been the present one.

So why, apart from the serendipitous gift of Mr Hague as an opponent, is Labour destined to win? As Toynbee and Walker point out, politics is full of little ironies. The government of spin has been slow to provide deeds capable of capturing the public imagination. It has also been curiously gauche about projecting them. As a result, people remember the banana skins, not what ministers did. Nevertheless - and this is a convincing theme of the book - New Labour has been neither inactive nor conservative.

"Having purged itself of socialism," the authors point out, "Labour was not left with any over-arching economic philosophy." A mixture of pragmatism and a Keith Josephite business ethic ruled. But it was pragmatism with a social purpose. Indeed, there has been a neat paradox at the heart of New Labour practice: a left-wing government quietly playing down its achievements because of its fear of alienating Middle England. Thus, rather than simply wallowing in the warm bath of Tory-induced affluence, Blairism has provided a nervously busy ministry - a government of low-key, behind-the-scenes activity, carried out by inexperienced but serious-minded politicians who, for two years, were required to square the circle of helping the badly off while not adding any new calls on resources.

Only after two years of Treasury-disciplined rigour, according to the authors, was the chancellor able to realise "Tony Crosland's dream of floating the public services on an expanding economy". The approach has been loaves and fishes: cunning widgets rather than quick fixes. Thus, the authors give Brown modestly good marks for "keeping spending tighter than the Tories would have done". They give him much more credit for innumerable (and often unmemorable) schemes that, while seldom big news in themselves (and sometimes of Heath Robinson-like complexity), have cumulatively improved the lot of the disadvantaged.

How can one measure progress? The "audit" method does not make it easy to do so. The authors list initiatives with newspeak labels - New Deal, City Academies, Fresh Start - the individual merit of which is often hard to judge. They print inconclusive graphs: crime and waiting lists going up or down, with barely a blip in 1997. They point to benchmark statistics. Thus, the government can boast that the poorest 10% are 8.8% better off than in 1997, while the richest 10% are 0.5% worse off. Redistribution lives - except, of course, that most of this change would probably have happened anyway, because of declining unemployment.

Has Labour delivered on its promises? The answer to this always boring question (people seldom notice promises, let alone vote because of them) is yes - but only because the actual pledges were so vague and minimal that with the passage of time they would have been achieved anyway. More interesting is the extent to which New Labour has exceeded expectations, or moved in intriguing new directions. Did Things Get Better? shows that from nursery classes to geriatric wards, New Labour has not been afraid to innovate. How much will last? Here we enter an area of judgment that even the most skilful audit cannot reach.

The authors tot up the pluses and minuses. Taxes, they believe, were kept disappointingly low. Scotland got home rule, bombs were dropped on Serbia, no decision was made about PR or the euro. But what of changes that have not yet had time to bear fruit? The Toynbee/Walker approach is necessarily short-termist. Voters have to make up their minds after four years, but history has a longer perspective. From little acorns, great oaks grow; many of the best achievements of Attlee and Wilson were ignored while they were still in office.

Thus the jury is still out on Tony Blair and his fellow adventurers - and, indeed, won't be called back in until 2005 or 2006. For the moment, we can say that this government has thrown up a handful of unglamorous personalities - Tony Blair, Gordon Brown, perhaps above all David Blunkett, "symbol of working-class aspiration, prophet of municipal socialism" - who are not loved, but who have a measure of public trust and have made a permanent mark on the national consciousness.

Now let us hope that trust can be translated into determination. The authors conclude: "Things did get better." More than 40 years ago, it was a Tory government that got handsomely re-elected using the slogan "You've never had it so good"; the phrase turned rapidly sour when things got worse. The 1997 election was about a winning formula; this time, no-longer-new Labour can afford to offer some radicalism. Meanwhile, this has been a lucky government that, generally speaking, has deserved its luck. Britain's voters will, rightly, be giving it the benefit of the doubt.

Ben Pimlott is author of biographies of Hugh Dalton and Harold Wilson, and Warden of Goldsmiths College.

webTitle: Review: Indira: The Life of Indira Nehru Gandhi by Katherine Frank

fields.headline: Chronicle of a death foretold
fields.standfirst: Geoffrey Moorhouse hails Indira: The Life of Indira Nehru Gandhi by Katherine Frank, the story of a woman who was cut down before her work was done
fields.trailText: Geoffrey Moorhouse hails Indira: The Life of Indira Nehru Gandhi by Katherine Frank, the story of a woman who was cut down before her work was done
fields.body:
Indira: The Life of Indira Nehru Gandhi
Katherine Frank
545pp, HarperCollins £19.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

I shall never forget boarding an Air India plane at Heathrow 17 years ago to find the entire cabin crew in tears. They had just heard that Indira Gandhi was dead, and were inconsolable throughout the flight. When we landed at New Delhi, the plane was immediately surrounded by police. In the distance columns of smoke were climbing into the sky over the old city, where Hindu mobs were massacring Sikhs in reprisal for Indira's assassination. Next day I sat with friends, watching the lying-in-state on television, with fans blowing cold air from great blocks of ice onto the body so that it wouldn't decompose. Later there was Rajiv Gandhi, shimmering in the heat haze as he walked seven times around his mother's pyre. I can remember every detail of that week with absolute clarity: like so much else about India, it was utterly indelible.

As Katherine Frank suggests in this excellent biography, the carnage that broke out after the assassination - more than 2,000 Sikhs were slaughtered in Delhi alone - was a depressing indication that Indira Gandhi's great mission in life, which she had inherited from her father, had failed. For the Nehrus were dedicated to the notion of a secular state in which no creed or caste would dominate anyone else; where the religious card that had beggared and bloodied the country's history since the year dot could no longer be played.

After many centuries of alien rule, first by the Mughals and then by the British, this was to be a democracy of unique and great distinction. Jawaharlal Nehru spent himself endlessly in this cause, and his daughter gave her life for it. The story of Indira Gandhi is a chronicle of what, between them, they did achieve; and although it is now spat upon by their infinitely less worthy successors, that was no small thing.

The book is dominated by three tremendous figures: Mahatma Gandhi, part saint, part humbug, and unrelated to Indira; Jawaharlal, the highly westernised (Harrow and Cambridge) Kashmiri agnostic who steered his country into and through independence and put India on the world map in its own right; and Indira, the most tragic figure of the three because her life was cut off some distance short of her goal. The Mahatma had achieved the seemingly impossible by shaming the British (which took some doing) into leaving his country alone, and Jawaharlal had given India a sense of moral purpose and a truly democratic structure, which shone like a beacon across the corruption and oppression that passed for government throughout the rest of the old colonial world.

Indira wanted to carry this on, and to do more: she wanted to put an end to her people's everlasting poverty, the more obscene because it was too often endured in the shadow of high walls protecting unimaginable wealth and privilege. She had a strangely sympathetic relationship with Margaret Thatcher, and it's easy to see why: both were strong-minded women with a clear sense of purpose who had made it to the top in a profession dominated by men, and both cherished deeply unattractive sons. There, however, the resemblance ended. Can anyone imagine the Grantham Grasper doing voluntary relief work in pestilential refugee camps, as Indira Gandhi did during the horrors of Partition?

Two lesser characters helped to shape Indira's destiny. One was her Parsee husband Feroze Gandhi; they became estranged, yet she still felt a responsibility for him. webTitle: Review: The Strength of Poetry by James Fenton

fields.headline: Strong words
fields.standfirst: Giles Foden enjoys James Fenton's lectures on poets' works and lives in The Strength of Poetry
fields.trailText: Giles Foden enjoys James Fenton's lectures on poets' works and lives in The Strength of Poetry
fields.body:
The Strength of Poetry
James Fenton
266pp, Oxford, £15.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

At first I thought the Oxford Professor of Poetry (1994-1999) had miscalculated in choosing this title for the printed version of the lectures he gave in that role. After all, Christopher Ricks published a collection of essays called The Force of Poetry in 1984. But it is the right title, one discovers, for James Fenton's enjoyable interrogation of what constitutes strength, both in life and poetic discourse.

There is some background to this. In Articulate Energy, Donald Davie wrote about "the strong line" in a technical sense - simple syntax, finite verbs. It was an approach favoured by Dryden, a poet Fenton also discusses. Not respecting a poetry of gaseous elaboration or rhetorical posturing, Dryden preferred plainer virtues - toughness of thought and language. This idea of "sinew" (one of F R Leavis's favourite marks of approval) has been kept alive by later poets and critics. Ted Hughes - or "T. Hews", as Oliver Reynolds once had it in a jokey poem - was a writer critics could hardly describe except as "muscular".

In his book, Ricks followed Dr Johnson's precept in looking for verse that "calls new power into being, which embodies sentiment, and animates matter" - rather as if the frog's leg of language were enlivened by the electricity of the poet's genius. Fenton is more concerned to show how such genius is forged by a lack of strength in the poet's life. A sense of lack, enfeeblement or humiliation (Auden thought life hurt us into poetry) is the unifying theme of the book. In this sense, The Strength of Poetry shares some characteristics with Edmund Wilson's theories about the relationship between writers' emotional lives and their work, as outlined in The Wound and the Bow.

Fenton shows us how Larkin, for instance, drew perverse, enraged strength from being turned down for the army (bad eyesight) and for further war work (applying unsuccesfully to Bletchley Park), or from having a fascist father, who kept "a statue of Hitler on the mantelpiece, which at the touch of a button leapt into a Nazi salute".

The relation of strength to betrayal is also considered: Sassoon's betrayal of his class, Pound's flirtation with fascism, Eliot's espousal of England over America, Auden's fleeing to America in the war years, Heaney's betrayal - as it is perceived in some quarters - of "nationalism as represented by the IRA". It is, says Fenton, "astonishing how often in the poetry of this century this theme of betrayal crops up".

Subject of two of the lectures, Auden is the key in all this. Once again he is the father figure (as for John Fuller, to whom the book is dedicated) who can unlock the door to Fenton's roomy brain. "Auden had the greatest gifts of any of our poets in the twentieth century, the greatest lap full of seed. And it was given him to know this, and to doubt it, to know and to doubt it." The relation of strength to self-doubt, and how they can betray each other, sometimes usefully (there was a kind of courage in Auden's flight), underpins the whole book. We are directed to the poem "1929", where Auden sketches the heroic qualities he lacked in the figure of a hustler with whom he had an affair: "Absence of fear in Gerhart Meyer / From the sea, the truly strong man".

A Hamburg sailor, Gerhart was - Fenton tells us - always going off with whores and demanding presents. Recording in his journal how he himself postured, Charles Atlas-style, before the mirror, Auden compared his body with the sailor's, wondering whether he was "up to his physical level". If working the body was to be abandoned, he'd have to pump iron in verse, make himself strong in that place as he could in no other.

It is in respect of this - of strength in poetic discourse - that Fenton introduces us to "Blake Auden" and "James Auden": "Blake sat at Auden's left when he wrote, urging concision, definite views, plain language . . . not the Blake of the long line, the interminable prophetic books, but the fiery Blake of The Marriage of Heaven and Hell, the Blake of the notebooks. "Henry James sat on Auden's right, suggesting fascinating syntaxes and ways of prolonging a sentence, giving a nuance to a nuance."

But nuanced stuff, "poetry" (say it sneeringly), can be the pathetic resort as well as the making of a weakling - as in time of war, for example. In a fine lecture on Wilfred Owen's juvenilia, Fenton begins by mocking a terrible line. "Excuse me: ' 'nointing with unction fine' - what's this 'nointing business? What is this 'nointing with unction fine?". He goes on to show how "a complicated set of forces", among them sexual anguish, war and suffering, combined to release Owen from the spirit of his juvenilia - to distract him from "poetry": "to make him say that he (of all people) was no longer concerned with it. And it was only when he was no longer concerned with it that he could be surprised, that he could be exalted by his gift."

In the Blake Auden and James Auden lecture, Fenton also deals with the question of an artist's relation to uncompromising political or military strength, the expediency at first admiringly described, later altered, and finally repressed with the rest of that notorious poem "Spain": "Today the deliberate increase in the chances of death; / The conscious acceptance of guilt in the necessary murder-".

That dutiful but sinister side of the Truly Strong Man was variously associated in Auden's work with spying, airmen, mountaineering, and journalism. As he writes with Isherwood in Journey to A War, "a journalist has his duty like a soldier. It is sometimes necessary for him to go into danger".

As a foreign correspondent, Fenton himself has gone "into danger" (at the fall of Saigon, notably). He has also long been out of it, tending his garden, being a Professor of Poetry, and not writing very much verse. But what he has written is wonderful. Appropriately, Out of Danger was the title of his most recent book of poems. For my money it is one of the best collections of the past 20 years, dramatising the possibilities inherent in being distracted from poetry, and in other failures: "When I was sure that I was strong. / I thought it was a medium / In which to grow, but I was wrong" ("The Possibility").

But benefits came all the same, those of a man who in accepting his frivolity (some of the poems are like supercharged nursery rhymes) sounded greater depths, or those of a gardener who is surprised by the joy of a lap full of seed.

webTitle: Review: John Ashbery and American Poetry by David Herd

fields.headline: All is poetry
fields.standfirst: Robert Potts hails John Ashbery and American Poetry by David Herd, an attempt to demystify the 'obscure' poet
fields.trailText: Robert Potts hails John Ashbery and American Poetry by David Herd, an attempt to demystify the 'obscure' poet
fields.body:
John Ashbery and American Poetry
David Herd
208pp, Manchester University Press, £45
Buy it at a discount at BOL

'"I live with this paradox; on the one hand, I am an important poet, read by younger writers, and on the other hand, nobody understands me. I am often asked to account for this state of affairs, but I can't." This self-assessment by the American poet John Ashbery is fair and succinct. Much admired, winner of many prizes, stylistically over-influential, Ashbery has nonetheless provoked hostility and scepticism from uncomprehending readers. His poems slide through a variety of voices and styles with quickfire cuts between sensations, comments and events; sometimes the disruption of expectation is so frequent that it becomes easy for a sceptical or lazy reader to feel that the poems are nothing more than a random agglomeration of words, images, quotations and phrases.

On a more sympathetic reading, what is sometimes perceived as a contempt for readers is arguably a generosity towards them. Ashbery, who frequently seems baffled, hurt or pissed off at the accusation that he does not communicate, once said: "If my poetry is oblique, it's because I want to slant it at as wide an audience as possible, odd as it may come out in practice. Therefore, if I'm writing a love poem it won't talk about specifics, but just about the general feeling which anybody might conceivably be able to share."

David Herd's fine study, John Ashbery and American Poetry, argues for this way of reading Ashbery while, valuably, sharing some of the entranced bafflement felt by Ashbery readers. In discussing "Europe", the most challenging poem in The Tennis Court Oath , Ashbery's most "difficult" book, Herd quotes the lines "We are not loved more than now/ The newspaper is ruining your eyes", drolly noting that: "Addressing a cultural condition which it thought damag ing to the reader's wellbeing, [the poem] was serious when it suggested . . . that they were never 'loved more than now'. The trouble was it had a funny way of showing it."

But an Ashbery poem, read at the right moment, in the right frame of mind (I like reading him on trains, and when I'm not too tired), can be an extraordinary thing: thought-provoking, mood-capturing, witty, political, camp, humane, inspirational. It is harder to say how the poetry works, and Herd's book starts from this very mixture of scepticism and sympathy, before placing Ashbery in various traditions and teasing out allusions, influences and developments. He discusses his early collaborations in the 1950s with the so-called New York School (a category that includes Frank O'Hara, Kenneth Koch and James Shuyler), and explains these writers' desire to escape the overbearing influence of Robert Lowell, and their enthusiastic participation in the avant-garde of their time.

In doing so, he articulates with admirable clarity the dilemmas of any avant-garde art: the need to move on and away from tradition, and therefore to be difficult and unpopular, while still requiring a community of readers and critics to preserve and ultimately popularise the work as it comes into its own. The avant-garde artist strives for fresh ways of seeing in order to counter the homogenised, consumerist world offered by the media, while remaining wary of these fresh ways of seeing becoming merely another homogenised orthodoxy. As Ashbery himself wrote: "Is there nothing then . . . between an avant-garde that has become a tradition and a tradition which is no longer one?"

Herd concentrates on Ashbery's idea that each poem arises out of, and includes, the occasion of its making. No detail is too grand or lowly, no style of speech too lofty or base, to be included. Everything is poeticised: the shared details of our social, economic and cultural lives freely mix, and through the poems we are persuaded to view them with fresh eyes. In this way, Ashbery's attention to every detail of existence is both generous and humble. It is political in the widest sense of the word - democratic, anti-consumerist, empowering. In Ashbery's poetry one frequently gets the sense of an alert citizen sharing his passion, stoicism, amusement or anger without ever hectoring or lecturing. It is a poetry of such radical scepticism that, while it can provoke as many readings as it has readers, none of them can remain settled or sustained across the oeuvre. More than anything, it is a poetry that gives readers room to think and feel for themselves.

At the same time, Herd's erudition is enormously helpful in providing a framework for those responses. Pasternak has always been a declared influence; Herd carefully explains how and where this affects Ashbery's use of (often bizarre) metaphor and simile. Likewise, he takes us into "Three Poems" by teasing out its argument with Pascal and Auden. In tracing allusions and influences, as well as the political, personal and poetic contexts in which Ashbery produced his various volumes, Herd provides points of access for the reader. He does so with an enthusiasm and humour that courteously match his subject's own.

Herd also makes much of the paradox of Ashbery's sudden success, when he wrote Self Portrait in a Convex Mirror and found himself transformed overnight from outsider into national institution. Ashbery himself has noted the danger that an artist can "pass from unacceptability to acceptance without an intervening period of appreciation", and his later career is thus plausibly seen by Herd as a constant negotiation towards further fresh starts. Ashbery's work, for himself and for everyone, is precisely about an attentiveness to one's own situation and potentiality, not a substitution of someone else's. Charmingly, in riposte to accusations of obscurity, Ashbery has stated that "a poem that communicates something that's already known to a reader is not really communicating anything to him, and in fact shows a lack of respect". Or, more strongly: "It's a veiled insult to the reader."

In this spirit, what Herd offers is not a reading of Ashbery but a way of reading Ashbery, and a critical language more appropriate to Ashbery's peculiarities than pre-packaged approaches, which merely make Ashbery reflect their own concerns. This is one of the most entertaining, lucid, witty, generous and hospitable works of criticism I have had the pleasure of reading. Like all good critics, Herd sends us back to the poems; prepared for the adventurous journey ahead, but not saddled with someone else's luggage.

Herd concentrates on Ashbery's idea that each poem arises out of, and includes, the occasion of its making. No detail is too grand or lowly, no style of speech too lofty or base, to be included. Everything is poeticised: the shared details of our social, economic and cultural lives freely mix, and through the poems we are persuaded to view them with fresh eyes. In this way, Ashbery's attention to every detail of existence is both generous and humble. It is political in the widest sense of the word - democratic, anti-consumerist, empowering. In Ashbery's poetry one frequently gets the sense of an alert citizen sharing his passion, stoicism, amusement or anger without ever hectoring or lecturing. It is a poetry of such radical scepticism that, while it can provoke as many readings as it has readers, none of them can remain settled or sustained across the oeuvre. More than anything, it is a poetry that gives readers room to think and feel for themselves. At the same time, Herd's erudition is enormously helpful in providing a framework for those responses. Pasternak has always been a declared influence; Herd carefully explains how and where this affects Ashbery's use of (often bizarre) metaphor and simile. Likewise, he takes us into "Three Poems" by teasing out its argument with Pascal and Auden. In tracing allusions and influences, as well as the political, personal and poetic contexts in which Ashbery produced his various volumes, Herd provides points of access for the reader. He does so with an enthusiasm and humour that courteously match his subject's own. Herd also makes much of the paradox of Ashbery's sudden success, when he wrote Self Portrait in a Convex Mirror and found himself transformed overnight from outsider into national institution. Ashbery himself has noted the danger that an artist can "pass from unacceptability to acceptance without an intervening period of appreciation", and his later career is thus plausibly seen by Herd as a constant negotiation towards further fresh starts. Ashbery's work, for himself and for everyone, is precisely about an attentiveness to one's own situation and potentiality, not a substitution of someone else's. Charmingly, in riposte to accusations of obscurity, Ashbery has stated that "a poem that communicates something that's already known to a reader is not really communicating anything to him, and in fact shows a lack of respect". Or, more strongly: "It's a veiled insult to the reader." In this spirit, what Herd offers is not a reading of Ashbery but a way of reading Ashbery, and a critical language more appropriate to Ashbery's peculiarities than pre-packaged approaches, which merely make Ashbery reflect their own concerns. This is one of the most entertaining, lucid, witty, generous and hospitable works of criticism I have had the pleasure of reading. Like all good critics, Herd sends us back to the poems; prepared for the adventurous journey ahead, but not saddled with someone else's luggage.

webTitle: Review: Death in Holy Orders by P D James

fields.headline: Clerical terrors
fields.standfirst: Roy Hattersley on genteel murder in Death in Holy Orders by P D James
fields.trailText: Roy Hattersley on genteel murder in Death in Holy Orders by P D James
fields.body:
Death in Holy Orders
P D James
397pp, Faber, £17.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

A thriller it is not, nor is Death in Holy Orders intended to justify that description. It proceeds at a pace appropriate to the speed of life at St Anselm's, the Anglican theological college at which most of the plot - "action" being quite the wrong word - is set. But P D James is able to meander with a sense of urgency. As a result, the absence of a new sensation in every chapter of her latest murder mystery increases the suspense rather than reduces the tension. Not once, as I read the description of Father Martin's bedroom, the paraphrase of Archdeacon Crampton's homily or any of the other vignettes of clerical life, did I think, "For God's sake, get on with it!" This is a novel of time and place as well as a detective story.

Indeed, by far the weakest moments in the book are the two occasions on which the author feels it necessary to make rapid progress by using the most artificial of literary devices, the narrative letter. The first, right at the beginning of the book, sets the scene. The second, near the end, explains the motives of the murderer. I suspect the publisher insisted that Commander Adam Dalgliesh should not extend his latest investigation to 400 pages.

Long ago, Baroness James convinced me that although coincidence is commonplace in life, in fiction it is usually unconvincing. Despite that indisputable truth, Death in Holy Orders begins with a suspicious death in a part of East Anglia to which Commander Dalgliesh is about to set off for a (naturally well-earned) holiday. And Dalgliesh, as a boy, spent a summer at the college that the dead man had briefly attended. My irritation at the contrivance lasted for 30 seconds. The unlikely explanation of his early acquaintance with St Anselm's justifies the Commander's knowledge of theology and church history. "The Nicene Creed was formulated by the Council of Nicaea in the fourth century . . . The Emperor Constantine called the Council to deal with the Arian Heresy." Moments of independent erudition, though rare in the Metropolitan Police, are essential to the James style.

The often irrelevant though always compelling asides are almost invariably evocations of old England. Dalgliesh, on his way to view the corpse of Archdeacon Crampton, "could be sure that none of his officers would attempt to anaesthetise the horror by facetiousness and crude graveyard humour". Anyone who did so "would not serve under him for long". The author's stern moral values are reflected on page after page. That, too, is one of the unique features of a P D James detective story.

Surprisingly, product identification - the curse of the modern novel - breaks out from time to time. Motor cars are rarely called motor cars. Dalgliesh has a Jaguar, Piers Tarrant (the sidekick without whom no fictional detective would be complete) an Alfa Romeo, and Sir Alfred Treeves (adoptive father of the first victim) a chauffeur- driven Mercedes. His murdered son was unpopular because he owned a Porsche. Perhaps the choice of vehicle is meant to illustrate class and temperament. But despite their different backgrounds, all the men meticulously fasten their seat belts before each journey. No character created by PD James would dare do otherwise.

The characters are cunningly constructed to carry James's message. Archdeacon Crampton is made into a hate figure with a description of the way he treats the college gardener. He becomes one of the essential features of a good detective story - a victim whose death readers do not mourn. But before he is murdered, he makes several attacks on what he regards as outdated attitudes. He is the enemy of elitism, the "seductive over-emphasis on ceremony" and the "temptation to overvalue intelligence". It cannot but be by choice that the assaults on tradition and convention are made by a man so small-minded that he worries about the damage that Blu-Tac does to college walls. Baroness James knows which side she is on.

Despite her expert knowledge of the Home Office and a life spent largely in London, James is at her absolute best on rural England - the world of wood fires, weed-free flagstones, pantries with brick floors and "the smell of moist earth and apples with a hint of paraffin" - places that give "the immediate impression of order and comfort". It is a world in which murder stories barely mention sex and, apart from the murders themselves, are wholly free of violence. P D James's flagstones and pantries are set in the 21st century, but the values their description represents are both loving and unfashionable. That is why Archdeacon Crampton had to die, and why the novels of P D James possess the special charm of fading memories.

fields.headline: Ancestral echoes
fields.standfirst: D J Taylor  on Fairness by Ferdinand Mount, a classic example of of a neglected strain of the English novel
fields.trailText: D J Taylor on Fairness by Ferdinand Mount, a classic example of of a neglected strain of the English novel
fields.body:
Fairness
Ferdinand Mount
318pp, Chatto & Windus, £16.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

It was quite by chance that I finished reading Ferdinand Mount's new novel during a rainy afternoon in February on the train back from Malcolm Bradbury's memorial service. Normally one wouldn't inflict this kind of situational exactitude on one's readers, but here amid the dank Norfolk fields - the reception took place at the University of East Anglia's Sainsbury Centre - could be witnessed a deeply symbolic event. The Poet Laureate was led smiling into the throng. At a table at the far end of the room were no fewer than four Booker winners. What was being celebrated, it became increasingly clear, was not merely the life of a distinguished ornament of the modern literary scene, but the triumph - or perhaps only the survival - of a particular brand of post-war English writing.

This is not a complaint about Ishiguro, Swift, McEwan or Rushdie, the four Booker winners seen conferring over the buffet; simply an acknowledgment that in the reputation-brokering that has accompanied the progress of the British novel over the past 20 years, a certain kind of writing has lost out in favour of another. The kind that lost out, it is fair to say, was the melancholic-humorous novel of English decline, the novel of ironic glances backward, of suppressed diminuendos; the kind of book that Anthony Powell used to write, that A N Wilson still does, and of which Ferdinand Mount is an absolutely classic contemporary exponent.

No consideration of Mount's Chronicle of Modern Twilight - a series of loosely linked novels (this is the fifth) going back as far as The Man Who Rode Ampersand (1975) - can altogether ignore the Powell connection. This is ancestral as well as stylistic: Powell, as it happens, was Mount's uncle by marriage. Gus Cotton, Mount's diffident civil-servant narrator, would hardly look out of place in A Dance to the Music of Time : he is a halting presence on the edge of things, a minute observer of human foibles, eager to please, always in search of an escape route when the emotional going gets tough. Mount specialises, too, in the unheralded reappearance: Dr Maintenon-Smith from the earlier novels, here found working on a fog-bound hospital ship, and Gerald Moonman, editor of the satirical magazine Frag (a dead ringer for Private Eye ), re-emerging to go off with his brother's wife.

Essentially, Fairness is the story of an unrequited love affair, set against several decades of post-war English history. Blonde, intense Helen, whom Gus first encounters on a rain-swept Normandy beach in the early 1960s and whom he marks down as a repository for moral seriousness, turns out to be a talismanic figure in his life. Whether she is seen at her parents' home on "Minnow Island", downriver from Teddington, squired to a down-at-heel motorists' club off Regent Street by Bobs, Gerald's younger brother, or found working for a dodgy South African mining enterprise, Helen's capacity to hurt, mystify and intrigue is a constant. Eternally out of reach, capable of contracting the most bizarre alliances, half-confidential, half-aloof, Helen is the hinge on which the novel turns. She picks up the other characters - including Dido Wilmot, the outsized American businessman, and his predatory wife - but always manages to preserve herself intact amid a mounting tide of personal and historical wreckage.

Gus and Helen's final encounter takes place at a child-abuse inquiry in the late 1980s, where he is the secretary and she a social-worker witness. However deviously plotted and neatly, or rather ambiguously, resolved - even the title contrives to marry a philosophical abstract with the name of the children's home - Fairness brings off many of its effects through sheer atmospherics. There is a characteristic moment when Gus makes one of his periodic visits to Bobs Moonman's gloomy flat, with its push-button lights and piles of uncollected post lying on the radi ator shelf. "You felt that the dust rising from the brown stair-carpet was the same dust that had filled your mouth and nostrils a month before as you gasped for breath on the landing."

Dust. Decay. Dereliction. This is not a world of bright futures, but of gently receding pasts. Mount's earlier novel The Clique (1978) - not part of the Chronicle series but capable of being read alongside it - was also like this; in fact, it was even more sharply figurative. Goater, its journalist hero, begins the book staking out the house of the "Last Great Englishman" (Winston Churchill) during his final illness, and later wanders through rows of East End terraces with names like "Tel-El-Kebir", "Balaclava" and "Inkerman".

It would be a mistake, though, to write Mount off as yet another of those well-bred English elegists whose threnodies rise every so often to break the torpor of the right-wing newspapers. Where he excels, and where he has the edge over practically every one of his more effervescent contemporaries, is in his depiction of character. The unexpected reappearances, for example, are handled with a shrewd eye for physical detail. Re-encountering John Stilwell, the husband of a woman with whom he had an unsatisfactory fling years before in Normandy, Gus reflects: "He didn't look older, but I was somehow more conscious of his physical presence, the tanned skin of his narrow cheeks and his dimity little chin, the bony fingers clasped round the handle of his square oxblood briefcase, the long black hairs on his skinny forearm . . ." However eccentric or self-obsessed they are, one can believe in Mount's people. Once discovered, they are somehow at large in your consciousness in a way that many a postmodern wraith is not.

There is no point in pretending that Fairness isn't a recognisably old-fashioned novel, or rather - a slightly different thing, perhaps - that it deals in some highly old-fashioned subject matter. A certain type of streetwise literary hipster will tell you that its manipulations of "character", its lives lived out in endless, brooding shadow, have simply been displaced by the post-1980s postmodern surge. And yet the reader will be struck, constantly and gratefully, by a spectacle that is now comparatively rare in fiction: the sight of ordinary people living in an ordinary - or not so ordinary - world.

fields.headline: Page to screen
fields.trailText: Good news for Hanif Kureishi - not only has his new novel Gabriel's Gift been considerably better received than the angst-ridden marital breakdown saga Intimacy, but Patrice Chereau's film of the latter has just scooped the Berlin Film Festival's Golden Bear Award.
fields.body:
 Good news for Hanif Kureishi - not only has his new novel Gabriel's Gift been considerably better received than the angst-ridden marital breakdown saga Intimacy, but Patrice Chereau's film of the latter has just scooped the Berlin Film Festival's Golden Bear Award. Although the Loafer notes that "film of" proves to be an elastic term - the screen version of Intimacy is, curiously, based on a short story in the collection Love in a Blue Time. More romping and less rowing, which might be the secret of its success - although not in America, where its blue content has sent distributors scurrying for cover.

 And more cheer for Kureishi's publishers Faber, whose protégés Victor Pelevin and Andrew O'Hagan feature on the £75,000 Impac shortlist. Feel you cast your eyes over their work some time ago? You'd be right - the 2001 award focuses on global fiction published in 1999, a full year being just about long enough for the world's librarians to cast their votes.

 The Loafer enjoyed a recent evening in the company of three Canadian writers, each of whom read obligingly from their new books after a few words from their publishers. Except for newcomer Camilla Gibb, who hovered nervously in the wings while Heinemann's Ravi Mirchandani praised her to the skies. Clearly unaware of the convention that a publisher's speech should not exceed in duration an author's reading, Mirchandani explained how the manuscript - plucked "from an unknown Canadian publisher" - had languished on his submissions pile for weeks on end. Doubtless, the Loafer thinks, while he was on a speech-writing course.

fields.headline: And now, Pooh wants to be a millionaire...
fields.standfirst: Almost 50 years after his death, AA Milne's work is held in great affection and remains highly collectable, writes Stewart Dalby
fields.trailText: Almost 50 years after his death, AA Milne's work is held in great affection and remains highly collectable, writes Stewart Dalby.
fields.body:
Is JK Rowling, author of the Harry Potter books, the modern-day equivalent of AA Milne, of Winnie the Pooh fame? Rare book dealer Adrian Harrington laughed at the suggestion and said: "Some people will tell you that the Harry Potter books are a one-off phenomenon. Others will tell you the Harry books are a flash in the pan."

Some flash! Even as a collectible, Harry Potter books have outperformed everything in sight. A first edition hardback copy of the first book, Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone, in fine condition and with a dust wrapper would now fetch a four-figure sum against £10.99 when new, in 1997. Only 500 were printed.

Harrington adds though: "If you are talking about children's writers who altered the form of the literature then yes, they are comparable.

"You must probably start with Lewis Carroll who changed the way childhood books were written by creating different imaginary worlds. So did Beatrix Potter, and her books sold internationally. JRR Tolkien's The Lord of The Rings has been voted by booksellers Waterstones the most popular children's book of the 20th century. You would probably have to include Roald Dahl, because he introduced anarchy into the genre.

"AA Milne created inimitable childhood tales, and they became best sellers in the 20s. They remain hugely popular today. There are many other children's writers, but these are the most significant in my view. What JK Rowling has done is to create just one imaginary world, that of witches, rather than overlapping ones."

Whether she proves as durable as AA Milne remains to be seen. For there is little doubt that many years after his death in 1956, Milne retains a hold on the affections of readers and is highly collectable.

What few people realise is that the children's books were a small part of his literary output. Bloomsbury Book Auctions is offering a private collection on April 5 which reveals the range of his work, including his stories, plays, letters, poems and autobiography as well as some original drawings by his illustrator EH Shephard. There is also a charcoal portrait of the author by David Low.

The collection has 64 lots and estimates range from £60 to £3,000. The vendor has been collecting for 30 years. He says: "I began with Now We Are Six and now that I'm 60 I have decided to sell."

Milne had an extremely varied career. His earliest writing days were spent as a humourist for Punch. He also wrote poems and plays and some controversial pacifist tomes such as Peace with Honour which caused quite a stir. There were also detective stories, of which perhaps the best known is The Red House Mystery.

His writing for children began in 1923, when Rose Fyleman asked him to contribute a poem to a magazine she was launching. The first issue of The Merry-Go-Round included Milne's poem The Dormouse and the Doctor.

While on a wet holiday in Wales, he embarked on a series of poems, which resulted in When We Were Very Young, the first of his four books for children, and in which Christopher Robin and Pooh made fleeting appearances. Then came Now We Are Six, Winnie-the-Pooh, and the House at Pooh Corner.

According to AA Milne's biographer Anne Thwaite, he went through a long period of regretting how Winnie the Pooh came to dominate his life. "The most exciting form of writing," he once said, "is writing plays."

There are plenty of plays in the sale. Peace with Honour, the first American edition in original cloth published in 1934, is estimated at £75 to £100. The Red House Mystery first edition, signed by the author on the title in good condition, is expected to fetch £1,500 to £2,000.

It is inevitably the children's books which will attract the greatest attention. When We were Very Young, a first edition from 1924 with illustrations by EH Shephard, original pictorial cloth, dust jacket slightly soiled and frayed may go for £2,000 to £3,000. As it was the first of the quartet, the print run was shorter and it is therefore scarcer. There are many cheaper editions of this title and the other three on offer.

EH Shephard has overshad owed AA Milne in some sales. The reason is that there is only one original drawing and often lots of books. Also, as Adrian Harrington points out: "There are about 12 defining images of Winnie the Pooh and any one of these will fetch a lot of money."

None of the Shephard sketches in the sale are from the Pooh books and many can be bought for hundreds. The most expensive Shephard is priced at £3,000.

fields.bodyText: Is JK Rowling, author of the Harry Potter books, the modern-day equivalent of AA Milne, of Winnie the Pooh fame? Rare book dealer Adrian Harrington laughed at the suggestion and said: "Some people will tell you that the Harry Potter books are a one-off phenomenon. Others will tell you the Harry books are a flash in the pan." Some flash! Even as a collectible, Harry Potter books have outperformed everything in sight. A first edition hardback copy of the first book, Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone, in fine condition and with a dust wrapper would now fetch a four-figure sum against £10.99 when new, in 1997. Only 500 were printed. Harrington adds though: "If you are talking about children's writers who altered the form of the literature then yes, they are comparable. "You must probably start with Lewis Carroll who changed the way childhood books were written by creating different imaginary worlds. So did Beatrix Potter, and her books sold internationally. JRR Tolkien's The Lord of The Rings has been voted by booksellers Waterstones the most popular children's book of the 20th century. You would probably have to include Roald Dahl, because he introduced anarchy into the genre. "AA Milne created inimitable childhood tales, and they became best sellers in the 20s. They remain hugely popular today. There are many other children's writers, but these are the most significant in my view. What JK Rowling has done is to create just one imaginary world, that of witches, rather than overlapping ones." Whether she proves as durable as AA Milne remains to be seen. For there is little doubt that many years after his death in 1956, Milne retains a hold on the affections of readers and is highly collectable. What few people realise is that the children's books were a small part of his literary output. Bloomsbury Book Auctions is offering a private collection on April 5 which reveals the range of his work, including his stories, plays, letters, poems and autobiography as well as some original drawings by his illustrator EH Shephard. There is also a charcoal portrait of the author by David Low. The collection has 64 lots and estimates range from £60 to £3,000. The vendor has been collecting for 30 years. He says: "I began with Now We Are Six and now that I'm 60 I have decided to sell." Milne had an extremely varied career. His earliest writing days were spent as a humourist for Punch. He also wrote poems and plays and some controversial pacifist tomes such as Peace with Honour which caused quite a stir. There were also detective stories, of which perhaps the best known is The Red House Mystery. His writing for children began in 1923, when Rose Fyleman asked him to contribute a poem to a magazine she was launching. The first issue of The Merry-Go-Round included Milne's poem The Dormouse and the Doctor. While on a wet holiday in Wales, he embarked on a series of poems, which resulted in When We Were Very Young, the first of his four books for children, and in which Christopher Robin and Pooh made fleeting appearances. Then came Now We Are Six, Winnie-the-Pooh, and the House at Pooh Corner. According to AA Milne's biographer Anne Thwaite, he went through a long period of regretting how Winnie the Pooh came to dominate his life. "The most exciting form of writing," he once said, "is writing plays." There are plenty of plays in the sale. Peace with Honour, the first American edition in original cloth published in 1934, is estimated at £75 to £100. The Red House Mystery first edition, signed by the author on the title in good condition, is expected to fetch £1,500 to £2,000. It is inevitably the children's books which will attract the greatest attention. When We were Very Young, a first edition from 1924 with illustrations by EH Shephard, original pictorial cloth, dust jacket slightly soiled and frayed may go for £2,000 to £3,000. As it was the first of the quartet, the print run was shorter and it is therefore scarcer. There are many cheaper editions of this title and the other three on offer. EH Shephard has overshad owed AA Milne in some sales. The reason is that there is only one original drawing and often lots of books. Also, as Adrian Harrington points out: "There are about 12 defining images of Winnie the Pooh and any one of these will fetch a lot of money." None of the Shephard sketches in the sale are from the Pooh books and many can be bought for hundreds. The most expensive Shephard is priced at £3,000.  Bloomsbury Book Auctions, tel: 020-7833-2636; Adrian Harrington Rare Books, tel: 020-7937-1465.

fields.headline: Go to the cinema
fields.trailText: How to...
fields.body:
Cinema is completely absorbing, interactive entertainment in which you can be totally engaged for two hours or more. And that's just booking the tickets on the phone.

Talking in the cinema is like whistling at a funeral. If you really want to talk, go to an arty foreign film with lots of depth and hidden meaning. None of the po-faced, glasses-wearing audience will mind you chatting away, because with subtitles you don't actually have to hear anything that's being said.

In the old days, you used to be able to smoke in the cinema. Many films remembered as classic black-and-white pictures by your parents were actually released as colour films: they just looked black-and-white because you had to view them through a forest fire.

At some stage on your first date with someone at the cinema, you have to get your arm around them. The seats are specially designed to make this anatomically impossible, so you have to do the equivalent of a 17-point turn to get your arm surreptitiously around the person next to you. (Be careful about trying this in a horror movie, as it can be disconcerting suddenly finding a sweaty hand on your shoulder.)

There are two reasons bad films do so well: they have lots of exciting romance/horror/action, which stimulates you to put your arm around someone or to put your head on their shoulder. The other reason is that you can then have a marathon half-hour snog and not miss any significant part of the plot.

When you go to the cinema to see absolute and utter rubbish, it's an important part of the ritual that you eat a selection of absolute and utter rubbish: ideally, start with a hot dog made from meat retrieved from the spinal column, follow this up with a box of popcorn the size of a small coffin, and finish off with a jumbo pack of sweets with the world's loudest wrappings.

Never arrive at a cinema late, as there will be only one seat left and that will be in total blackness at the furthest point from you. While you're inching forward with one toe trying to find the next step, you may think you're in pitch darkness, but everybody else will have their night vision and so can clearly see you prannying about like a total jessie.

Leaving the cinema is often a bit of a let-down. Cinema foyers are usually pretty glam, but they always let you out through the fire exit and straight into a public convenience. It's a deliberate ploy by the management to say, 'That was Hollywood, this is Swindon.' Welcome back.

fields.headline: Felicity Kendal
fields.standfirst: Felicity Kendal was born in Warwickshire in 1946, and raised in India, where her actor parents ran a touring theatre company. After appearing in the 1965 film Shakespeare Wallah, she made her West End debut the same year. Perhaps best known for her role in the 70s TV sitcom The Good Life, she has continued to work in the theatre, playing many classic roles. She is currently starring in the Noël Coward comedy Fallen Angels at the Apollo Theatre, London.

fields.body:
What is your idea of perfect happiness?
A family holiday with all the babies and children, by the sea.

What is your greatest fear?
The serious illness of my children, my sister's children and their children.

Which living person do you most admire?
Nelson Mandela - does it need an explanation?

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
Um, indecision.

What makes you depressed?
Other people's bad temper.

What is your most unappealing habit?
Interrupting people as they speak.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?
Nothing - I've got used to it by now.

What is your greatest extravagance?
Shoes, preferably Manolo Blahniks.

What is your favourite smell?
Fresh jasmine and Johnson's Baby Powder.

What is your favourite journey?
Toy train to Darjeeling.

What is your favourite fantasy?
To live for a very long time.

How did you vote in the last election?
Wisely, I think.

How will you vote in the next election?
In the same way.

Should the royal family be scrapped?
How rude! Definitely not.

Do you believe in capital punishment?
Of course I don't.

Do you believe in monogamy?
Sometimes.

What or who is the greatest love of your life?
Pass.

Which living person do you most despise?
I don't wish to be sued, so pass on that one, too.

Which words or phrases do you most overuse?
'Yes', when I mean maybe.

How would you like to die?
Very old and wide awake, with a glass of champagne on a beach at sunset.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
We are not in charge. Life is very short and we don't know which day our goodbye is.

webTitle: 'Forget studying architecture - I can't even afford to buy Harriet a Lego set'

fields.headline: 'Forget studying architecture - I can't even afford to buy Harriet a Lego set'
fields.trailText: Jet-lagged and lovelorn. Fred turned cold and silent on the homeward flight, after I spilt Chablis on his chinos. I lie awake all night wondering if his hatred had built slowly over the weeks, or if it was a sudden mad falling head-over-heels in loathing.
fields.body:
Jet-lagged and lovelorn. Fred turned cold and silent on the homeward flight, after I spilt Chablis on his chinos. I lie awake all night wondering if his hatred had built slowly over the weeks, or if it was a sudden mad falling head-over-heels in loathing.

Get up after sleepless night to confront family and finances - always a ghastly cocktail. Never mind fading memories of Last Tango on Tobago. It's the rest of my life with this lot I have to sort out. Elaine and her child are still with us, though the waters have gone down around her Georgian rectory and some kind of decision is pending. She and Gordon have been having long serious talks in my absence, according to Harriet. About money.

"I can't remember what the leader of the Liberal Party is called!" cries aunt suddenly in panic.

"I can't remember who the leader of the Liberal Party is !" drawls Gordon.

"I know!" I cry, "It's Nigel Kennedy!" Always distinguished by my general knowledge. Wonder if I could manage to get to sleep by counting the leaders of the Liberal Party jumping over a gate - or sitting on a fence. Distract aunt from her memory loss with photos of tropical birds. "I want to show you my motmot, Auntie," I smile. Aunt is not listening, but scrabbling for an envelope in her bag.

"Just a minute, dearr , I wanted to ask you about the phone bill. I'm trying to work out a thirrrd of this." Aunt offers page of scribbled figures. Her ability to do sums is declining.

"You shouldn't be paying a third this quarter, Auntie. You've hardly used the phone at all."

"I should pay it!" cries Elaine. "All those calls to Tom! The bastard!" She fights back tears. Who would have the heart to charge her a realistic rate for her phone calls, even if she had any money?

Suddenly feel immensely tired and dull. Make secret plan to go back to bed and head for the door looking as if I have an important errand.

"Mum?" Harriet grabs me. "Can I talk to you about my A-levels? I've gotta choose them, like, now."

"Well, what do you want to do for a living?"

Harriet looks important. "I wanna be an architect."

Gobsmacked. "An architect? Don't architects have to study maths and engineering?"

"Thass Okay. Thass cool."

"Okay, Harriet. Who was the greatest British architect?" Harriet frowns. "He rebuilt St Paul's after the Great Fire? I'll give you a clue. Sir Christopher? Sir Christopher? I'll give you another clue. His name is a small British bird."

"Sir Christopher Robin?" she suggests. Exhausted by this gruelling careers advice session, I retreat to the study, where more bills await. Never mind studying architecture - at the moment, I couldn't even afford to kit her out with a Lego set. The aunt's money must remain untouched. I'm sure I knew about Wren at Harriet's age. But then, general knowledge was always my favourite party game. Such a shame it can't be a nice little earner. Although...

Quiet moment, nobody about, seize opportunity, lift phone and dial recruitment number for Who Wants To Be A Millionaire, which has somehow lodged in my consciousness. First I have to key in a few codes to let them know what sort of phone I have, colour of hair, etc. Then comes the first question that will lead, if I'm lucky, to the strange elevated chair, the compulsory clinches with Chris Tarrant, and the cheque for, oh, let's be modest, £32,000? "The song America appears in which of these musicals: Porgy & Bess, West Side Story, Oklahoma!, or Guys & Dolls?" Oh God, musicals! Suggest, with mad lunge, Oklahoma! and a pre-recorded Chris Tarrant informs me that I'm wrong. Mud on knees, egg on face, total prat. No wonder Fred hates me. Hang up and am about to slink off to bed when the phone rings. Have brief but horrible feeling it's Chris Tarrant calling back with a mocking coda.

"Hi, it's Fred. I'm ringing from the hospital. I've just had my appendix out. It started to hurt on the plane but I didn't mention it because I didn't want to worry you." Oh, the sweetheart! So there might be a bit more to this love affair after all. A kind of appendix, I suppose.

fields.headline: An open and shut case
fields.standfirst: Snowdrops may win all the plaudits, but the crocus will always be the spring flower of choice for Christopher Lloyd
fields.trailText: Snowdrops may win all the plaudits, but the crocus will always be the spring flower of choice for Christopher Lloyd
fields.body:
Idon't know whether snowdrops are actually more popular than crocuses, but they are certainly more adept at hitting the headlines. There are galanthus openings and meetings of a kind that is unheard of for crocuses. The reason for this is almost certainly that crocuses are moody; snowdrops are not. If the weather is not right for them, crocuses simply remain shut - and a closed crocus is no more enlivening than a closed golf umbrella, however bright that may be when fully expanded. However, when crocuses do open it means that the sun is shining and we ourselves can experience the same happiness, and the feeling that spring is finally with us.

We feel expansive about crocuses. That is what I love about them, together with their great range of colours and markings, and the differences between the inside and outside of the flower. When seen together, the presentation is ideal. The gardening writer Ernest Bowles described them as his first garden love, and admitted that his raptures may appear the vapourings of a love-sick monomaniac (he was not far wrong).

No bulb could be easier to grow, always provided you are not plagued by mice or voles. On my heavy soil, in which they find it hard to work, there is no problem. The corms (the globular stem base) multiply at a great rate, and many of them self-sow. By now, we are probably in the full tide of the Dutch hybrids, the largest kinds, which are purple, mauve, white or stripy. They are not refined, but they make a tremendous and gladdening show - and they self-sow like mad.

When planting in turf, use a long-shafted bulb planter, if you possibly can, and take out individual plugs at irregular intervals, so that the planting looks relaxed and natural. Taking short cuts, there is a fashion for cutting a turf on three sides, turning it back as a flap and crowding corms in the rectangle underneath, then replacing the flap. This looks terrible; if you can persuade yourself otherwise, you can believe anything.

Planting in turf is the ideal, as long as it isn't in self-conscious circles around a tree, as the mower will then reluctantly have to leave that area uncut for a few weeks to allow the crocus "grass" to finish its cycle, which won't be until as late as May. Planting in a meadow area among daffodils is also a good idea, because the crocuses flower before the daffodils are tall enough to spoil their display. I planted a few hundred Crocus tommasinianus 'Whitewell Purple' in our old orchard three years ago, and where there was originally one corm, there were up to eight or nine blooms this year. They are of a far richer colour than the plain species, too. 'Whitewell Purple' is, in fact, one of the most enthusiastic self-sowers, and it was already at its best last month.

The Dutch yellow crocus is one of the most popular. It is an early flowerer, and Fergus likes it so well that he has marked some of the largest clumps with a view to dividing and spreading them around later this month. The point about this crocus is that it is sterile, and so cannot self-sow; one has to help it. This is the one that sparrows love to tear to shreds. Equally early and even more beautiful in its way is the species from which it derives, C. flavus (also C. aureus). It is smaller-flowered but of a richer shade of orange, and is a great self-seeder, though less widely offered. It combines and contrasts well with C. tommasinianus . These crocuses are good in borders, too, provided you don't get impatient with their lanky foliage after flowering. This foliage is narrow, and I don't find it unduly irritating for a few weeks. If you are not neurotic about their manurial regime, you can liven up your rose beds with crocuses in early spring. There won't be a trace of them left by the time the roses are ready to perform.

Among the jolliest and most varied of the species is C. chrysanthus. It is naturally yellow, but varies tremendously thanks to selection. My favourite is 'Snow Bunting', which is creamy white with some dark stripes on the outside. It is deliciously scented and also one of the earliest. Unfortunately, a different cultivar is often sold under its name; whiter, but late-flowering and with no scent. So I was glad, at the February RHS show in Westminster, to see 'Snow Bunting' correctly named and identified. This species is so amazingly fertile that, after a few years of growing one next to another, you will find that they have given birth to some really exciting variants, with subtle combinations of mauve and yellow. It is difficult not to feel proud of one's offspring.

At this time of the year, the easiest autumn-flowering species to colonise - C. speciosus and C. nudiflorus in my case - are making carpets of their "grass". They have no leaves when flowering, but become green in late winter. And they have this colonising, carpeting habit. Spring flowerers will not thrive among them. If you want to increase the range of your autumn flowerers, lift them in the next few weeks, while you can still see where they are. In a meadow setting, this is particularly easy while the turf is still short and tight.

The regime to follow in such cases is to give the grass its first and main cut in July or August, after its contents have scattered their seed; then to await the flowering of colchicums and autumn crocuses, complete by the end of October; after which the turf can be cut again, tight as you can get it, so as to set off the short-stemmed snowdrops and crocuses to best effect
