So I was glad, at the February RHS show in Westminster, to see 'Snow Bunting' correctly named and identified. This species is so amazingly fertile that, after a few years of growing one next to another, you will find that they have given birth to some really exciting variants, with subtle combinations of mauve and yellow. It is difficult not to feel proud of one's offspring. At this time of the year, the easiest autumn-flowering species to colonise - C. speciosus and C. nudiflorus in my case - are making carpets of their "grass". They have no leaves when flowering, but become green in late winter. And they have this colonising, carpeting habit. Spring flowerers will not thrive among them. If you want to increase the range of your autumn flowerers, lift them in the next few weeks, while you can still see where they are. In a meadow setting, this is particularly easy while the turf is still short and tight. The regime to follow in such cases is to give the grass its first and main cut in July or August, after its contents have scattered their seed; then to await the flowering of colchicums and autumn crocuses, complete by the end of October; after which the turf can be cut again, tight as you can get it, so as to set off the short-stemmed snowdrops and crocuses to best effect

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Metaphors help
fields.body:
One of the problems of communicating about wine is the ineffability of the subject. Metaphors help, but what you regard as sweet, I may think of as half-dry; and what you infer as being peachy in a wine, I may conclude is more like kumquat. These are some of the reasons why I have a scoring system. From this, the reader is left in no doubt of my view of a wine: 20 out of 20 is utterly marvellous, 15 obviously pretty good, 10 ordinary but drinkable, and 5 tending towards the pits.

I am minded to reflect on this matter, because a couple of readers have queried my awarding, last year, 17 points to Chile's Cono Sur Cabernet Sauvignon 1999 (£4.99, Asda, Safeway and Waitrose). A wine reaching this heady pointage is pretty remarkable and, since a value-for-money gauge is woven into my system, also a bargain. Was the wine fading? Had it lost its impactful richness since I last tasted it? Well, I recently re-tasted it, drank it with various dishes, and felt that, yes, it had lost a little - but only a little, so it now rates 16.5 points. It still presents huge depths of chocolate-textured fruit and is still fantastic value. It is not as madly fruity as the 2000 vintage, which is coming on shelf soon (or, indeed, may already be on shelf in some branches) and which has to rate 17, but other palates may disagree. My postman (not to mention my email in-tray) will bear the weight of any disagreement.

There are few such disagreements among readers about Morrisons, which continues to be a bastion of bargaindom. La Passion Blanc Vin de Pays de Vaucluse 1999 (15 points, £2.99, or two for a fiver until March 18) has some warm, fruity touches, ripe melon in style, but the overall theme is simple refreshment. La Passion Rouge 1999 (14 points, on the same price deal) is a charming, dry party wine that works well chilled and served with fish. Nottage Hill Cabernet Sauvignon/Shiraz 1999 (16.5 points, on offer for £4.49 until March 18) has tannins and subtle spiciness. Nottage Hill Chardonnay 1999 (16 points, down to £3.99) is classic Aussie chardonnay, though at that Morrisons price, perhaps its true score should be 16.75. Inycon Chardonnay 1999, from Sicily (16 points, down to £3.99), offers delicious, unfussy, unwoody fruit of depth, texture and style, and is classy and stylish on the finish. It is also available at Sainsbury's, Safeway, Waitrose and the Co-Op, where it is more likely to be £4.99. Di Notte Pinot Grigio 1999 (14 points, offered at £2.99) has some moving, if hardly seismic, apricot sensations.

Sainsbury's also has some bottles that are worth the detour. La Palmeria Merlot Gran Reserva 1999 (17.5 points, £7.99), from Chile, shows a magnificent structure: towering, richly elegant and soft as taffeta, with bright, corduroy patches of tannin and a superb complexity that finishes with such style it takes one's breath away. It's in limited distribution at Sainsbury's (call 0800 636262 for details), and can also be found at Oddbins. Errazuriz Wild Ferment Chardonnay 1999 (17 points, £8.99) is also Chilean and, with its hint of vegetality and very lingering, creamy woodiness, is like a wild Meursault. The wine has a long-delayed richness, complex and fine, that demands the drinker takes her time. Also, the latest vintage of Chteau La Vieille Cure Fronsac 1997 (16.5 points, £10.99) has arrived, and it's in good form - this is good-value claret, offering stylish cedarwood and tobacco fruit with fine-grained tannins, and is so much more charming than many more much higher priced, and allegedly finer, bordeaux reds.

Sainsbury's has a couple of interesting three-litre wine boxes, too. Kumala Chardonnay (16.5 points, £14.99), from South Africa, throbs with purpose and plump melon tones, a touch of pear and pineapple, and a subtle undertone of baked fruit. If this sounds a bit of a mouthful, however, it is nothing compared with Banrock Station Mataro Shiraz (15 points, on offer at £12.99 until March 17), which is tarrily rich, jammy, thick and hugely food friendly. At 54p a glass, it makes for bargain, throat-rippling tippling.

 For the latest wine news, and to email Malcolm Gluck, visit www.superplonk.com

fields.headline: The secret ingredient
fields.standfirst: Even today in Arab cooking, sumac is still preferred to lemon in many instances
fields.trailText: Even today in Arab cooking, sumac is still preferred to lemon in many instances
fields.body:
It is nigh on impossible to imagine a time when lemon was not an integral part of the kitchen. However, in the Rome of the ancient Romans and earlier, before the lemon was introduced to Europe, another ingredient, sumac, was used to sour and alter foods that may have been too sweet or too salty. Even today in Arab cooking, sumac is still preferred to lemon in many instances, as its effect is less astringent although, in truth, the flavours are very different.

Sumac is made from a berry grown high in the mountains of Sicily, from where it is exported mostly to Lebanon, though it is used also in Iran, Turkey and Iraq. It normally makes an appearance as a bowl of gorgeous red powder served on the table to be sprinkled on kebabs, though it also features in zaatar, a marvellous mixture of sumac and wild thyme that is dusted over fried eggs. (Your best bet for getting hold of sumac in this country is to head for your nearest Asian or Middle Eastern grocer.)

This week's other spice (although, in reality, a seed) is sesame, a regular feature in the food of southeast Asia. But it, too, is famed for its use in Middle Eastern cookery, most notably in hoummos, in the form of tahini, a paste of sesame seeds. It may seem odd to include among the recipes a dish that is so simple to make and already well-known, but I wonder how many people eat or make their own. In comparison with the real McCoy, shop-bought varieties are like grouting for tiles.

All recipes serve six.

HOUMMOS BI-TAHINI
Considering the many variations of hoummos (most of them appalling) that take up as much shelf space in a supermarket as butter, it is amazing that we retain such a deep fondness for this dish. Proper hoummos is made only of chickpeas, tahini, garlic, lemon juice and olive oil. As usual, the classic simple approach cannot be bettered, so leave all fancy variations well alone. The hoummos at Alwaha in Westbourne Grove, London, is a great treat: it has the smoothest texture I have ever eaten. This is achieved by soaking and then peeling the chickpeas before cooking - and even I wouldn't suggest going that far.

200g dried chickpeas
1 tsp bicarbonate of soda
200ml tahini
2 lemons, juiced
3 cloves garlic, crushed
Paprika
Extra-virgin olive oil

It is vital to soak the chickpeas for 24 hours prior to cooking. Place them in plenty of cold water, add the bicarb, and leave to soak. Next day, rinse the chickpeas under cold water, place them in a deep saucepan and cover them again with water. Bring the pot to a boil, reduce the heat to a rapid simmer and cook until very tender. This should take one to two hours, depending on the age of the chickpeas. Place a colander over a deep bowl and drain the cooked chickpeas, reserving the liquor.

Place the chickpeas in a food processor and render to the smoothest of pastes. Place the purée in a bowl and stir in the tahini. Add the lemon juice spoonful by spoonful until it is sour enough for your taste, then add the garlic. Add a little of the liquor if the mixture becomes too stiff.

The Lebanese serve hoummos by spreading it over an oval dish before giving it a dusting of paprika and pouring over a little olive oil.

FATTOOSH
This salad really merits the search for sumac. It is quite brilliant whether eaten just as it is, or stuffed into warm bread or jazzed up and served with a roast fish. It is also a template for the quality and quantity of herbs and greens we should use in salads. It is essential that all the herbs and leaves are thoroughly washed and dried before chopping them with a heavy, sharp knife. It would be an injustice to these fine ingredients were one to put them in the food processor, which will bash and bruise, rather than chop them fine.

6 little gem lettuces
12 spring onions
5 mini (ie, Lebanese) cucumbers
5 firm, red tomatoes
2 handfuls flat-leaf parsley, picked
150g fresh mint
150g purslane (use extra parsley if this is unavailable)

To dress

4-5 tbsp sumac
Sea salt
9 tbsp extra-virgin olive oil
Good pitta bread

Remove any blemished outer leaves from the lettuces, then shred them with a sharp knife. Wash thoroughly and leave to drain. Trim and thinly slice the spring onions. Cut the cucumbers in half length-wise, and slice them thinly. Chop the tomatoes into small pieces. Coarsely chop the herbs. Put all these ingredients in a bowl, then strew with sumac, a little salt and the olive oil. Toast the pittas, and break them into the salad. Stir well to dress thoroughly, then serve.

A STUFFING FOR VEGETABLES
Where the reputation of hoummos seems unsullied, the fate of the once ubiquitous stuffed vegetable seems beyond repair. This stuffing is pure Lebanese, and quite delicious - it works especially well with vine leaves, courgettes, aubergines and peppers.

210g paella rice (or arborio)
450g ripe tomatoes, chopped
1 bunch spring onions, chopped
1 big handful flat-leaf parsley, chopped
1 small handful fresh mint, chopped
3 heaped tbsp sumac
tsp ground cinnamon
1 level tsp ground allspice
1 level tsp milled black pepper
Sea salt
2-3 tbsp fresh lemon juice
150ml olive oil
3-4 ripe tomatoes, sliced

Wash the rice in two or three changes of cold water and drain. Put in a pan with plenty of water, bring to a boil and cook for three to four minutes. Thoroughly rinse and drain the rice, then put it in a mixing bowl, along with all the chopped tomato, onion and herbs, sumac, cinnamon, allspice, pepper and salt to taste. Pour in the lemon juice and olive oil, and adjust the seasoning as necessary.

Choose a vegetable to stuff, say red peppers. Cut the top off the peppers, and spoon out all the seeds and white pith. Fill the peppers three-quarters full - this gives the rice space to expand - and pop the pepper lids back on top. Arrange the tomato slices in the bottom of a shallow casserole, and sit the peppers on top.

Fill the dish with cold water to come 2cm or so from the lip, then cover and bring up to a boil. Reduce the heat, and leave to simmer for 45 minutes or so. Check the stuffing to ensure the rice is cooked, remove the pot from the heat, and leave to sit for 10 minutes. Carefully lift out the peppers. If the liquor in the pot is still thin, simmer it down until it is a sauce-like consistency. Pour this gravy into a bowl and serve with the peppers

PERSIAN CUBED LAMB KEBABS
Aka Tikkeh Kabab. While I was putting together this week's dishes, it quickly became apparent, quite by accident, how very retro these recipes seemed. Kebabs may not feature in our cooking as often as they once did, but they remain inexpensive, simple to prepare, straightforward to cook and truly delicious to eat. This recipe is from The Legendary Cuisine Of Persia, by Margaret Shaida (Grub Street, £14.99), and is brilliant in its economy. Traditionally, these would be served at the Feast of the Sacrifice, and the fillet of a lamb freshly slaughtered in one's own courtyard by a professional butcher would be used. However, this might be pushing it a bit in Blighty. Needless to say, any lean cut of lamb will do very well. The recipe for saffron liquid and the rice may seem laborious and even of another era, but the result is so very good and unusual that it is well worth the effort.

500g boned lamb (leg, shoulder or neck fillet), cut into small cubes
2 medium onions
2 lemons, juiced
Sea salt
Pepper

For the basting sauce

60g butter
1 lemon, juiced
tsp liquid saffron
1 small bowl suma

To make the liquid saffron, grind 30 stamens of saffron to a powder in a pestle and mortar, or with the back of a spoon, and mix with five teaspoons of boiling water. It will keep for several weeks in a sealed jar in the fridge.

Wash the lamb in cold water, then rinse and dry. Peel and grate the onions and put into a bowl, along with the lemon juice, some sea salt and freshly milled black pepper. Coat the lamb with the marinade, put it in a bowl, cover, and refrigerate overnight.

Thread skewers with the meat and lay these on a plate. Melt the butter, and mix in the lemon juice and liquid saffron. Start cooking the kebabs - you can either grill them over coals (always the best way to cook such dishes), or pop them under the grill or in a ridged pan - basting regularly with the sauce, until they are deeply coloured all over and a blush of pink remains in the meat.

Serve with a bowl of sumac, to allow guests to help themselves.

RICE WITH HERBS
Aka Sabzi Polow.

500g basmati rice
Salt
100ml vegetable oil
4 tsp liquid saffron
60g clarified unsalted butter
350g fresh herbs, made up of equal measures parsley, coriander, dill and chives
1 generous pinch dried fenugreek
1 clove garlic

Pick over the rice, discarding any impurities, and wash it four or five times in cold water. Let the rice sit, covered in cold water with two tablespoons of salt, for two hours or so.

Pick, clean and dry the herbs. Chop them fine with the fenugreek and garlic. Fill a large pan of water, add two tablespoons of rice, and bring to the boil. Spoon out the rice, then tip the rest of the rice into the water and boil for two to three minutes. Drain in a colander, rinse lightly in cold water and then toss to loosen all the grains.

This next stage requires a bold streak and a nod from God. Place the pot over a high heat, add the oil and, with care, two or three tablespoons of water. Heat until sizzling then remove from heat. Spread a layer of rice over the base of the pan, strew this with herbs and repeat thus, building up a conical mound, ending with a layer of rice. With the handle of a wooden spoon, make three holes in the mound, pushing it right through to the bottom of the pan. Thoroughly seal the lid, place the pot over a high heat for three minutes, then reduce the heat to very low and leave to steam gently for around 30 minutes or so.

Once cooked, the rice can be left to sit off the heat, lid on and undisturbed, for a good half an hour longer. Before serving, spoon over the liquid saffron and butter, add a little salt to taste and, with a fork in each hand, lightly mix the rice. Pile on to a serving dish and surround with scrapings of the hard crust that will have formed at the bottom of the pan

 Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, Butlers Wharf, London SE1.

fields.headline: No hang ups
fields.standfirst: You've grown out of clip-frames and had enough of those ragged-edged Athena posters. It's time for some original, dramatic, large-scale art work in the home - and you needn't be Jean Paul Getty to buy it. Charlotte Abrahams on how to find your very own Brit art masterpiece
fields.trailText: You've grown out of clip-frames and had enough of those ragged-edged Athena posters. It's time for some original, dramatic, large-scale art work in the home - and you needn't be Jean Paul Getty to buy it. Charlotte Abrahams on how to find your very own Brit art masterpiece
fields.body:
There comes a time when you fancy spending some money on real art. The trouble is, you've never bought a painting or print before. Sure, there have been a few posters, even a rather nice copy of Picasso's dove from the local bookshop, but an original piece of contemporary art? Now that's different - it's an intimidating world, and you have little idea where to start.

So, you set off for the nearest gallery. You stand on the street peering in at the paintings and lithographs, then try the door but can't get in. You notice the sign near the bell: "Viewing by appointment only". Back to your posters and bookshop prints you go.

Or do you? Not if you are determined because, although the closed-door gallery is the best-known face of the serious art market, it is by no means the only place to buy original, high-quality art. Why, you can even find great things on the high street.

Emma Underhill is arts coordinator at Habitat, one of the people responsible for the store's contemporary art programme. This, she says, is designed "to endorse our commitment to making good art and design part of everyday life". There are two parts to the programme. The larger one is the print collection, which is basically a set of posters, but instead of the standard fare of sunflowers and cornfields, it offers contemporary images from both established names such as Richard Caldicott and Zaha Hadid, and rising Brit Art stars such as Emma Hatch. Prices range from £5 to £25.

The other part of the programme focuses on original pieces, primarily by emerging artists. Underhill finds many of these at MA degree shows, which are ideal places to discover new, affordable work. From time to time, a chosen artist is given an exhibition space in a store in London (King's Road or Tottenham Court Road), Glasgow or Dublin, and shoppers get the chance to see contemporary art in a familiar environment.

Prices are fair - a large-scale painting by a relative unknown can go for between £1,000 and £3,000, which, by art-market standards, isn't a lot. And, while you may not have heard of the artist, he or she could be destined for stardom. In the past five years, Habitat has exhibited Tracey Emin and Gary Hume, whose work sells for the kind of sums that make an outlay of, say, £1,500 seem like pocket money.

It's not only Habitat buyers who can seek out new talent in Britain's studios and art schools: ordinary punters can do it, too. The thing to remember, as print-maker and lecturer Nick Devison points out, is that artists want to sell their work. "MA students are desperate to sell," he says. "Very often they are in debt and at the very least they want someone to come and see their show."

Finding these sale-hungry new artists isn't that difficult. All major cities have an MA course in painting or print-making: www.ucas.ac.uk, the website for the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service, lists the address, email and phone numbers of every institution in the country. There is also a handbook for those who prefer printed pages to screens (see information panel on page 45).

Armed with this information, you can find out when the shows are, turn up, and, bingo, you could be the owner of a piece by a future winner of the Turner prize. It won't cost you much, either - a small print can be picked up for as little as £75. A painting will always be more, however, because it's a one-off; similarly, a mono print will cost more than an edition, and a print from a large edition will be a little cheaper than one from a small edition (see glossary).

It's surprisingly easy to track down working artists in their studios, too. The noticeboard at the local civic art gallery should have details of exhibitions in your area. And AN, the artists' newsletter, lists studios across the country which in turn can provide details of "open studio" events where the public can meet artists and buy their work.

Once you get into a studio, the secret of success is not to be intimidated. Devison, himself a practising artist, says that, far from having to come out with arty terminology, all you need to do is be friendly and open. "Artists," he says, "are often deeply complimented that people want to buy their work. If someone says, 'I absolutely love your work', then the artist's ego has gone through the roof and you can start to negotiate a price."

So, how do you spot a piece with investment potential? The short answer is you can't. Buying art as an investment is a different business entirely; the average punter buying for their home should buy on the basis of taste alone. That said, there are ways of ensuring that your print or painting is unlikely to lose its value. Devison recommends buying from an older (ie, 30-plus) artist because if he or she is still making art at this age, then they are likely to continue doing so. (This is why MA shows are a better bet than BA shows.)

He also suggests buying from someone who has exhibited before, because a successful artist will never sell for less than at the last exhibition.

Gallery owner Mark Wilson, on the other hand, advises first-timers to go for an established name. "You should never buy something you don't like," he says. "You must like it even if the price goes through the floor, but I would advise anyone starting out to go for a bankable name - after all, if you buy a £2,000 sofa, you could always sleep on it if you lose your house, but you can't sleep on a painting."

True, but doesn't a bankable name mean serious money and one of those intimidating, closed-door galleries? No - at least not if you are online. Nearly three years ago, Wilson set up www.artforsale.co.uk as an adjunct to his bricks-and-mortar gallery in north London. "Everyone was beginning to talk about the internet," he explains, "and a friend built the site as an experiment."

The experiment paid off; Wilson now has about 500 virtual visitors a day, a number he could never have dreamed of when he relied solely on feet-through-the-door. And there are many advantages for the cyber buyer. Obviously it is convenient and unthreatening - no danger of a snooty gallery assistant sniggering over your terminology here - but it also gives you the chance to look at work in a way you never could do in a gallery.

You can search by price (up to £500, £500-£999, £1,000-£4,999, £5,000 upwards) which is always embarrassing face to face if you have a limited budget; by medium (oil on canvas, screen print, etching, etc); by artist; or you can choose to view the entire range of work for sale (about 242 pictures in total). If you like what you see, you simply fill in your details, any questions, and submit. The process then gets a bit more low-tech (although Wilson plans to introduce online purchasing this year) because most people prefer to see the print or painting before they buy, and Wilson himself likes to check his clients are sure before they part with their money. (He does have a returns policy, but admits that it gives him sleepless nights if it's used too frequently.)

Artforsale.co.uk is not the only online gallery, but what sets it apart from most of its rivals is the quality of what is on offer. There are a number of up-and-coming artists whose work can be bought for a few hundred pounds, but there are also a lot of those "bankable names", chief among whom are Patrick Caulfield and Bridget Riley, an artist whose work has quadrupled in price in the four years that Wilson has been dealing in her work. Obviously, a Riley isn't going to be cheap, but the chances are that if you buy it online it will be a little bit less than in a smart city-centre gallery because there's no ground rent in cyberspace.

Art for the elite and the expert? Nonsense. Let them ring for entry into hushed galleries if they want to; the rest of us are finding exciting, original, contemporary work on the high street, in studios and on the web.

For details of Habitat shows, call 020-7255 2545.

Where to look

Space London Studio Around 400 artists in 15 buildings around the capital. Call 020-7613 1925 for dates of open studio events.

WASPS Artists' Studios Similar organisation to Space, but for Scottish artists, 0141-402 5020.

www.ucas.ac.uk and On Course Handbook (£1.95 from bookshops), for art courses UK-wide.

London Art & Artists Guide £9.95: galleries, shops, associations, events.

AN Magazine £3, or £26 per year, 0191 241 8000 (www.anweb.co.uk). Galleries, open studios and exhibitions.

Nick Devison 020-7585 0803 - prices around £70-£350.

www.artforsale.co.uk The online gallery. Also can be contacted at Cross Street Gallery, 020-7226 8600.

Know your prints

An artist's print is the artwork itself, whereas a mass-produced print is a copy of an artwork. The value of the former depends on whether it is a mono print (a unique print); an edition (a series of the same original print, always numbered with the edition number having no bearing on its value: ie, print No1 is worth the same as print No15); and multiple print (an original print that is sold without editioning ie, there is no limit to the number printed).

Relief prints Made by placing the paper directly on to a printing block that has been engraved or scored. Intaglio prints (more commonly called etchings) are made by pushing the paper into depressions in the printing plate. These are usually made by hand.

Lithographs Made on a flat surface as a result of a chemical reaction between grease and water.

Screen prints Made on a flat surface by forcing ink through a stencil.

Digital prints Made with the aid of computers.

After purchase

Framing Use the best quality materials you can afford: ie, acid-free mount board, non-reflective glass, shatter-resistant fronts to protect the picture from UV exposure and corrugated polypropylene backings to protect against moisture. Keep frames simple.

Hanging Don't hang too high. As a rule, the centre of the picture should be level with your eye, but if you're in doubt, go lower - then, if you have made a mistake, at least you won't see the drill holes in the wall. Don't hang pictures over a working fireplace.

Lighting Avoid direct light and, where possible, use natural light. If using artificial lights, don't put them too close to your picture, as the heat may damage it. Don't worry whether your picture will 'go' with the rest of the room; a good picture will look good anywhere, especially if you leave a space between the edge of the picture and the frame.

Thanks to the Chubb Masterpiece Fine Art Advisory Service.

fields.headline: The grand old loser
fields.trailText: Alexander Chancellor Stassen was one of those rare people who cheerfully fought election after election utterly undaunted by the prospect of defeat
fields.body:
When I was a child, there was a pottery jug on the chimney piece of my parents' dining room with the following words in relief on the side: "Effort, honest, manful, humble effort, succeeds by its reflective action upon character better than success." This sentence was from a speech by William Gladstone, the Liberal statesman, and the jug was a souvenir of his 1880 Midlothian campaign that brought him to power as prime minister for the second time.

My father considered the quotation so profound that he made his children learn it by heart. Although pretty interested in success, both for himself and for his children, my father clearly thought that, in a perfect world, we should share the values of the Grand Old Man rather than his own. What Gladstone was saying, in a rather elaborate way, was that trying hard to do anything is good for you, even when there is no chance of you succeeding. Indeed, the effect on your character of the effort of trying is far more important than success would be. This is quite different from saying, "If at first you don't succeed, try, try again", which still has success as the objective. Gladstone didn't even want you to succeed; he wanted you to try for the sake of trying.

This is a very odd concept in the modern world, which values success more highly than anything. The worst thing you can be is a loser. To try and try and not succeed is regarded as pitiful and absurd. That is why Harold Stassen, who died last weekend at the age of 93, suffered so much mockery in the US. He was famous for having run for president nine times, usually with failure guaranteed in advance.

His first attempt was in 1948; his last was in 1992. Even that wasn't the end of it. In 1996, aged 89, he proposed himself to 72-year-old Bob Dole as his vice-presidential running mate, suggesting that he might make the ageing Republican candidate look young by comparison. And in 1998, aged 91, he tried, in a doomed final throw, to be accepted as a candidate for the governorship of Minnesota, his home state.

Stassen was a curious, driven fellow. He was reputed to have almost no sense of humour, apart from reportedly once laughing at a cartoon showing all his political supporters convening in a telephone box. But it must be conceded that he was one of the rare people in public life who have cheerfully fought election after election completely undaunted by the prospect of defeat. But unlike Screaming Lord Sutch and his ilk, Stassen was no oddball. He was, in fact, an extremely successful man. Only his apparently obsessive pursuit of the presidency provoked derision in his obituaries.

Born in Minnesota of Scandinavian descent, Stassen had already started a brilliant, lifelong career in the law before being elected district attorney for Dakota County, Minnesota, at the age of 23 and making headlines by arresting criminals on horseback. At 31, he became governor of Minnesota, the youngest of any state in American history. In that job, he rooted out corruption, reformed the labour laws and introduced a black officer to Minnesota's National Guard - an amazing thing to have done in the prewar era.

Twice re-elected to the governorship, and frequently described as the "boy wonder" of the Republican party, Stassen left politics to serve in the navy during the war. But soon after returning home, heavily decorated, he began his series of unsuccessful campaigns for his party's presidential nomination. His best chance, in 1952, was ruined by Eisenhower entering the race, and Stassen then served for five years in the Eisenhower administration, partly as a disarmament negotiator with the Russians. His presidential hopes then suffered a fatal blow in 1956 when he tried to get Richard Nixon removed from Eisenhower's re-election ticket. After the Watergate debacle, nearly 20 years later, Stassen said, "My biggest disappointment was that I was not able to save the country from the tragedy of Richard Nixon's candidacy. I tried, you know."

But was he not also disappointed by the repeated failure of his presidential bids? Not at all. He felt it was his responsibility to run, he said, because he knew what needed to be done. "To me, the election in itself has never been the important thing. What are more important are the forces you set in motion, the discussion and the debate you generate." He was contemptuous of politicians who depended on their "so-called image staff" for planning their campaigns, and of those who tailored their views to what "an uninformed public" told the opinion pollsters. As for defeat, he said, "It keeps you humble."

After his ninth and final presidential bid in 1992, Stassen summed himself up: "It's really been a winning life," said the man dubbed "the Grand Old Party's grand old loser". Tony Blair and Peter Mandelson might be puzzled by this claim, but the Grand Old Man would have known what he meant.

fields.headline: Destiny's children
fields.standfirst: Refugee children who make their way to the UK on their own have often survived appalling trauma and yet go on, given half a chance, to recover and prosper. But, Melanie MacFadyean discovers, care for them is haphazard and sometimes harsh and neglectful.
fields.trailText: Refugee children who make their way to the UK on their own have often survived appalling trauma and yet go on, given half a chance, to recover and prosper. But, Melanie MacFadyean discovers, care for them is haphazard and sometimes harsh and neglectful.
fields.body:
'If we are in politics for one thing - it is to make sure that all children are given the best chance in life.'

Tony Blair, 1999 Labour party conference

Why would any child abandon family, home, country? Why go into exile? What child would choose dispossession? Amazingly, there are 100,000 children living separated from their parents in Europe, children who have escaped from war, torture, bombs and mines. Do we do right by these children when they arrive in the UK alone - as they do in increasing numbers? What kind of a welcome do they get?

Kannan was 13 when he arrived in the UK from Sri Lanka. Dumped in a British port at dawn after a long and terrifying journey, he emerged from a container truck wondering where he was. Four other Tamils had been in the container, too, all shoved into metal boxes. One of them managed to ask a man in uniform where they were. He replied, "Japan, mate - where do you think?" Then Kannan saw a Union Jack and worked it out.

His eyes are too haunted, too dark for a 14-year-old. As he speaks, he holds a Hindu prayer leaflet tenderly in his hands - it was a present from his mother, and is the only possession he has left from his childhood. He always carries it with him, and sleeps with it under his pillow.

One afternoon 18 months ago, he returned home from school in his village to find neighbours gathered around his door. They tried to stop him going into the house, warning him that the army was looking for him and would kill him. "They told me to run for my life," he says, "but I forced my way in." What he saw returns to him in flashbacks. His mother was dead - she had been shot - his elder sister had been raped and shot, and his 18-month-old sister strangled. He's not sure who murdered them, but his father, under threat of death to himself and his family, had been made to drive a truck for the Tamil Tigers. The night before the rest of his family was butchered, Kannan's father died when his truck was blown up. The family didn't know that as they sat up all night waiting for him.

"People in the community took me and my seven-year-old sister, who had also been at school that day, secretly in a boat to a faraway jungle area where we would be safe," says Kannan. He made a hut with leaves, and traders from stalls along a lonely highway gave him food. Four months later, his sister got typhoid and, with no access to medical help, he had no choice but to watch her die. The highway traders helped him cremate her. Kannan finds it almost unbearable to talk of his sister and tries not to weep as a panel member from the Refugee Council, the main charity assisting refugees, translates for him. He says it is thanks to her he has not gone mad.

The Tamil Tigers found him, threatened to kill him, tied his hands and bundled him into a truck. They shaved his head and his eyebrows, so that if he tried to run away he would be easily recognisable, then trained him and forced him into battle. Young boys were used on the front line to protect the more experienced fighters. Kannan was wounded and sent to the capital, Colombo, to distribute propaganda and do what he calls "risky jobs". In desperation, he decided to go on the run in search of some distant relatives, who he thought lived a few miles away. He ran a long way under cover of night until he reached their home. His relatives kept him hidden from the Tigers, and arranged for him to be flown to safety by one of the agents operating travel scams and supplying false papers for refugees, selling some of their land to meet the agent's fee.

Kannan's journey was terrifying. After a 15-hour flight, landing he had no idea where, he was handed over to two white men. "They locked me in a room with bread and water for three days and threatened me," he says. "I was crying, I feared the future." On the third night, they took him to a deserted car park and ordered him to get into a dark container. Playing for time, he said he was thirsty. "They gave me Coca-Cola, then I felt strange and passed out." He had been drugged and came round many hours later, crammed into a barely ventilated steel box. Hearing the murmur of voices, he struggled out to find the four other Tamils. They talked about running away, but since they had no idea where they were, this idea seemed futile. It was then that they were helpfully told they were in Japan. They spent that first night in the UK in jail; the next day some relatives came to meet the others. Kannan was taken to foster carers, who were kind but did not speak Tamil, and he wandered around their house weeping inconsolably.

Since then, Kannan has been well cared for by social services and has now been taken in by Tamils, but he doesn't want to reveal where he lives because, he says, the Tigers are everywhere. He had been here for 10 months when I met him, but he wasn't yet in school. He was frightened to go out, venturing no further than a local temple. "I am grateful to those who have taken me in, grateful to this country for accommodating me," he says. He speaks softly, as though fearing the sound of his own voice.

A phrase people working with such children often use is that they don't have a voice. In the case of Tamara, a 15-year-old from eastern Europe, this was literally true: when she arrived in the UK in November 1997, she was mute. But, because she was with her sister, who was 18, she was deemed to be accompanied by an adult. Both had been tortured, both were traumatised.

On their first night in the UK, the sisters stayed in a transit lounge. "It was very cold; they gave us a chocolate biscuit," Tamara remembers. The next day, they were taken to a hostel that was full of male drug addicts and alcoholics. Tamara couldn't leave their room alone, and when she did so with her sister, they encountered the clientele, sometimes semi-clothed, usually out of their heads, hanging about on the staircase and landings. On one occasion, a man exposed himself to her. "Sometimes they came into our room asking for tea and sugar, they were lurching, we were very frightened." The first time she went outside, a man kerb-crawled them. The hostel was in a suburban red light area. Local authority officials classified Tamara as not alone; on the other hand, she and her sister did not qualify as a family, eligible for other accommodation.

Tamara had the good fortune to be referred to principal child and adolescent psychotherapist Sheila Melzak at the Medical Foundation for the Victims of Torture. At first, she would curl up in Melzak's office and cry. She wanted to die. It was 10 months before she spoke, having previously communicated through drawings and poems expressing suicidal feelings. She has come through, learned English, flourished at school, and is now doing well at college. Had it not been for the voluntary agencies who helped her, among them the Medical Foundation, it is questionable whether she would have survived at all.

Melzak sees children from all over the world who have been tortured, bereaved, abandoned. They come from places of conflict and poverty, sent here by parents, family or friends who scrape up agents' fees to spirit them away from life-threatening situations. They come from Iraq, Sri Lanka, Angola, Nigeria, Afghanistan, Kosovo, Sierra Leone. They are children first, refugees second, but the authorities in the UK, says Melzak, do not recognise that. "These children's vulnerability is compounded by their experience of violence. They come from cultures in whichthey would not be expected to live alone, they would live at home until they get married. And yet there is an assumption, by the authorities in the UK, that because they get here alone, they are capable of independent living. That is simply not the case."

Earlier this year, the Audit Commission reported that "it is routine for some boroughs to place new arrivals in unsupported temporary accommodation - 41% of unaccompanied children in the care of London boroughs (at October 1999) were housed in bed-and-breakfast accommodation, hotels or hotel annexes, including some children aged 15 or under".

It is not only lone refugee children who are put in B&Bs; indigenous children are, too, according to both the Department of Health and the Association of Local Government(ALG). ALG says, "It is all part of a very carefully worked out, detailed process. This is the same for all children, regardless of where they were born." Really?

Responsibility for the care of refugee children arriving alone - known either as unaccompanied minors or separated children - lies with social services departments. The children are covered, as are UK-born children, by the Children Act - under Section 20 or Section 17. Under Section 20, a child is deemed to be "looked after", and the local authority has a "duty to safeguard and promote the safety of the child". The child is fostered or accommodated in a children's home, and kept track of after their 18th birthday. When necessary, this can be extended into young adulthood.

But the 3,350 separated children who arrived in the UK last year will mostly be dealt with under Section 17, which, for many of them, means empty days and lonely nights in B&B hotels with little or no back-up from overstretched social services departments.

Social services funding for these unaccompanied children comes from the Department of Health. The Guardian put the question of whether B&B accommodation is suitable for such children to John Hutton, health minister with responsibility for social care. His reply was, "We do recognise that some councils find it difficult to find suitable placements."

Authorities in receipt of government top-up grants for refugees get £500 a week for children up to 16 and £300 post-16. The costs of looking after indigenous children in similar circumstances are often more than double that amount. In 1999/2000, the estimated national shortfall between expenditure and the grant was £3m, leaving the local authorities with the task of topping up the top-up grants.

As a result of these limitations, once they reach 18, these young people are truly on their own. The first time I visited her at the Medical Foundation, Melzak was on the phone to a local authority asylum worker. They were talking about a distressed refugee who, having turned 18, was no longer classified a child, despite his problems. "My client has been put in a room near a railway line," Melzak said to a voice down the line. "He cannot sleep because he was tortured, he has terrible nightmares. Why did you move him from the hostel where he had settled in?" She paused, staring at the ceiling as though it might give her patience. "He was happy there - yes, I know he turned 18, yes, I know you have given him another room, but that is also right beside a railway line."

The client in question, a gentle, willowy boy, arrived here from a Middle Eastern country where, aged 16, he had been imprisoned for two months, during which time he was frequently beaten while being interrogated about his family's politics. His father was in jail and his mother in hiding. An uncle spirited him out of the country. His first months in the UK were very strange, but he liked the people running the central London hostel where he was living, and at least he was getting £35 worth of vouchers per week.

Those were the good old days. When he turned 18, he was told to leave the hostel and offered first one and then another room by the railway line. Every 10 days or so, the landlord delivered a consignment of frozen food - sausage in gravy, fish cakes, chips, peas - and sliced bread. He had neither cash nor vouchers. "I feel safe for the life," he told Melzak, "but not for the peace of mind." He has now been allotted a room away from the railway, and is once more receiving vouchers.

The local authority in question just happens to have been Lambeth, but could just as easily have been one of any number in the UK, says Melzak. None of the 95 or so unaccompanied 16-17-year-olds in Lambeth's care is on Section 20, a spokesman explained.

Melzak says that the way these children are dealt with by social services is "utterly random". Kieran Breen, assistant programme director of Save the Children Fund, agrees: "It's an idiosyncratic jigsaw of ad hoc practice; how they are treated depends who's on duty and where a child comes in. It's down to individual social workers even within boroughs, and that determines the outcome. It's not just refugees who get bad delivery of services, it's abused children generally. The choice between sections 17 and 20 of the Children Act has become a national lottery." Only one borough in the UK, West Sussex social services, automatically takes separated children under Section 20, the "cared for" category of the Children Act.

It's hard to imagine what the soulless acres of airport transit corridors and lounges look like to a terrified solitary child inching towards the immigration desk, waiting in line with a beating heart. Some wander around before being noticed by a cleaner or, perhaps, by airport surveillance. Olu arrived in the UK at 14, clutching one small bag. She had never been out of Nigeria before, she had never been on a plane and she had certainly never walked alone through the grey zones of airport transit. It was an arrival that compounded the fears she hoped she had left behind.

Haltingly, Olu tells the fragmented story of her childhood. The trouble began when her father was forced to join some kind of cult. "Before you join, you have to make a sacrifice, they take part of your body and eat it," she says. He was murdered - she remembers when her family found his body. "He was in a mortuary, his head split in two. We embalmed him and took him home to bury him, but the cult went to his grave and took part of his body." The cult - perhaps a criminal gang, perhaps a rival tribe - came back. They raped Olu, her sisters and her mother. Wherever they fled, their attackers pursued them, and so the family split up in order to survive. Olu went on the run, sleeping rough for three nights until she found a friend of her father's, who gave her an air ticket and a forged passport. He told her not to tell immigration her real age, but to try and seem older. It was a bad mistake.

She was frightened on the plane, and cold, because she had no coat. "I felt as if everybody was looking at me," she says. She had been told that an "auntie" would meet her at Heathrow, identifiable by a sign with Olu's name written on it.

When she got to the end of her nervous walk through the grey zones, she stood in line until she got to the immigration desk. An officer asked her where she was going, she replied that she was going to meet her auntie. Her bag was searched, and she was taken to what she describes as an "alcove" by two female officials who strip searched her. She was then left in a waiting room and, at around 2am, informed that she would be searched again, and led to a room where she was told to take off her clothes. A female doctor was present and Olu was x-rayed for drugs they suspected she was carrying internally. Then she was given a green robe and the doctor examined her, including, she says, giving her an internal vaginal examination. "I was crying," she says. "So was one of the lady officers." Olu was told that this was routine procedure for drug suspects. She says that she was not interviewed or asked any relevant questions before the search began, and that she did not tell them she was only 14, as the man in Nigeria had told her not to.

The day after her examination, she says she was interviewed, which was when she revealed her real age. An immigration officer at Gatwick told me that only she and one other at the airport had any special training for dealing with unaccompanied refugee children.

Olu was taken from the airport to Campsfield House, a detention centre for refugees near Oxford. The Refugee Council has an agreement with the immigration service that it will notify them of unaccompanied minors. In Olu's case, this contact was not made for about four weeks, and she spent six weeks in total at Campsfield, feeling suicidal, before the Refugee Council and social services managed to get her out. She then went to live with a foster family, of whom she speaks very warmly, and is now living happily in a shared flat.

A list of questions was sent by the Guardian to Barbara Roche, the minister in charge of immigration for the Home Office, and to John Hutton, at the Department of Health. A spokesperson answered unequivocally on Roche's behalf: "Unaccompanied children are never detained in prisons." But in July last year, Roche said, "Unaccompanied children should never be detained other than in the most exceptional circumstances, and then only overnight with appropriate care if they, for example, arrive alone at an airport." However, Terry Smith, head of the children's section of the Refugee Council, says that their records for the past five years show that they had 210 children referred to them, who claimed to be under 18, and who had been held in detention, some of them as young as 14. And, according to an Amnesty International report published in May 1999, between January 1997 and June 1998, 76 unaccompanied refugee children had been detained, "some in young offenders institutions and even in adult prisons". Amnesty cited one case of a 14-year-old Nigerian girl held in Holloway.

During a very brief telephone interview with Roche, when this apparent contradiction was put to her, she indicated that she would like to see the Amnesty data. The same questions about detention were put to Hutton, who replied, "We have no evidence that children are being held in detention, and would welcome any further details so that this can be looked into."

Even more sinister than the detentions is the unknown number of child refugees disappearing in suspicious circumstances. West Sussex social services, the area that covers Gatwick Airport, is among the best in the country in relation to its treatment of separated children. Yet a total of 71 child asylum seekers - the majority of them girls from poor Nigerian families - disappeared from its care between October 1995 and December 2000.

So far, only two of the missing children have been found, and nobody knows the fate of the others. Police conclude that most have been taken by traffickers for prostitution, forced domestic labour and crime, a trade worth an estimated $7bn globally. Prosecution of traffickers is difficult, because of the absence of anti-trafficking laws in the UK and most of Europe, and because the young people - the witnesses - are too scared to pass on information, let alone testify. Many have been threatened that their families will die if anything is revealed. So far, no trafficker has been successfully prosecuted in this country.

Detective Superintendent David Gaylor has worked on the West Sussex cases. "We feel neutered and disempowered," he says. "We have struggled to influence anyone at a high enough level to make a difference and nobody is looking at the potential scale of it. Initially, when we raised some specific issues with the Home Office in 1999, they replied in so many words that it wasn't their problem, that social services shouldn't lose these people. We have since then had some response from Barbara Roche, but there's still a long way to go. I hope the Home Office will now strive for European and international liaison, because one small police force and social services department in the south of England isn't going to change the price of fish on their own. I am sorry to say it may be one of those cases where not enough notice will be taken until there is a death and then social services will get the blame. We are saying don't wait for that tragedy."

Suspicion of asylum seekers and refugees is often fuelled by xenophobic comments by politicians and public figures, and it is underpinned by a high level of ignorance. A recent Mori poll found that many respondents believed that refugees received £113 a week - the truth is, they get around £35 in vouchers, to be used at specific shops; they believed that 20% of the current UK population is made up of immigrants - the figure is 4%; they thought 27% of the population belonged to an ethnic minority - the figure is 7%.

The Sun made its position absolutely clear: "It's awful that any youngster feels desperate enough to leave his or her home... but... sentiment leads to detriment for British-born children."

Hopefully, the 20-year-old Afghan in Birmingham with whom I spoke didn't see that particular comment, or the headline "Ungrateful Afghans are welcome - to go home". A quietly spoken, achingly polite young man, he fled from the Taliban aged 16 and, on a long, dangerous journey, got lost in a remote region of the Commonwealth of Independent States; he is too frightened to say where. Arrested because he had no travel documents, he was thrown into jail. Jail was a narrow room with 44 other people, almost all adult men - "Criminals, Mafiosos, rapists, killers," he says. They slept in rotas because there were only bunks for 20. They were all stripped to their underpants. He witnessed the gang rape of the only other teenager. The young Afghan had never told anyone this story before, but wants people to know the depths of cruelty to which separated children are subject. Ungrateful? No, he's very grateful. Go home? He would love to, but he would be killed.

The problem for Tony, a 19-year-old Kosovan, is that the home where he might once have returned was ransacked after his family was forced to flee to a refugee camp in Macedonia. Someone else has moved into the family's flat - going "home" would involve a bitter and dangerous conflict. Tony arrived in the UK on May 5, 1998. He was just 17.

He was smuggled out of the country by an agent to whom Tony's father had paid the higher going rate of about £2,500, because the cheaper rate, about half that amount, gives no guarantees of survival. Tony has now settled, has a flat and has done well in his first year at university studying computer science. His mother and 12-year-old sister joined him recently, his father having died of a heart attack brought on by the stress of the war. When it looked as if the family would be dispersed under current UK policy, Tony went to war. In his only lapse from fluent English, he said, "I fought like a lion and bored their heads!" It didn't go down well with the local authority - asylum seekers are expected to be grateful for any crumbs they receive - but it worked. With help from Nick Hardwick, director of the Refugee Council, Tony and his family are now settled together.

Under the 1951 UN Refugee Convention, the UK is obliged to grant protection to children, as well as to adults, who are at risk of persecution in their own country due to race, religion, nationality, political opinion or membership of a social group. Under the UN Convention against Torture, the UK cannot return anyone to a country where they might suffer torture or ill-treatment. However, the UK entered reservations to clauses of the 1989 UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, refusing to be bound, as Amnesty International put it, "to ensure that a refugee child receives appropriate protection and humanitarian assistance in the enjoyment of its rights".

Separated children are seven times less likely to receive refugee status than those in their 20s. Most of those granted it can prove they will suffer political persecution if forced to return. Even so, children are rarely, if ever deported, or "removed", to use a Home Office euphemism. But it does happen, accordingto a Refugee Council panel member, in cases where the asylum seeker's age is disputed. So how do officials determine whether someone is giving the right date of birth? "There's no special training given for this," explains an asylum screening unit spokesman, "so, in an age dispute, if an officer is challenged, a supervisor is called. It comes down to the view of the person interviewing with the supervisor checking." Checking, says a Refugee Council panel member, consists of staring.

One young man who has been through the removal procedure is Inka Oshodi, originally from Surinam. Oshodi, now 20, has been here for nine years. More than three years ago, he applied for asylum. When he was 11, Oshodi's parents brought him to the UK, leaving him temporarily with an aunt. His parents were killed in a car crash shortly afterwards, and his aunt threw him out. He left, aged 12, with nothing but the clothes he wore, and wandered around Brixton unnoticed, save by a man who offered him drugs. He slept on the street. Like someone from a fairytale, the next day a young man took Oshodi home to his mother who, having overcome her initial shock, took the child in. Oshodi spent the next four years with the family, who treated him like a son, working in their shop, but never attending school.

Impenetrable bureaucracies prevented Oshodi's new family from securing him any documents, however. So when, at 16, he met some older people hanging out in Trafalgar Square who said they could get him a passport, he gave them his earnings. Unknown to him, they used the passport to open a bank account that was used fraudulently. Oshodi was arrested, but the charges were dropped immediately. He was nevertheless taken to Campsfield House as an illegal immigrant. During the three months he spent there, he turned 17, and soon after two attempts were made to "remove" him.

The first time he was taken to Gatwick and told he was going to Nigeria. "I said, 'I've never been to Nigeria! I'm not from Nigeria, I'm not going there!'" They escorted him to a plane. "They tried to put me in a seat," he says, "I said, 'I want to see the pilot,' I was very upset and threw the tea trolley. The pilot said, 'I'm not taking that boy.' He asked me where I was from and I said Surinam. Meanwhile, the security guys were trying to force me into the seat. I fought them and then I had an asthma attack and ended up in hospital." He spent three days in the hospital wing of another detention centre. They tried once again to "remove" him. "The immigration officers said I was going to Surinam. I said there was nobody there to receive me, the law says there has to be someone checked out by the authorities here to meet a minor being deported."

This time, when asked for his passport by an airline official before embarkation, he replied he didn't have one, whereupon she refused to allow him on the plane.

Oshodi was returned to Campsfield and eventually, with help from the Refugee Council, his lawyer and social worker, he got out. Enrolled at an FE college since 1997, he is currently doing A-levels and aims to go to university. This country is Oshodi's home - he has lived here almost as long as he lived in Surinam. His immigration status was finally resolved as we went to press; it took five years. It was still unresolved when he bravely spoke at a Labour party fringe meeting organised by young separated child refugees, backed by several charities. Labour MP Tom Levitt, parliamentary private secretary to Barbara Roche, sat on the panel as Oshodi and three others gave stirring accounts of their experiences.

After Oshodi spoke, Trevor Phillips, chairman of the Greater London Authority, said passionately, "We need to rock the boat... Our policies have gone off the rails because they are driven by political imperatives from somewhere else. We know the way we treat refugees is not decent, not fair, not right. We've got to get honest here, and I'm right off-message already. Vouchers, for example, send all the wrong messages. Nobody who aspires to Labour values could tolerate it in our society, it's wrong, it's wrong, it's wrong."

In his speech, Levitt rattled through the immigration problems that New Labour "inherited" from the Tories, before turning to the question of beggars. He complained of people begging on the tube with babies "drugged up to the eyeballs on Calpol". He praised the National Asylum Seekers Service (Nass) and landlords from whom accommodation was being rented. He added, "Vouchers protect asylum seekers against exploitation from protection rackets and the shops are training their staff so there are no unfortunate incidents, and if there are, I want to know about them."

The Home Office recently set up a working group on the question of unaccompanied asylum seeking children. In a letter - seen by the Guardian - which was sent to working group guests at the end of December last year, Kathy Casey of the Asylum Appeals Policy Directorate, wrote of new approaches to policy, costs and processes which would produce "fair outcomes for individuals".

Casey went on to say that new directives include suggestions that asylum applicants only be accepted if they can produce evidence of their age or if "their appearance clearly supports the age claimed". How does an immigration officer establish age in a young person of a culture about which he or she knows very little? These children arrive either with forged documents or no documents - how can they "provide evidence" of their ages?

Casey's list of aims continues with plans to "eliminate the incentives which attract unaccompanied children", and "reduce the potential growth in spending". In order to prevent them from settling once they are here, Casey suggests that "where there is no prospect of safe return, exceptional leave to remain may be granted to unaccompanied children for four years or until their 18th birthday".

It becomes clear why these children are almost never granted refugee status - at 18 anyone can be deported, under 18 there are nigh on impossible protective measures which have to be met before a child can be returned. Casey writes that the Home Office seeks "to enforce the removal of the unaccompanied asylum seeking children who have been refused asylum and who have no other basis to stay in the UK when they reach 18".

The odds are so stacked against these young people that their determination, dignity and pride in the face of obstruction are very impressive. All whom I met were studying or, like Kannan, struggling to get into school, a vital element if a child is to feel included in any society. And yet, according to the Refugee Council, 1,400 asylum-seeking children have no school places. Many come from stable, loving families, and when the impact of trauma is mediated by good experiences before and after the trauma, says Sheila Melzak, their chances of achieving peace of mind are increased.

Arturo Correia and Joshua Salo are two who have experienced trauma and violence, but have found help since. Correia, an Angolan, was 14 in 1994 when bombs started falling as he sat in his classroom. He never went home again and knows nothing of his family's fate. He was flown to a Red Cross camp in Luanda with his brother and the other kids from their school. He and his brother were befriended by a Frenchman who worked for an aid agency. He got them passports, air tickets to the UK and gave them $600. The $600 was stolen before they reached the UK. "We asked the cabin crew where to go when the plane landed, but they couldn't help us," says Correia. "Luckily, someone took us to a Red Cross lady who spoke Portuguese." It was she who interviewed them.

Correia and his brother were taken to a foster family, who were very kind, and whose teenage children managed to communicate with

Tony Blair, 1999 Labour party conference Why would any child abandon family, home, country? Why go into exile? What child would choose dispossession? Amazingly, there are 100,000 children living separated from their parents in Europe, children who have escaped from war, torture, bombs and mines.
