A phrase people working with such children often use is that they don't have a voice. In the case of Tamara, a 15-year-old from eastern Europe, this was literally true: when she arrived in the UK in November 1997, she was mute. But, because she was with her sister, who was 18, she was deemed to be accompanied by an adult. Both had been tortured, both were traumatised. On their first night in the UK, the sisters stayed in a transit lounge. "It was very cold; they gave us a chocolate biscuit," Tamara remembers. The next day, they were taken to a hostel that was full of male drug addicts and alcoholics. Tamara couldn't leave their room alone, and when she did so with her sister, they encountered the clientele, sometimes semi-clothed, usually out of their heads, hanging about on the staircase and landings. On one occasion, a man exposed himself to her. "Sometimes they came into our room asking for tea and sugar, they were lurching, we were very frightened." The first time she went outside, a man kerb-crawled them. The hostel was in a suburban red light area. Local authority officials classified Tamara as not alone; on the other hand, she and her sister did not qualify as a family, eligible for other accommodation. Tamara had the good fortune to be referred to principal child and adolescent psychotherapist Sheila Melzak at the Medical Foundation for the Victims of Torture. At first, she would curl up in Melzak's office and cry. She wanted to die. It was 10 months before she spoke, having previously communicated through drawings and poems expressing suicidal feelings. She has come through, learned English, flourished at school, and is now doing well at college. Had it not been for the voluntary agencies who helped her, among them the Medical Foundation, it is questionable whether she would have survived at all. Melzak sees children from all over the world who have been tortured, bereaved, abandoned. They come from places of conflict and poverty, sent here by parents, family or friends who scrape up agents' fees to spirit them away from life-threatening situations. They come from Iraq, Sri Lanka, Angola, Nigeria, Afghanistan, Kosovo, Sierra Leone. They are children first, refugees second, but the authorities in the UK, says Melzak, do not recognise that. "These children's vulnerability is compounded by their experience of violence. They come from cultures in whichthey would not be expected to live alone, they would live at home until they get married. And yet there is an assumption, by the authorities in the UK, that because they get here alone, they are capable of independent living. That is simply not the case." Earlier this year, the Audit Commission reported that "it is routine for some boroughs to place new arrivals in unsupported temporary accommodation - 41% of unaccompanied children in the care of London boroughs (at October 1999) were housed in bed-and-breakfast accommodation, hotels or hotel annexes, including some children aged 15 or under". It is not only lone refugee children who are put in B&Bs; indigenous children are, too, according to both the Department of Health and the Association of Local Government(ALG). ALG says, "It is all part of a very carefully worked out, detailed process. This is the same for all children, regardless of where they were born." Really? Responsibility for the care of refugee children arriving alone - known either as unaccompanied minors or separated children - lies with social services departments. The children are covered, as are UK-born children, by the Children Act - under Section 20 or Section 17. Under Section 20, a child is deemed to be "looked after", and the local authority has a "duty to safeguard and promote the safety of the child". The child is fostered or accommodated in a children's home, and kept track of after their 18th birthday. When necessary, this can be extended into young adulthood. But the 3,350 separated children who arrived in the UK last year will mostly be dealt with under Section 17, which, for many of them, means empty days and lonely nights in B&B hotels with little or no back-up from overstretched social services departments. Social services funding for these unaccompanied children comes from the Department of Health. The Guardian put the question of whether B&B accommodation is suitable for such children to John Hutton, health minister with responsibility for social care. His reply was, "We do recognise that some councils find it difficult to find suitable placements." Authorities in receipt of government top-up grants for refugees get £500 a week for children up to 16 and £300 post-16. The costs of looking after indigenous children in similar circumstances are often more than double that amount. In 1999/2000, the estimated national shortfall between expenditure and the grant was £3m, leaving the local authorities with the task of topping up the top-up grants. As a result of these limitations, once they reach 18, these young people are truly on their own. The first time I visited her at the Medical Foundation, Melzak was on the phone to a local authority asylum worker. They were talking about a distressed refugee who, having turned 18, was no longer classified a child, despite his problems. "My client has been put in a room near a railway line," Melzak said to a voice down the line. "He cannot sleep because he was tortured, he has terrible nightmares. Why did you move him from the hostel where he had settled in?" She paused, staring at the ceiling as though it might give her patience. "He was happy there - yes, I know he turned 18, yes, I know you have given him another room, but that is also right beside a railway line." The client in question, a gentle, willowy boy, arrived here from a Middle Eastern country where, aged 16, he had been imprisoned for two months, during which time he was frequently beaten while being interrogated about his family's politics. His father was in jail and his mother in hiding. An uncle spirited him out of the country. His first months in the UK were very strange, but he liked the people running the central London hostel where he was living, and at least he was getting £35 worth of vouchers per week. Those were the good old days. When he turned 18, he was told to leave the hostel and offered first one and then another room by the railway line. Every 10 days or so, the landlord delivered a consignment of frozen food - sausage in gravy, fish cakes, chips, peas - and sliced bread. He had neither cash nor vouchers. "I feel safe for the life," he told Melzak, "but not for the peace of mind." He has now been allotted a room away from the railway, and is once more receiving vouchers. The local authority in question just happens to have been Lambeth, but could just as easily have been one of any number in the UK, says Melzak. None of the 95 or so unaccompanied 16-17-year-olds in Lambeth's care is on Section 20, a spokesman explained. Melzak says that the way these children are dealt with by social services is "utterly random". Kieran Breen, assistant programme director of Save the Children Fund, agrees: "It's an idiosyncratic jigsaw of ad hoc practice; how they are treated depends who's on duty and where a child comes in. It's down to individual social workers even within boroughs, and that determines the outcome. It's not just refugees who get bad delivery of services, it's abused children generally. The choice between sections 17 and 20 of the Children Act has become a national lottery." Only one borough in the UK, West Sussex social services, automatically takes separated children under Section 20, the "cared for" category of the Children Act. It's hard to imagine what the soulless acres of airport transit corridors and lounges look like to a terrified solitary child inching towards the immigration desk, waiting in line with a beating heart. Some wander around before being noticed by a cleaner or, perhaps, by airport surveillance. Olu arrived in the UK at 14, clutching one small bag. She had never been out of Nigeria before, she had never been on a plane and she had certainly never walked alone through the grey zones of airport transit. It was an arrival that compounded the fears she hoped she had left behind. Haltingly, Olu tells the fragmented story of her childhood. The trouble began when her father was forced to join some kind of cult. "Before you join, you have to make a sacrifice, they take part of your body and eat it," she says. He was murdered - she remembers when her family found his body. "He was in a mortuary, his head split in two. We embalmed him and took him home to bury him, but the cult went to his grave and took part of his body." The cult - perhaps a criminal gang, perhaps a rival tribe - came back. They raped Olu, her sisters and her mother. Wherever they fled, their attackers pursued them, and so the family split up in order to survive. Olu went on the run, sleeping rough for three nights until she found a friend of her father's, who gave her an air ticket and a forged passport. He told her not to tell immigration her real age, but to try and seem older. It was a bad mistake. She was frightened on the plane, and cold, because she had no coat. "I felt as if everybody was looking at me," she says. She had been told that an "auntie" would meet her at Heathrow, identifiable by a sign with Olu's name written on it. When she got to the end of her nervous walk through the grey zones, she stood in line until she got to the immigration desk. An officer asked her where she was going, she replied that she was going to meet her auntie. Her bag was searched, and she was taken to what she describes as an "alcove" by two female officials who strip searched her. She was then left in a waiting room and, at around 2am, informed that she would be searched again, and led to a room where she was told to take off her clothes. A female doctor was present and Olu was x-rayed for drugs they suspected she was carrying internally. Then she was given a green robe and the doctor examined her, including, she says, giving her an internal vaginal examination. "I was crying," she says. "So was one of the lady officers." Olu was told that this was routine procedure for drug suspects. She says that she was not interviewed or asked any relevant questions before the search began, and that she did not tell them she was only 14, as the man in Nigeria had told her not to. The day after her examination, she says she was interviewed, which was when she revealed her real age. An immigration officer at Gatwick told me that only she and one other at the airport had any special training for dealing with unaccompanied refugee children. Olu was taken from the airport to Campsfield House, a detention centre for refugees near Oxford. The Refugee Council has an agreement with the immigration service that it will notify them of unaccompanied minors. In Olu's case, this contact was not made for about four weeks, and she spent six weeks in total at Campsfield, feeling suicidal, before the Refugee Council and social services managed to get her out. She then went to live with a foster family, of whom she speaks very warmly, and is now living happily in a shared flat. A list of questions was sent by the Guardian to Barbara Roche, the minister in charge of immigration for the Home Office, and to John Hutton, at the Department of Health. A spokesperson answered unequivocally on Roche's behalf: "Unaccompanied children are never detained in prisons." But in July last year, Roche said, "Unaccompanied children should never be detained other than in the most exceptional circumstances, and then only overnight with appropriate care if they, for example, arrive alone at an airport." However, Terry Smith, head of the children's section of the Refugee Council, says that their records for the past five years show that they had 210 children referred to them, who claimed to be under 18, and who had been held in detention, some of them as young as 14. And, according to an Amnesty International report published in May 1999, between January 1997 and June 1998, 76 unaccompanied refugee children had been detained, "some in young offenders institutions and even in adult prisons". Amnesty cited one case of a 14-year-old Nigerian girl held in Holloway. During a very brief telephone interview with Roche, when this apparent contradiction was put to her, she indicated that she would like to see the Amnesty data. The same questions about detention were put to Hutton, who replied, "We have no evidence that children are being held in detention, and would welcome any further details so that this can be looked into." Even more sinister than the detentions is the unknown number of child refugees disappearing in suspicious circumstances. West Sussex social services, the area that covers Gatwick Airport, is among the best in the country in relation to its treatment of separated children. Yet a total of 71 child asylum seekers - the majority of them girls from poor Nigerian families - disappeared from its care between October 1995 and December 2000. So far, only two of the missing children have been found, and nobody knows the fate of the others. Police conclude that most have been taken by traffickers for prostitution, forced domestic labour and crime, a trade worth an estimated $7bn globally. Prosecution of traffickers is difficult, because of the absence of anti-trafficking laws in the UK and most of Europe, and because the young people - the witnesses - are too scared to pass on information, let alone testify. Many have been threatened that their families will die if anything is revealed. So far, no trafficker has been successfully prosecuted in this country. Detective Superintendent David Gaylor has worked on the West Sussex cases. "We feel neutered and disempowered," he says. "We have struggled to influence anyone at a high enough level to make a difference and nobody is looking at the potential scale of it. Initially, when we raised some specific issues with the Home Office in 1999, they replied in so many words that it wasn't their problem, that social services shouldn't lose these people. We have since then had some response from Barbara Roche, but there's still a long way to go. I hope the Home Office will now strive for European and international liaison, because one small police force and social services department in the south of England isn't going to change the price of fish on their own. I am sorry to say it may be one of those cases where not enough notice will be taken until there is a death and then social services will get the blame. We are saying don't wait for that tragedy." Suspicion of asylum seekers and refugees is often fuelled by xenophobic comments by politicians and public figures, and it is underpinned by a high level of ignorance. A recent Mori poll found that many respondents believed that refugees received £113 a week - the truth is, they get around £35 in vouchers, to be used at specific shops; they believed that 20% of the current UK population is made up of immigrants - the figure is 4%; they thought 27% of the population belonged to an ethnic minority - the figure is 7%. The Sun made its position absolutely clear: "It's awful that any youngster feels desperate enough to leave his or her home... but... sentiment leads to detriment for British-born children." Hopefully, the 20-year-old Afghan in Birmingham with whom I spoke didn't see that particular comment, or the headline "Ungrateful Afghans are welcome - to go home". A quietly spoken, achingly polite young man, he fled from the Taliban aged 16 and, on a long, dangerous journey, got lost in a remote region of the Commonwealth of Independent States; he is too frightened to say where. Arrested because he had no travel documents, he was thrown into jail. Jail was a narrow room with 44 other people, almost all adult men - "Criminals, Mafiosos, rapists, killers," he says. They slept in rotas because there were only bunks for 20. They were all stripped to their underpants. He witnessed the gang rape of the only other teenager. The young Afghan had never told anyone this story before, but wants people to know the depths of cruelty to which separated children are subject. Ungrateful? No, he's very grateful. Go home? He would love to, but he would be killed. The problem for Tony, a 19-year-old Kosovan, is that the home where he might once have returned was ransacked after his family was forced to flee to a refugee camp in Macedonia. Someone else has moved into the family's flat - going "home" would involve a bitter and dangerous conflict. Tony arrived in the UK on May 5, 1998. He was just 17. He was smuggled out of the country by an agent to whom Tony's father had paid the higher going rate of about £2,500, because the cheaper rate, about half that amount, gives no guarantees of survival. Tony has now settled, has a flat and has done well in his first year at university studying computer science. His mother and 12-year-old sister joined him recently, his father having died of a heart attack brought on by the stress of the war. When it looked as if the family would be dispersed under current UK policy, Tony went to war. In his only lapse from fluent English, he said, "I fought like a lion and bored their heads!" It didn't go down well with the local authority - asylum seekers are expected to be grateful for any crumbs they receive - but it worked. With help from Nick Hardwick, director of the Refugee Council, Tony and his family are now settled together. Under the 1951 UN Refugee Convention, the UK is obliged to grant protection to children, as well as to adults, who are at risk of persecution in their own country due to race, religion, nationality, political opinion or membership of a social group. Under the UN Convention against Torture, the UK cannot return anyone to a country where they might suffer torture or ill-treatment. However, the UK entered reservations to clauses of the 1989 UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, refusing to be bound, as Amnesty International put it, "to ensure that a refugee child receives appropriate protection and humanitarian assistance in the enjoyment of its rights". Separated children are seven times less likely to receive refugee status than those in their 20s. Most of those granted it can prove they will suffer political persecution if forced to return. Even so, children are rarely, if ever deported, or "removed", to use a Home Office euphemism. But it does happen, accordingto a Refugee Council panel member, in cases where the asylum seeker's age is disputed. So how do officials determine whether someone is giving the right date of birth? "There's no special training given for this," explains an asylum screening unit spokesman, "so, in an age dispute, if an officer is challenged, a supervisor is called. It comes down to the view of the person interviewing with the supervisor checking." Checking, says a Refugee Council panel member, consists of staring. One young man who has been through the removal procedure is Inka Oshodi, originally from Surinam. Oshodi, now 20, has been here for nine years. More than three years ago, he applied for asylum. When he was 11, Oshodi's parents brought him to the UK, leaving him temporarily with an aunt. His parents were killed in a car crash shortly afterwards, and his aunt threw him out. He left, aged 12, with nothing but the clothes he wore, and wandered around Brixton unnoticed, save by a man who offered him drugs. He slept on the street. Like someone from a fairytale, the next day a young man took Oshodi home to his mother who, having overcome her initial shock, took the child in. Oshodi spent the next four years with the family, who treated him like a son, working in their shop, but never attending school. Impenetrable bureaucracies prevented Oshodi's new family from securing him any documents, however. So when, at 16, he met some older people hanging out in Trafalgar Square who said they could get him a passport, he gave them his earnings. Unknown to him, they used the passport to open a bank account that was used fraudulently. Oshodi was arrested, but the charges were dropped immediately. He was nevertheless taken to Campsfield House as an illegal immigrant. During the three months he spent there, he turned 17, and soon after two attempts were made to "remove" him. The first time he was taken to Gatwick and told he was going to Nigeria. "I said, 'I've never been to Nigeria! I'm not from Nigeria, I'm not going there!'" They escorted him to a plane. "They tried to put me in a seat," he says, "I said, 'I want to see the pilot,' I was very upset and threw the tea trolley. The pilot said, 'I'm not taking that boy.' He asked me where I was from and I said Surinam. Meanwhile, the security guys were trying to force me into the seat. I fought them and then I had an asthma attack and ended up in hospital." He spent three days in the hospital wing of another detention centre. They tried once again to "remove" him. "The immigration officers said I was going to Surinam. I said there was nobody there to receive me, the law says there has to be someone checked out by the authorities here to meet a minor being deported." This time, when asked for his passport by an airline official before embarkation, he replied he didn't have one, whereupon she refused to allow him on the plane. Oshodi was returned to Campsfield and eventually, with help from the Refugee Council, his lawyer and social worker, he got out. Enrolled at an FE college since 1997, he is currently doing A-levels and aims to go to university. This country is Oshodi's home - he has lived here almost as long as he lived in Surinam. His immigration status was finally resolved as we went to press; it took five years. It was still unresolved when he bravely spoke at a Labour party fringe meeting organised by young separated child refugees, backed by several charities. Labour MP Tom Levitt, parliamentary private secretary to Barbara Roche, sat on the panel as Oshodi and three others gave stirring accounts of their experiences. After Oshodi spoke, Trevor Phillips, chairman of the Greater London Authority, said passionately, "We need to rock the boat... Our policies have gone off the rails because they are driven by political imperatives from somewhere else. We know the way we treat refugees is not decent, not fair, not right. We've got to get honest here, and I'm right off-message already. Vouchers, for example, send all the wrong messages. Nobody who aspires to Labour values could tolerate it in our society, it's wrong, it's wrong, it's wrong." In his speech, Levitt rattled through the immigration problems that New Labour "inherited" from the Tories, before turning to the question of beggars. He complained of people begging on the tube with babies "drugged up to the eyeballs on Calpol". He praised the National Asylum Seekers Service (Nass) and landlords from whom accommodation was being rented. He added, "Vouchers protect asylum seekers against exploitation from protection rackets and the shops are training their staff so there are no unfortunate incidents, and if there are, I want to know about them." The Home Office recently set up a working group on the question of unaccompanied asylum seeking children. In a letter - seen by the Guardian - which was sent to working group guests at the end of December last year, Kathy Casey of the Asylum Appeals Policy Directorate, wrote of new approaches to policy, costs and processes which would produce "fair outcomes for individuals". Casey went on to say that new directives include suggestions that asylum applicants only be accepted if they can produce evidence of their age or if "their appearance clearly supports the age claimed". How does an immigration officer establish age in a young person of a culture about which he or she knows very little? These children arrive either with forged documents or no documents - how can they "provide evidence" of their ages? Casey's list of aims continues with plans to "eliminate the incentives which attract unaccompanied children", and "reduce the potential growth in spending". In order to prevent them from settling once they are here, Casey suggests that "where there is no prospect of safe return, exceptional leave to remain may be granted to unaccompanied children for four years or until their 18th birthday". It becomes clear why these children are almost never granted refugee status - at 18 anyone can be deported, under 18 there are nigh on impossible protective measures which have to be met before a child can be returned. Casey writes that the Home Office seeks "to enforce the removal of the unaccompanied asylum seeking children who have been refused asylum and who have no other basis to stay in the UK when they reach 18". The odds are so stacked against these young people that their determination, dignity and pride in the face of obstruction are very impressive. All whom I met were studying or, like Kannan, struggling to get into school, a vital element if a child is to feel included in any society. And yet, according to the Refugee Council, 1,400 asylum-seeking children have no school places. Many come from stable, loving families, and when the impact of trauma is mediated by good experiences before and after the trauma, says Sheila Melzak, their chances of achieving peace of mind are increased. Arturo Correia and Joshua Salo are two who have experienced trauma and violence, but have found help since. Correia, an Angolan, was 14 in 1994 when bombs started falling as he sat in his classroom. He never went home again and knows nothing of his family's fate. He was flown to a Red Cross camp in Luanda with his brother and the other kids from their school. He and his brother were befriended by a Frenchman who worked for an aid agency. He got them passports, air tickets to the UK and gave them $600. The $600 was stolen before they reached the UK. "We asked the cabin crew where to go when the plane landed, but they couldn't help us," says Correia. "Luckily, someone took us to a Red Cross lady who spoke Portuguese." It was she who interviewed them. Correia and his brother were taken to a foster family, who were very kind, and whose teenage children managed to communicate with

fields.headline: When the good times roll
fields.standfirst: Christian Lacroix is a couturier whose dazzling frou-frou designs are adored by the rich and frivolous. Happily for him, the taste for unashamed glamour is returning. Yet, Jess Cartner-Morley discovers, Lacroix's own designer-hero is Agnès b, a leftist and the queen of tasteful discretion
fields.trailText: Christian Lacroix is a couturier whose dazzling frou-frou designs are adored by the rich and frivolous. Happily for him, the taste for unashamed glamour is returning. Yet, Jess Cartner-Morley discovers, Lacroix's own designer-hero is Agnès b, a leftist and the queen of tasteful discretion
fields.body:
A Christian Lacroix catwalk show is a little like an old-fashioned children's bedtime story brought to life. One where, in the dead of night, everything in the attic dressing-up box - a swathe of ruched raspberry satin, say, a chiffon stole, ballet shoe ribbons, some pompoms, a black lace veil, crystal beads, a garland of midnight blue feathers, a scrap of harlequin print, some ostrich leather - comes alive and unites in an ecstatic dance to create an extraordinary, 4am vision of a party dress. The kind of dress you might find yourself wearing in a particularly surreal dream. Beautiful the clothes may be, staggeringly expensive they certainly are, but there's an engaging whimsy, a wilful madness about them. "I found some photos of cats dyed blue and pink, and of a masked ball in French Africa or French Indochina at the turn of the century," is the best explanation Lacroix can give of his latest haute couture collection.

Lacroix burst on to the fashion scene in the mid-80s in a cloud of puffball skirts and hyperbole. The newspaper France Soir called him "a Messiah". The Guardian called his work "a rallying cry for the liberation of couture". No one since Yves Saint Laurent a quarter of a century earlier had made such an impact, and no single new arrival since has caused such universal excitement.

Yet Lacroix's clothes are not conceptual or challenging in the mould of Issey Miyake or Hussein Chalayan. Neither are they clothes for the Armani and Jil Sander devotees who harness the power of the perfect charcoal jacket to their own ends. Nor do they have the calculated, goal-oriented sexuality of Versace. They are girlish and chichi and frou-frou and flouncy, overflowing with pomp and ceremony. In other words, they are not everyone's cup of tea.

Whatever you think of his clothes, it would be hard to dislike Lacroix himself. Most fashion designers make female visitors from the real world feel immediately ill at ease - too short, too lumpen, too loud. Lacroix, however, does not give the impression that his idea of feminine perfection is a wispy, pencil fashion illustration. The Christian Lacroix who presides over the Rue du Faubourg St Honoré salon looks youthful for 50, with prominent eyebrows and fleshy lips; a cross between a young Orson Welles and Marlon Brando. Dressed in jeans, bright red trainers and a coffee-coloured poloneck, he seems quite disengaged from Christian Lacroix, couturier and dreamer of pink cats.

He is a man at home in the realm of theatre and character: since 1985, he has had a parallel career as a costume designer, and in 1996 won the prestigious Molière award for best costumes for a Comédie Française production of Racine's Phèdre. "When I'm designing fashion, it's as if I have a twin. He's a funny guy and I'm like, what is he doing? I am much more myself in my theatre work." He is at ease with such contradictions. This is a designer who is famous for fairytale wedding dresses - most recently, Catherine Zeta-Jones's - yet his own wife, and collaborator, Françoise, whom he married 10 years ago after 18 years together, wore as a bridal gown a second-hand smock she'd found in Portobello market.

Nonetheless, there is a lot of Lacroix in his designs. In particular, he attributes his flamboyant, baroque style to the influence of his native south of France. Christian Marie Lacroix was born in Arles, the son of an engineer from the mountains of Cévennes whom he describes as strict, sober and moral, and a "warm, emotional" Provençal mother. After graduating from the University of Montpellier, Lacroix left behind the bullfights and black Spanish lace of Arles to study art history and museum studies at the Sorbonne and the École du Louvre in Paris, with the vague intention of curating at a costume museum. Instead, he found a job as an illustrator at Hermès, and moved into fashion.

By 1981, Lacroix was designing for the house of Jean Patou. It was during his five years there that Lacroix made his name, whipping up excitement with haute couture collections full of wit and verve at a time when couture - fashion's most exclusive circle, in which fantastical clothes are made to order for the indulgent rich - was generally considered a dying art. In 1986, Lacroix won the Golden Thimble award for his couture work.

It was then that Lacroix met a very ambitious young French businessman called Bernard Arnault. Arnault - now chairman of luxury goods giant LVMH - saw in Lacroix the chance to create a new, lucrative fashion brand name, an image that could be marketed, like Coco Chanel or Yves Saint Laurent, to sell tubes of lipstick and bottles of perfume by the million. With an innate understanding of the economics of luxury, he knew that in concocting the image no expense could be spared. Lacroix was given a fabulous salon on the Rue du Faubourg St Honoré and blank cheques to pay the most fashionable decorators in Paris. With a team of the most skilled seamstresses on hand, he was given free rein to launch the house of Christian Lacroix.

The first couture collection in July 1987 was a soaraway success. Fashion editors stood on their chairs and threw flowers at the designer. The debut knocked Yves Saint Laurent from his long-established position on the front page of American industry bible Women's Wear Daily. The signature shape was a shoulder-less cone with a puffball skirt, layered with previously unimagined multiple combinations of colour and fabric, a veritable knickerbocker glory of fashion. This was the giddy peak of the bloated 80s, and the Ivana Trumps of the world loved Lacroix for releasing them from power dressing and into extravagant, be-ribboned babydollery.

But in the autumn of that year, while he was working on his first ready-to-wear collection, the New York stock exchange crashed and the bubble in which Lacroix had been conceived was burst. In his first two years in the couture business, he sold just 20 dresses. The timing was lucky, however - a year later, it would have been inconceivable folly for anyone to fund a new couture house but, having invested heavily, Arnault stuck by him.

The recession hit Lacroix hard, not just because fewer people could afford his clothes, but because his playful show-offery jarred with the mood of the times. But a loyal flow of critical support, and Arnault's steady financial backing, saw him through, and in recent years the pendulum has begun to swing back in his favour. Renewed economic confidence is reflected in the emergence of celebrities such as Zeta-Jones, the kind of diamond-wearing actress who is isn't afraid to wear movie star clothes, and the revival of 80s style. At last July's couture show, for the first time in years the most influential stylists were applauding the same outfits as the sable-clad front row.

He may have invented the puffball skirt, but for Lacroix fashion is not about trends. "It is always the same story," he says matter-of-factly, "but with different ingredients each season. It is east meets west, north meets south, past meets future. Always." But while he finds the relentless speed of the seasonal trend cycle pointless, Lacroix is nonetheless determined to move his image forward. "To a lot of people, I'm still the guy with the heavy buttoned silk and all that. I know I can never sell a little black suit. There are so many places to buy a little black suit, and if women come here they want something sparkling. But I don't always want to be about the south and bullfighting. I'm tired of it - not tired of it in my personal life, but tired of having just this image. It is a very tricky subject.

The kind of dress you might find yourself wearing in a particularly surreal dream. Beautiful the clothes may be, staggeringly expensive they certainly are, but there's an engaging whimsy, a wilful madness about them. "I found some photos of cats dyed blue and pink, and of a masked ball in French Africa or French Indochina at the turn of the century," is the best explanation Lacroix can give of his latest haute couture collection. Nor do they have the calculated, goal-oriented sexuality of Versace. They are girlish and chichi and frou-frou and flouncy, overflowing with pomp and ceremony. fields.headline: The last word on   Power
fields.standfirst: The greater the power, the more dangerous the abuse -   Edmund Burke
fields.trailText: The greater the power, the more dangerous the abuse - Edmund Burke
fields.body:
Everyone knows Acton's saying about the corrupting power of power. History proves the truth of his observation by offering egregious individual examples, from Nero to Genghis Khan, from Shaka the Zulu to Pol Pot. What is remarkable is how often power in the hands of an unconstrained individual or claque leads to harm. How many examples are there of the powerful reversing the world's entropic tendencies in order to bring peace, succour and comfort to those in need of them? Woefully few. It is a curious and unhappy fact that those who strive to provide these things - aid organisations, charities, individuals hurt into action by the suffering of their fellows - tend themselves to be anything but powerful.

There are plenty of examples of harmful power in the contemporary world. Attention naturally fixes on the likes of Pinochet, Slobodan Milosovic and Robert Mugabe as cases of men resolved to get their own way no matter what. Such men possess political authority, and have command of armies and police forces; but they do not possess tolerance or respect for alternative views. Unless restrained by democratic institutions and the rule of law - exactly what Mugabe is now brushing aside in irritation at the obstacles they present; for as Lucan warned, "if a strong man does not get what he thinks is his due, he will take all he can" - they will have no reason to stop short of threatening, bullying, and finally "disappearing" their enemies.

There are other kinds of power, no less harmful if in different ways. Consider Rupert Murdoch and his influence on the future of the United Kingdom. He owns several of the country's largest-selling national newspapers and a television network, and although he is not British and does not live in Britain, he does not wish to see the United Kingdom join the single European currency. By every logic of economics and history, the United Kingdom must and will do so - the sooner the better, unless it is content to become a minor offshore banana republic on the sidelines of history. Since Mr Murdoch is no fool, it is tempting to wonder whether that is his aim.

The problem is not the existence of power, but its presence in ungoverned hands. "The first principle of a civilised state," said Walter Lippman, "is that power is legitimate only when it is under contract." The application of this principle is obvious as regards a government's power to enforce the laws it passes, and to keep order in its jurisdiction.

Democracy is a contract by which the exercise of such power is kept responsible. But there are less obvious contracts constraining other kinds of power. The power to state an opinion publicly, for example, is subject to the unwritten contract of debate; the opinion can be disagreed with, its supporting arguments challenged, the facts on which it is based checked. This contract has been hard won in the course of modern history, because it is not long since it was fatally dangerous to disagree with the opinions of those in power, whether they were Popes in the Vatican or party secretaries in the Kremlin. In some places, the danger has not yet passed: Afghanistan and China are examples.

Power's tendency to corrupt is a function of the work it does in liberating man's worst characteristics. A man feels his power over another more acutely when he breaks the other's spirit than when he wins his respect. To have power over others is to be in a position to deprive them of choices and options, to bend them to one's will, to make use of them.

Almost any sensibility can quickly decay into finding this pleasurable as well as convenient. How many SS men denied themselves the pleasure of absolute control over others when it was offered? Perhaps history never got the chance to record the heroism that such denial would truly represent. Unquestionably, to use real power gently and for the good of others is one of the most heroic of virtues; which is why examples of it are so rare.

Almost any sensibility can quickly decay into finding this pleasurable as well as convenient. How many SS men denied themselves the pleasure of absolute control over others when it was offered? Perhaps history never got the chance to record the heroism that such denial would truly represent. Unquestionably, to use real power gently and for the good of others is one of the most heroic of virtues; which is why examples of it are so rare.

webTitle: The burial of boyhood is just a wild night out

fields.headline: The burial of boyhood is just a wild night out
fields.trailText: Wendy Holden: I was hoping to return with at least some idea about what really happened on the lurid and legendary male occasion that is the stag night
fields.body:
Last week, I went to a burial that I hadn't been invited to. It was in Paris, and involved nipples, fighting, enormous amounts of food and 13 men whose daily average consumption of beer each topped the 14-pint mark. "L'enterrement de vie de garçon" (the burial of boyhood) is French for stag night, and my brother-in-law was preparing for marital bliss via a weekend of excess in his favourite city, helped by a clutch of old mates and a sister-in-law who'd come along for the ride.

The official reason for my presence was that I was visiting some friends of my own. Although not planning to be around for the lap-dancing, I was nonetheless hoping to return with at least some idea about what really happened on these lurid and legendary male occasions. I expected to be surprised. Shocked, even. I was not disappointed. As the party assembled at Waterloo International, one stag turned up toting a bag of Farley's Rusks while another appeared clutching a women's magazine. And, no, it wasn't Cosmopolitan. Confused? Well, I was, actually.

Explanations that the Farley's were for an expat friend's baby son (Brit rusks apparently taste better) and the mag-scanning was part of a journalistic assignment did not allay my growing suspicion that anything of a thongs 'n' baby-oil nature looked unlikely. But it was not long before I gained an insight into the world of chocolate willies. At the Friday night dinner - not an official stag occasion - my neighbour, a friendly Leicester solicitor, described the depressingly bestial nature of the live sex show he had once witnessed during a stag night in Amsterdam. His party was not alone; a group of Welshmen was undergoing the same rite of passage (in every sense of the word). After the opening tableau - couple copulating on stage - the entertainment progressed to a naked woman with a lighted candle who dripped hot wax all over her body. During her routine, the woman turned her back to the audience and waggled her very shapely bottom, at which point, in spontaneous tribute to the superiority of her posterior, the Welshmen broke into applause. It was, the solicitor explained, the only civil moment in an evening of unrelenting grimness.

Even worse was the story from my neighbour opposite, about a stag night he had heard of that had descended into depravity so extreme that everyone involved - former close friends - were afterwards far too embarrassed and ashamed ever to speak to each other any more. Not least of the gory details - group sex, transvestites - was the fact that the marriage this event had preceded broke up a mere six months later. It was becoming clear that, far from being a man's idea of stag night heaven, the idea of having a lap-dancer grinding her bottom into one's face was actually embarrassing, degrading and dreadful.

Perhaps fortunately, given all this, and despite my earlier mentions of nipples and fighting, the only breasts my brother-in-law saw were broad, hairy and belonged to the best man with whom he shared a hotel room. As for fisticuffs, my husband, also one of the party, actually did sustain an injury to his cheek. He was accidentally headbutted in the face by the three-year-old son of a friend who lives near the Parc Monceau. Which is not to say that scenes of Lucullan excess were entirely lacking. It was calculated on Sunday morning that, during the 18-hour binging session that the rest of the world knew as Saturday, several stags consumed at least 14 pints of lager each. They must have been a fearsome sight: in one bar, up the wrong end of the "colourful" rue St Denis, the group was even allotted its own bouncer by a patron wary of the English reputation for football-and-mouth disease.

I returned to London having learned two things about stag nights. First, that it was much more fun being a stag than a hen - one Scottish friend of mine was tied to a dustcart and pelted with rubbish the week before her wedding, while my own toe-curling pre-marital ordeal was to be serenaded for what seemed like hours by the Chinese Elvis in the Old Kent Road. The second and more amazing revelation was that - listen up, ladies - men really can communicate socially. They can analyse, amuse and - shock, horror - even gossip. I have seen it, heard it, witnessed the affection and good humour between 13 men, who, from the moment they met to the moment they parted, never stopped nattering. The refreshing 14 pints of lager a day, however, definitely helped.

I also returned to London pondering on the many small but crucial cultural differences that mark out the French from the British. Their national obsession with chemists, for instance. Those number codes you need to penetrate their apartment blocks. Bendy French buses, horse meat, men's socks that look like tights, bits of carpet in the gutter and the fact that absolutely everyone smokes. And, most of all, bolsters. These bizarre, pipe-shaped, continuous pillows come in all shapes and sizes, from Peperami to Toulouse sausages, and not one of them permits more than 40 minutes' fitful dozing. So what are they for? They are not, as one might assume, a practical joke played upon hapless tourists. The French have them, too.

It's obvious why, if you think about it. Bolsters are essential for maintaining that sleepless, Serge Gainsbourg, baggy-eyed look so closely associated with male French allure. And that Gallic reputation for being hot stuff in the sack - the other great division between the nations - is possibly connected as well.

Bolsters, after all, make beds impossible to sleep in. Perhaps, then, they are useful as sex aids - they can, I imagine, be bent and arranged in any number of ways to support the most unlikely of positions, possibly for hours on end. In addition, they can be of use when things are going less swimmingly - by being placed lengthways down the centre of the bed and removed only when the other party has mended their ways to the satisfaction of the other. Musing on this, I wondered if any couple starting married life can possibly afford to be without one. Does John Lewis do bolsters?

 Pastures Nouveaux, by Wendy Holden, is published by Headline, priced £10 hardback.

webTitle: If you are in clover then a healthy meadow may result

fields.headline: If you are in clover then a healthy meadow may result
fields.standfirst: A garden from a hundred packets of seeds
fields.trailText: A garden from a hundred packets of seeds
fields.body:
The Micro-Meadow

Everyone is attracted by the idea of a meadow, or by the notion that meadow conditions can be imitated in the garden. A few discouraging but realistic remarks might be helpful. One thing I never see emphasised is that a meadow - a real meadow, that is - is a field with a product. If you have no use for the product, the hay, you are likely to have a problem with a meadow.

I recently read an admirable account of a garden grown largely for the benefit of insects: every plant was rated according to the number and variety of insects it attracted. Towards the end, the author admitted that, finding it hard to compost the hay from her garden, she had the local council cart it away instead. But there must be something wrong with the ecology of growing hay for council infill sites.

Another thing that sets my teeth on edge when meadow-enthusiasts describe what they have done is the insistence that, since meadow flowers grow best on poor soil, you should lower the fertility of your soil before you begin. So far, so justifiable. But they go on to say that, if necessary, you should remove the fertile topsoil before sowing your meadow seed mixture.

I protest. Who is handing out this destructive advice, and who is listening to it? Who is carting away his or her fertile topsoil, and what are they finding underneath when they have done so? What plants, what bulbs, what seeds are being carted away? And what have they done wrong?

It is only from the specialist point of view of the gardener that a meadow must have low fertility. An actual working meadow may have at least two obvious sources of fertility. It may have clover. Does the meadow gardener propose to exclude clover from the mix, on the grounds that it introduces too much nitrogen in the soil?

The second source of fertility is, of course, animals. "Sheep eat the grass, then dung the ground for more," wrote that admirable poet George Herbert, describing a desirable aspect of providence. A meadow is grown for its hay. When that is cut, and the grasses have grown again, the field is grazed. Among the beneficial effects (from the point of view of the meadow gardener) of this grazing is the fact that the cattle tread the new seed into the ground. Indeed, one way in which you can turn a cultivated field into a meadow, and which we have practised on my farm with some success, is to take the hay from another meadow and spread it over the target area, and then put cattle on it. The cattle both eat the hay (or not, if they don't feel like it) and tread it under foot.

The easiest way to start a meadow is to take a field or patch of lawn and put it under a meadow regime: no fertilisers, pesticides or herbicides, no animals to graze it, no mower to touch it before the first cut of the year - and this cut to come only after the seeds of the desirable wildflowers have been allowed to ripen. Meadows, like lawns, arise through management, and this is the basic management for a wildflower meadow. The results are to be appreciated over years, decades even.

This kind of meadow is distinct from the vision you tend to see in blurry pastel photographs, in which poppies, cornflowers and corncockle give an "impressionist" effect. The annual flowers blooming in such fields are the weeds of cornfields, and in order to bloom readily they need a cornfield regime. But this implies annual ploughing - and this is very far from the repertory of most gardeners.

However, what is possible - and much easier to achieve than a really satisfactory perennial wildflower meadow (which should be viewed as a longterm project) - is a micro-meadow of annual flowers, grown in a small patch. Two years ago, we did this, and the reaction of visitors was always at first to laugh at the small scale of our project: intended as a cornfield with traditional extras, it measured only six paces by two.

The corn we took from a handful or two of mixed birdseed - a mistake, since such seed may often be heat-treated, which destroys its viability. The wildflowers came from a couple of packets of wildflower mix, available in any garden centre, together with the things we particularly wanted: cornflowers (which have featured earlier in this list) (no 61) Agrostemma githago or Corncockle, and (no 62) Papaver rhoeas or Field Poppy.

The ground was prepared in April and the seed mixture scattered over. In the early stages, some obvious weeds were removed, others, like the purple-flowered Wall Fumitory, Fumaria muralis , were left. A dominant presence among the flowers, along with the cornflowers and poppies, was Corn Chamomile, Anthemis arvensis . In due course, we had a spectacular display, but little evidence of corn in our field.

Later I was reading the introduction to Annuals and Biennials, the important book by Roger Phillips and Martyn Rix which I have already mentioned, when I came across this sentence: "Poppies, cornflowers, corn-cockle and Nigella, combined with some grasses, umbelliferae and white daisies, will make a fine scheme to recreate a Neolithic Mediterranean cornfield." This was indeed what we had achieved, with just the sort of poor germination of corn that Neolithic man might have expected in a bad year, but with compensating blooms of (no 63) Leucanthemum vulgare or Ox-eye Daisy.

Chiltern Seeds offer (no 64) a Mixture of Annual Varieties, and (no 65) a Mixture of Perennial Varieties, which could serve as a basis for two such miniature schemes. Of interest as well is (no 66) their California Wildflower mixture. Phillips and Rix go on to say that "Californian annuals include the wonderful blue and purple Phacelia and the pale blue Nemophila, as well as the different colours of Californian poppies. Lupins, Clarkias and white Oenothera complete a grouping which could occur in California."

An article in the current issue of the Garden, the Journal of the Royal Horticultural Society, reports on experiments with this kind of direct sowing. It recommends a thin layer of sand spread over the bed as a weed-suppressing mulch (the seeds being sown onto this sand), and it shows the difference between results with or without a modest use of slug pellets. The authors calculate that to plant a square metre with herbaceous perennial plants may cost £20-£25 at garden centre prices; using seed, the same area comes out at 20-50p.

 All the seeds mentioned above may be had from Chiltern Seeds, Bortree Stile, Ulverstone, Cumbria LA12 7PB, or www.chiternseeds.co.uk

fields.headline: Grande dame of Bayswater
fields.standfirst: As an avant-garde actress and part of the 60s theatrical revolution, she performed Lady Macbeth in the nude. Today, as a maverick impresario, her business acumen is combined with trademark eccentricity to bring the best of world theatre to Britain.  John O'Mahony  reports
fields.trailText: As an avant-garde actress and part of the 60s theatrical revolution, she performed Lady Macbeth in the nude. Today, as a maverick impresario, her business acumen is combined with trademark eccentricity to bring the best of world theatre to Britain. John O'Mahony reports
fields.body:
Perched at the top of a treacherously narrow stairway sandwiched between the Strand Theatre and the Waldorf Hotel in central London, the headquarters of Thelma Holt Ltd has all the fugitive ambience of a backstage dressing room. Hardly more than an attic annexe in what was once Ivor Novello's West End eyrie, its faded walls are cluttered with the inevitable theatrical posters and framed Olivier awards, recalling such Holt-produced triumphs as the Redgraves' Three Sisters and Yukio Ninagawa's Tango At The End Of Winter. Elsewhere, cut-out pictorial relics of Holt's acting years lean at odd angles from behind filing cabinets, one showing an imposing, gamine, razor-jawed redhead dressed in a corset and brandishing a whip.

And strewn everywhere is that carefully-chosen rummage characteristic of theatre people: an untidy collage of newspaper headlines, the topmost proclaiming "Theatre is for Wankers", a Japanese wall-hanging surmounted by a tacky picture of the Virgin Mary; and, in one corner, an embroidered cushion bearing a legend that might plausibly serve as Holt's epitaph: "If I wanted your opinion, I would have stopped talking by now."

In the centre of the room, reclining regally on a dimpled leather chair, commanding attention like the grande dame of some long- running West End show, is the irrepressible Thelma Holt herself, one of Britain's best known theatre impresarios. Her assistant, Sweetpea, has already given a warning about our first meeting: "You might be forgiven for thinking she's absolutely bonkers. She's capable of anything, from storing champagne in the dishwasher to going to the theatre on a first night and forgetting to put her dress on, so that she is just wearing her satin overcoat."

Holt, dressed today in Issey Miyake, her favourite designer - plus a pair of bright orange pumps - does not disappoint. She launches into a long, swerving monologue about something called Ignatian Theory, in which an Irish priest called Father Billy has apparently been instructing her. Then we're on to the first time she met Robert Maxwell, her patron at north London's famously avant-garde Round House theatre in the late 70s: "He stood at the end of this big conference table," she says, "and he said: 'I'm Robert Maxwell'. He always said that - 'I'm Robert Maxwell - even though everyone knew damn well who he was. Then he said: 'There are three things you need to know about me - I don't drink, I don't gamble and I don't sleep with women'. I'm not that quick but I had St. Anthony protecting me that day. My mouth opened and out came: 'Mr. Maxwell, how splendid! At least we have two things in common.' Of course, I didn't say which two."

Suddenly she's off on a story about her ex-husband - she's had three - the American actor, Lawrence Pressman: "I was with a friend and this television thing was on. Rock Hudson was the leading man and there was this other character who was extremely good. I said, 'I know that actor'. And my friend said, 'Yes, dear, it's Rock Hudson'. And I said, 'No, the other one, I know that actor'. At the end I went out to get some coffee and my friend shouted from the living room: 'Of course you know that actor, darling, you were married to him.'" Only after another hurtling diversion involving both David Mamet and the Arts Council, is she finally distracted by the telephone.

Dubbed the First Lady of British Theatre, Thelma Holt is one of the country's most daring and visionary producers, a true maverick who can effortlessly combine the commercial prerogatives of the West End with the panoramic breadth of vision of some of the world's most progressive theatre artists. Over two and half decades, she has introduced the Georgian director Robert Sturua and his Rustaveli company to British theatregoers, produced shows by continental titans such as Peter Stein, Ariane Mnouchkine, Giorgio Strehler, Franco Zeffirelli, and been the tireless champion of the pioneering work of Ninagawa, presenting his Macbeth and Medea at the National Theatre in 1987 and producing nine of his subsequent UK shows.

Yet, her outlook has also remained supremely British and she is as much at home with her current production of Noel Coward's Semi-Monde (opening at the Lyric Shaftesbury Avenue on March 21) as any piece of Japanese exotica: "As a producer she is virtually unique in our business," says friend and colleague Cameron Mackintosh. "She has a passionate commitment to being almost a solo national theatre, in the kind of work she does. She doesn't put down the commercial aspect. She is not in any way a snob. She just believes in great theatre, and she takes wonderful risks."

On a practical level, Holt is a hands-on producer like no other. Her ongoing love-affair with the acting profession continues unabated, as she dispenses starring roles to friends such as Vanessa Redgrave and Alan Rickman, and makes lifelong friends of her stars, as in Janet McTeer, whose career was transformed by Holt's production of A Doll's House. While many West End casts might be lucky to catch a glimpse of the producer on first night, Holt attends every rehearsal and every performance: "She specialises in being earth mother to the production," says producer and friend Bill Kenwright, "She's there all the time. It's like she's up on the stage with them. And after the show or during rehearsals, you'll find her taking chicken soup in for the actors."

While Holt has managed to ascend the male-dominated ranks, she transcends any easy feminist tags: "Nobody says, 'Oh, here comes a woman who has triumphed in a profession controlled by men'," says Alan Rickman. "They just say, 'Oh, here comes Thelma'." Yet it is no co-incidence that, in terms of sheer charisma and force of personality, nothing like Holt has graced the theatre world since the last great female crusader, Lilian Baylis. Cameron Mackintosh says, "She is the living proof that providing you have your beliefs you can make a difference. As the corporate world begins to continually take theatre over, she is brave and crusading, a fantastic beacon."

In person, Holt is a larger-than-life eccentric, a bravura wit with a jagged edge of artful insanity that makes every conversation a joyride of one-liners and oddball anecdotes. Wholeheartedly genuine and deeply frivolous, she speaks in that plummy, received pronunciation that only a half-Irish, Catholic girl from Lancaster might affect, greeting everyone with the same fountain of "darlings" and "dears". But there is also more than a touch of Looney Tunes."

However, Holt can be as shrewd and ruthless as any city banker when it comes to something really important, Sweetpea says. She'll even fall back on the baffled-woman act, pretending not to understand. Truth being that she is about six feet ahead of everyone else around the table."

Holt is also ferociously loyal to the people close to her: "A warm and merry person who cuts through the bullshit," according to Vanessa Redgrave, a friend since the 50s. "Champagne and roses are easy," says Janet McTeer, "but making someone a cup of tea and giving them a cuddle can be quite hard. And that is where Thelma excels." Overall, Holt defies every received notion of the producer in modern theatre. She lives in a modest maisonette in London's Bayswater with her cats Poppy and Psyche, her only outward luxuries the Miyake creations she gets at knock-down prices from a Japanese contact and the religious paraphernalia that lines her bedroom: votive candles, a lush Prie Dieu and a reliquary. Every night you walk from the dark into the light and you don't know where you are going. That requires a lot of courage and caring for and looking after. It is my job to make that leap possible."

Thelma Mary Bernadette Holt was born on January 4 1932, in the small Lancashire town of Barton on Irwell, the second daughter of an English electrical engineer named Peter David Holt and Eleanor Finnagh Doyle, an Irishwoman originally from the village of Dunmanway, County Cork. She joined a sister, Elizabeth, who was 10 years older: "I was a twin - the boy was stillborn," she says. "My sister always maintained that I kicked him to death in the womb."

From an early age she displayed idiosyncratic religious tendencies: "I was particularly interested in funerals," she recalls, "I used to hold them in the back garden and bury my sister in a shoe box - it was just a doll, but I would pretend it was my sister. I know it makes me sound like Charlie Manson's aunt, but I used to stand over this shoebox doing the De Profundis." She was so captivated by the altar-side theatricality of the Catholic ritual that her earliest ambition was to enter holy orders: "I wanted to be a priest," she beams, "If at the age of four you are taken to a ceremony that is extremely interesting and smells nice, it's perfectly natural. Plus, there is a leading man in a great frock"

Shortly after the onset of the second world war, when Thelma was eight, her father was killed in an air-raid on Southampton. This early loss has often been cited by Holt and others as the underlying compensatory impulse that has drawn her to dominating, egotistical and patriarchal men (Charles Marowitz, her partner at the Open Space theatre; Robert Maxwell; and Peter Hall, her mentor at the National all broadly fall into this category). However, at the time, the impact was cushioned: "I cried because Daddy didn't come home," she says, "But I certainly didn't feel any great sense of loss. If there was a vacuum it was immediately filled by a very determined, strong-willed mother."

Throughout Thelma's early years, the family moved about, first to Hove and then, two years later, to Brighton. But during the war Thelma was sent to live with her Godmother in Lancashire. There she attended St. Anne's School for Girls, going on to become the youngest-ever prefect and later school captain: "She stood out from the rest of us," remembers her friend and classmate Anne Shaw, "She was very full of it, had lots of personality and was very theatrical. I can remember Thelma walking through the square in St Anne's, snow on the ground, bitterly cold and she's got these great big sunglasses on. And I remember saying to her: 'What are you doing with those on?' And she said, 'Oh darling, you have to be prepared for anything'."

Realising by now that she was probably deeply unsuited to the priesthood, Holt ploughed her substantial energies into theatre, excelling in male leads in school productions of Gilbert and Sulli van. On leaving St. Anne's she won a place at Rada and joined the class of 1952 alongside Joe Orton, with Joan Collins just a few years ahead. Though her axe-like jawline and striking red hair led to offbeat roles, it was her social virtuosity that contemporaries remember: "I don't particularly recall Thelma being a shining star," says her classmate, the producer and actor David Conville. "She networked and charmed people while not doing anything too stunning, acting-wise. Everybody liked her."

During her final-year showcase, Holt was offered a contract by Binkie Beaumont, then one of the West End's most powerful producers. She would spend the following decade playing minor roles and understudying stars, building up a phalanx of prominent theatrical friends (including Redgrave and Jill Bennett) but growing ever more disenchanted with her own prospects: "I was good. But I wasn't Maggie [Smith] or Vanessa," she says, "I would only want to be Maggie and Vanessa and I knew there was something I could do much, much better."

Then, in 1965, came an encounter that would radically change the tone, emphasis and direction of Holt's life. Charles Marowitz, an American experimental director and critic was largely responsible for organising, along with Peter Brook, the legendary Theatre of Cruelty seasons at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art in 1963-4. By the mid-60s he was planning his own experimental company, and while casting around for actors, chanced upon Holt in a club theatre production of Leonid Andreyev's He Who Gets Slapped.

"She was wearing a brocade corset, black net stockings, high heels and a bowler hat," Marowitz recalls. "She held a whip in one hand and her countenance was one of the most wicked I had ever seen in a woman." Immediately, he explained the prospective avant- garde project, for which he had already located a suitably dingy basement at 32 Tottenham Court Road, and offered Holt the part of Gertrude in a prospective dissected Dadaist production that would later go down in theatre history as the Marowitz Hamlet.

"I didn't believe for a moment I would ever see her again," Marowitz writes in his autobiography, Burnt Bridges, "I could think of nothing more antithetical to an aesthetically driven experimental theatre with a radical bias than the temperament of this slithery, almond-eyed ingénue bred on Noel Coward and Terence Rattigan." Not only did Holt call back some weeks later to say she would take the part, but offered to help build and finance what would become the Open Space theatre.

Over the next eight years, this makeshift 200-seat venue would become the cornerstone of the London fringe, attaining near-mythical status as the subterranean launchpad for a generation of today's most stellar writing talents: "There were four of us in that cellar, doing these new plays," remembers veteran Open Space actor Tony Milner. "It was just a stream of new writing by people we had never heard of: Howard Brenton, David Hare, Howard Barker, Sam Shepard. Now we can see that was a very rich experience. At the time it seemed we had no idea what we were doing."

Marowitz also whipped up a storm with his own experimental productions: the mangled Hamlet, which led one critic to lament, "Alas poor Hamlet, Charles Marowitz has been at him again", and a cropped Macbeth, with Holt sleepwalking in a see-through nightgown as Lady Macbeth: "I went on the David Frost programme after that," Holt recalls, "and Mary Whitehouse went for me in a big way. I said: 'I don't understand why you think that anybody is coming to sit through an hour an a half of almost incomprehensible Shakespeare to see a not-at-all well-endowed lady - that's me - when less than 10 minutes away in any phone booth there are telephone numbers of girls with big tits and arses who will give them far better value for money."

Throughout the Open Space era, Holt and Marowitz maintained an extraordinary partnership, with Holt regularly referring to herself as Mother and the difficult, and sometimes dictatorial Marowitz as Father. From fundraising to feeding actors with vitamins, Holt ran the place with such alacrity that Marowitz suggested she turn full-time to production: "Thelma supported Charles 100%," remembers Tony Milner. "Without her, nothing would have got done. Thelma kept him elevated, but you knew all the time that if she wasn't there he would fall down."

Despite rumours, they were not lovers: "We were as close as two people can be," says Marowitz, "but we shared no sexual relationship. It was more than platonic, we got raided together [in 1970 police confiscated a copy of Warhol's film Flesh and a £200 fine was imposed], we had to represent the theatre publicly, we were living in each other's pockets. We were platonic lovers. And we shared more than if we had been real lovers." In fact, Holt's personal life throughout this period involved more entrances and exits than the average Open Space production.

In the same year as she began her collaboration with Marowitz, she met and fell in love with an American actor named Lawrence Pressman, who would briefly become her second husband. Holt, a self-confessed wedding junkie - "I love the ceremony, and you get to have a great big party afterwards," - had married fellow RADA student Patrick Graucob when she was 22, a union which lasted over a decade, but eventually unravelled as Graucob abandoned acting and their interests sharply diverged. Later on, in the early 70s, she would go on to husband number three, referred to only as "an Italian I met" who was summarily dispatched back to Italy "within a matter of weeks".

The relationship with Pressman began in late 1967, when Holt spot ted the handsome 27-year-old in a production of Robert Shaw's The Man In The Glass Booth. An affair began shortly afterwards, and when Pressman returned to America at the end of the run, Holt followed. "She was nuts, wacky in the best sense of the word," says Pressman, going on to tell how Holt, unable to find a sharp knife in his apartment, had once prepared a rice and almond pudding by chewing up almonds and spitting them on the plate. "The affair had reached that place where you inevitably had to do something, so we decided to get married," says Pressman. "She said, 'I'll talk a Rabbi into marrying us', which she did. I think she promised that she would take instruction. We were married in Mount Neboh Synagogue in October 1968. And then promptly it began to fall apart." Unable to withstand the pressure of Holt's devotion to the Open Space and Pressman's reluctance to resettle, their "legalised love affair" ended in divorce in 1972. "Thelma follows her own light," says Pressman, "I wanted to get married and probably have children. I was extremely naïve to think that I could tie a tin can to Thelma."

The Open Space eventually imploded in 1977 in what became known as the Pink Bathroom Scandal, when Marowitz was accused by a newspaper of purchasing with production funds a bathroom suite for his personal use. He claimed it was for a devised piece to be called Bridal Suite and threatened to sue, but never did. Holt resigned and the whole thing fizzled out. Holt would emerge from the Open Space experience, however, with growing confidence in her burgeoning production abilities, which she immediately put into practice at the eternally cash-strapped Round House. Originally engaged for a year, she stayed for six, building on the legacy of playwright and founder Arnold Wesker's experimentalism with a programme of regional showcases (including Ibsen's Lady From The Sea from the Manchester Royal Exchange Theatre) and international imports (Circus Oz, Antoine Vitez and the Rustaveli Hamlet in 1979).

It was during this time that Holt became acquainted with the Round House treasurer and primary sponsor, Robert Maxwell: "He was unpardonably rude," she remembers, "and he would often shout at me. But if I'm bullied I shoot to kill. He once shouted at me and I shouted back, calling him a Czech spiv. Well, he didn't like that, and rang back to ask why. I said 'Because you are Czech and you wear plastic shoes'. Next time we met, he showed off these brand-new leather shoes he'd bought." By the end of their association, during which the duplicitous tycoon simply became known as "Daddy", Holt could play the stops of his gargantuan ego so expertly that his family were said to have spoken of her "hold" over him. Even Maxwell, though, couldn't save the rodent-infested Round House when it was abandoned by funding bodies in 1983, and Holt presided over its sale.

After 18 months at the Theatre of Comedy, where she fulfilled a long-time dream of producing RADA classmate Joe Orton's Loot with Leonard Rossiter in the lead, only to have Rossiter succumb to a heart-attack two weeks into the run, Holt was invited by Peter Hall to become head of touring and commercial exploitation at the National Theatre: "I gave her a budget and a brief and told her to get on with it," says Hall. "She had an enormous amount of autonomy. She is a very good maverick person to put into an organisation. She rides roughshod over foolishness and she gets terribly angry over inefficiencies. But she doesn't do it for the greater glory of Thelma Holt, but in order to get something on the stage."

Over the next five years, Holt would mastermind numerous National Theatre foreign tours, including a trek across the US and Canada with Animal Farm and a spectacularly jinxed odyssey through Russia and Georgia with Hall's Cymbeline and The Winter's Tale, during which all the sets and costumes went missing en route to Tblisi: "Thelma is the best person to have in a crisis," remembers Hall. "In Moscow she was like a combination of a female Diaghilev and a character in a John le Carré novel, spouting stories of how we got around the Russians."

Holt's crowning achievement at the national was the international season of 1987, when Hall allowed her complete freedom to assemble a programme that would eventually include Ingmar Bergman's Miss Julie, Peter Stein's The Hairy Ape, and Ninagawa's Medea: "Not since the legendary visit by the Berliner Ensemble in 1956 have we seen a more exciting theatrical import than the Ninagawa Company from Tokyo," raved the Guardian, about what was generally regarded as a landmark theatrical event. "Their production of Euripides's Medea is, quite simply, sensational."

When Hall left the National in 1989 Holt followed him into the Peter Hall Company before breaking away 18 months later to form Thelma Holt Ltd. Since then, she and Malcolm Taylor and Sweetpea have produced 55 shows from various minuscule West End offices, including Sturua's Three Sisters, the UK transfer of Frank McGuinness's masterpiece Observe The Sons Of Ulster, and A Doll's House, which gleaned four Tony awards. She has also been active in humanitarian areas, making a Unicef film with Vanessa Redgrave on women in Iraq, and organising benefit performances for Romanian orphanages.

In the mid-90s, Holt served as chairman of the Arts Council Drama Advisory Panel, antagonising the grey, male-dominated bureaucracy with her unflinching approach. Lord Gowrie, former chairman of the Arts Council, says: "Thelma was a difficult colleague and I welcomed that. She is someone I love and admire but she can sometimes behave like the great diva she is, full of trembling resignation. She had the ability to make grand alliances but sometimes the reverse was also true. She could be quite quarrelsome."

Now approaching 70, Holt shows no sign of slowing down. "Every year she goes to the brink of bankruptcy and every year she bounces back," says Kenwright, "she lives like a hurricane." Responding to Sir Richard Eyre's recent homily on the failings of English theatre companies, she says: "I don't think there is any room in the theatre for pessimists. Many of the things he said were true: London is dirty, it is expensive. But as we speak on Shaftesbury Avenue we have a Medea, a classic that no-one would have dared do 30 years ago, we have The Graduate playing to full houses, and I'm about to open a play with a cast of 29 people.

"I think there is every reason for optimism. You get these articles every three years or so, saying how the theatre is dying. But audiences keep coming. It's certainly no worse than New York. He's absolutely right in much of what he says. But it just means that we must raise the quality of the work."

But while she regularly questions whether the current environment will continue to allow her to produce her brand of theatre, she won't be giving up soon: "I worry that it is harder now than ever. We could say 'cool it, don't take risks, we're a small organisation but let's put on a money-making sure-fire hit.' No, thank you. If you think I want to get to that great Round House in the sky with Leonard Rossiter waiting for me screaming abuse, then, no, I wish to be welcome when I get there."

Life at a glance: Thelma Mary Bernadette Holt.

Born: January 4 1932, Barton on Irwell, Lancashire.

Education: St Anne's School for Girls; Royal Academy of Dramatic Art, 1952-54.

Married: Patrick Graucob ( '56-68); Lawrence Pressman ('68-72).

Career as administrator: Co- founder and administrator Open Space Theatre ('69-77); artistic director Round House ('77-83); head of touring and commercial exploitation National Theatre ('85-89); executive producer Peter Hall Company '90; Thelma Holt Ltd '90-.

Productions include: The Hairy Ape, dir Peter Stein ('87); Miss Julie, dir Ingmar Bergman ('87); Medea and Macbeth, dir Yukio Ninagawa ('87); The Wild Duck ('90); Three Sisters, dir Robert Sturua ('90); Les Atrides, dir Ariane Mnouchkine ('92), The Tempest, dir Ninagawa ('92); A Doll's House ('96); Observe The Sons Of Ulster ('96); The Maids ('97); Miss Julie ('00); Semi-Monde ('01).
