Marowitz also whipped up a storm with his own experimental productions: the mangled Hamlet, which led one critic to lament, "Alas poor Hamlet, Charles Marowitz has been at him again", and a cropped Macbeth, with Holt sleepwalking in a see-through nightgown as Lady Macbeth: "I went on the David Frost programme after that," Holt recalls, "and Mary Whitehouse went for me in a big way. I said: 'I don't understand why you think that anybody is coming to sit through an hour an a half of almost incomprehensible Shakespeare to see a not-at-all well-endowed lady - that's me - when less than 10 minutes away in any phone booth there are telephone numbers of girls with big tits and arses who will give them far better value for money." Throughout the Open Space era, Holt and Marowitz maintained an extraordinary partnership, with Holt regularly referring to herself as Mother and the difficult, and sometimes dictatorial Marowitz as Father. From fundraising to feeding actors with vitamins, Holt ran the place with such alacrity that Marowitz suggested she turn full-time to production: "Thelma supported Charles 100%," remembers Tony Milner. "Without her, nothing would have got done. Thelma kept him elevated, but you knew all the time that if she wasn't there he would fall down." Despite rumours, they were not lovers: "We were as close as two people can be," says Marowitz, "but we shared no sexual relationship. It was more than platonic, we got raided together [in 1970 police confiscated a copy of Warhol's film Flesh and a £200 fine was imposed], we had to represent the theatre publicly, we were living in each other's pockets. We were platonic lovers. And we shared more than if we had been real lovers." In fact, Holt's personal life throughout this period involved more entrances and exits than the average Open Space production. Holt, a self-confessed wedding junkie - "I love the ceremony, and you get to have a great big party afterwards," - had married fellow RADA student Patrick Graucob when she was 22, a union which lasted over a decade, but eventually unravelled as Graucob abandoned acting and their interests sharply diverged. Over the next five years, Holt would mastermind numerous National Theatre foreign tours, including a trek across the US and Canada with Animal Farm and a spectacularly jinxed odyssey through Russia and Georgia with Hall's Cymbeline and The Winter's Tale, during which all the sets and costumes went missing en route to Tblisi: "Thelma is the best person to have in a crisis," remembers Hall. Since then, she and Malcolm Taylor and Sweetpea have produced 55 shows from various minuscule West End offices, including Sturua's Three Sisters, the UK transfer of Frank McGuinness's masterpiece Observe The Sons Of Ulster, and A Doll's House, which gleaned four Tony awards. She has also been active in humanitarian areas, making a Unicef film with Vanessa Redgrave on women in Iraq, and organising benefit performances for Romanian orphanages. In the mid-90s, Holt served as chairman of the Arts Council Drama Advisory Panel, antagonising the grey, male-dominated bureaucracy with her unflinching approach. Lord Gowrie, former chairman of the Arts Council, says: "Thelma was a difficult colleague and I welcomed that. She is someone I love and admire but she can sometimes behave like the great diva she is, full of trembling resignation. She had the ability to make grand alliances but sometimes the reverse was also true. She could be quite quarrelsome." Now approaching 70, Holt shows no sign of slowing down. "Every year she goes to the brink of bankruptcy and every year she bounces back," says Kenwright, "she lives like a hurricane." Responding to Sir Richard Eyre's recent homily on the failings of English theatre companies, she says: "I don't think there is any room in the theatre for pessimists. Many of the things he said were true: London is dirty, it is expensive. But as we speak on Shaftesbury Avenue we have a Medea, a classic that no-one would have dared do 30 years ago, we have The Graduate playing to full houses, and I'm about to open a play with a cast of 29 people. "I think there is every reason for optimism. You get these articles every three years or so, saying how the theatre is dying. But audiences keep coming. It's certainly no worse than New York. He's absolutely right in much of what he says. But it just means that we must raise the quality of the work." But while she regularly questions whether the current environment will continue to allow her to produce her brand of theatre, she won't be giving up soon: "I worry that it is harder now than ever. We could say 'cool it, don't take risks, we're a small organisation but let's put on a money-making sure-fire hit.' No, thank you. If you think I want to get to that great Round House in the sky with Leonard Rossiter waiting for me screaming abuse, then, no, I wish to be welcome when I get there." Life at a glance: Thelma Mary Bernadette Holt. Born: January 4 1932, Barton on Irwell, Lancashire. Education: St Anne's School for Girls; Royal Academy of Dramatic Art, 1952-54. Married: Patrick Graucob ( '56-68); Lawrence Pressman ('68-72). Career as administrator: Co- founder and administrator Open Space Theatre ('69-77); artistic director Round House ('77-83); head of touring and commercial exploitation National Theatre ('85-89); executive producer Peter Hall Company '90; Thelma Holt Ltd '90-. Productions include: The Hairy Ape, dir Peter Stein ('87); Miss Julie, dir Ingmar Bergman ('87); Medea and Macbeth, dir Yukio Ninagawa ('87); The Wild Duck ('90); Three Sisters, dir Robert Sturua ('90); Les Atrides, dir Ariane Mnouchkine ('92), The Tempest, dir Ninagawa ('92); A Doll's House ('96); Observe The Sons Of Ulster ('96); The Maids ('97); Miss Julie ('00); Semi-Monde ('01).

fields.headline: Thank you, Madam
fields.standfirst: How Ninette de Valois made 'sad, bad' English ballet into a national glory. By Judith Mackrell
fields.trailText: How Ninette de Valois made 'sad, bad' English ballet into a national glory. By Judith Mackrell
fields.body:
There are some characters in history who, however you turn events around, seem to have been essential to the plot. How do you tell the story of the Roman Empire without Julius Caesar? Or of modern France without Napoleon? And how do you possibly figure British ballet without Dame Ninette de Valois, who died on Thursday?

This tiny woman, whose lively charm was always armoured by a military ruthlessness, surprised no one by living to the age of 102. Her tenacity and discipline were famous, and gave rise not only to nicknames - the Hockey Mistress and, most enduringly, Madam - but also to the Royal Ballet, Birmingham Royal Ballet and the Royal Ballet School, whose foundations she began masterminding in the 1920s.

Most of the great European ballet companies were established centuries ago as appendages to the royal courts. British ballet was, by comparison, an end-of-pier entertainment. At the beginning of the last century most dance took place on the variety or music hall stages and most dancers scraped a training at private studios. The few who made the grade usually worked abroad, where they had to hide their ignominious origins. Alice Marks became Alicia Markova and Hilda Munnings briefly suffered the indignity of being billed as Munningsova.

Edris Stannus from County Wicklow, Ireland, also changed her name - to Ninette de Valois - and, despite beginning her career with the gruesomely-named Wonder Children, was determined to escape what she called "that sad, bad thing, the English ballet". She patched together a serious training and in 1923 got a job dancing with Diaghilev's Ballets Russes. At the time, this was the most exciting place to be, but while most of her colleagues clung to the company until Diaghilev's death in 1929, De Valois left after only two years. She didn't want to be a star - she wanted to run her own school and create a national ballet for Britain.

The story of her success is well known. After opening a dance academy in London and turning her hand to theatre, opera and ballet, she was hired by Lilian Baylis in 1931 to run a ballet ensemble (and school) at the Old Vic and Sadler's Wells. Baylis's explanation was: "You seem to have had more experience than all these others, dear." But she also saw in De Valois a woman who shared her own exalted vision of a national arts scene, and who could make others see it too.

Certainly, despite having no subsidy, De Valois succeeded in poaching most of the best dancers and choreographers for her new Vic-Wells company. Markova agreed to become its first ballerina, even though it meant turning down far more prestigious offers. As she recalls, she couldn't resist De Valois's call to national service. "Dame Ninette said if we didn't put down some roots now, we'd have no ballet of our own. So I threw in my lot with her. She had that ability to make us feel we all shared the same goal."

Under the guidance of De Valois and Constant Lambert, the company began to stage an impressive repertory of new work. By 1946 the main company had moved into the Opera House, becoming the Royal Ballet in 1956, while the smaller Sadler's Wells company became Birmingham Royal Ballet in 1990. To anyone ignorant of their history, the Royal Ballet institutions now appear to rest on a weight of tradition comparable to most of the old European companies. But could anyone other than De Valois have reformed so radically the sad, bad English ballet?

There were, of course, other people setting up companies at the same time, but none rivalled De Valois, for none had any special interest in Britain or in creating an institution that would outlive them. De Valois was a gifted dancer and choreographer, but Beryl Grey, one of the Royal's early ballerinas, remembers: "She never pushed herself and her own work. She only ever pushed the company."

There was, however, one other woman with her eye on the British ballet scene: Marie Rambert. She was neither choreographer nor dancer (though she had briefly performed in Diaghilev's corps de ballet) but she was a teacher and a visionary. In 1920, she set up her own school in London, which attracted enough talent for Rambert to stage performances at the tiny Mercury Theatre from 1926.

Rambert certainly had a nose for genius - it was she who bullied Frederick Ashton out of his hopeless dream of dancing like Pavlova and got him making ballets - and was also a gifted, gritty director. Against brutal odds she managed to sustain her own inventive, versatile Ballet Rambert for decades, and it still survives after her death as Rambert Dance Company, directed by one of her protegés, Christopher Bruce.

But most of Rambert's peers agree she was too volatile and her judgment too subjective for her to have built an enterprise as big as the Royal. She wasn't driven by the same empire-building ambitions as De Valois, nor did she possess the same rigorous organisational skills.

Beryl Grey thinks De Valois's unique constellation of qualities made her the only woman for the job. "She had a capacity to see ahead that is very unusual in the British. People were very much in awe of her but she could also charm the hind legs off a donkey. She had a very Irish knack for saying the right thing at the right time. Rambert didn't have that diplomacy."

Other British companies began to emerge in the late 1930s and early 1940s, such as Mona Ingelsby's Ballet International, but by then the Vic-Wells was too large to be ousted. Markova also intermittently ran her own company with Anton Dolin, but it was primarily to showcase their own talents. By the time it expanded into London Festival Ballet during the 1950s, its role was to complement the Royal as a touring company outside London.

So De Valois seems to have been the right person in the right place at the right time. But, having set out so doggedly to create this huge enterprise, how much of a personal mark did she make on it? Certainly its very Britishness is due to her. In the 1930s and 1940s, Russian ballet was considered the finest in the world and several successors to Diaghilev's company were floating around. De Valois knew she could not compete with them, which is why she insisted on nurturing home-grown dancers and choreographers. Though she employed some guest teachers from abroad, the only foreign ballets she put on before the war were the 19th-century classics, which she staged meticulously. And even after the war she brought in relatively few ballets from outside.

De Valois's critics have argued this was a drab, parochial policy. It deprived Vic-Wells audiences of an international repertory and meant British dancers lacked the dazzle that might have rubbed off from contact with starry foreign guests. When, in 1948, Moira Shearer visited the great Russian ballerina Karsavina, who was retired in London, for some private coaching for her debut in Giselle, De Valois was livid. Her control over her company style had been breached.

Yet even if the British style tends towards physical and emotional reticence, De Valois drilled qualities of elegance, musicality and lyricism into it that have produced dancers such as Margot Fonteyn, Antoinette Sibley, Anthony Dowell and Darcey Bussell. Also, De Valois's policy of encouraging in-house choreography has produced an extraordinary creative line - from Ashton to John Cranko, Kenneth MacMillan, David Bintley and Ashley Page.

Though today's repertory is much more international, at its core remains a significant body of British ballets. De Valois's stable has also produced many of the UK's ballet directors, most recently Dowell at the Royal, Bintley at Birmingham, Derek Deane at English National and the late Christopher Gable at Northern. Not to mention those artists she sent abroad, helping to found state companies in Australia, South Africa and Turkey.

So she was, truly, an empire-builder. Yet, another of the criticisms levelled against De Valois is that she never stopped being empress. The question of what Madam might have thought has, according to some, engendered an enfeebling climate of deference and nostalgia. But it has also produced a consistency other companies yearn for.

Bintley, for one, believes that without the traditions De Valois put in place "our companies wouldn't have lasted nor would they continue to last. We have followed a gradual process of change that has allowed us to keep pace with trends. She always said, 'One foot in the future, one foot in the past.' I think we have got it right."

fields.headline: Bad news for the nobs
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
The splendours and miseries of the bourgeoisie were on display last night, in what was virtually a masterclass in the theory and practice of English life. The theory came from BBC2, which presented a perplexing picture of gracious living in Middle Classes: Their Rise and Sprawl. The focus was on the inter-war years, that Indian summer of wealth and privilege before the great levelling of the second world war. For two decades, families like the Courtaulds lived out a dream of Englishness, frolicking in their stately home and bestowing their wealth on deserving causes, notably the arts. Stephen and Virginia Courtauld transformed Eltham Palace into the last word in 1930s chic, a place where statesmen and musicians rubbed shoulders with industrialists and explorers (and where the pet lemur had its own room; doesn't yours?). If this was middle-class life, God help the rest of us: the Courtauld style was more royal than the royals.

Quite why Middle Classes chose the Courtaulds as a paradigm of the period wasn't clear. True, they had some significant figures within their ranks, but they were so exceptional they hardly revealed much about the rest of the nation. That said, they're a fascinating study, not least because Rab Butler, Churchill's wartime education minister, married into the clan and then set about delivering it a mighty hammer-blow. His 1944 education act provided decent secondary education for all - bad news for the nobs.

A mood of intense nostalgia suffused the last 20 minutes, as we fast-forwarded through the post-war reforms and the birth of the "meritocracy", right up to the present day, where birth and rank stand for little. This should have been a good thing, but when we saw the braying classes at a London "salon", it was hard to believe the change had been for the better.

Meanwhile, on BBC1, there was a practical demonstration of middle-class manners in the final episodes of two largely unloved comedy series. Office Gossip has an over-active laughter track and the worst theme song in the world - ever! ("If you come across/Any juicy goss/Keep it to yourself.") That said, Pauline Quirke as Jo was light on her feet in an occasionally stodgy script. She joined a dating agency and saw some predictable videotapes of freaks and losers, before deciding that she'd rather go to Dunkin' Donuts with her daughter than bother with all that mucky love business. She learned this after a day at the office, where resident stud Simon (Neil Stuke) was stabbed in the nose with a plastic fork by his boss/lover, thus prompting some desperate levity ("I've come across a forked tongue before, but never a forked nose"), which only the laughter track could love.

Far more satisfying was Adrian Mole - The Cappuccino Years (BBC1), which disappointed many but still seemed head and shoulders above the competition. Adrian (Stephen Mangan) discovered life as an ex-celebrity chef wasn't all cherries, after being gunged on The Rowland Rivron Show. Pandora (Helen Baxendale) fell from grace after some unguarded remarks about Peter Mandelson and deformed genitals (you had to be there). A romantic rapprochement seemed likely, until Alastair Campbell and a pesky firebomb intervened, leading to a genuinely affecting conclusion in which Adrian, like Office Gossip's Jo, learned that his kids really seemed to mean quite a lot to him.

Such faith in the coming generation may be touching, and even laudable, but you only have to recall the sobering lessons of history, as presented in Middle Classes, to realise that they'll all break your heart in the end.

Far more satisfying was Adrian Mole - The Cappuccino Years (BBC1), which disappointed many but still seemed head and shoulders above the competition. Adrian (Stephen Mangan) discovered life as an ex-celebrity chef wasn't all cherries, after being gunged on The Rowland Rivron Show. Pandora (Helen Baxendale) fell from grace after some unguarded remarks about Peter Mandelson and deformed genitals (you had to be there). A romantic rapprochement seemed likely, until Alastair Campbell and a pesky firebomb intervened, leading to a genuinely affecting conclusion in which Adrian, like Office Gossip's Jo, learned that his kids really seemed to mean quite a lot to him. Such faith in the coming generation may be touching, and even laudable, but you only have to recall the sobering lessons of history, as presented in Middle Classes, to realise that they'll all break your heart in the end.

fields.headline: Out on a limb
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... a pose too frequently adopted
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... a pose too frequently adopted
fields.body:
A reader looks askance at the Guardian's use of akimbo. He noticed a reference on the obituaries page to the "arms akimbo" style of a footballer whose career was being remembered. "I shall gently but pedantically point out," he said, "that akimbo has a very specific meaning: 'with hand on hip and elbow bent outward' (my Chambers suggests that it comes from Middle English 'in kenebowe'). [And probably, according to the Concise Oxford, from Old Norse before that.] To stand with arms akimbo is to assume the position of righteous indignation or amused tolerance or anger."

What the writer of the obituary clearly meant, my correspondent said, was that the footballer ran around with spread or flapping arms and not with his hands constantly on his hips. The obituarist actually wrote this: "His arms-akimbo style led his fellow England players to nickname him Flipper."

We usually get this right. Here is an example from the work of Neville Cardus, remembering a speech by George Bernard Shaw in Manchester in May 1906 (quoted in an article in the Guardian by Shaw's biographer, Michael Holroyd): "As he stood on the platform, arms akimbo, in tweeds and still the red flame of socialism in his beard, he told us to burn down Manchester town hall and the cathedral." We get the picture.

We can visualise the golfing coach David Leadbetter correctly too in this description of him: "the Englishman, who spends his days on the world's practice ranges, arms akimbo and long legs apart in a huge inverted V, is famous for his objectivity." More about legs in a moment, but before that one final example of "arms akimbo", this time from the women's pages, that provides an almost perfect illustration of the expression: "Think pantomime dame with arms akimbo and ballooning crinoline."

The Oxford English Dictionary, still hyphenating the word as 'a-kimbo' in the rather whiskery edition I have in front of me, provides just one unequivocal definition: "Of the arms: In a position in which the hands rest on the hips and the elbows are turned outwards."

The historical examples provided by the dictionary show the progress of the word towards us down the centuries, gradually assuming its recognisable present form, beginning with this quotation from about 1400: "The hoost... set his hond in kenebowe."

It quotes Sir Thomas Urquhart from the mid-17th century: "With gingling spurrs, and his arms a kenbol"; Sir Richard Steele, from the Spectator of the early 18th century: "She would clap her arms a kimbow"; Samuel Richardson in Clarissa (1748): "She set her huge arms akembo"; and finally Robert Browning in 1879: "Both arms a-kimbo."

Nowhere, you will notice, is there any mention of legs. To return to my correspondent for a moment: " 'Legs akimbo' is something that I see in your paper even more frequently [than arms akimbo]. I think this is actually very witty if you know what the word means, but I'm increasingly of the opinion that no one does. Shame."

Let us have a look. Here is something that appeared in a television programme note in one of our Saturday supplements, the Guide, recently: "The acting then takes on Eldorado proportions and [the actor] stands defiantly, legs akimbo in a proverbial force 10, pissing into it." One fears the worst.

Some of the paper's finest have fallen into the trap of mistakenly believing that akimbo simply means apart. Thus a photographer finds himself "straining over my camera with tripod legs akimbo". Many are caught "legs akimbo on the sofa", among them Anne Robinson, discovered "on her sofa in her black leather pants and her black boots and her black sleeveless T-shirt, knees up, legs akimbo"; and Liz Hurley, "posing in a silver lamé bikini with legs akimbo and tongue flickering provocatively".

We have used it in the context of childbirth: "Pregnant women are faced with two stark and equally unpalatable extremes: either submit legs akimbo to the stirrups..."

You could perhaps present an argument that some of these examples were describing legs that had assumed roughly the same shape as arms when akimbo. It does not sound very convincing, does it?

The most interesting thing for me is the way in which this illustrates how easily we adopt into our vocabulary a word without referring to the dictionary to check its meaning. I could provide umpteen examples from the Guardian, but then so could you. But, for instance: the confusion of "appraise" and "apprise" has been annoying some of us - the first means to estimate the value or quality of something and the other means to inform, so you might certainly appraise your mum, as one columnist did recently, but you would not be apprising her of anything.

I am digressing. My advice is to keep your arms akimbo or you won't have a leg to stand on.

fields.headline: Suns and dotters
fields.standfirst: Paul Signac's scenes of summer in St Tropez are taking the chill out of Paris in winter.  Stuart Jeffries  on the bad-boy of neo-impressionism
fields.trailText: Paul Signac's scenes of summer in St Tropez are taking the chill out of Paris in winter. Stuart Jeffries on the bad-boy of neo-impressionism
fields.body:
Another season, another cheerful French blockbuster exhibition at the Grand Palais in Paris. Last autumn, the gallery hosted Mediterranée: Courbet to Matisse, chronicling painters' love of setting up their easels in picturesque places along the sunny coastline. As winter set in, that show was just what hard-faced Parisians needed.

Now, as sleet falls outside the Grand Palais, we are drawn inside, where the blinds are down, to bask in a world of central heating and summery colours. Paul Signac (1863-1935), a sailor he, loved bobbing in his boat (called Olympia, after Manet's painting of the bored nude) off St Tropez and thereabouts. And, when he wasn't bobbing, he loved dotting canvases into being - of yachts on the red and silver Mediterranean.

He was a pointillist, you see - great friends with Georges Seurat. The pair formed a loose grouping of (hard to believe, this) bad-boy neo-impressionists in the mid-1880s. With leading aestheticians of the day, they developed elaborate theories about the massing of dots. A small corner of this exhibition is devoted to those theories, but few visitors go there. Instead, they wallow in the application of those theories - the peaceful view of the Cap Canaille at Cassis, with its single cottage overlooking a calm bay and an orange cliff. Very soothing.

Signac was a committed paysagiste - a Claude Lorrain of sun and dots - and so part of the pleasure of this exhibition is to study the changes in topography. St Tropez was, in the 1880s at least, a quiet fishing village, not marred by thong-wearing toughs or Brigitte Bardot's little dogs.

Paris, too, was quieter. In Signac's 1884 impressionist (not yet neo-impressionist) painting Rue Caulaincourt, there are two grey windmills hovering above the yellow street, the green-yellow picket fence and the blue-green field. Montmartre was rustic then. But the neighbourhood went to pot shortly afterwards: Van Gogh moved in, then Picasso, then all those hacks who paint people's portraits in the Place du Tertre. Signac, at least, recorded it before it all went wrong.

Such early works owe a great deal to Monet, but in 1886 Signac embraced pointillist techniques. La Neige was one of the first such works, depicting a light snowfall on the Boulevard de Clichy - dots of white fluttering against the trees, buildings and trams that have been miraculously dabbed into solidity. This was the start of his neo-impressionist revolution, and very pretty it was too. When Signac did figures, they almost inevitably recall what Seurat had done a little while before.

Thus, the bust and trussed waist of his servant in La Salle à Manger (1887) recalls the solid embonpoint of the woman in profile in Seurat's La Grande Jatte (1886). Signac is a happy painter: even One Sunday, with the Victorian paterfamilias glumly poking the fire, and his wife looking out of the windows, is pulled back from alienation by a too-jaunty palette.

It's a well-adjusted, rather banal career that unfolds before us, culminating in Au Temps d'Harmonie (1895), with its pseudo-prophetic subtitle: "The golden age is not in the past, it's in the future." Half-naked men play boules, picnickers pull figs off trees, people read, paint, swim, relax, court each other, dance in a circle underneath a spreading chestnut tree. What a boring vision of harmony! But Signac wasn't just dotty. His watercolours are sweeping, vertiginous affairs - or at least they would be if he had been more disturbed. In his studies of Antibes, the sky swirls like a timid version of Van Gogh's Starry Night.

A pleasant exhibition, but one that makes you hunger for an artist who didn't just record a floating world, but grabbed it by the throat. Signac was too polite to do that.

fields.headline: North Pembrokeshire
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
Before the countryside was shut down we had a sunny walk through the Pentre Ifan woods. This area has been wooded since the 12th century. With its many meandering streams and steep declivities it was best left to willow, oak and ash. In the 1960s it was turned into a conifer plantation which was subsequently neglected. As the board tells you "this effectively destroyed the natural habitat". For humans it also obliterated the natural contours of the land because it was impenetrable. Now the national park has taken over the wood. They started by cutting conifers. During this period the public was naturally urged to stay away. To gain access broad pathways were opened up. Once we were allowed to return we encountered an unrecognisable wood. There had been one footpath marked by a stone. Now you see the stone and struggle to orientate yourself.

All deciduous trees have been left standing, but where did the path go? The one you walked along with the dog's gloomily slinking behind: no smells, only uneasiness. The Brothers Grimm could have been collecting stories. No sounds. Now you bound along broad paths, discover pools, carry on to connect with yet another path, well-signposted to fresh delights. On the edge of the wood there used to be a cobbler's cottage. Naturally he planted snowdrops and they multiplied. There are primroses, lesser celandines and daffodils all looking after themselves. Daisies are flowering on grassy paths. A hazel bush has extravagant catkins flourishing their ripe potency surrounded by small, brilliant maroon female catkins.

Now you can see the flowers in the lanes, but not in the woods. If you're a farmer you cant move your sheep off their winter pastures. The land they're on may be waiting for potatoes to be planted or for a spring refurbishment for visitor's caravans or whatever, but the sheep stay where they are. This country relies on agriculture. And tourism. So perhaps we shouldn't be so shocked to see a pair of walkers, booted and rucksacked, marching over the land. But we are.

fields.headline: Blue heaven
fields.standfirst: In the church of jazz, it's a holy relic. Miles Davis made it in nine hours in 1959 and it still sells today. Ashley Kahn on the birth and afterlife of Kind of Blue
fields.trailText: In the church of jazz, it's a holy relic. Miles Davis made it in nine hours in 1959 and it still sells today. Ashley Kahn on the birth and afterlife of Kind of Blue
fields.body:
On a December morning in 1999, I entered Sony Music Studios, a squat, near windowless building on 10th Avenue. Inside, down a dimly lit corridor lined with posters of rock and rap artists, thick doors with porthole windows led into studios where large consoles with matrices of red and white lights stood next to racks full of the latest sound equipment.

Sony Music had built their recording centre in the remains of the old 20th-Century Fox Movie-tone repository. Where dusty film canisters had once stored a weekly chronicle of the world's troubles and triumphs, four stories of state-of-the-art studios now operated: new technology rising phoenix-like from the vestiges of old.

Four months earlier, I had written an appreciation of Miles Davis's melancholy masterpiece Kind of Blue on the 40th anniversary of its release. Now I had been granted a rare opportunity to hear the complete master tapes of the two sessions that produced the album. Sony Music - the parent company of Columbia records, which released Kind of Blue and remained Miles's record label for the majority of his career, rarely sent anyone to their subterranean archives in upstate New York or allowed the reel-to-reel tapes to be auditioned. When dealing with priceless and irreplaceable 40-year-old recordings, even the wear on the tape is a consideration. For a jazz fan like me, the occasion had the rarified, historic air of, say, the unearthing of an Egyptian tomb.

The receptionist directed me to room 305. Equipment dedicated to sound reproduction, including a turntable in a stone base with a speed lever reading "78 rpm," filled the room. Sitting amid the machines, scattered tape reels, vinyl records of varying formats and general clutter was an engineer trained in audio formats new, old and ancient. Delicately, he placed a reel of reddish-brown, half-inch ribbon on to a tape machine, manufactured expressly to play back archival three-track tapes. He paused, asked if I was ready. (Ready? I had been giddy with anticipation for weeks.) He hit the "play" button.

The tape threaded its way across the playback heads and I heard the voices of Miles Davis and his producer, Irving Townsend, the instantly recognisable sound of Miles's trumpet, John Coltrane's tenor saxophone, Cannonball Adderley's alto sax and the other musicians. I listened to their harmonised riffs start and stop and grew acclimated to the rhythm of the recording process. What could I hear or intuit that would reveal the secret of that spring, when Davis assembled his famed sextet (Coltrane, Adderley, pianist Bill Evans, bassist Paul Chambers and drummer Jimmy Cobb, with pianist Wynton Kelly taking over from Evans on one number) in a converted church in downtown Manhattan? How did this band talk while creating music for the ages? Was that Coltrane's voice or Adderley's? How - if at all did they prepare? What was Miles like in the studio? Why did that take end? I had learned that the three master reels, the few rolls of black and-white film, and the less-than-distinct memories of the drummer, a photographer, and a tape operator who were in the East 30th Street studio on that day back in 1959 were about all the evidence there was of the making of the album.

Still acknowledged as the height of hip four decades after it was recorded, Kind of Blue is the premier album of its era, jazz or otherwise. Its vapoury piano-and-bass introduction is universally recognised. Classical buffs and rage rockers alike praise its subtlety, simplicity and emotional depth. The album has sold millions of copies around the world, making it the best-selling recording in Miles Davis's catalogue and the best-selling classic jazz album ever. Significantly, a large number of those copies were purchased in the past five years, and undoubtedly not just by old-timers replacing worn vinyl: Kind of Blue is self-perpetuating, continuing to cast its spell on a younger audience more accustomed to the loud-and-fast aesthetic of rock and rap.

The album's appeal was certainly enhanced by Miles's personal mystique. Cool, well-dressed, endlessly inspired, and uncompromising in art and life, Davis was and still is a hero to jazz fans, African Americans and the international musical community. "Miles Davis is my definition of cool," Bob Dylan has said. "I loved to see him in the small clubs playing his solo, turn his back on the crowd, put down his horn and walk off the stage, let the band keep playing, and then come back and play a few notes at the end."

Davis, the second son of a well-to-do dentist in east St Louis, was seduced by jazz at an early age:

"I was in the sixth grade and before we went to school, there was a programme on the radio called Harlem Rhythm and I listened to it for 15 minutes - that's all it was. So I said, "I want to play music like that." Duke Ellington, Jimmie Lunceford, Count Basie and other swing-era luminaries led the big bands that caught the ear of the precocious youngster, who soon started playing on a surprise gift from his uncle: a used trumpet.

Miles discovered that his hometown had a vibrant and fertile jazz scene "St Louis then was like a conservatory," he recalled, filled with talented musicians like trumpeter Clark Terry, under whose spell Miles fell. His trumpet playing improved as fellow musicians taught him the value of a vibrato-less tone and stressed the need for sight-reading.

When, in 1944, a big band led by vocalist Billy Eckstine and featuring alto saxophonist Charlie Parker and trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie hit town, Miles was awestruck. The sounds he heard were the earliest rumblings of the bebop revolution - intense, unbridled solos rife with harmonic invention. Before the year was out he headed for New York city, ostensibly to get a musical education at the Juilliard conservatory. But when he arrived, he made a beeline for the bebop scene on 52nd Street and uptown in Harlem; that world had been his destination from the start. "I spent my first week in New York looking for Bird and Dizzy," Davis recalled.

He located his bebop heroes and began to perform with them regularly. At the start of his second year at Juilliard, he dropped out, complaining of the school's limited, classical approach to music education: "The shit they was talking about was too white for me." Yet, Miles thought less of his idols for ignoring the same music.

"I couldn't believe that all them guys like Bird, Prez [Lester Young], Bean [Coleman Hawkins], all them cats wouldn't go to museums or libraries and borrow those musical scores so they could check out what was happening. I would go to the library and borrow scores by all those great composers, like Stravinsky, Alban Berg, Prokofiev."

The pianist Bill Evans arrived at modal jazz more through his own conservatory studies (at South Eastern Louisiana University and later Mannes College of Music) than through the environment of clubs and studio dates. And it was his relationship with Davis that created the spark that resulted in Kind of Blue.

On the surface, it would be difficult to imagine two more contrasting musicians. One had grown into a charismatic performer, comfortable and serenely confident on centre stage; the other, bookish and withdrawn by nature, held himself and his music in extremely modest regard. Whereas Davis had left the conservatory for a nightclub education, Evans had an extensive academic background in classical studies and general music theory. While Davis was riding the crest of modern jazz explorations through the mid-50s, from bebop to cool to hard bop, Evans was performing with society bands and orchestras, taking Nat "King" Cole's swing-based piano playing as a model.

Despite their opposing characteristics, Davis and Evans proved to be two musical explorers bound by kindred passions and visions. Both were ardent fans of modern classical composers such as Rachmaninov and the French impressionists. In their ears, jazz and classical were two streams feeding into the same river. Miles's live-in girlfriend (and future wife), the dancer Frances Taylor, recalls that "the music we heard at home was Khatchaturian, Ravel, Brahms, and all of that, constantly". As related in Peter Pettinger's biography of Evans, How My Heart Sings, an old girlfriend of the pianist's remembered his daily routine: "He would usually play classical music... Rachmaninov, Beethoven and Bach. He would play that and then just drift into jazz in a very fluid kind of way."

Both Davis and Evans had also developed personal voices that, in strong contrast to the technique-driven jazz styles flowing around them, were all about pruning away excess and distilling emotion. They shared an obsessive lyricism and a melodic flow that suggested, rather than obviously defined, musical structure. Evans's rich, classical voicings on piano - uncommon in a jazz context - avoided playing the root note of a chord, thus opening up the music's harmonic possibilities. Miles's, by "playing one note and having it relate to several chords at the same time," accomplished something similar from another direction. Cannonball Adderley told Ira Gitler: "Coltrane and I call it the 'implied reference', the things Miles does."

Describing the pianist's effect, the usually terse Davis said: "Bill had this quiet fire that I loved on piano. The way he approached it, the sound he got was like crystal notes or sparkling water cascading down from some clear waterfall."

Some encountered the music when it first appeared in 1959: on a late-night radio station in Cleveland; in a Wisconsin furniture store selling records; live in a New York nightclub or at an outdoor festival in Toronto; on a jukebox in a Harlem watering hole. Others came across it in the 60s: among the mono LPs a friendly sales clerk with a flowered tie was selling off at a dollar a disc; playing at a late-night party in Greenwich Village. One acquaintance heard it in a college class on Zen.

Jazz veteran Ben Sidran recalls that "Clearly it was just a great seduction record. I can close my eyes and remember situations with long-forgotten girls." Because of "the trance-like atmosphere that it created, it's like sexual wallpaper. It was sort of the Barry White of its time," Steely Dan's Donald Fagen remembers. fields.bodyText: On a December morning in 1999, I entered Sony Music Studios, a squat, near windowless building on 10th Avenue. Inside, down a dimly lit corridor lined with posters of rock and rap artists, thick doors with porthole windows led into studios where large consoles with matrices of red and white lights stood next to racks full of the latest sound equipment. Sony Music had built their recording centre in the remains of the old 20th-Century Fox Movie-tone repository. For a jazz fan like me, the occasion had the rarified, historic air of, say, the unearthing of an Egyptian tomb. The receptionist directed me to room 305. Equipment dedicated to sound reproduction, including a turntable in a stone base with a speed lever reading "78 rpm," filled the room. Sitting amid the machines, scattered tape reels, vinyl records of varying formats and general clutter was an engineer trained in audio formats new, old and ancient. Delicately, he placed a reel of reddish-brown, half-inch ribbon on to a tape machine, manufactured expressly to play back archival three-track tapes. He paused, asked if I was ready. (Ready? Its vapoury piano-and-bass introduction is universally recognised. Classical buffs and rage rockers alike praise its subtlety, simplicity and emotional depth. Cool, well-dressed, endlessly inspired, and uncompromising in art and life, Davis was and still is a hero to jazz fans, African Americans and the international musical community. Davis, the second son of a well-to-do dentist in east St Louis, was seduced by jazz at an early age: "I was in the sixth grade and before we went to school, there was a programme on the radio called Harlem Rhythm and I listened to it for 15 minutes - that's all it was. Miles discovered that his hometown had a vibrant and fertile jazz scene "St Louis then was like a conservatory," he recalled, filled with talented musicians like trumpeter Clark Terry, under whose spell Miles fell. The sounds he heard were the earliest rumblings of the bebop revolution - intense, unbridled solos rife with harmonic invention. fields.headline: How it's done
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: The fertility specialists who seek to clone a human being are targeting men who want to have a genetically related child but have no sperm of their own.
fields.body:
The fertility specialists who seek to clone a human being are targeting men who want to have a genetically related child but have no sperm of their own.

They will take a cell from the infertile man and remove the nucleus containing the man's DNA, the set of 46 chromosomes containing the genes that determine most of his appearance.

The nucleus will then be injected into an egg, possibly taken from the man's wife or partner, which has had its own chromosomes removed.

Following the technique developed by Ian Wilmut and his team to create Dolly the sheep, a tiny pulse of electricity will be applied to fuse egg and transplanted nucleus into a single cell and, by a process which is still not understood, reprogram the transplanted genes to operate as if they were "young" again, enabling the cell to divide and differentiate into all the cells of a human body.

This cell will then, effectively, have been transformed into a human embryo.

The operation will be carried out many times to create a number of embryos.

In animal cloning, scientists implant many embryos in multiple surrogate mothers to maximise the chance of success. The Italian-American-Israeli human cloning consortium has stated that it will implant embryos in only one mother; it believes that it will be possible to screen embryos so thoroughly that the chance of a successful pregnancy will be as good as in conventional IVF treatment.

The child born in this way would resemble very closely, in physical appearance, the parent from whom the DNA was taken. But its upbringing and education would inevitably be different, as would its gestation in the womb.

webTitle: Team prepares to clone human being

fields.headline: Team prepares to clone human being
fields.standfirst:
Fertility experts present plans as last frontier in battle to defeat male sterility
Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Fertility experts present plans as last frontier in battle to defeat male sterility.
fields.byline: James Meek, science correspondent, in Rome
fields.body:
It is a contest they are unlikely to win, and one many believe should not be waged. But amid the chaos and doubt in Rome yesterday, it was clear, at least, that Severino Antinori and his partners had fired the starting gun in a race to produce a cloned human being.

Boasting of unlimited funds, a choice of six countries to work in and an embarrassment of scientific expertise, the Antinori private human cloning consortium set out its stall at a seminar in Rome's Institute of Clinical Obstetrics and Gynaecology.

Or to put it another way, the consortium would not say where, when or how they would clone a human being, who would do it or how much it would cost.

Only the fact that Mr Antinori and his colleagues work with human embryos on a daily basis in their fertility clinics and their single-minded determination to use cloning to treat one straightforward problem - male infertility - prompted the thought: What if they pulled it off?

Mr Antinori told the seminar - 90% of the delegates were, in fact, journalists - that his clinics had already begun sounding out clients.

Of 300 male patients whose sperm was unsuitable to produce children, he said, 70% had asked to be given the opportunity to produce a cloned child.

"Cloning may be the last frontier in our attempts to defeat male sterility," he said. "Cloning creates ordinary children who grow up to be unique individuals. We are here to encourage fruitful scientific research and good ethical behaviour."

"We do intend to clone the first human being," said Panos Zavos, Mr Antinori's key partner, who runs a fertility clinic in Lexington, Kentucky. "This is a solution to a human problem.

"We want to do it as soon as possible, but we have no intention of stepping over dead bodies."

Later he said the first experiments to lay the groundwork for the cloning programme could begin within weeks, with the first cloned embryo ready for implantation in a mother's womb within one and a half to two years.

He ruled out using the technology to try to clone dead children or famous people. The idea was to help men who had no sperm to have genetically related children without relying on a sperm donor.

"It's a dead-end street, it's a stop sign, if you're one of those males that face this particular difficulty, you think: 'God, why me? Why do I have to borrow sperm in order to get a child?'" he said.

Mr Zavos added that, unlike animal cloning programmes, they would not be implanting scores of embryos in many surrogate mothers in the hope of getting one successful pregnancy.

Twenty-three years of human IVF work had laid the basis for a more sophisticated approach, he said, involving screening embryos at the stage when they consisted of only a few cells to select the most likely to implant successfully, cultivating extra embryos from the best, and then implanting them in one mother.

The appearance of a third partner on the platform, Avi Ben Abraham, described as an Israeli-American biotechnologist, prompted speculation that the "Mediterranean country" referred to as a possible site for the first human cloning attempt was Israel. But the consortium would not be drawn.

If the organisation of yesterday's seminar was anything to go by, would-be clonees would be advised to look elsewhere. In the cramped well of a dingy lecture theatre, the animated, silver-haired Mr Antinori and assistants beat off waves of camera crews and photographers as they made their presentations.

At one point a man in a white coat entered and announced that the head of the department which ran the lecture theatre had been watching the seminar with mounting horror on CNN during a trip to China and strongly objected to an event supporting human cloning - condemned by the UN, the EU, the Council of Europe, the World Health Organisation and a catalogue of other bodies.

Towards the end, the hulking, bearded figure of Richard Seed, an early, discredited prophet of human cloning, unexpectedly took the floor. His last words before his microphone was cut off and he was led away were: "I'm going to try to clone my wife first. I'm going to try to keep the first five clones in the family - "

Real cloning is seen as lying in the realms of science. For now, it does. But the equipment and know-how required to at tempt to clone a human being is cheap and simple compared to that needed for a nuclear weapon or to put an astronaut in space.

Reproductive human cloning is not technically illegal in Britain, but the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority would certainly refuse permission. However, while some US states and countries, such as Japan, have banned it outright, others have not, and there are now few parts of the world without IVF centres: China, India and the former Soviet Union have many.

The science of human cloning is much tougher. All labs which have succeeded in cloning animals report a massive failure rate, from embryos failing to implant in wombs to miscarriages and deformities at birth.

The only lab in the world to have successfully cloned an animal from the family to which humans belong, the primates, told the Guardian this week that it had given up further attempts until it understood what was going wrong.

The Oregon Regional Primate Centre, which recently announced the birth of ANDi, the world's first genetically modified monkey, has never managed to clone a monkey using the Dolly technique, where an embryo is cultured from an adult cell. It has only ever done it with an older method, using a single cell from a natural embryo.

The centre's Don Wolf said: "I think it's ridiculous to venture into the realm of human reproductive cloning. The risks are clearly unacceptable."

It has only ever done it with an older method, using a single cell from a natural embryo. The centre's Don Wolf said: "I think it's ridiculous to venture into the realm of human reproductive cloning. The risks are clearly unacceptable."

webTitle: Has science found its clone prince?

fields.headline: Has science found its clone prince?
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Severino Antinori, the man who aspires to be the 21st century's clone prince, is president of the Italian society of reproductive medi cine, head of a thriving Rome-based chain of IVF clinics and now chairman of the Italian-US-Israeli private human cloning consortium.
fields.body:
Severino Antinori, the man who aspires to be the 21st century's clone prince, is president of the Italian society of reproductive medi cine, head of a thriving Rome-based chain of IVF clinics and now chairman of the Italian-US-Israeli private human cloning consortium.

Unlike other would-be cloners, such as the maverick Richard Seed or the Raelian cult - which claims a troop of 50 women volunteers as surrogate mothers - Professor Antinori has a long record of making children happen for desperate parents with money.

When Rossana Della Corte's son Ricardo died in a motorbike accident at the age of 17, she longed for another son. With the help of Prof Antinori and his IVF clinic, she gave birth to a baby boy called Ricardo in 1994. She was 63 years old.

Antinori has helped many other post-menopausal women, including, in 1993, a wealthy 59-year-old Briton, to have children.

That prompted the then Conservative health secretary, Virginia Bottomley, to say: "Women do not have the right to have a child. The child has a right to a suitable home."

Prof Antinori offered more than a dozen mothers guaranteed millennium babies, with a promise they would be born just after midnight on 31 December 1999, and claims to have helped infertile men by rearing their sperm to fitness in the testicles of mice.

Prof Antinori is 55 and has two children. He says he is a devout Catholic, and has met the Pope, although the Vatican has described his work as "grotesque" "evil" and involving "execrable techniques."

He is fascinated by the links between British and Italian work on human fertility. He reveres the British IVF pioneers, Robert Edwards and Patrick Steptoe, who created the world's first "test tube baby", Louise Brown, in 1978.

But he said yesterday that when, in 1777, the Italian Lazzaro Spallanzani wanted to try his newly discovered technique of artificial insemination on humans, it was a Briton, William Hunter, who dissuaded him.

fields.headline: Foot and mouth outbreak escalates
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Twenty new cases of foot and mouth reported yesterday - the largest daily total yet - has confirmed a second wave of the disease in cattle, ending all    hopes of an early end to the crisis.
fields.body:
Twenty new cases of foot and mouth reported yesterday - the largest daily total yet - has confirmed a second wave of the disease in cattle, ending all hopes of an early end to the crisis. The government's chief vet, Jim Scudamore, who had predicted that this weekend would see the number of cases dropping in response to the containment policy, said yesterday it would be a long haul. Restrictions on movement will be extended again.

An unknown number of sheep which were traded in infected markets cannot be traced because the sales were informal and no paperwork was completed.

With more than 100,000 carcasses to dispose of, the government is suffering logistical difficulties and in some areas animals are lying dead in the fields for days. In the West Country, farmers are calling for a state of emergency to be declared so the tonnes of coal and thousands of bales of straw needed for the pyres can be requisitioned.

There are fears that the holiday trade in parts of Cumbria, Northumberland and the West Country will be seriously damaged because movement restrictions will not be lifted in time for the Easter holidays.

Another casualty is the three-day Badminton Horse Trials, which attracts 250,000 spectators. The event, held on the Duke of Beaufort's estate in May, has been cancelled.

webTitle: Amazon boss accused of insider dealing

fields.headline: Amazon boss accused of insider dealing
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The bruised image of the dot.com industry suffered another blow yesterday when the founder of Amazon.com became embroiled in allegations of insider trading.
fields.body:
The bruised image of the dot.com industry suffered another blow yesterday when the founder of Amazon.com became embroiled in allegations of insider trading.

Reports suggested that Jeff Bezos, who is now chairman of the company which sells books, videos and CDs online, is being investigated by US financial regulators after selling 800,000 shares in the company. The disposals, at the beginning of last month, saw Mr Bezos pocket $11.5m.

The investigation is said to be focusing on the timing of the sales which took place the day before the publication of a negative report from an influential Wall Street analyst, Ravi Suria of Lehman Brothers, which questioned the ability of the online retailer to continue operating in 2001. It suggested the company's worsening financial position could subject it to a credit squeeze.

Amazon executives had received an advance copy of the research note a week earlier.

A similarly negative report from Mr Suria last June caused Amazon shares to fall by 20%, wiping $1bn from the founder's fortune. The company hit back describing his research as "hogwash".

The cloud over the sale ends another wretched week for the internet industry in which the chief executive of Yahoo! resigned.

A spokesman for Amazon said the company had not been informed of any investigation into the matter by the US regulator, the Securities and Exchange Commission.

He said the timing of the share sale had been dictated by Amazon's internal rules on when a director is allowed to trade rather than being influenced by the research note.

"Jeff's transaction had absolutely nothing to do with the report," the spokesman added. "Mr Suria first issued this report last June and this was an update which came to the same conclusions. There was absolutely nothing in it that hadn't already been said."

The spokesman pointed out that shares in Amazon had actually risen in value on the day Mr Suria's most recent report was published. "The company was aware of the report but whether Jeff saw it I don't know," he added.

The US regulator declined to comment on whether it had instigated an investigation. Last year it pursued 40 actions related to insider trading. It would need to prove that an individual acted on information that would have a material effect on a share price before it become public.

Mr Bezos, an internet pioneer, whose fortune ran to $8bn at the company's peak, is a role model for the get rich quick e-generation. His father came to the US from Havana in the early 1960s as part of a humanitarian effort to "rescue" young people from Cuba and arrived unable to speak English.

Amazon, launched by Mr Bezos in July 1995, has become the best known of the online retailers.

But it has been unable to escape the turmoil which has battered the dot.com sector in the past year. Amazon shares, worth more than $70 a piece 12 months ago, are now worth less than $12 each. Mr Bezos, who still owns about one-third of the company, has seen his worth shrink to around $1.3bn.

At the end of January, the online retailer announced plans to cut 1,300 staff - 15% of its workforce - and warned that sales in the coming year would be 10% lower than previously forecast.

The company's quarterly results showed that sales in its core books, CDs and videos segment are slowing dramatically to growth of just 11%.

webTitle: Sports stars caught in stocks sting

fields.headline: Sports stars caught in stocks sting
fields.trailText: The tennis star Steffi Graf and a high-profile American football player, Brian Cox, were duped in a mob-infiltrated stock fraud scheme that cheated investors around the world of $50m, a source close to the investigation revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
The tennis star Steffi Graf and a high-profile American football player, Brian Cox, were duped in a mob-infiltrated stock fraud scheme that cheated investors around the world of $50m, a source close to the investigation revealed yesterday.

Graf, identified in court on Thursday only as a professional tennis player, was cheated of more than $600,000 in a three-month period. Cox was identified in court only as a National Football League player. The amount of money he lost was not disclosed.

Among the other victims were two businessmen who each lost $1.2m, the New York state attorney general Eliot Spitzer said at a news conference announcing the arrest of 20 people thought to be involved in the fraud.

Kenneth Breen, who is prosecuting the case, said many of the investors were sophisticated, "including some financial advisers and people who knew the markets and had an understanding of the financial world".

A team of federal agents culminated a three-year investigation during raids on Thursday morning, in which they arrested 17 people in New York and one each in New Jersey, Florida and California.

The suspects were arraigned on charges including securi ties fraud and money laundering, which carries a maximum sentence of 20 years in prison. Two, Hunter Adams and Michael Reiter, were identified as associates in the Gambino organized crime family.

An indictment accused them of funneling illicit profits to their mob bosses from First United Equities Corporation, a now-defunct brokerage that had offices in New York, Garden City, New York state, and Woodbridge, New Jersey.

"Those behind this scam berated and threatened victims, made unauthorized trades, failed to execute sell orders and took their clients for all they were worth," Mr Spitzer said.

Attorney Joseph Tacopina, who represents one First United broker, James Bila, said his client "was just doing his job. He did nothing improper. We're confident he'll be cleared of any wrongdoing".

Between 1994 and 1998, brokers at First United and two other former boiler-room dealing operations - Lexington Capital, in Hauppauge, New York, and AGS Financial Group, in New York city - used high-pressure sales tactics to sell penny stocks at inflated prices, court papers said.

The defendants profited by selling off their own "house shares" before prices crashed, and tens of millions of dollars were laundered through domestic and foreign bank accounts, the papers added.

webTitle: The Budget: So who pays for care of elderly?

fields.headline: So who pays for care of elderly?
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's refusal to tackle the thorny issue of who will pay for the care of the elderly is unlikely to cost the Labour Party many votes, but it still ranks as one of the major election promises trumpeted by Tony Blair last time around that has somehow been sidelined,  writes Phillip Inman.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's refusal to tackle the thorny issue of who will pay for the care of the elderly is unlikely to cost the Labour Party many votes, but it still ranks as one of the major election promises trumpeted by Tony Blair last time around that has somehow been sidelined, writes Phillip Inman.

While the Scots have gone ahead and pumped cash into a scheme that will provide all forms of care to the over 65s without charge, pensioners in England and Wales too frail or sick to look after themselves must pay for their care in residential homes and their own homes if their assets amount to more than £18,000. Many of the two million pensioners eligible for income support benefit or living in rented accommodation will therefore receive care services free.

Following a Royal Commission report in 1999 that recommended free nursing and personal care for the elderly, the government chose instead to follow a rival report written by two dissident members of the commission who said only nursing care should be provided free. Ministers said free nursing care would apply from October this year. They added that nursing care could only be provided by a registered nurse. More commonly provided services by nursing assistants - even under the delegation and supervision of a registered nurse - will count as social care and must be paid for by the pensioner.

Mervyn Kohler, of Help the Aged, says the government has shied away from tackling the issue head on. "He shows no willingness to put public resources into the vital area of long-term care, which is a frighteningly expensive lottery of need which touches one in five older people."

The average age of a pensioner entering a residential home these days is 85, which means that most people will spend their retirement in their own home and need low-level care that is nonetheless expensive. It has been estimated that providing care services free to all elderly people would cost the government £1.1bn.

This week, shadow health secretary Dr Liam Fox bit the bullet and said that while he would match Labour's commitment to provide free nursing care for the elderly, he would seek better ways of funding long-term residential care.Dr Fox estimated that over the last four years, 160,000 people have been forced to sell their properties to finance residential care.

"To bring to an end the unacceptable asset-stripping of our elderly citizens, we will reward individual responsibility, and those who make reasonable provision for themselves," he said.

Dr Fox suggested that people who make their own provision to pay for up to £20,000 of residential care costs - roughly the average cost of such care - would be indemnified by the state if their stay in residential care proved to be longer and more expensive than the average. He claimed that would protect them against having to run down their assets to £18,000. Help the Aged, meanwhile, believes the government should follow the advice in the Royal Commission and pay for all care services.

webTitle: The Budget: Why were savers ignored this year?

fields.headline: Why were savers ignored this year?
fields.standfirst: The Chancellor has been accused of turning his back on investors. Rupert Jones looks at how this week's changes will affect them
fields.trailText: The Chancellor has been accused of turning his back on investors. Rupert Jones looks at how this week's changes will affect them.
fields.body:
Gamblers and those who like a drink enjoyed a Budget boost this week, but there wasn't much in Gordon Brown's red box for savers and investors.

There was some good news with the widening of the 10p income tax band, but the Chancellor was accused of missing a huge opportunity to give people more control over the way they can use their pension fund money when they retire. And he also rejected calls for a cut in stamp duty on small share purchases by private investors.

The rules have been changed to allow people to tuck more money away in tax-free Isa accounts - but we already knew about that, as it was fully announced in the November pre-Budget report.

And while Mr Brown endorsed a report issued this week, whose recommendations will encourage pension funds to invest in a wider range of companies, hopefully spelling higher returns, this will not give immediate benefits.

The Chancellor's lack of interest in savers is surprising because personal savings are at a worryingly low level. Recent official figures show that consumers are saving less of their incomes now than at any time in the past 12 years.

So what was - and wasn't - in the Budget for savers and investors?

Annuities

It wasn't mentioned in Gordon's speech or in the sheaf of Budget press releases, but buried deep in one of the thick Treasury documents was the news that the government has rejected calls to reform the rules that force people to buy an annuity with their pension savings when they retire.

That is a huge blow to many thousands of people approaching retirement who are dreading the moment they will have to convert their hard-earned pension fund into an annuity - which will provide them with an income for the rest of their life.

The very small consolation was that the government says it is keen to enable those buying annuities to make better-informed decisions and that it will look at what can be done to encourage more people to shop around for their annuity rather than simply taking the one offered by their pension company.

At the moment everyone with a personal pension or who belongs to a money purchase company scheme must use most of their pension fund to buy an annuity by the age of 75. Annuity rates have plummeted in recent years because of falling interest rates and because people are living longer.

The best level annuity rate currently available for a 65-year-old man is around 8%-9%, compared to a decade ago when they were at 14%-16%. That means a 65-year-old man with a £100,000 pension pot is looking at an income of, at best, £9,000 a year.

It has been suggested that people should only be required to buy an annuity large enough to keep them above the state support threshold, leaving them free to use the rest of their money in other ways. But the Treasury rejected such ideas as being too expensive.

This left campaigners fuming. Former Labour MP Dr Oonagh McDonald, director of the Retirement Income Reform Campaign, says: "I very much regret that Gordon Brown has not taken this opportunity to reform the unfair rules. Over 1m working people, having saved prudently throughout their working lives, will suffer."

10p rate of income tax gives a boost

Around 1m savers, many of them pensioners, will benefit from the widening of the 10p income tax band, which will apply to savings income. The Chancellor has extended the 10p starting rate of income tax by £300 to the first £1,880 of earnings. But those people benefiting will now have the hassle of reclaiming some of the tax that's automatically deducted from their savings.

Isas

As announced in the pre-Budget report, the annual limit of £7,000 on the amount people can invest in Isas will be kept for a further five years, until April 2006. It had been due to drop to £5,000 next month. Also, as announced, 16-year-olds and 17-year-olds will be allowed to open cash Isas, extending tax-free saving to 100,000 under-18s who work and pay tax, and the rules for Peps will come into line with those for Isas, giving Pep holders access to a wider range of investment opportunities.

Stamp duty on share deals

There were rumours that the Chancellor might halve or even abolish stamp duty on share buying, but these came to nothing. That means investors will continue to pay 0.5% stamp duty on share purchases.

This lack of action was widely condemned. IFA BestInvest says this tax makes the UK one of the most expensive places to deal in Europe, while stockbroker TD Waterhouse says: "Even though the government is encouraging individuals to make their own investments for the future, it is still taxing people for doing so."

Encouraging those on low incomes to save

The government says it will be consulting with the financial services industry on further ways of encouraging people on low and moderate incomes to save.

It revealed it might consider launching a new type of account where the money an individual puts in is matched by a contribution from the State. These are known as Individual Development Accounts (IDAs) and already operate in America.

There, IDAs typically encourage the less well-off to save for a specific purpose, such as buying a home, by matching the money they put in with a contribution from public or private funds.

Annuities It wasn't mentioned in Gordon's speech or in the sheaf of Budget press releases, but buried deep in one of the thick Treasury documents was the news that the government has rejected calls to reform the rules that force people to buy an annuity with their pension savings when they retire. That is a huge blow to many thousands of people approaching retirement who are dreading the moment they will have to convert their hard-earned pension fund into an annuity - which will provide them with an income for the rest of their life. The very small consolation was that the government says it is keen to enable those buying annuities to make better-informed decisions and that it will look at what can be done to encourage more people to shop around for their annuity rather than simply taking the one offered by their pension company. At the moment everyone with a personal pension or who belongs to a money purchase company scheme must use most of their pension fund to buy an annuity by the age of 75. Annuity rates have plummeted in recent years because of falling interest rates and because people are living longer. The best level annuity rate currently available for a 65-year-old man is around 8%-9%, compared to a decade ago when they were at 14%-16%. That means a 65-year-old man with a £100,000 pension pot is looking at an income of, at best, £9,000 a year. It has been suggested that people should only be required to buy an annuity large enough to keep them above the state support threshold, leaving them free to use the rest of their money in other ways. But the Treasury rejected such ideas as being too expensive. This left campaigners fuming. Former Labour MP Dr Oonagh McDonald, director of the Retirement Income Reform Campaign, says: "I very much regret that Gordon Brown has not taken this opportunity to reform the unfair rules. Over 1m working people, having saved prudently throughout their working lives, will suffer." 10p rate of income tax gives a boost Around 1m savers, many of them pensioners, will benefit from the widening of the 10p income tax band, which will apply to savings income. The Chancellor has extended the 10p starting rate of income tax by £300 to the first £1,880 of earnings. But those people benefiting will now have the hassle of reclaiming some of the tax that's automatically deducted from their savings. Isas As announced in the pre-Budget report, the annual limit of £7,000 on the amount people can invest in Isas will be kept for a further five years, until April 2006. It had been due to drop to £5,000 next month. Also, as announced, 16-year-olds and 17-year-olds will be allowed to open cash Isas, extending tax-free saving to 100,000 under-18s who work and pay tax, and the rules for Peps will come into line with those for Isas, giving Pep holders access to a wider range of investment opportunities. Stamp duty on share deals There were rumours that the Chancellor might halve or even abolish stamp duty on share buying, but these came to nothing. That means investors will continue to pay 0.5% stamp duty on share purchases. This lack of action was widely condemned. IFA BestInvest says this tax makes the UK one of the most expensive places to deal in Europe, while stockbroker TD Waterhouse says: "Even though the government is encouraging individuals to make their own investments for the future, it is still taxing people for doing so." Encouraging those on low incomes to save The government says it will be consulting with the financial services industry on further ways of encouraging people on low and moderate incomes to save. It revealed it might consider launching a new type of account where the money an individual puts in is matched by a contribution from the State. These are known as Individual Development Accounts (IDAs) and already operate in America. There, IDAs typically encourage the less well-off to save for a specific purpose, such as buying a home, by matching the money they put in with a contribution from public or private funds.

Tax on wagers abolished.

Improved maternity pay Additional £10 a week children's tax credit for new born children from April 2002

Compulsory paternity pay.
