webTitle: Police obscenity squad raid Saatchi gallery

fields.headline: Police obscenity squad raid Saatchi gallery
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: The Saatchi gallery has been raided by officers from Scotland Yard's obscene publications unit and warned that they will return to seize pictures in its current exhibition, I am a Camera, unless the offending images are removed before the gallery opens its doors to the public again.
fields.body:
The Saatchi gallery has been raided by officers from Scotland Yard's obscene publications unit and warned that they will return to seize pictures in its current exhibition, I am a Camera, unless the offending images are removed before the gallery opens its doors to the public again.

The Metropolitan police confirmed last night that officers had visited the gallery twice this week after three complaints under anti-child pornography legislation and a report was being forward to the crown prosecution service.

The exhibition features the work of a group of artists and photographers selected by Charles Saatchi himself and taken from his personal collection of photographs and paintings. It has been running for eight weeks and has been reviewed in most of the broadsheet papers and magazines from the Tatler to the Telegraph, without any public complaints to the gallery.

The police have also warned a London international fine art publisher, Edward Booth-Clibborn, to remove from sale thousands of copies of his book I am a Camera, on which the exhibition is based, by next Thursday or he will also face the threat of prosecution. "The police told me that they want them 'all out' of the bookstores," he said.

The images at the centre of the police action against the gallery involve two photographs by Tierney Gearon, a former fashion photographer, in a series of 15 snapshot-style images that document her personal family life. They both depict her two children, Emily and Michael, aged six and four, naked or partly naked while playing. In one the two children are wearing theatrical masks while in the other her son is urinating in the snow. The police have also voiced concerns about a small photograph by Nan Goldin on page 50 of the 499-page book, which also features pictures by Tracey Emin and Andy Warhol.

Inspector Brian Ward of Scotland Yard's obscene publications and internet unit first visited the gallery "as a member of the public" to see the photographs on display before he went to the gallery in St John's Wood, north London, on Thursday for a second time with other officers to confront the curator. He told them he would return with a warrant to seize the pictures if they were not removed before the gallery reopens to the public next Thursday.

The Met would not confirm last night that it was acting after a complaint from a Sunday newspaper but Insp Ward told the gallery's curator, Jenny Blythe, and Mr Booth-Clibborn that he was acting after receiving complaints from the press and members of the public. A Met spokeswoman said there had been three separate complaints but was not prepared to discuss who had made them.

Within hours of the inspector's second visit, Tierney Gearon, the photographer in question, was visited by two journalists at her home address initially claiming they were from the Telegraph. They gained entry while she was out by claiming they had an appointment. The News of the World last night denied that it was behind the complaint to the police or had visited the artist's home.

Ms Blythe of Saatchis said the gallery had been shocked by the police's action and vigorously denied that the photographs in question were in any way pornographic. "I was so surprised I could not quite believe it," she said. "They are funny and delightful. Tierney Gearon is totally devoted to her children. They are snapshots of her children at play. They are not depraved in any way."

A leading lawyer on freedom of expression, Geoffrey Robertson, is believed to have advised the gallery that what it faces amounts to censorship by police threat and that the depiction of children without sexual overtones is not indecent.

The police are understood to have taken legal advice before raiding the gallery and are acting under the 1978 Protection of Children Act, which makes it a criminal offence to take an indecent photograph of a child. Police questioned the ITN newsreader Julia Somerville under the act in 1995 over pictures she took of her seven-year-old daughter in the bath. The CPS took no action.

Mr Booth-Clibborn's book is on sale in bookshops throughout Britain and also in America, Japan and Germany. One of the controversial photographs features on the cover of the British edition. He said that police suggested he cut out the pages that contained the photographs.

The raid is the first on an art gallery since the obscene publications squad seized pictures by John Lennon and others in the late 1960s.

webTitle: The Budget: What it means for them? The Royle Family.

fields.headline: What it means for them?
fields.standfirst: The Royle Family
fields.trailText: The Royle Family
fields.body:
Denise and David

More designer clothes for baby David? A Budget aimed at families should see Denise and David with lots of extra cash - but only if they go out to work. Oh Denise, not sure you're going to like it.

The Children's Tax Credit and Working Families tax credit are worth a bumper £3,245 to a family with an income of £10,000, £538 more than last year. A £10,000 earner also picks up an extra £134 from income and NI tax cuts, while child benefit for baby David goes up to £15.50 a week from £15.

But the catch is that the Chancellor made it very clear that he wants to reward hard-working families, not benefit claimants. Dave, a part-time DJ, probably does not fall within the formal tax system so baby David may in reality see little extra cash. Families on income-related ben efits will not gain from the increases in WFTC or the CTC, obtaining just £1.50 extra per week in allowances from next October.

Quite how Denise is going to keep her 40-a-day habit going is difficult to fathom out. There's only an extra 6p on cigarettes, but that takes the cost of 40-a-day from £3,044 a year to £3,087 - assuming she doesn't buy them off the back of a van.

Jim and Barbara

"Everyone's a winner? My arse!" There's precious little cash for Jim Royle from the Chancellor this week - and a threat from Mr Brown that the hard-to-employ will face "stronger sanctions" to get them back into the workforce.

Assuming Barbara earns £10,000 a year down at the bakery, she will see her income rise by £134 a year - or little more than the cost of sending Lurky down the chippie once a week.

And as Antony is over 16, they've recently had to wave goodbye to £15 a week in child benefit, and won't see a penny from the Children's Tax Credit.

Without a car, they won't even gain from the cut in the petrol price.

Generally, employed but childless couples gained little in the Budget - an extra £260 from the widening of the 10% tax band, but not much else.

Nana

Nana gets an extra £5 on her state pension, taking it to £72.50 a week, probably enough to pay for a few more snowballs.

If she doesn't receive any money from other sources she also gains from the rise in the minimum income guarantee to £92.15 a week for a single pensioner. Carry on like this and Jim might finally let her move in.

But the thing that may finally tip Jim over is the fact that, now 75, Nana gets a free TV licence.

Generally pensioners fared moderately well from the Budget, with the personal allowance for people aged between 65 and 74 rising by £200, meaning that the first £5,990 of income is not taxed.

Couples enjoy a pension rise of £8 to £115.90 a week, and the minimum income guarantee increases to £140.55.

fields.headline: Slowdown hits Wetherspoon
fields.trailText: Fears about a slowdown in sales yesterday knocked the froth off fast-growing JD Wetherspoon, which now runs 470 pubs.
fields.body:
Fears about a slowdown in sales yesterday knocked the froth off fast-growing JD Wetherspoon, which now runs 470 pubs. Shares lost 56.5p to 347.5p as chairman Tim Martin announced underlying sales in February up just 3.1% on last year's levels. In February 2000 growth was running at 14%.

Mr Martin has been warning the City of a slowdown in growth for some time, but yesterday said that March sales had picked up.

The share price reaction wiped more than £100m off the value of the group, however, which had been a favourite among many City analysts. The shares had outperformed the stock market by 21% over the past 12 months.

Mr Martin - who has a 15% stake in the group worth more than £110m - said he was unconcerned about the City's reaction: "I'm not an expert in shares. I always try to ignore the share price as much as I can. It has its ups and downs and I believe the business is stronger than it has ever been".

He was announcing half-year profits up 31% at £20.5m and a 10% increase in the dividend payout to 1.0p. The February sales slowdown came after 6.5% growth in the half-year to the end of January, which included a 10% increase in Christmas business.

"The like-for-like sales slowdown brings the group close to the industry norm," said analyst Nigel Popham at Teather & Greenwood. Mr Popham has rated the shares a "sell" for some time as he regards them as expensive in a mature market.

Mr Martin said the group's margins had been hit by two promotions - offering coffee at 49p instead of 99p and a "beer and a burger" for £2.99. He was particularly pleased with the coffee campaign, which doubled the number of cups sold to 400 per pub per week.

He is now considering opening his pubs early to try to steal business from the likes of Starbucks and Costa coffee. "We want their business bad," he said.

Wetherspoons is also intending to start promoting more local ales. "We are pushing ahead with more traditional ales from small brewers, which are a neglected area," said Mr Martin.

He hit out at the decision by the big brewers to increase their prices this month - a move which could put 6p-10p on the price of a pint at the bar. Scottish Courage prices went up 2.5% last Monday and Bass plans a 2.8% price rise on March 25.

He said: "I don't think it was very clever of them to put up prices just after the chancellor has said he is freezing the duty. It is not the most brilliant marketing ploy."

Wetherspoons, which specialises in turning old supermarkets, cinemas and garages into pubs, plans to open up to 100 pubs a year.

fields.headline: Stella's marketing star quits Interbrew
fields.trailText: Miles Templeman, the man who made Stella Artois "reassuringly expensive", has resigned as boss of Interbrew's British arm after a year of turmoil surrounding the business's ownership, writes Andrew Clark.
fields.body:
Miles Templeman, the man who made Stella Artois "reassuringly expensive", has resigned as boss of Interbrew's British arm after a year of turmoil surrounding the business's ownership, writes Andrew Clark.

Mr Templeman was managing director of Whitbread's brewing arm when it was bought by Interbrew last year. He said yesterday that he was uncomfortable with the Belgian conglomerate's level of involvement in the business: "From my point of view, my autonomy as managing director was going to be less free."

Interbrew followed its acquisition of Whitbread's brewing division by paying £2.3bn for Bass Brewers. Trade secretary Stephen Byers has ordered this deal to be unwound, however.

Initially, Mr Templeman lost out to Iain Napier, the head of Bass Brewers, in the battle to run Interbrew's combined British operations. He got his job back when it became clear that Bass Brewers would need to be kept separate.

Mr Templeman is considering job offers at venture capital firms but has ruled out joining a buyout bid for Bass Brewers: "I have agreed that I will not join the competition."

He is credited with repositioning Stella Artois as a premium lager, with marketing campaigns stressing its continental exclusivity.

He has been replaced by Stewart Gilliland, previously sales and marketing director.

fields.headline: Nasdaq falls for an old trick
fields.standfirst: Hi-tech index drops £2,000bn
fields.trailText: Hi-tech index drops £2,000bn.
fields.body:
Today is March 10, the first anniversary of the day the Nasdaq peaked at 5049. Last night this US hi-tech indicator stood just above 2000, having fallen almost 5% during the day. A fitting salute from Wall Street.

This startling period in stock market history - $2,000bn or more of paper wealth created and destroyed in a matter of months - will draw gasps from future generations. So we should note a few examples of the singular thinking of the era which now seems quite mad but which just 12 months ago permeated every corner of the business and investment world.

Remember the concept of getting "Amazon-ed?" There was a belief that established businesses were incapable of thinking and acting quickly enough to engage in the internet revolution. Since shops, for example, would cease to exist in a physical sense, Barnes & Noble, then America's biggest book retailer, would die. This model was transposed onto any and every form of commerce.

A few sceptics at the time suggested Jeff Bezos' company should be called Amazon.org since it was a non-profit organisation that would never turn a dime. They were more than half right, although Mr Bezos still managed to turn a good few of his paper millions into good ol' cash before the world noticed that all well-managed companies - whether old or new - were capable of implementing technology and protecting their business space.

Then there was the idea that in order to play in the web economy, participants had to eschew traditional businesswear and don things like shorts instead - an arrogant and divisive notion which was never going to go down well beyond sun-kissed California.

It was pointed out recently that Marks & Spencer used to experience a surge in demand for suits during times of recession. The threat of economic hardship spurred an urge to conform. So perhaps we should all be looking to buy shares in tailors. (M&S is a bad management tale, an old economy company that simply didn't get "people" rather than failing to understand "technology." Forget the stock.)

These were called "internet incubators" and, in Britain especially, they proved to be one of the most dangerous variants of the web investment disease. Typically, a bandit financier would raise, say, £5m amongst his mates in the City at 10p a share. The vehicle holding this money would be floated on the Alternative Investment Market as a shell company, taking advantage of a loophole in the regulations which allows the quotation of business which are not businesses at all.

The shell company would then knock out a statement saying it was going to make strategic investments in the new economy and the share price would go to £5. Simple as that.

A year on from the Nasdaq peak, there is no calling whether the rot has almost stopped. Yesterday, one US commentator was predicting the US index would fall all the way to 500 before prices looked realistic. But then investment history says the time to buy is when everyone is shouting "sell!" For the moment, we will bottle-it and say "hold".

If you can make it there, you'll make it anywhere but sadly Belgo has gone down like a dish of dodgy shellfish in New York.

It appears that, not for the first time, the company's chairman Luke Johnson has been a touch over-confident in his expansion strategy.

Despite having just a handful of restaurants in Britain, the company decided to jump across the Atlantic at the first opportunity. Bigger operators, including Mr Johnson's former vehicle Pizza Express, have found the move similarly challenging.

American diners are fond of easy-to-grasp brands, which Belgo is not. Particularly in the sweltering summer, New Yorkers prefer a light and airy environment to Belgo's bare-brick dungeons. Belgo's quirks, such as waiters in monastic attire and scores of different flavours of schnapps, did not conform to the Big Apple's idea of cool.

Belgo's usually upbeat tone was flatter yesterday, following a poor first couple of months to the year. Gossips say even The Ivy, the company's top-end London establishment, is feeling the pinch, although it was fully booked yesterday.

A great deal is riding on Belgo's new pizza concept, Strada. It has made a good start, but if it fails to establish a niche in an already crowded pizza market, Mr Johnson and his colleagues could start feeling the heat from investors hungry for something more appetising.

webTitle: New York rejects mussels and beer

fields.headline: New York rejects mussels and beer
fields.trailText: Belgo, the mussels and beer restaurant chain, has closed its restaurant in New York after failing to convince American diners of the delights of moules meuniere and Leffe Blonde.
fields.body:
Belgo, the mussels and beer restaurant chain, has closed its restaurant in New York after failing to convince American diners of the delights of moules meuniere and Leffe Blonde.

The failure of the firm's first excursion outside the British Isles cost £1.38m, causing a 65% dive in half-year profits to £555,000.

Chief executive Andy Bassadone said: "We have a very traditional north European food offering in a modern environment. I think Americans found it a bit of an unusual concept."

The cultural gap was aggravated by a poor choice of site: "It was a difficult location - not quite in the East Village, with a very small frontage."

Belgo made its name in London with quirks such as waiters dressed as monks. Chaired by former Pizza Express supremo Luke Johnson, the company now has 22 restaurants, including a pizza chain named Strada and exclusive London eateries such as The Ivy and Le Caprice.

Belgo's Dublin restaurant is faring poorly and further overseas expansion has been put on hold. Belgo's shares, which reached 10p two years ago, fell 0.25p to 3p.

fields.headline: National Mutual up for grabs
fields.trailText: Windfalls of several hundred pounds each could be on the way for up to 250,000 policyholders of mutual pension company National Mutual after it effectively put itself up for sale yesterday.
fields.body:
Windfalls of several hundred pounds each could be on the way for up to 250,000 policyholders of mutual pension company National Mutual after it effectively put itself up for sale yesterday.

The company, which counts Queen Victoria and Winston Churchill among its past customers, looks set to bring 105 years of mutuality to a close after it announced it was approaching prospective buyers as part of a review of its status.

National Mutual said it had made the decision partly because of the continued speculation about its status. During the last year or so it has been targeted by carpetbaggers.

The company has been viewed as a potential takeover target for some time, and some industry observers said it lacked the necessary size to compete in today's market, which is set to be transformed next month by the arrival of low-cost stakeholder pensions.

Based in Hitchin, Hertfordshire, the company has 250,000 policyholders, of whom 150,000 are members holding with-profits policies. Its total assets are £4.8bn, and there are 690 staff.

Any deal would have to be approved by 75% of members voting.

fields.headline: Riots against Kuchma rock Kiev
fields.trailText: Ukrainian riot police used teargas and truncheons yesterday against thousands of protesters hurling stones and bottles at the presidential administration building and demanding the resignation of President Leonid Kuchma.
fields.body:
Ukrainian riot police used teargas and truncheons yesterday against thousands of protesters hurling stones and bottles at the presidential administration building and demanding the resignation of President Leonid Kuchma.

The police said as many as 18,000 people joined the protest in the capital, Kiev, in the course of the day, making it the biggest and most violent of the present political crisis.

As night fell vicious fighting broke out between demonstrators from the Ukraine Without Kuchma movement and the chain of police officers defending the building.

"Fascists! Fascists! Kuchma out! Kuchma out!" the crowd chanted as a core of 100 demonstrators repeatedly hurled themselves at the police.

Teargas canisters were picked up and thrown back at the police, and the crowd cheered after one officer's tear-gas gun exploded in his hands.

"Look, look, look at this, Ukrainian blood spilled by Ukrainians," one woman yelled, brandishing a bloodstained handkerchief at the police during a lull in the battle.

The protesters, 70 of whom were arrested according to the police, accused Mr Kuchma of being involved in the murder of the journalist Georgy Gongadze, whose headless corpse was found outside Kiev last year.

In November an opposition leader produced audio tapes on which the president's voice could be heard telling subordinates to "deal with" the reporter.

Mr Kuchma denies being involved is his death and claims that the tapes have been doctored.

The investigation of Gongadze's death has made little progress.

Witnesses in the capital saw police officers beat demonstrators on the legs and heads, while protesters with home-made truncheons injured several officers, some seriously.

The windows of buses and cars were smashed as the crowd moved through the city.

The demonstration was timed to disrupt the celebration of the 187th birthday of Ukraine's most famous poet, Taras Shevchenko.

The demonstrators failed to stop Mr Kuchma laying a wreath at the poet's grave in the morning, but they later removed and destroyed it: an opposition leader said it was an act of "symbolic cleansing".

Mr Kuchma, who left the city after the wreath-laying to survey the floods that have swept through the country this week, said: "If all the money that has been spent on political actions was sent here, then people would be much better off."

Despite the protests, political analysts doubt that Mr Kuchma will be toppled soon. They point to his tough grip on the government and his skill in exploiting and facing down the less-than-united opposition.

webTitle: Rebels walk Zapata's road to Mexico City

fields.headline: Rebels walk Zapata's road to Mexico City
fields.standfirst: Subcommandante Marcos invokes the magic of a revolutionary hero to seek concessions from the new president
fields.trailText: Subcommandante Marcos invokes the magic of a revolutionary hero to seek concessions from the new president.
fields.byline: Duncan Campbell and Jo Tuckman in Tlaltizapan
fields.body:
He stands in the main square of Anenecuilco with his rifle clasped in his right hand, his ammunition belts across his chest, wearing the hat that has made him famous around the world. He is 15ft tall.

Emiliano Zapata, the assassinated hero of the Mexican revolution of 1910-20, is commemorated by the statue in this, his home town in the central south of the country. And behind him on this crisp blue morning is the man who is seen by his followers as heir to the revolutionary's dreams and is about to describe himself as a son of Zapata.

Subcommandante Marcos may not be carrying his rifle and wearing his ammunition belt, but he stands at least 15ft tall in the eyes of the hundreds of admirers who have gathered to hear the first speech of the day by the rebel leader from Chiapas.

His face hidden by his ski mask, he puffs his pipe and acknowledges the cheers in which cries of "Viva Zapata!" mingle with "Viva Marcos!"

This is day 12 of the march of the Zapatistas from their base in Chiapas to Mexico City to advance their battle for the rights of indigenous people.

Tomorrow - Sunday - they are due to enter the Zocalo, Mexico City's main square and the symbolic heart of the nation. But this is a day of homage to the man who gave his name to the Zapatista movement, the man who was ambushed and killed on 10 April 1919 but has remained a symbol of the frustrated hope of radical change in Mexico.

"We come here to pay tribute like children and grandchildren," says the subcommandante.

"Our general, Emiliano Zapata, taught us not to struggle for power, because power poisons the blood and clouds the mind."

The day began at the church of San Nicholas in Tetelcingo, where Marcos and his 23 fellow commandantes were billeted overnight by a friendly priest.

After leaving the smoking Popocatepetl volcano far in the distance, the caravan is visiting the places where Zapata was born, was killed, and from which he launched his triumphant entrance into Mexico City in 1914.

This march, which also aspires to a triumphant entrance to the capital, was begun by the Zapatistas after Vicente Fox made a peace offer to the rebels one of his first acts as president.

The marchers want all Zapatistas held prisoner since their Chiapas uprising began in 1994 released, troops withdrawn from the state, and a bill guaranteeing political and cultural rights to the 10m indigenous Mexicans, the "poorest of the poor" in a country of 100m.

The "Zapatour" has been portrayed by some as a sort of rock tour with politics: an impression enhanced by the T-shirts emblazoned with the dates of the venues - Oaxaca, Veracruz, Morelos, Hidalgo - and the many requests to Subcommandante Marcos for his autograph.

Of the 24 buses in the caravan, 23 are filled with supporters and observers from all over Mexico, and from as far away as Spain and Italy, Argentina and Canada.

One carries the commandantes. But as the tour wends its way through the state of Morelos it seems closer to an upbeat Latino Jarrow march. Thousands of people line the streets in isolated villages and small rural towns to wave the Zapatistas on.

Children are held aloft to catch a glimpse, old women squint against the morning sun and wave triangular Zapatista flags, pot-bellied ranchers with straw cowboy hats, doctors with stethoscopes round their necks, teenagers in Iron Maiden T-shirts, all wait patiently in the sun as little boys shout: "They're coming! They're coming!"

Margarita Aguiano, 90, can recall the original Zapata bringing food to her family during the revolution.

"We are all indigenous," she says. "We are all equal, we are all children of God. I want to see him, I want to see Marcos."

Appeal to ideals

Even the urbane President Fox, interviewed the previous night on television, accepted that 75% of the country was in favour of the march, though this support depends on an eventual peace between the guerrillas and the government.

By lunch-time the caravan has arrived at Chinameca, where the bullet holes in the crumbling hacienda archway on the main square still give testimony to Zapata's end. At each stop the subcommandante introduces one or two of his fellow Zapatistas: Commandante Tacho or Commandante Susanna or Commandante Moises, all masked.

They stand a few inches shorter than their leader and are less assured public speakers than "el sub", delivering their speeches from a handwritten text in a school notebook. The crowds applaud them politely, but it is Marcos they want to hear and - as far as it is possible through the wisps of pipe smoke, the mask and the battered combat cap - to see.

He speaks briefly, signs autographs and climbs back on the bus. His speeches are alternately polemical and poetic, and peppered with humour. Even his wave to the crowd is a playful one, the kind that grown-ups give children, clenching and unclenching fingers like a wink.

It is an acknowledgement that the strength of this army lies not so much in the weapons it left in the jungles of Chiapas as the hold it has on the country's imagination and the memories it conjure of the idealism Zapata represented before the word "revolution" was devalued by the Institutional Revolutionary party, (PRI), itself dispatched by the voters in July after 71 years of power.

Hard bargaining

The third stop of the day in Morelos state is Tlaltizapan, the old headquarters of Zapata's army. Here teenagers drape themselves over the branches of the two giant truenos (thunder trees) which overshadow the main square. Elderly women wave bowls of incense over the stage in a ritual of protection.

There is even one of Zapata's surviving footsoldiers, an ancient and frail soul brought on stage in a wheelchair to meet the leader of the movement that has taken her old general's name.

"People of Morelos, you have given us the most beautiful history lesson we have ever received in our lives," Subcommandante Marcos says. "You have known how to look after the memory and we know the memory is the fuel for those who struggle."

Predictions that the march would run into hostility from rightwingers disgruntled by President Fox's decision to allow this strange caravan of outlaws and their supporters to travel so freely have, so far, not been realised.

The federales are shadowing the match at a discreet distance, heavily armed and bullet-proofed. The 230 Italian radicals who took charge of security and were nicknamed the monos blancos (white monkeys) because of their white dungarees were withdrawn after criticism in the Mexican press.

A sense of optimism hangs over the gatherings like the smell of sugar from the nearby refineries, one of which bears the old Zapata slogan Tierra y Libertad on a derelict brick chimney.

"We are certain that there is an overwhelming national consensus that things cannot stay the way they are," Subcommandante Marcos says before heading off for the final rally of the day at Milpa Alta, on the outskirts of the capital, "that we cannot continue living the way they have made us live until now."

Tomorrow they enter the capital - in the case of some of the Zapatistas, for the first time. After that, the hard bargaining will begin.

Subcommandante Marcos knows that the people he will be addressing next will not be the adoring indigenos and the admiring Mexican left but traditional politicians less amenable to his radical views and less swayed by his charm. But to the marchers the dream is still alive. The dogs bark and the caravan moves on to the strains of "Viva! Viva! Viva!"

fields.headline: Sharon invites Arafat to meeting
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, who famously said he would never shake the hand of Yasser Arafat, has invited the Palestinian leader to talks.
fields.body:
The Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, who famously said he would never shake the hand of Yasser Arafat, has invited the Palestinian leader to talks.

The offer, extended after Mr Sharon's first full day as prime minister yesterday, makes no mention of his repeated inistance that Mr Arafat must rein in the uprising before the negotiations can resume.

His message reads: "I hope we can find a way of establishing personal contacts soon, in order to put an end to the cycle of bloodshed, violence and incitement, and to renew the economic and security cooperation."

Prime ministerial aides insisted that the offer of "personal contacts, or channels of communications" did not represent a retreat by Mr Sharon.

"A meeting is not negotiations," his spokesman, Ra'anan Gissin, said. "That will not happen. It is simply a meeting in order to explain Mr Sharon's position."

That explanation may not satisfy Israelis, particularly those who voted for Mr Sharon expecting him to live up to his reputation as a warrior and crack down hard on the Palestinians.

Mr Sharon outlined his three conditions for resuming negotiations in a telephone conver sation with Mr Arafat two weeks ago, and made his refusal to hold talks under fire the central plank in his election campaign.

The apparent softening of his stance coincides with the first report of disagreement with his foreign minister, Shimon Peres.

webTitle: Priest curses Mugabe at farmer's funeral

fields.headline: Priest curses Mugabe at farmer's funeral
fields.standfirst: >Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: An emotional funeral gathering of farmers and opposition members heard a Presbyterian minister call down a curse on President Robert Mugabe's government yesterday in this town in southern Zimbabwe.
fields.body:
An emotional funeral gathering of farmers and opposition members heard a Presbyterian minister call down a curse on President Robert Mugabe's government yesterday in this town in southern Zimbabwe.

The occasion was the service for Gloria Olds, the white farmer murdered earlier this week. She is the latest casualty of the movement to take over white farms, takeovers which the supreme court has ruled are illegal but the government encourages.

Sincethat ruling the chief justice has been forced into early retirement, and yesterday it was announced that his successor was to be a Mugabe ally, Judge Godfrey Chidyausiku, 54, a former deputy minister.

Olds's elder son Martin was killed last year. At yesterday's service the Rev Paul Adrianatos said: "For those responsible for the murders of Gloria and Martin Olds, I pray that they be cursed."

"For officials and cabinet ministers who ignore and act against just laws, I pray for your curse. For the leaders of this country who are not honest, sincere and have compassion for the people, I pray that they be removed or cursed."

Mr Adrianatos is to leave Zimbabwe this weekend, because officials have refused to renew his work permit.

He criticised the inertia of the police after Olds's murder on Sunday. "They said they could not come because they had no transport. No police roadblocks were set up."

Olds stayed on the family farm after her son was murdered last April by members of the "war veterans" movement, which is leading the incursion on white farms. She shot in the legs while doing her early morning chores.

According to forensic investigators, she tried to crawl to her truck. Two killers with AK-47 automatic rifles followed her, shot her three dogs, and then riddled her with bullets.

Olds's son was killed when more than 70 members of the veterans group, which supports Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party, surrounded the farmhouse and engaged in a five-hour gun battle. Martin Olds was known as a supporter of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC).

Yesterday's service was attended by 250 members of the white farming community, including Olds's younger son David and his family, also farmers, and black and white supporters of the MDC.

Opposition figures said the government was intensifying its repression in the surrounding Matabeleland, an area of MDC strength.

David Coltart, the MDC MP for Bulawayo North, who has received death threats, emerged from hiding to be at the funeral, entering the church by a back door.

"There is no doubt the killing was carried out by government supporters," he said.

"The ammunition which killed Gloria Olds can be traced back to the government, according to experts who investigated the site.

"By murdering Gloria Olds in such a brutal way, the government is trying to intimidate the farming community and to get them to give up."

He accused the local governor, Obert Mpofu, of making statements inciting violence against white farmers.

He also accused two Mugabe allies, Border Gezi, the minister for youth and employment creation, and the war veterans' leader, Chenjerai Hunzvi, of encouraging more political violence when they visited Matabeleland two weeks ago.

An MDC official, Eddie Cross, said: "The central intelligence organisation has gone house to house in Victoria Falls and other centres, beating people suspected of supporting the MDC. Farmers have seen increased aggression and death threats."

He had "no doubt" that Olds was executed by the CIO or the army.

webTitle: Face to Faith: the church must retrieve the plot

fields.headline: We must retrieve the plot
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Hindsight often walks hand in hand with a dangerous companion: nostalgia. While hindsight calls us to look back responsibly at the whole of our past, nostalgia is always there ready to beckon us down memory lane to a never-never land where only good memories survive.
fields.body:
Hindsight often walks hand in hand with a dangerous companion: nostalgia. While hindsight calls us to look back responsibly at the whole of our past, nostalgia is always there ready to beckon us down memory lane to a never-never land where only good memories survive.

The new millennium is a time when old orders and former certainties are under question. The rediscovery that science and rationality do not have all the answers has left many outside established religious groups with a deep sense of longing for real meaning in life. Today's global village is full of people trying to discover identity and purpose. Many long for a world disenchanted by empty rationalism to be re-enchanted by music, art, and yes, religion. They have discovered that the angels do indeed keep their ancient places.

But where are the churches in all of this? I think, probably, in a state of confusion. So, at a time when children read the magical tales of Harry Potter and adults indulge in mysticism, the churches by and large throw out enchantment and become happy clappy. At a time when people long for authenticity, the churches behave as if embarrassed by offering in worship the best to God, and instead idolise the commercial, the ephemeral. And at a time when people find the old codes of logic and behaviour things to be questioned and possibly distrusted, the churches insists that members become "on-message" and confuse faith with certainty, whereas these two are at opposite poles.

In our post-modern age, when so many feel lost and spiritually stateless, the churches increasingly function as members-only organisations, offering services only for those who are truly saved, instead of having the confidence to see worship as a converting ordinance, through which, more powerfully than any other medium, the good news of God can be communicated.

And we wonder why we have lost the plot.

The reality is that the large groups in the churches today are stuck in a strange and crippling nostalgia for a dead modern world, insisting that there is just one right way to live, to be moral. The strange alliance which whipped up support to defend Clause 28 in the House of Lords was evidence of this. Three years ago, the Lambeth Conference of Anglican Bishops had its own infamous trip to fairy land. Since then, the Church of England claims to be having an ongoing discussion about the ethics of homosexuality. The discussion is, in any case, severely unbalanced because precisely those who could contribute much - the gay clergy - are silenced by the fear of losing their jobs.

Given hindsight, future generations may well look back and see the controversies which occupy today's Christians rather in the same light that we today view the flat earthers, or the anti-evolutionists at the time of Darwin.

The heart of the Christian message is not, after all, a concern about the minutiae of people's private lives. The heart of the Christian gospel is a call to respond in love to God's love made manifest in the life of the human being. But this response must be more than passive, and does indeed bring with it many duties. It demands that we love the poor. It calls us to work for the release of the captive, the building up of the broken victim, to make a better world of justice and freedom for the oppressed. Yet so often and certainly today, in the case of gay men and women, the church acts in the role of oppressor instead of liberator and harbinger of justice.

Our new world longs for better things. It demands that we recognise the value of every human being and the validity of their perspective of the world. "Do unto others as you would have done to you," says the gospel. Our world today will value us, our gifts, our gospel, only and if we learn to value it.

The church has so many gifts to bring to this new world. It has the means to satisfy today's world's longing for enchantment and prayer. But the church also has a strange gift for dangerous nostalgic reflection. Nostalgia for former certainties can easily lead to a form of authoritarianism which is untenable today. The truth is that such misuse of authority was always untenable for a people whose gospel demands that leadership is expressed in service, and power in humility.

To be a valuable part of today's global community, the churches must rediscover that elusive and generous judgment which reflects key gospel values.

 Nigel Hawley is an Anglican priest in Stockport.

fields.headline: Rosemary DeCamp
fields.standfirst: America's favourite screen mother
fields.trailText: America's favourite screen mother.
fields.body:
Rosemary DeCamp, who has died aged 90, was the mother of all mothers. The Institute of Family Relations once granted her its mother of distinction award for doing "more to glorify American motherhood through her film portrayals than any other woman". When Warner Bros wanted someone to play someone's apple-pie baking mom, DeCamp, under contract to the studio from 1941 to 1953, was called upon.

Who better to play Mrs Winfield, archetypal girl-next-door Doris Day's understanding mama, in the idyllic small-town nostalgic musical On Moonlight Bay (1951) and its sequel By the Light of the Silvery Moon (1953)? She helped create the cosy family atmosphere of the movies. An attractive woman who would have liked more glamorous roles, she never got them because, she said, her "deplorable nose wouldn't photograph".

After obtaining a masters degree at Mills College in San Francisco, DeCamp taught speech and drama for one year, but hated it. She moved to New York, worked briefly as a theatre critic and landed a bit part in George S Kaufman's Merrily We Roll Along on Broadway. She then broke into radio where, for 16 years, she played Nurse Judy in the Dr Christian series, about a saintly small-town doctor, played by Jean Hersholt.

DeCamp made her screen debut as a gauche immigrant girl in Cheers For Miss Bishop (1941). Her first maternal role was as Mowgli's poor Indian mother in Alexander Korda's The Jungle Book (1942). Then came Warner Bros and the Oscar-winning biopic of the multi-talented George M Cohan (James Cagney) in Yankee Doodle Dandy (1941), in which, with the help of flattering ageing makeup, she was his adoring mother, although she was Cagney's junior by 11 years. In Rhapsody In Blue (1945), DeCamp played George Gershwin's Jewish momma although she was only four years Robert Alda's senior.

Playing her own age, she was a sympathetic nurse who helps blinded soldier John Garfield get through a crisis in Pride Of The Marines (1945). In Nora Prentiss (1947), DeCamp was excellent as the unsuspecting wife of a doctor (Kent Smith) carrying out an affair with a night-club singer (Ann Sheridan). She suffered again as the abandoned and penniless wife who blackmails ruthless newspaper editor Broderick Crawford in Scandal Sheet (1952), departing slightly from her virtuous parts.

On television, she played a string of maternal roles, from the long-suffering wife of unlucky working man Chester A Riley (William Bendix) in The Life Of Riley in the late 1940s to Shirley Jones's mother in the Partridge Family in the 1970s.

In private life, she was happily married to Judge John Ashton Shidler from 1941 until his death in 1998. She brought up four daughters, who survive her and was a respected copper enamel artist.

Rosemary DeCamp, actress; born November 14 1910; died February 20 2001

fields.headline: Mario Covas
fields.standfirst: Politician of impeccable ethics and favourite choice for Brazil's next president
fields.trailText: Politician of impeccable ethics and favourite choice for Brazil's next president.
fields.body:
Mário Covas,who has died of multiple organ failure aged 70 was a giant of Brazilian politics and favourite choice for the Brazilian presidency until his protracted and very public battle with the cancer that led to his death. In 1986, Covas, an architect of Brazil's return from dictatorship to democracy during the 1980s, received what is still the record number of votes for a senator.

Since 1994 he had been governor of São Paulo, Brazil's richest, most populous state. It was only when his health deteriorated dramatically recently that power was transferred to his deputy.

Covas stood out in Brazilian politics as a combative, hardworking administrator who preferred to balance books rather than overspend on populist projects. This won him wide-ranging, cross-party respect although the austerity measures he often had to adopt because of his predecessors' profligacy deprived him of popular affection.

Unlike many Brazilian politicians at his level, who often acquire unexplained fortunes in office and who readily switch convictions and parties, Covas neither personally profited from his positions nor deviated from his centrist political principles. He was a hard-talking, stubborn orator and, as the left-wing leader Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva observed, Covas was an example of ethical behaviour, dignity, morality, and of a man who kept his promises.

One of the seven founders of the Brazilian Social Democratic Party (PSDB) in1988, Covas was its candidate for president the following year - the first direct elections for president since the end of the 1964-85 dictatorship. Campaigning on a platform that argued for a "capitalist shock", he came fourth. However, after the resignation of President Fernado Collor in a corruption scandal in 1992, the PSDB finally won the presidency in 1994 with Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who was re-elected in 1998. Covas was the obvious choice for 2002 until he was diagnosed with bladder cancer, shortly after Cardoso's second victory.

A coffee broker's son, Covas was born in Santos, a port built on the export of coffee. He began his political career in 1962, entering Congress for the Brazilian Democratic Party. Four years later, as he started his second term, Brazil's new military regime stripped him of his political rights for publicly defending an opponent to the regime. He was briefly imprisoned, then chose not to go into exile like many colleagues but to work as an engineer.

He returned to politics in 1979, after a general amnesty, entering Congress for the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party. In 1983, he was appointed mayor of São Paulo, one of the world's biggest cities, with an inner-city population of 10m.

Once the military relinquished power, Covas became majority leader of the Constitutional Assembly which drew up a new democratic charter. For David Fleischer, a professor of political science at Brasilia University, the constitution was probably Covas's most lasting contribution to Brazil. But he was also, Fleischer suggested, the PSDB's moral conscience, holding it to the straight and narrow and keeping it from alliances with the right. In 1986, Covas was elected to the senate with 7.8m votes.

While at the helm of São Paulo state, whose population of 36m makes it as large as a medium-sized country, Covas restored it from near-bankrupcy to financial health. He made tough and unpopular decisions, such as dismissing nearly 200,000 civil servants in 1995. His main political failing was an inability to find solutions to the rapid rise in violent crime.

Covas's reputation for courage and transparency was evident in his approach to cancer. By making his struggle public, he won widespread respect and sympathy.

He is survived by his wife, Lila, his son and daughter.

webTitle: John O'Farrell: Blair has Thatcher in his attic

fields.headline: She's behind you...
fields.standfirst:
Luke Skywalker had Darth Vader for a dad. Poor Tony Blair has Maggie Thatcher in his attic
Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Luke Skywalker had Darth Vader for a dad. Poor Tony Blair has Maggie Thatcher in his attic.
fields.body:
Yesterday it was revealed that dozens of Tory candidates have been arranging photos of themselves shaking hands with Lady Thatcher. The story came to light after a number of merchant bankers were suddenly rushed to casualty with broken fingers. Conservative hopefuls are rejecting offers to pose next to William Hague and are choosing instead to associate themselves with the Tory leader before last while John Major, wearing his best suit, sits sadly by the phone wondering if anyone's going to call. With the Conservatives being perceived as extreme and out of touch, these candidates have decided that what they need now is to be seen with the Iron Lady. It's like Rosemary West calling Myra Hindley as a character witness.

It's incredible that after all these years Mrs T continues to have such a grip over the Conservative imagination. They cannot forget the way her career ended in tragedy. Indeed it did; she became prime minister for 11 years. For the dwindling band of diehard Tory activists, Lady Thatcher is the King Over the Water and they cling to the belief that she could walk over it at any time to return her rightful place as party leader and PM. They have a political heroine addiction, they crave her smack of firm government; they're desperate to escape back to that simple, separate reality and feel that quick rush they'd get from another Thatcher outburst on Europe.

Meanwhile for senior Conservatives, Lady Thatcher is the mad old lady in the attic, an embarrassing senile relation who needs to be kept under lock and key. Last week, on the anniversary of the Gulf war, she infuriated Major by claiming that if she'd remained in power, the allied forces would have carried on into Baghdad and removed Saddam Hussein. Yes, she was always overruling American presidents on military operations. It's good to hear her come out with this nonsense just to be reminded how completely loony, awful, self-deceiving and wrong she always was. Another recent contribution to the national debate was the suggestion that single mothers should be placed inside religious institutions to be taught traditional values. Maybe she could get Cecil Parkinson to set the scheme up.

Terrible though it is to admit it, in a strange way I sort of miss her. Because she was the embodiment of all evil, there was a certainty to life that isn't there anymore. In the film Alien, when the creature has its limbs locked round John Hurt's face and is forcing its tentacles down his throat, he could at least be sure of what the problem was at that particular moment. So it was when Maggie was PM.

And now there is a whole generation of voters who do not even know who she is. Recently I gave a talk to a group of sixth formers which was littered with references to "Thatcher" and most of them thought I was talking about Ben Thatcher who plays for Tottenham Hotspur. But loathe her or hate her, her political legacy is still undeniable. Just as Luke Skywalker discovers that he is the son of Darth Vader, and Buzz Lightyear's father is the evil Emperor Zorg, so Tony Blair is the political offspring of the Iron Lady. He may be the antithesis of her bigoted, confrontational xenophobia but without Thatcher, Prime Minister Blair would not exist. Her destruction of the labour movement gave rise to New Labour which her Conservative successors now find so unassailable. Early on in his premiership, Tony Blair shocked many Labour supporters by inviting her round to Downing Street to ask her advice on one or two things. Apparently she said you have to give it one long flush and then another quick flush immediately afterwards.

For Labour today, her continued presence is a useful reminder of how the poison that emanated from Downing Street dictated the atmosphere of the whole country back in the mean-spirited 80s. For Hague the problem of the mad old lady in the attic is a slightly trickier one. I can see only one way forward for him.

Next year sees the 20th anniversary of the Falklands war, and to commemorate this Hague should arrange a lecture tour of Argentina for Britain's former dictator. He can then pretend to be shocked and alarmed when she is arrested in Buenos Aires and detained for crimes against humanity. General Pinochet will visit her and express concern that she is being made to stand trial with her health failing her so suddenly. If William really wants to rub salt into the wounds he could even appoint Lord Lamont to organise a campaign for her release.

But until someone does the decent thing and puts a stake through her heart, the Conservative party will never be able to move forward. Even then they'll probably keep searching for the nearest thing to the original. If George W Bush can follow in his father's footsteps, then shouldn't they be finding safe Tory seats for Carol and Mark? No, I shouldn't suggest it, not even in jest.

fields.headline: Mir - a brief history
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: February 20, 1986 The launch of Mir - which means new world, peace or community - surprised many because Salyut 7 was still operational. Mir was made up of two cylinders, one 3m in diameter and one 4m across with two cabins and a room with a carpeted 'floor' and a white 'ceiling': in space there is no up or down.
fields.body:
February 20, 1986 The launch of Mir - which means new world, peace or community - surprised many because Salyut 7 was still operational. Mir was made up of two cylinders, one 3m in diameter and one 4m across with two cabins and a room with a carpeted 'floor' and a white 'ceiling': in space there is no up or down.

May 20, 1991 British cosmonaut Helen Sharman begins her seven-day visit. Each day, cosmonauts had to ride 10km on a cycling machine and walk 5km on a treadmill. Each drank 2.7 litres (5 pints) of water to make 1.2 litres of urine a day, in turn to retrieve oxygen.

Feb 6, 1995 The first docking with a US shuttle. Mir had a series of dramas, including health alarms - involving a heart arryhthmia - and over pay. When the USSR collapsed Soviet officers were left marooned high above a democratic Russia.

June 25, 1997 A Progress craft crashed into Mir, threatening the two Russians and the Lincolnshire-born astronaut Michael Foale.

November 20, 1998 Russia launches the first module of the International Space Station. Nasa believed the Russian struggle to keep Mir aloft was hampering co-operation on the US-led international station. There was talk of renting Mir for space tourism, of leasing it as a film set. In 2000, US space buffs and Russia formed Mircorp. But Mir, alas, was deteriorating too fast.

March 18-25, 2001 If Mir did go out of control, the 130-tonne craft could crash anywhere between latitude 51N and Latitude 51S. Most of it would burn up like a meteor. Yuri Karash, a trained cosmonaut, claimed that mutant fungus aboard Mir, itself exposed to damaging cosmic rays, could release toxins and infection on Earth.

webTitle: Mir prepares to cross its final frontier

fields.headline: At long last, Mir prepares to cross its final frontier
fields.standfirst:
Russia's ageing and accident-prone space station is days away from a fiery end and a watery grave
Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Russia's ageing and accident-prone space station is days away from a fiery end and a watery grave.
fields.body:
In about 10 days - it depends on the weather in space - a season of high drama should come to both a fiery end and a watery grave. Three puffs of fuel from a Progress rocket will pull the 130-tonne Russian space station Mir down to its last orbit. A fourth will send it careering half-way round the globe to burn up in the atmosphere and then put out its blazing embers in the emptiest quarter of the Pacific Ocean. Just in case anything goes wrong the Russians have taken out a £135m accident insurance policy.

If something goes badly wrong and Mir plunges into Britain, the Home Office is prepared and police and local authorities are ready to put emergency plans into action. But there is probably greater nervousness among the 16 nations of the South Pacific Forum, where many homes are made out of grass, corrugated iron and wood, and where some of the 40-plus tonnes of space hardware expected to survive the re-entry could cause extensive damage.

Mir was designed for five years in space but stayed in orbit for 15. It circled the world every 92 minutes, and it provided hotel and workshop facilities for almost 100 visitors. Its life-support system recovered oxygen from cosmonaut urine and turned cosmonaut perspiration into drinking water. Its air-conditioning system removed the toxic chemicals from what the Russians politely termed "human gases" and discarded them into space.

But it was accident prone. Mir survived blocked lavatories, a fire, a collision with one of its own supply ships, an oxygen crisis and a series of computer shutdowns. It tested military technology during the Cold War but after the collapse of the Soviet Union the cosmonauts on board turned swords into ploughshares and grew wheat in space, as a kind of dress rehearsal for some future voyage to Mars.

Mir evolved into a remarkable experiment in space endurance and one engineer spent 747 days on board, in three separate missions. A record. The space station became, briefly, private property, leased to an international commercial outfit called Mircorp. In the end, it grew rotten, infested by fungus, just like any other old house with damp. The last cosmonauts and their American colleagues aboard were spending 80% of their time trying to keep the old crate in working order. The end had come.

Right now, Mir is hanging, with its heaviest part downwards, revolving twice an hour about 140 miles above the planet, a Progress rocket laden with 2.7 tonnes of fuel sticking out like a little stubby tail. This tail is about to wag the dog goodbye.

The end could come at any time between March 18 and March 25, due to weather problems in space: the sun is at its maximum in its 11-year-cycle, and a series of million-mile-an-hour showers of hot particles from the sun have been heating up the Earth's atmosphere, making it expand and, in effect, reach up to Mir and drag it down a little, which affects the timetable.

At present the most likely date of doom is March 20. With a series of burns from the Progress rocket, ground control in Moscow will distort its orbit into an ellipse: 140 miles at its highest, 110 miles at its lowest. Then they will wait for the ideal orbital track and choose their moment. At some point over the equatorial Atlantic, as Mir heads north over the planet, controllers will press the button and send it into an orbit with its lowest point at 40 miles altitude. This is an orbit Mir will never complete. The huge space station will travel half-way round the planet to begin its dive over heavily populated Europe and Asia, although most of it will perish over the empty south seas.

Over the past 43 years, a total of 18,000 tracked objects have returned from space. There has never been a human casualty. At five miles a second (about 17,500 mph) Mir will dive into the atmosphere and start to slow down dramatically. At 86 miles altitude, aerodynamic torque will start to increase. By 75 miles, the fate of Mir will be sealed. At 62 miles altitude its solar panels will begin to bend; at 50 miles the solar arrays will tear off. At 37 miles the sturdier parts of Mir will have heated up to 30,000C before bursting apart. The space station will continue to dive; not so much like a large, ungainly bomber, but like a formation of blazing fighters.

At 25 miles, Mir's fragments should have slowed to a terminal velocity of about 125 mph and may reach the Earth's surface. Most of the US Skylab perished upon re-entry over the Indian Ocean in 1979, but some large lumps of titanium did landed in Western Australia. Fragments of Soviet Cosmos 954's nuclear reactor were strewn over northern Canada after its re-entry a year before.

"From past experience a number of orbital objects do find their way back to Earth," says Richard Crowther, a space scientist. "They tend to be circular or cylindrical in shape. They tend to spin as they come into the atmosphere, so they dissipate heat, and distribute it over their surface, so there is no heat concentration. But the damage is extremely local. There are no fires, there are no craters. It just falls to Earth."

In fact, nothing should fall to Earth, just ocean. Mir's ocean landing will be along a 3,700-mile track of the southern Pacific Ocean, 125 miles wide, on either side of latitude 47S. There are no inhabited islands and local shipping will have been warned. Mir's last moments will be tracked by the Russians and by western control centres used during the Cold War, among them the command post at Cheyenne Mountain in the US Rockies, and the radar tracking station at Fylingdales in North Yorkshire. An aircraft has even been chartered, to take sightseers to observe Mir's last moments.

But the betting is that the only mourners will be the Russians, as they watch a symbol of their former space supremacy perform its very own vanishing trick. Russia's new space platform is the International Space Station, mostly built and run by the American space agency, Nasa.

"We can't hold on to what is old. We need to move forward," said Leonid Gorshkov, one of the Mir space station's designers.

Roald Sagdeev, a leading figure in Soviet space research for many years, said: "Mir outlived not only the original manufacturer's warranty, but also its parent state, the USSR, by 10 years _ Mir has finally become a liability."

fields.headline: An inspector calls, and gallery is left reeling
fields.standfirst:
Saatchi visit by obscene publications detectives evokes memories of bad old days when leading museums were raided by 'art critic' police

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Saatchi visit by obscene publications detectives evokes memories of bad old days when leading museums were raided by 'art critic' police.
fields.body:
It is more than 30 years now since Roy Jenkins, as home secretary, reprimanded the Metropolitan police for raiding the Victoria and Albert Museum and the Tate Gallery to check they were not displaying obscene pictures by showing works by Aubrey Beardsley and Jim Dine.

But this week's visits by Scotland Yard's obscene publications section to the Saatchi Gallery in north London, and their threat to seize Tierney Gearnon's photographs in an exhibition personally selected by Charles Saatchi makes it seem as though it were only yesterday.

Equally surprising was the attendant warning by the police to an international fine art publisher, Edward Booth-Clibborn, that thousands of copies of the book, I Am a Camera, should be withdrawn from sale from the shelves of Waterstones and other bookshops by next Thursday and the offending pictures removed, or he too would face unspecified action under the 1978 Protection of Children Act.

The 436-page book showcases Charles Saatchi's personal collection of photographs, including images from Tracey Emin, Cindy Sherman and Andy Warhol. The exhibition was based on the £49.99 book published by Booth-Clibborn Editions.

For Jenny Blythe, the curator of the Saatchi Gallery, it was quite a shock when Inspector Brian Park and his plain clothes colleague from the Yard's clubs and vice unit turned up at the St John's Wood gallery in north London on Thursday. The exhibition had been running for eight weeks and been well reviewed in the broadsheets and the colour supplements, from the Tatler to the Telegraph, with full illustrations and without complaint.

"He said they had had complaints from journalists and the public about materials in the exhibition and had come down previously to investigate. There were a couple of images they wanted us to remove and if we did not remove then they would get a warrant and remove the exhibits themselves. I was so surprised I couldn't believe it.

"They said they were looking at the threat of prosecution," she said. "We then had quite a long talk about art."

The two images in question are photographs by an American fashion photographer who lives in London, Tierney Gearon, of her own children, Michael and Emily. One pictures the two children, aged four and six, at play by the seashore dressed only in masks, while the other picture shows Michael urinating in the snow. They are part of a series of 15 images on show at the Saatchi gallery through which Gearon builds up a documentary account of her family life.

The Saatchi curator said they were snapshots which conveyed a "celebration of the wonderment and joie de vivre of her children".

While the police raid was in progress the photographer turned up at the gallery for an interview with BBC Radio 4 and was surprised to discover Inspector Ward and his colleague present. "It was a shock. The police said they had received complaints from customs and excise and from journalists. They said the pictures were indecent and needed to be removed from the exhibition. I was shocked by this. They just captured a moment of life. It is something that children do. I am a mother and around children a lot. None of them are posed. They are not set up."

Gearon was even more surprised to receive a visit from two journalists at her home just hours after she had given the police her unlisted phone number and private home address. All public records of her home are in her married name.

"I had just gone out to the grocer's. My nanny let in two people who claimed to have an appointment. When I got home they said they were from the Telegraph but they were obviously not from the Telegraph. They said they knew the police had come to the gallery."

At the Saatchi Gallery there was suspicion that the two journalists may have been from a Sunday newspaper who had been tipped off by the police. But Scotland Yard last strongly denied that officers would have passed on Gearon's name and address.

Stuart Kuttner, managing editor of the News of the World, which has run a controversial anti-paedophile campaign, denied that thenewspaper was behind complaints to the police or that its staff had confronted Gearon at her home. At the same time, Inspector Ward had phoned Mr Booth-Clibborn.

"He warned me that the book I have published was in contravention of the obscenity acts and said that there were three offensive pictures that must be removed from the book and that I had until Thursday to ask Waterstones and all the other bookshops to remove all the books," he said. "He had got a copy from Waterstones.

"I am flabbergasted. I have been a publisher for more than 20 years and I know what child pornography is and I would never go near it. This is not child pornography. They are brilliant works of art."

The publisher's catalogue includes work by Damien Hirst and the Saatchi Young British Art collection, as well as books based on collections from the Hermitage Gallery in Moscow, and the Egyptian Museum in Cairo.

The last time that action under the Protection of Children Act hit the headlines was in 1995 when police interviewed ITN newscaster, Julia Somerville, and her partner, Jeremy Dixon, about family snaps showing her daughter, aged seven, in the bath, following a complaint from a Boots employee. Details were leaked to the press and splashed over the front pages, but four weeks later the crown prosecution service announced it was letting the matter drop.

Immediately after the police raid, Saatchi's took legal advice from the barrister Geoffrey Robertson, who advised them that the police were acting on wrong legal advice if they believed that the photographs were indecent simply because the children were naked. It is believed that court precedents make clear that indecency needs to involve an element of lewdness or sexual provocation.

In the 1960s, police raids on the national art galleries produced protests from Jennie Lee, the arts minister, and Lord Goodman, chairman of the arts council, and resulted in the home secretary warning the police not to set themselves up as art critics. Perhaps such warnings are needed again.

Commentary
Family snapshots a peculiar art

When I got home they said they were from the Telegraph but they were obviously not from the Telegraph. They said they knew the police had come to the gallery." At the Saatchi Gallery there was suspicion that the two journalists may have been from a Sunday newspaper who had been tipped off by the police. But Scotland Yard last strongly denied that officers would have passed on Gearon's name and address. Stuart Kuttner, managing editor of the News of the World, which has run a controversial anti-paedophile campaign, denied that thenewspaper was behind complaints to the police or that its staff had confronted Gearon at her home. At the same time, Inspector Ward had phoned Mr Booth-Clibborn. "He warned me that the book I have published was in contravention of the obscenity acts and said that there were three offensive pictures that must be removed from the book and that I had until Thursday to ask Waterstones and all the other bookshops to remove all the books," he said. "He had got a copy from Waterstones. "I am flabbergasted. I have been a publisher for more than 20 years and I know what child pornography is and I would never go near it. This is not child pornography. They are brilliant works of art." Details were leaked to the press and splashed over the front pages, but four weeks later the crown prosecution service announced it was letting the matter drop. Immediately after the police raid, Saatchi's took legal advice from the barrister Geoffrey Robertson, who advised them that the police were acting on wrong legal advice if they believed that the photographs were indecent simply because the children were naked. It is believed that court precedents make clear that indecency needs to involve an element of lewdness or sexual provocation. In the 1960s, police raids on the national art galleries produced protests from Jennie Lee, the arts minister, and Lord Goodman, chairman of the arts council, and resulted in the home secretary warning the police not to set themselves up as art critics. Perhaps such warnings are needed again. Commentary Family snapshots a peculiar art

webTitle: Mark Lawson: Saatchi Gallery risks prosecution over exhibits

fields.headline: Innocence observed or abused?
fields.standfirst:
The Saatchi Gallery must remove some exhibits or risk prosecution

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: The Saatchi Gallery must remove some exhibits or risk prosecution.
fields.body:
When artists label their work "Untitled", it's usually from a desire to avoid steering the eye and nudging the mind. We must see in the images whatever we find there. The American photographer Tierney Gearon leaves almost all her pieces without a name, and the News of the World and the police have chosen to see in her images of her children playing - often naked in front of adults, sometimes urinating or dressed in animal-heads - a potential for interpretation as paedophilia. The Saatchi Gallery in Hampstead has until Monday to remove her pictures from the I Am A Camera exhibition, or risk prosecution.

The argument over her photographs rests on two key judgments: intent and consent. On the question of the effect the artist wanted the images to have, there's clearly a difference between Gearon's work and the snaps of naked children posed and posted on the internet or printed in magazines in the Netherlands. The latter have a paedophile intention; the former may have a paedophile effect.

The distinction is that the works on display at the Saatchi began in innocence as the family snaps of a mother. Gearon was not a professional photographer until last year. No sane person would suggest that she knowingly set out to expose her children to the gaze of pederasts in Manhattan and Hampstead. But because the mother with the camera was, in this case, an artist, she must accept - as all creative people are forced to acknowledge - that there may be in the work a psychological drive of which she is unaware. The photos are clearly intended to explore the borders between childhood and adulthood - the seeds of sexuality within a child - and it's possible that Gearon went further over the border than she mapped out.

She must also accept that images intended innocently can be put to abusive uses. Blue Peter's viewers almost certainly include some - middle-aged single men living with their mothers - who are tuning in for the wrong reasons, but the BBC could not reasonably be accused of encouraging paedophilia through its scheduling of children's programmes.

Even so, a weakness for Gearon in the defence of unintentional interpretation is the nature of the images. In the present climate of parental and newspaper neurosis, it's unlikely that Blue Peter would run a competition for the best home video of children playing in a paddling pool, purely because of the risk of a round of one-handed applause from the wrong quarter. While Gearon is properly coy with her daughter's genitals, her son's penis is displayed. Visually, the photo in which he urinates has a familial connection - however distant and accidental - with the pornographic variety known as golden showers. Similarly, the use of animal masks in some of the pictures might quicken the step of any gallery-visitor who happened to be into kids-and-pets porn. No artist gets to choose their audience. There's no doubt that, given the contemporary hysteria over child abuse, anyone who sent a roll of Gearon-like images along to Boots for processing would find a copper standing next to the sales assistant when they went in to collect them. Social services would at least want to talk to the children.

So the question is whether artistic talent gives Gearon the licence to behave as no civilian parent could? Certainly, it seems improbable to me that any dedicated paedophile would head to the Saatchi Gallery in search of a kick from these images. They're ambiguous and tame beside the targeted nastiness to be found elsewhere.

For observers of the tabloid arts, the motivation of the News of the World is fascinating. While suspected paedophilia in any place is the tabloid's trigger-issue at the moment, in this instance it's also clear that class anger plays a part. As the paper views it, the liberal middle-classes regard pictures of naked nippers as fine for those with university degrees who call it art, but paedophilia if you download them from cyberspace on a council estate. The News of the World sees the Saatchi Gallery as a descendant of the Chatterley case counsel, who wished to protect his servants from the novel, while implying that educated men would not be swayed by it.

Gearon is most vulnerable on the matter of consent. There's always discomfort when the subjects of a picture don't fully understand the implications of display. This question arises, in a different way, with projects involving Alzheimer's patients. While, for Emilie and Michael, the shoots for Untitled were doubtless innocent fun with mum, you wonder about their reaction as teenagers and adults to the realisation that they have been displayed naked around the world. That isn't a police matter, but it's an important moral one.

But history shows that the children of artists suffer one way or another. Novelists cannibalise their offspring for plots and dialogue. The children of photographers and film-makers endure the same process but with less possibility of disguise, unless mum or dad is into abstracts.

Tierney Gearon's work promotes unease: some of it intended, some resulting from a failure to consider all the consequences. But the policing should be left to Brian Sewell, not the vice squad. For any tiny thrill bicycle-seat-sniffers might achieve at the gallery, they'd have to submit to rooms full of Charles Saatchi's rather erratic taste in modern art. You feel that the time of the filth cops would be better spent online or in Soho than in Hampstead.
