fields.headline: Germans in no mood to stroll down memory lane
fields.trailText: Everywhere, in this city that is always becoming and never is, there are bulldozers and cranes at work. Building up. Tearing down. Making a new Berlin. But also destroying the last one.
fields.body:
Everywhere, in this city that is always becoming and never is, there are bulldozers and cranes at work. Building up. Tearing down. Making a new Berlin. But also destroying the last one.

The latest chunk of cold war Berlin to fall to the demolition workers' pickaxes is the Palasthotel, which the East German leader Erich Honecker had built just 20-odd years ago for honoured foreign guests and anyone else able to stump up the necessary hard currency.

Already its distinctive copper-coloured windows have gone. Hoardings have been thrown up around the site, and the sounds of heavy machinery can be heard from within.

Last week Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung's long-serving correspondent in the east, Peter Jochen Winters, recalled with nostalgia the Palast's glory days, when it was the fiefdom of Honecker's embargo buster and currency mastermind, a special operations officer in the east German intelligence agency called Alexander Schalck-Golodkowski.

Thatcher and Reagan were in office. The Soviet Union, run by a former head of the KGB, Yuri Andropov, had ceased to be a partner in detente and become the "evil empire" instead.

In the Palast's regrettably named Sinus Bar, where Erich Mielke, the head of the Stasi, threw parties for his friends, prostitute-spies hunted for western visitors with more libido than common sense.

Soon the Sinus Bar will be a part of history and a heap of dust. Cold war Berlin is disappearing at a bewildering rate - and what remains is pretty much invisible to all but those in the know.

Across town, in the west, the western intelligence agencies' Teufelsberg eavesdropping complex is being turned into a leisure complex. As for the Wall, it has virtually disappeared.

There is a stretch by the Ostbahnhof and another in Niederkirchnerstrasse, in the centre. Elsewhere there are just tiny fragments, like the one which stands incongruously in a cemetery not far from the Guardian bureau here. Altogether, I doubt if what remains adds up to a quarter of a mile.

Now there are plans to tear down one of the last remaining watch-towers, in Potsdamer Platz, to make way for a new road.

What is surprising is that more has not been done to preserve the recent past for purely commercial reasons.

Checkpoint Charlie has been kept. But you could spend for ever crossing and recrossing the Glienicke bridge, where the spy exchanges took place, without realising that it had a place in history.

For the most part Berliners just seem to want to forget. And who can blame them?

The Wall was nothing to get sentimental about if your relatives lived on the other side. And why should they care about the disappearance of a hotel which, anyway, catered mainly for rich outsiders?

The circumstances of modern German history have meant a process of constant reinvention, for individuals and places alike. The transformation of Berlin is just the latest manifestation of an established process.

But that does not make it any the less disorientating for those of us who come to it afresh. Eighteen months ago, in my first week as the Guardian's correspondent here, my assistant took me to see something she felt was quintessentially Berlin. It was a big, rather vulgar, plastic sign above a steak house, behind which you could make out quite clearly a painted-over socialist realist mural. The other day I walked past it and saw that the mural had been completely erased. All that is left now is the big, rather vulgar, plastic restaurant sign.

Maybe, for those of us who remember what was once there, that makes it even more quintessentially Berlin.

fields.headline: Leap in the dark
fields.standfirst:
Dome's circus troupe battles on

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Dome's circus troupe battles on.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
When Matt Costain took a deep breath and jumped almost 100 feet from the highest point of the Millennium Dome, he thought he was changing his life. And so he did, but not quite as he expected.

The dome cost a billion pounds, give or take some loose change. Storm, the circus arts show which is sheltering 19 of the survivors, is costing £100,000. It opens in London next month and then embarks on a national tour.

The young company learned circus skills for the spectacular aerial show in the vast central arena, the only universally popular part of the dome fiasco. Now all the equipment has been broken up or sold off with the giant hamster and the pubic lice. All that remains is their lithe bodies and their talent. They hope recycling these will give them a lasting career and Britain a permanent touring circus.

"We were only human, everyone hopes for a fairytale ending," Costain, Sky Boy in the dome show, said. "We all thought 'we are in The Show, in The Place, in The Year, anything could happen'. I did think somebody might come along and sweep us off to fame and fortune.

"The show was always great, but every day we'd read these amazing stories in the papers, and wonder what could possibly happen next. We used to joke that the only thing that could still happen was somebody would try to steal the diamonds."

When he made his spectacular dive Costain could see clearly when the huge cast and crew heavily outnumbered the audience. Corporate shows for sponsors, which might be 100 people drinking champagne and chatting among 25,000 empty seats, were the worst.

Since January 1, many performers have been shipped off to Euro Disney, others have joined circuses and acrobatic stage shows, some are back working as waiters and barmaids, but Storm was determined to use the team spirit forged in the eye of the hurricane in the dome.

Now the company is back where it started three years ago, at the Circus Space in a former east London power station where it will open in April before touring from the end of May.

webTitle: Anti-obesity drug given licence for NHS use

fields.headline: Anti-obesity drug given licence for NHS use
fields.trailText: A new drug for obesity which prevents fat from being absorbed by the body was approved for use in the NHS yesterday, but strictly limited to those whose weight is a serious medical problem.
fields.body:
A new drug for obesity which prevents fat from being absorbed by the body was approved for use in the NHS yesterday, but strictly limited to those whose weight is a serious medical problem.

Orlistat (brand name Xenical) is the first anti-obesity drug that does not work by suppressing the appetite. It has been hailed as potentially one of a new breed of lifestyle drugs. Weight reduction, like conquering social shyness and ending impotence, can be seen in the context of quality of life rather than serious damage to health.

The decision that the NHS should pay for orlistat, announced by the national institute for clinical excellence (Nice), came with conditions to make sure that only those whose health and in some cases life is threatened by their weight will get it.

The patient must also show they are committed to losing weight and keeping it off by shedding at least 2.5kg in the previous month through ordinary diet and exercise.

The tablets are not a miracle cure. They have to be used in conjunction with dieting and exercise and offer their own rather unpleasant incentive to cut down on fat intake. They work by reducing the capacity of the body to absorb fat. Any surplus passes straight through the gut and is excreted with some urgency.

Most patients will not be prescribed orlistat for longer than a year and none should have it longer than two years, Nice says. They will only be allowed to stay on the pills if they manage to lose at least 5% of their body weight every three months.

Peter Littlejohns, clinical director of Nice, said: "Doctors and patients need to work together to manage this condition and today's guidance provides advice on the contribution which orlistat can make."

The Nice decision is partly a response to the worrying in crease in obesity in the UK, which looks set to follow the pattern in the United States. Some 11,000 seriously overweight people are likely to be prescribed the pills, at a cost to the NHS of £12m a year. Even this represents savings on the bill for treating medical conditions which can be a consequence of obesity over many years.

Ian Campbell, chairman of the National Obesity Forum, said: "The decision underlines the importance of treating obesity and the overweight - an epidemic that is having an alarming impact on our nation's health - before it is too late.

"By treating obesity and overweight we can reduce the burden of disease linked to obesity, such as coronary heart disease and diabetes."

Around 61% of British men and 52% of women are thought to be overweight, while 16% and 18% respectively are clinically obese and therefore likely to have damaged health. As in the US, children seem to be following in the fatness trend. A survey found that in the last 10 years there has been a sharp increase in the numbers who are overweight, customarily put down to junk food, and too much television and computer game-playing.

The national audit office said recently that the inactivity and overeating, which causes obesity, were killing 31,000 people prematurely a year. In 10 years, it said in a report, the UK could catch the US, where a quarter of the population is obese.

Orlistat will only be given to those with a body/mass index of over 30 kg/m2 or 28 kg/m2 if they have a serious illness such as diabetes or high blood pressure. Body mass index is the person's weight in kilograms divided by their height in metres squared. A BMI of 20 to 25 is normal, 25 to 30 is overweight and more than 30 is obese. A man of about 5ft 10in weighing more than 15 stone or a woman of 5ft 6in and 13.5 stone would be regarded as obese.

fields.headline: Lawrence case sergeant in dock
fields.trailText: A police sergeant praised by the Stephen Lawrence inquiry for his anti-racist views yesterday faced nine charges of rape and one of perjury when he appeared at Bow Street magistrates court in London.
fields.body:
A police sergeant praised by the Stephen Lawrence inquiry for his anti-racist views yesterday faced nine charges of rape and one of perjury when he appeared at Bow Street magistrates court in London.

Peter Solley was awarded an OBE in the new year's honours list for his police work and had angered some in the Metropolitan police when he told the Lawrence inquiry of a "canteen culture" of racism in the force.

Solley, 47, is alleged to have raped a 50-year-old community worker between April 1995 and October 2000.

One attack took place at her home, another in a room at the Bramshill police college in Hampshire, the court was told.

He is also alleged to have committed perjury at the Lawrence inquiry on June 23, 1998, in making a statement "which he knew to be false or did not believe to be true", the court heard. The perjury charge relates to an eight page document Solley produced at the inquiry, which he described as an aide memoir and to have written himself.

Solley - who met Stephen Lawrence's parents, Doreen and Neville, after the racist murder of their son - was praised in Sir William Macpherson's report on the police investigation of the killing.

It said Solley, a community liaison officer for 10 years, was a "sympathetic and well intentioned man" whose "value to the community was and is in our opinion considerable".

Solley was charged after answering bail at Belgravia police station yesterday. The officer has been suspended from duty since last October while inquiries into the allegations continued.

He was granted bail on condition that he surrendered his passport and will appear at the Old Bailey later this month. He denies the charges.
fields.bodyText: A police sergeant praised by the Stephen Lawrence inquiry for his anti-racist views yesterday faced nine charges of rape and one of perjury when he appeared at Bow Street magistrates court in London. Peter Solley was awarded an OBE in the new year's honours list for his police work and had angered some in the Metropolitan police when he told the Lawrence inquiry of a "canteen culture" of racism in the force. Solley, 47, is alleged to have raped a 50-year-old community worker between April 1995 and October 2000. One attack took place at her home, another in a room at the Bramshill police college in Hampshire, the court was told. He is also alleged to have committed perjury at the Lawrence inquiry on June 23, 1998, in making a statement "which he knew to be false or did not believe to be true", the court heard. The perjury charge relates to an eight page document Solley produced at the inquiry, which he described as an aide memoir and to have written himself. Solley - who met Stephen Lawrence's parents, Doreen and Neville, after the racist murder of their son - was praised in Sir William Macpherson's report on the police investigation of the killing. It said Solley, a community liaison officer for 10 years, was a "sympathetic and well intentioned man" whose "value to the community was and is in our opinion considerable". Solley was charged after answering bail at Belgravia police station yesterday. The officer has been suspended from duty since last October while inquiries into the allegations continued. He was granted bail on condition that he surrendered his passport and will appear at the Old Bailey later this month. He denies the charges.

webTitle: Saatchi gallery snapshots a peculiar art

fields.headline: Family snapshots show a peculiar art
fields.trailText: Tierney Gearon's pictures look like what they are, family snapshots which she insists are unposed and spontaneous. They are odd to see in a gallery, not because of their content but because of their formal qualities, or lack of them.
fields.body:
Tierney Gearon's pictures look like what they are, family snapshots which she insists are unposed and spontaneous. They are odd to see in a gallery, not because of their content but because of their formal qualities, or lack of them. The harsh colours and shallow focus reveal that these really are snaps, taken with a fairly ordinary camera, blown up big.

Gearon's claim to ingenuousness is plausible. She is an American living in London who has never exhibited before. She does not as yet have a dealer, and had no track record as an artist before Charles Saatchi saw her work and asked her to be in the show I Am a Camera alongside Andy Warhol, Nan Goldin and Richard Billingham.

Her images of naked children on the beach and a child peeing in the snow, that police claim are in contravention of the child protection act, are pictures by a mother of her own children, taken in the maelstrom of family life.

Yet the reason these pictures are in an art gallery rather than on a mantelpiece is that they are a little peculiar. In the two pictures that caused most distress to the police, the children's faces are concealed. The boy pissing in the snow wears black goggles, as does the girl looking at him. On the beach, the children are nude, except for identical masks of a weird, cartoonish blonde bombshell.

The boy points a toy gun at us, while the girl stands hand on hip.

Gearon is not the first artist to portray children in a way some might find troubling. The police officers who visited the Saatchi Gallery might want to scrutinise the work of Julia Margaret Cameron, the Victorian photographer who posed her great niece Florence Fisher as a semi-nude John the Baptist in 1872, not to mention Lewis Carroll, whose photograph of Alice Liddell as a beggar girl in off-the-shoulder rags was greatly admired by Lord Tennyson.

As a billion family albums bear witness, children have a special relationship with the camera. All you have to do is point a camera at them and you have a memorable image.

In fact far from being offensive, Gearon could be accused of being derivative. When the American photographer Sally Mann published in 1992 her book Intimate Family, full of black and white pictures of her children nude, in languid poses in a decadent-looking Virginia, there was an international outcry - and Mann was established as a contemporary classic.

Other artists have flirted even more graphically with the line between childhood innocence and adult experience; a couple of years ago British artist Mat Collishaw exhibited photographs in which boys pose in reconstructions of 19th-century Italian pornography, but amid all the riot of Britart the provocation wasn't even noticed.

Gearon's images play on the border that we patrol most insistently. Art will tend to do that, just as children will do what they're told not to.

 Jonathan Jones writes on art for the Guardian

Related story
An inspector calls, and gallery is left reeling

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Vivendi talks of share swap
fields.body:
Vivendi talks of share swap

Jean-Marie Messier, head of media and utilities group Vivendi Universal, said yesterday he was interested in swapping part of his group's stake in BSkyB for more shares in television programming business USA Networks.

Vivendi has a 43% stake in USA Networks and about 20% in BSkyB, which regulators have demanded it sell as part of its merger with Seagram. Mr Messier has two years to sell the stake and said he was in no hurry. He is believed to be eyeing the USA Networks stake held by Liberty Media.

Virgin Trains' £200m boost

One of Britain's busiest rail routes was handed a boost today after Railtrack and Virgin Trains agreed a £200m funding package. The upgrade work at five locations along Virgin's cross-country network is expected to improve journey times and reliability. Railtrack said the agreement with Virgin formed part of £1bn worth of investment planned over the next two years for the cross country service.

Sir Denys steps down

Sir Denys Henderson, one of the grandees of British business, is stepping down from his last high-profile boardroom position.

The former chairman of ICI is retiring as chairman of the Rank Group at the end of next month after six years at the helm of the leisure company.

Sir Denys, a lawyer by training, spent nearly 40 years at ICI when it was Britain's biggest manufacturing company. He was chairman from 1987 to 1995 and oversaw the demerger that created the AstraZeneca drugs group.

His successor at Rank is Alun Cathcart, chairman of Avis Europe and of Selfridges.

Wolves extends deadline

Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries has extended its deadline for bidders to table formal takeover offers from April 5 to 20.

The move follows pressure from leisure entrepreneur Robert Breare, who is the leading contender with backing from venture capital firm Botts & Co. Mr Breare said earlier this week that he needed at least six weeks to complete legal and accounting preparations.

Go chief aims to stay on

The head of Go, the budget airline being sold by British Airways, told Reuters yesterday she expects to keep her job if rival KLM buys the business. Chief executive Barbara Cassani said BA was still reviewing a number of offers for the no-frills airline with the aim of reaching a deal around the end of March.

She was confident she would keep the job she started when Go was introduced three years ago.

fields.headline: How the vision became reality
fields.standfirst: Mary and Doug Perkins were at the forefront of the 80s eyecare revolution with their chain of opticians Specsavers. Eileen Sheridan spoke to them
fields.trailText: Mary and Doug Perkins were at the forefront of the 80s eyecare revolution with their chain of opticians Specsavers. Eileen Sheridan spoke to them.
fields.body:
It is hard to imagine that in this age of consumer choice there was a time - and not so long ago - when opticians were prevented from advertising and almost everything to do with eyecare was regulated by the government.

It was into this world that Doug and Mary Perkins, founders of the opticians chain Specsavers, graduated from University College, Cardiff in the late 60s. "It was a crazy time," says Doug, "they made obstacles for anybody actually expanding."

They began their own practice in Mary's home town of Bristol, working days and three evenings a week. During the next few years they began to expand.

Their business philosophy was to explore value for money to their customers - known as 'patients' then. They opened a series of practices outside Bristol under the name of John Perkins and Partner.

"We had to develop our practice solely on goodwill, by word of mouth and with outadvertising. We opened practices in places like Weston-super-Mare, Exeter, Plymouth, Newport, Swansea and Port Talbot," says Doug.

"Everything in those days revolved around the NHS - all the lenses and the eye testing were standard. It was about the mid-70s that the fashion side broke out and NHS frames began to disappear."

Even then, Doug and Mary took a modern approach to the business - their practices had shop windows with displays and prices.

"That was quite unusual," Mary says. "And people liked the thought that you could have medical care of your eyes as well as fashion. That's what we were always striving to do - put the two together in a professional manner."

By 1980, the monopoly in optical care was under scrutiny. Doug and Mary found running 23 practices as sole owners was stretching them, so they sold their interest to a public company. They could also see that dispensing glasses and contact lenses was going to become a different type of business as pressure was mounting to deregulate it.

"It was going to be a corporate chain thing and we really didn't want to be just a standard chain of opticians," says Doug. They took a career break and spent the next 18 months deciding what to do.

Meanwhile, in 1984 Margaret Thatcher's government passed legislation which allowed opticians to advertise and customers to go where they liked for their specs.

Doug says: "We decided optics was something that we could not live without. I didn't want to own a standard chain and we came up with a joint venture agreement."

And that was how Specsavers was launched. For the first three months, Doug and Mary worked from their bedroom with two staff and a table tennis table for a desk.

They opened the first store in Bristol in 1984, followed by other pilot stores in Swansea, Bath, Plymouth and Guernsey. These were privately owned by the couple, but promoted the joint venture concept to other opticians around the country.

"It was totally new in the profession in the UK," says Doug. "Building a national chain meant that we had the best of being a chain in terms of buying ability as well as allowing the independent optician in each town to own and to enjoy the profits of each business."

Specsavers holds a "helping hand" stake in each business, charging a fixed management fee related to turnover. For this the optician has a full back-up in shop fittings, stock, equipment and deals with other business issues such as EC compliance.

Mary directs sourcing and creating the product. "Spectacle frames are branded for Specsavers and made for us to our specifications. You can't get them anywhere else," she says.

The company has grown to 400 outlets throughout Britain and Ireland, providing spectacles and contact lenses to one in four of the population and is still expanding with a view to opening overseas - Holland is already on the Specsavers map. "We are exploring the different competitive environments," Doug explains.

With an annual turnover last year of £362m, 8,000 employees, 565 partners and headquarters in Guernsey, Specsavers remains very much a family business - all three of the Perkins' children work for it. And the two staff who started out with Doug and Mary are still with the company.

"We are pleased that we found a concept that we are able to look after the customers and a business that we feel is permanent and solid and one that we enjoy," says Doug.

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: The three most profitable businesses are supposedly narcotics, prostitution and ethical pharmaceuticals.
fields.body:
The three most profitable businesses are supposedly narcotics, prostitution and ethical pharmaceuticals. A recent Oxfam report and the new novel by John le Carré have brought ethical pharma-companies into the spotlight. Both allege these companies exploit the poor in the developing world.

With a median 35% return on equity, pharmaceuticals is far and away the world's most profitable major industry. With profits of more than $6bn, pharma-companies such as Pfizer and Glaxo SmithKline dwarf the likes of Unilever, BT or Coca-Cola. But to understand the sources of their wealth one must look to the West rather than the developing world.

Europe, the US and Japan account for virtually all the profits of these companies. Their riches stem from the unique industry structure that governments have allowed them to create.

In most markets profits are driven down by the power and price sensitivity of customers. But in pharmaceuticals, neither the patient who consumes the drugs, nor the doctor who prescribes them, is price sensitive. This is not because drugs are absolutely essential to life. If that were the case bread and milk companies would make huge profits. Customers for medicines are not price sensitive because they do not pay for them. In the UK it is the taxpayer who foots the bill.

Whereas most companies have profits capped by aggressive industry buyers, the pharmas have to negotiate only with civil servants. As we have seen with the likes of the Dome, the Home Office computer debacle, or the £650 a day being paid to Railtrack labourers, when taxpayers money is available, commercial disciplines disappear.

The second force that drives down prices in most industries is new competition. In electronics - an industry even more innovative than pharmaceuticals - excess profits from a new product soon disappear as competitors bring out copies. But in the pharmaceutical business, patents and government regulations block new competitors for an average of 10 years.

The consequence of this ability to negotiate very high prices and the absence of competitive threat is that the giant pharmaceuticals have no incentive to compete on price. It also explains why the pharma-companies have been unwilling to sell cheap medicines to the poor in Africa and Asia. The real worry is that dropping prices to the developing world would undermine the enormous margins being received in the UK and US. Smart traders would soon be reimporting medicines at a fraction of the official price. Even the civil servants at the Department of Health might be stung into tougher negotiating.

The industry's justification for its high prices and patent monopolies is that it encourages innovation. If margins were lower and patents were not enforced there would be no carrot to stimulate investment in R&D. But innovation appears to depend on sticks as much as carrots. Intense competition in electronics is the stick that forces companies to innovate continually. Without new and better products companies such as Sony and Philips know they will not maintain growth and market share.

Cost structures also appear to undermine the industry's case. Marketing expenses are typically almost double the R&D spend. Glaxo, for example, has 10,000 scientists but 40,000 salespeople. Pharma-companies spend more on marketing current products than they do on developing new ones.

• Peter Doyle is professor of marketing and strategy at the University of Warwick. His latest book is Value-based Marketing (Wiley).

fields.headline: Company vitae
fields.standfirst: BBA Group, which this week posted pre-tax profits of £287m, valuing it at £1.25bn
fields.trailText: BBA Group, which this week posted pre-tax profits of £287m, valuing it at £1.25bn.
fields.body:
Let me guess. Does it run all those stud farms?

That's the British Bloodstock Agency. BBA Group is a thoroughbred standard bearer of Britain's traditional manufacturing skills, with businesses in the specialist materials technology and aviation services.

Oh yeah, where does it fly to?

Its aviation services business is engaged in overhauling jet engines and providing business and commercial aviation services. The company is the world's largest servicer of private and corporate aircrafts. It owns Signature Flight Support, the US chain of airport based operations. BBA also makes aviation hydraulics and landing gear.

Must have a pedigree to service wealthy firms' flying machines?

It was founded in the 1870s as a family owned engineering concern making conveyor belts in Cleckheaton, West Yorkshire.

Does all its money come from posh people's planes?

Not all; it is a leading maker of non-woven materials for use in disposable nappies, feminine hygiene stuff and medical products. Its specialist materials technology division chips in around 48% of its annual earnings, feeding on the growing demand for health and hygiene.

Give us a glimpse of its corporate vision?

Last August, the group sold off its Automotive Friction business, which manufactured braking systems for car makers, raising £389m. The new corporate plan is to move up the value chain by establishing BBA as the first-choice partner for customers wanting cutting-edge technology and high-quality service by expanding the core business into new sectors. Filtration is a potential growth area for non-wovens, particularly in medical applications for disposable single-use items, such as surgical masks.

BBA will build on its unrivalled 'nose to tail' range of aviation services and the geographic spread of its network.

Has it made any strategic acquisitions?

Earlier this year, it acquired the engine overhaul and repair business of Gulfstream, the US jet manufacturer, giving it a new market in servicing a new class of engines. Last November, it paid £106.2m for Aircraft Service International Group, a Florida-based network of fuelling and ground cargo handling facilities at air ports in North America and the Caribbean, plus eight airports in Europe, including Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted. It flew into the European aviation services market when it picked up Lynton Aviation for £37m with operations at Luton and London City Airport. And, with its acquisition of Oxford Aviation for £55m, it has moved into the lucrative pilot training market.

Is the stock flying high, then?

Although it has performed consistently in difficult markets, its shares have been dragged down by investors' lack of enthusiasm for the engineering sector. What's more, three-quarters of its turnover is generated in the US, which makes it vulnerable to a downturn in the American economy. After posting pre-tax profits of £287m, shares were trading at 278p, valuing the firm at £1.25bn.

Any corporate turbulence?

This week it announced that it was cutting 600 US jobs to save £20m, offsetting difficult US market conditions.

No point in writing off for a job then?

The group also said that it will spend £50m to raise productivity. The firm makes 1.3m aircraft movements, handles 250m pounds of freight and dispenses more than 2.5bn gallons of fuel to aircraft ranging in size from a Cessna 172 to a Boeing 747. It is always in the market for skilled aircraft engineers and maintenance technicians.

Is it serious about equal opportunities and training?

There are no overt gestures, but Sarah Shaw, as group secretary and legal director, flies the flag for women in the executive suite. And it encourages its team leaders from diverse backgrounds to take up its executive leadership courses, run by Ashridge Management College.

The bosses must own private planes?

Not on their wages: top three boardroom salaries before perks or bonuses range from £250,000 to £545,000.

Any chance of dialling up workers' wages?

Average salaries among its 13,900 workers come out around £27,000.

Who fields job applications?

David McKee, the group human resources director, Corporate Headquarters, 70 Fleet Street, London EC4Y 1EU.

The firm makes 1.3m aircraft movements, handles 250m pounds of freight and dispenses more than 2.5bn gallons of fuel to aircraft ranging in size from a Cessna 172 to a Boeing 747. It is always in the market for skilled aircraft engineers and maintenance technicians. Is it serious about equal opportunities and training? There are no overt gestures, but Sarah Shaw, as group secretary and legal director, flies the flag for women in the executive suite. And it encourages its team leaders from diverse backgrounds to take up its executive leadership courses, run by Ashridge Management College. The bosses must own private planes? Not on their wages: top three boardroom salaries before perks or bonuses range from £250,000 to £545,000. Any chance of dialling up workers' wages? Average salaries among its 13,900 workers come out around £27,000. Who fields job applications? David McKee, the group human resources director, Corporate Headquarters, 70 Fleet Street, London EC4Y 1EU.

webTitle: Surge in rentals brings leap in profit for Canary Wharf

fields.headline: Surge in rentals brings leap in profit for Canary Wharf
fields.trailText: Surging rental income has helped Canary Wharf produce a 78% leap in underlying half-year profits, just a couple of days after topping out two new towers.
fields.body:
Surging rental income has helped Canary Wharf produce a 78% leap in underlying half-year profits, just a couple of days after topping out two new towers.

Excluding interest and exceptional items, the firm's operating profits jumped from £23.5m to £42m as tenants began paying for their office space, after an initial rent-free "inducement" period.

However, a one-off gain last year from the sale of a building meant the pre-tax profits were down 38% to £22.5m.

In a ceremony on Tuesday, Canary Wharf completed the shell of Docklands towers. Chief executive George Iacobescu said: "That was a milestone for the construction industry - it's a very powerful message that this kind of building can be done in just 24 months."

The HSBC building has cladding all the way to the roof and is ready for occupation as high as its 39th floor.

Canary Wharf, which is Britain's second biggest property firm, expressed optimism about continuing demand for office space. Mr Iacobescu said: "There's an extremely low vacancy rate across the whole of central London - just 3.3%."

Canary Wharf's shares slipped 7p to 517p.

webTitle: Working environment: the boss can relax with feng shui

fields.headline: When the boss can relax with feng shui
fields.standfirst: Stressed out? Paranoid? Or merely under pressure? Many firms already offer their staff counselling but, reports Joy Francis, this may not be enough. That's why some employers are starting to look at new age alternatives
fields.trailText: Stressed out? Paranoid? Or merely under pressure? Many firms already offer their staff counselling but, reports Joy Francis, this may not be enough. That's why some employers are starting to look at new age alternatives.
fields.body:
Amid evidence of spiralling stress levels and the unsettling presence of bullying in the workplace, another hidden trend that has yet to generate its own statistics is threatening to change the way businesses are run.

Directors of small companies and multi-million pound enterprises find themselves drawn to the seemingly unfathomable benefits of new age or alternative remedies. For example, the ancient Chinese arts of feng shui - the placement of furniture and plants to harmonise energy flows - and I ching, a system of divination, are used to enhance profit margins and create healthier working environments.

The motivation for this untraditional search has solid foundations. Last month a survey by Professor John McLeod from Dundee's Abertay University of 10,000 sufferers of workplace stress revealed they were displaying symptoms similar to those of psychiatric outpatients.

Some 1,000 firms are already offering their employees free stress counselling services to counter the problem, but is this enough? No, argues Kenny D'Cruz, founding director of the Feng Shui Partnership. His clients, made up of estate agents, teachers, architects, computer specialists and management consultants, reveal a lack of fulfillment which, he says, is at the heart of the crisis. "The traditional way of doing business was based on being good and uncritical. If you didn't conform, you could be out of a job. Business is about good relationships with staff, clients and suppliers with everyone giving positive energy."

Sarah McCrum, managing director of the four-month-old Energy "Bank", run by Satellite 603, finds it hard to disagree with Mr D'Cruz's assessment. Located near Liverpool Street, London, surrounded by high finance, the Energy "Bank" says it simply provides energy through a range of services from massage to life design consultancy for managers and staff. "It's a bit like a bank, but where energy is the currency rather than money," she explains.

Although this definition would possibly cause the Bank of England to balk in disbelief, Satellite 603 isn't short of high-flying clients.

From advertising agencies and investment bankers to dot.com companies and film producers, these clients are of ten stressed, exhausted, have recurrent illnesses and depleted energy levels.

Clients make use of relaxation sessions in any one of the "bank's" five halls based on natural elements - fire, water, earth, wood and metal. Guided by the principles of feng shui and I ching, the company's main aim is for you relax 24 hours a day, wherever you are, be it at your desk or on a train. Professional business associations are treading very carefully on this new ground. A spokesman from the British Chambers of Commerce says cautiously: "It would be inappropriate for me to suggest or advise that businesses take up or explore feng shui or some other new age option at the more unusual end of the spectrum." It suits 40-year-old Steve Saragossi. After 20 years in full-time employment, he decided eight months ago to launch The Comfort Factor Ltd, a direct marketing consultancy company.

Mr Saragossi was introduced to feng shui when Mr D'Cruz and his business partner Kristian Pengkerego did a presentation for the Business Network International organisation. He was four months into his new role as managing director and the business wasn't looking too promising. "I was stuck. There were lots of quotes for jobs, but hardly any commissions." On a whim he commissioned Mr D'Cruz and Mr Pengkerego who drew up western and Chinese astrological charts based on Mr Saragossi's date and time of birth.

An extensive consultation was conducted, covering his life experiences, health and relationships, identifying recurring theme. Next was a visit to Mr Saragossi's office.

"My desk was facing a wall that was overburdened with shelves, and my back was to the door. They said this was making me feel claustrophobic, under pressure and I couldn't see who was coming in, which was right," Mr Saragossi admits.

On advice, he bought a new desk and positioned it so that his back was to the wall, creating a feeling of security. Now he could see the door, which reduced feelings of paranoia and a lack of control.

The shelves were removed and their contents were relocated to a box of drawers creating even more space. The dark green oppressive colour scheme was repainted in a light orange creating a sense of calmness.

The positive results were immediate. "Business calls increased and my phone hardly stopped ringing. Quotes I had made months before were coming back as commissions. It was a turning point and a lot more opportunities have presented themselves since." Before the feng shui consultancy, Mr Saragossi's biggest contract was £12,500. Afterwards it was £38,000. He feels more relaxed, less panicked and is now negotiating his biggest quote ever at £300,000.

Jonathan Miller, the 30-year-old managing director of Alexanders, an estate agent in north-west London, has been using the Feng Shui Partnership for two-and-a-half years.

When he first commissioned them his seven-year-old company was doing quite well, but was stagnating. All four workers including the accountant had a full consultation leading to a change in seating arrangements and decor. A crystal went on to Mr Miller's desk to suck up the negative ions. A mirror was placed outside the toilet door located at the bottom of the stairs that led straight into the office. "This ensures that the energy bounces back up the stairs back into the office rather than going, quite literally, down the toilet."

A few weeks before the feng shui session Mr Miller had placed his quarterly VAT return and the company's turnover stood at £50,000. By the next quarter it had doubled to £100,000, and it hasn't stopped rising since.

After further consultations, Miller is about to take on more staff, is opening another office next month and has just refurbished his existing branch. His agents' commissions have regularly increased and clients appear more satisfied, leading to a rise in repeat business. Back at the Energy "Bank" Dominic Richards, 34, is planning a business energy package for key members of his 17-strong staff.

As joint chief executive of Queercompany.com, Mr Richards has been using the "bank" since December, a month after the official launch for the gay and lesbian lifestyle portal.

Virtually every newspaper covered Queercompany's bold advertising campaign, particularly the one featuring two women kissing in bed with the title "Thank God for Women". Despite this promising start Mr Richards felt that as a senior manager fronting a £3.5m venture, he had to be effective and calm. He was acutely aware that he had to make £2m by the end of this year. "As the joint chief executive of the company, any change or progress has to start with me. If I'm not calm, sorted, together and clear either I'm not going to make the right decisions." Since January he has been attending relaxation and life training sessions with an instructor every morning.

Like Mr Miller and Mr Saragossi, Mr Richards had his western and Chinese birth charts produced along with a consultation about his goals and the blocks to his achieving them.

He realised he was panicked, felt he had to control everything and was stressed. Now, he is calmer and is working more harmoniously with his management team in a way that wasn't apparent before. "People find me more approachable now. We are finding new avenues of income and new partnerships. It has been brilliant," he says. From his more relaxed position Mr Richards noticed that stress-related illnesses were already an issue among his staff who had been working hard since April in preparation for the launch. It doesn't help that there are 30 computers in one room and papers everywhere. Which is why he is negotiating a relaxation package for his staff with the Energy "Bank". Attending it made Mr Richards realise that "I have to look after the well being of my people and my company".

He plans to refurbish the offices including the creation of three large communal workstations surrounded by calm colours along with a juice bar "so there'll be high energy and soft energy spaces".

Not all of the commercial clients who are seeing positive results from using these techniques are willing to go on the record. Many fear ridicule or unfavourable feedback from their profit conscious shareholders.

Richard Wilson, Business Policy Executive at the Institute of Directors, isn't surprised at the reticence, but concedes the information they hold could be "useful if shared more openly".

That openness may take some time coming. But as some companies are offering their hard working staff free membership to gyms and dating agencies there is definitely a move away from traditional methods of retaining staff.

Sceptics may want to take Jonathan Miller up on his offer. "Get feng shui done. If it doesn't work I'll pay for it."

 The Feng Shui Partnership. Tel: 0208 883 1261 or www.fengshuipartnership.co.uk Prices start from £150.

 Satellite 603 The Energy "Bank", The Exchange, 132 Commercial Street, London, E1 6NG. Tel: 020 7650 0718. Life training and relaxation sessions start at £11. Tailored business packages are also on offer.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Telemonde, the telecoms company run by Kevin Maxwell, is based in the UK and not in the Bahamas, as reported in our financial pages on March 6. Furthermore, it was not forced to restate its earnings last year and has not suffered accounting irregularities. Apologies.
fields.body:
Telemonde, the telecoms company run by Kevin Maxwell, is based in the UK and not in the Bahamas, as reported in our financial pages on March 6. Furthermore, it was not forced to restate its earnings last year and has not suffered accounting irregularities. Apologies.

 In a short piece about the De La Warr pavilion in Bexhill-on-Sea, page 13, G2 (Arts), March 5, we described it as "the first building in the UK to have a steel structure". Steel frame buildings in Britain certainly date from well before that, with Robinson's Emporium at West Hartlepool, erected by Basil Scott, 1896, sometimes cited as the first of its kind (as in R Dixon and S Muthesius: Victorian Architecture, Thames and Hudson, 1978).

 In an article about racism in sport, page 26 (Comment), March 8, we seemed to suggest that Min Patel had not yet played cricket for England. He has, on two occasions, both against India in the Test series of 1996, the first, at Birmingham, and the third, at Nottingham.

The theatre where Somebody Bin Usin' That Thing is showing is the Rosemary Branch Theatre (not Rosemary Brank as it appeared on page 10, Friday Review, yesterday).

The readers' editor writes about unacceptable uses and variations of the term "arms akimbo", page 7, today's Saturday Review.

fields.headline: Cash   18-30
fields.trailText:
In the clinic: Sean Suckling
Age:30
Occupation: Local government officer
fields.body:
In the clinic: Sean Suckling
Age:30
Occupation: Local government officer

The problem

Can you help? I escaped from London two months ago to Yorkshire, mainly as a result of not being able to join the property ladder, and my partner and I recently became parents for the first time.

We've been saving like mad for the past couple of years and have a substantial amount for a deposit. Shall we go all out and mortgage ourselves to the max? Or do we buy a property just using my borrowing potential?

I also have an outstanding student loan of £3,500 - should I pay this off so we can borrow more? Or should I buy some extra years on my government pension scheme instead? I earn £22,500.

The solution: All our experts agree that you should not overstretch yourself on the mortgage. There is no consensus on the student loan, however.

1 I would recommend for the sake of neatness and your own peace of mind that you get rid of the student loan without delay. I don't know how long you've had it, but with your current commitments, the quicker you get rid of it the better.

I don't believe in maximum mortgages. As a new purchaser you are likely to have a mortgage for 25 years and in that time anything can happen to rates. Although there are special deals around, don't be lulled into a false sense that borrowing is cheap.

Remember that as a basic rate taxpayer, you will have to earn £12.82 for every £10 of mortgage, and apart from anything else, you will still have to get used to having a new addition to the family and assessing how much extra this is going to cost. There are also other considerations - will your partner be going back to work? How much will childcare cost if she does? What is the income she gives up if she doesn't? The other thing to be aware of is that a salary rising with inflation isn't going to make you rich as a local government officer.

I suggest that you pay a deposit that is large enough to avoid what is known as mortgage indemnity guarantees - and anyway, the more you put down, the more equity you will own in your home from the outset.

It might sound old- fashioned, but try to borrow as little as possible for as short a time as possible. But, it would be a good idea not to spend all your savings on a deposit, so you can keep some aside for emergencies.

Harry Katz
Norwest Consultants

2 Although I can understand the desire to start as high up the housing ladder as possible, a word of caution: you should keep three months' household expenditure on accessible deposit in case of emergency.

Do not forget to include in this calculation an analysis of expected household expenditure. Student loans represent cheap money at the moment.

Paul Duckworth
IFA

3 I would not extend your mortgage to the max. With a new child there are probably other areas where you will want to spend money. You could go for a flexible mortgage, which would allow you to borrow for other purposes at mortgage rates.

However, these are more expensive than standard mortgages, and unless you are likely to have large lump sums to pay in to offset your borrowings, it is probably not worth it in your case.

I think the best thing to do would be to go for a 90% loan and keep back some money, rather than borrowing the most you can. Regarding the student loan, interest rates are very low, so there is probably no point your paying it off.

As for buying extra years, this is a fantastic idea in principle, but I think you are planning for your retirement too early - you already have a pension, so I would advise you to just see how your costs pan out over the next few years.

John Stewart
PMI Independent Financial Adviser

Interviews by Liz Stuart

webTitle: Letters: For the love of a good book

fields.headline: For the love of a good book
fields.trailText: As owners of a small independent bookshop which has, as yet, not succumbed to the onslaught of market forces, we would agree with Matthew Engel that "providing a brilliant service or ambience" (Bookshops are closing. Hurrah, March 6) is a major factor in our survival.
fields.body:
As owners of a small independent bookshop which has, as yet, not succumbed to the onslaught of market forces, we would agree with Matthew Engel that "providing a brilliant service or ambience" (Bookshops are closing. Hurrah, March 6) is a major factor in our survival.

However, his analysis is naive and ill-thought through. He has to acknowledge that his local bookshop closed, not because the "owner was a bit of a grump" but because "Waterstones was moving into pole position, opposite McDonald's". Exactly, Matthew. It is competition from chains, supermarkets and the internet, as well as soaring rents, which kill off small bookshops. So, let's hope that our ambience, excellent service and lack of grumpiness will be enough to guarantee our future - or there will be one more hurrah from Engel.
Jackie Slack and Christine Fisher
Little Green Dragon Bookshop, Alton, Hants

 Matthew Engel makes a generalisation and writes a pa tronising sentence too far. The collapse of the net book agreement (NBA) was "held off" not because of the terror of decimation of small bookshops. The NBA was ultimately undermined by the largest publishing groups bypassing the Publishers' Association.

The NBA, an agreement among publishers, was a helpful "control" which protected book-buyers, booksellers and the mass of publishers from potentially rampant unfair competition (the chains obtaining much larger discounts than independents; "loss leader" title promotions replacing a genuine range of stock).

There is one generalisation, amidst the many not argued through or supported, which has credibility - books are indeed "units of production" in the industrialised processing and selling of the international publishing agglomerations.

However, there are those of us in small bookshops, in small publishing houses and even in the recesses of the giant monopolistic publishers, who will continue to offer a dedicated service to our book-loving customers rather than "go to the wall".
Malcolm Stanton
Ludlow, Shropshire

 Sutton is fortunate to have a small independent bookshop. Its owners are very knowledgeable about their books. If the book you want is not in stock they will order it for you and telephone you immediately when it has arrived, often by the following day. Browsing around their shop, I hardly ever leave without buying at least one book.

On a cold day before Christmas I was surprised to be served with a glass of sherry and mince pies. Less than five minutes walk away, a two-storey Waterstones opened some time ago.
Inge Trott
Cheam, Surrey

 Our reading group (Letters, March 7) began in 1966 and are still going strong. We began as young mums in our early thirties in need of intellectual stimulation. Many of us are now retired and still enjoy the excitement that reading and discussion brings. As society changed its attitude to women with children working, we resumed our careers and in many cases developed new ones. Those changes in society are reflected in our choice of books: the first one in 1966 was Robin Pedley's The Comprehensive School; in 1976 we read Melanie Klein's Working With Groups; in 1980, Marilyn French's The Women's Room; in 1990 Have The Men Had Enough? by Margaret Forster. Our next book is Jeremy Leggett's The Carbon War.

What keeps us going? The love of a good book, of course.
Vera Ransome and the other 16 in the group
Lewes, East Sussex

fields.headline: Four's a crowd
fields.standfirst: But three Spice Girls would be one too few
fields.trailText: Once there were five. Then Geri Halliwell left. Did she jump? Was she pushed? No one knew. The rest of the Spice Girls shrugged off her disappearance and went on wowing their young - often very young - fans and topping the charts. But now another defection looms.
fields.body:
Once there were five. Then Geri Halliwell left. Did she jump? Was she pushed? No one knew. The rest of the Spice Girls shrugged off her disappearance and went on wowing their young - often very young - fans and topping the charts. But now another defection looms. Spokespeople say the girls are still in business, but that's not how Mel C, otherwise known as Sporty Spice, makes it sound. "We're still linked business-wise and still friends," she is quoted as saying, "but I don't really consider myself to work as a band member any more."

If she goes, it may well be the end, not least because she is rated their strongest singer. They might go on as a trio, though some say a trio would never get into the charts. These are not the days of the Beverley Sisters. They might recruit some suitably talented newcomer: acquiring Dame Kiri te Kanawa, say, or Barbara Bonney would give them fresh prestige. But more likely the Spice Girls are now on their way to that bourn from which there is no return. Their last album was called Forever. It did less well than expected. Maybe their fans suspected that in the ephemeral world of the pop group, there is rarely such a thing as forever.

webTitle: Leader: Police must leave pictures alone

fields.headline: Off the wall
fields.standfirst:
The police must leave these pictures alone
Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: It should be heart-warming news to learn that some of our hard-pressed police have found time to visit an art gallery in London. Where better to find sanctuary from the stressful and ceaseless fight against crime?
fields.body:
It should be heart-warming news to learn that some of our hard-pressed police have found time to visit an art gallery in London. Where better to find sanctuary from the stressful and ceaseless fight against crime? Sir John Stevens, the Scotland Yard Police Commissioner, should encourage more of his staff to sample the cultural offerings within his Metropolitan patch. No beat officer could see the Caravaggios currently on display at the Royal Academy and leave without a spring in his step.

But Sir John also has a duty not to waste police time. And it is difficult to think of a bigger waste of time than for highly experienced police officers to be making repeat visits to the Saatchi Gallery in north London with a view to prosecuting the gallery, not to mention the accompanying book, for obscenity. If - as seems likely - the raids were at the instigation of a Sunday red-top tabloid the waste of time is doubly scandalous.

The pictures to which the policemen have taken exception are photographs by an American living in London, Tierney Gearon. The pictures were described by one critic as "taking conventional delight and amusement in her small children as they mess around, play games, take baths and so on". In some of the pictures her children are not wearing any clothes. Some critics have found them sweet and innocent, others have found them disturbing. Either reaction is valid. What is unimaginable is that officers should return to the gallery next week, snatch the images off the walls and place them under lock and key.

We have been here with weary regularity before. It was in 1956 that the editor of the Sunday Express, John Gordon, pronounced Lolita "the filthiest book I have ever read" and urged that anyone selling it should be imprisoned. Ten years later the Met's "Dirty Squad" decided to prosecute a West End gallery for exhibiting the prints of Jim Dine. The then arts minister, Jennie Lee, protested and Lord Goodman wrote to the home secretary, Roy Jenkins, to say that it would be "very reassuring to enlightened humanity throughout the country" if he would send out an instruction that "pictures on the walls should be inviolate so far as artistic judgments by policemen are concerned". It would be very reassuring if the culture secretary, Chris Smith, would write to Jack Straw in similar terms today. And if Scotland Yard would stop wasting police time.

fields.headline: Terms of endearment
fields.trailText: No, tart is not "an abbreviation of sweetheart" (Letters, March 8). Tart is a slang use of the SE tart, a covered or uncovered fruit pie.
fields.body:
No, tart is not "an abbreviation of sweetheart" (Letters, March 8). Tart is a slang use of the SE tart, a covered or uncovered fruit pie. It is thus cognate with a range of similarly affectionate terms for women, eg sweetie, sweetiepie, cookie, cupcake, lamb chop, sugar, honey, hot tamale and tomato, all of whom are "good enough to eat".

Its non-pejorative use seems to have appeared c.1860; the slang lexicographer JC Hotten quotes "Jim the Patterer" in 1864: "Tart, a term of approval applied by the London lower orders to a young woman for whom some affection is felt."

The pejorative use, meaning a promiscuous woman or even whore, emerges c.1885. Although the negative use is considered more common today, I have found affectionate or neutral (ie meaning simply "a woman") citations throughout the 20th century and into the 21st.
Jonathon Green
London
slang@crayford.demon.co.uk

 When I lived in Edinburgh, women were called "hen". When I moved to Nottingham, I noticed they were called "duck", as are men. An Eastwood shopkeeper once addressed me as "My love". Taking this as my cue to comment on the pervading influence of DH Lawrence' s views on sexuality, I was repulsed by the retort, "That dutty buggah."
Dr Allan Dodds
Bramcote, Nottingham
a.g.dodds@ntlworld.com

 Here at the cutting edge of zeitgeist cool which is Lincolnshire, men call men duck. They don't call women anything much.
Morag McGill
Lincoln

fields.headline: Capital letters
fields.standfirst: Mortgage maze | Overseas shares | Credit cards
fields.trailText: Mortgage maze | Overseas shares | Credit cards
fields.body:
We owe £55,000 on our home loan with ten years to go. We earn £3,000 a month after deductions between us and we can save £500 a month. I am tempted to take out one of the new-style mortgages which combine home loans with current accounts. Would they be suitable or are there hidden drawbacks? LE, Leicester

It seems that your main desire is to pay off your loan as quickly as possible. That makes sense as it is better to repay a loan than to keep a large amount of savings on which you pay tax. You should, of course, have an emergency fund as well.

As you are not held in by redemption penalties, you have three main choices. You could stay with your present lender and arrange to increase your payments. But you are likely to be on a high standard variable rate.

A second choice is to take out a combined loan and current account package. But the choice is not large. Britannic (formerly First Active), Clydesdale, Intelligent Finance, Virgin, Woolwich and Yorkshire Bank are the main players. These accounts do offset interest on your loan against your whole bank balance, but you may have to pay in your salary and re-arrange overdraft facilities.

Possibly your best option is to go for a flexible mortgage with a lump sum withdrawal facility for emergencies. This would cope with your extra £500 a month but return some of your additional payments in case of need. There is a wide variety of these.

My £59,000 mortgage has 17 years to run - I'm currently paying 6.84% fixed until April 2004. If I want to redeem it, there is a penalty clause during the next three years which will cost 4% of the sum borrowed. But I have recently come into a £60,000 inheritance. Should I clear the mortgage even though I have to pay the penalty or should I invest the money?

AF, Bradford

Bite the bullet and pay the penalty. Unless you are willing to take substantial risks with your cash which come right, paying off your loan makes sense. Here's the arithmetic. You are paying £4,035 a year in interest or £12,105 over the remaining three years. But how much would you earn from your savings - assuming your are a basic rate taxpayer? You would be lucky to keep up 6% gross on your lump sum over the period unless you are prepared to take risks. This would amount to around £8,640 - £6,480 if you are a higher rate taxpayer. Add those figures to the penalty, which works out at £2,360 (from your windfall) and you are better off clearing the loan.

We recently remortgaged from First Direct to Hinckley & Rugby Building Society, saving more than £60 a month on a £92,000 mortgage and freeing up £6,000 for home improvements into the bargain. But our experience has thrown up issues. These include:

 A daunting range of deals, each of which claims to be the best
Complicated cash-back deals which seem to be paid for by higher interest rates
Huge amounts of form-filling and the need to produce original documents
 Legal fees running up to £350 in our case.

PW and SH, London

There is nothing for nothing in finance. Working your way through the minefield of confusion marketing - where no two products are comparable - is not easy, but can become simpler if you decide your priorities from a remortgage. You may want to swap legal costs for a higher rate or go for lower interest by giving up initial attractions such as cash-backs. Before you switch your loan again, phone 0800-694-6444 for a free copy of the Guardian Guide to Remortgaging.

Problems holding overseas shares

I hold a few shares in South African diamond producer De Beers, which has received a takeover bid from mining group Anglo American. The only form of payment, I have heard, is cash. But that would give me a complicated capital gains tax calculation. Is there any way of avoiding or delaying a capital gain either by receiving shares in Anglo American or another firm?

ME, London

This is a complicated situation in that Anglo and De Beers already own about a third of the shares in each other. And it does not help that few private client stockbrokers follow either of these South African companies even though Anglo is, for convenience, listed in London.

These companies are really two facets of the same Oppenheimer finance and mines empire. Your problem is not as great as you fear as the deal, whose chances of failure are about the same as of you finding gem quality diamonds at the bottom of your garden, swaps each De Beer share for $14.40 in cash (about £10) and 0.43 Anglo shares (worth about £20).

So, any capital gains tax would only be levied on the cash element which may well be within your annual limit. But if your holding is large, you could shelter some of the gain if you reinvest in a Venture Capital Trust.

This takeover has not been arranged to benefit small shareholders or even institutional UK shareholders. That is always a risk when dealing in overseas shares.

Why was I refused a credit card?

I recently applied for a Nationwide credit card and was turned down. I found this surprising as I am in comfortable circumstances, have been with the same employer for 25 years and in the same house for 20 years. I have never had any problems with debt or credit and usually clear my cards each month. The Experian report confirms my exemplary financial history. I no longer want the credit card as I got a better deal with Egg, but would like to know why Nationwide rejected me.

MP, London

And that is all you are likely to get. Credit card companies are not obliged to tell you why they turned you down. It seems, however, that someone made a mistake and has covered it up. But the current Egg deal is better than anything Nationwide can offer.

A savings plan for my baby

I had my first baby in September 2000. I am receiving £60 per month Child Benefit and would like to establish a regular savings plan to make some tax-efficient use of these extra funds for long-term investment. perhaps for school fees later. What should I do? Take out a friendly society bond?

JW, London

Friendly society bonds suffer from high charges and low investment limits - currently £25 a month. As you are investing your money for your child, you should look for an investment trust with a low-cost savings scheme which has a worldwide general remit - the biggest include Foreign & Colonial, Witan and Scottish American. You can get a list from the Association of Investment Trust Companies on 0800-085-8520.

£8,000 payments comedy of errors

Last November, I decided to switch my credit card balance from MBNA to Halifax. I liked the Halifax introductory rate and the better facilities. In December, my Halifax card arrived and I asked Halifax to pay £8,000 to MBNA to close my debt with it. I then chopped up the MBNA card.

But that's when my problems started. Firstly, Halifax told me the sum was too big even though it was within my credit limit. At the same time, however, someone else did switch the £8,000 to MBNA.

When they finally responded to my request for information on my credit limit, they sent a further £8,000 to MBNA. But I did not know this as I went to South Africa at Christmas. On my return, I discovered the Halifax was charging interest on £16,000.

Several phone calls got me nowhere - and letters seem to be ignored. Eventually, I got through to someone who promised to sort it out.

The end result was that both of the £8,000 sums were taken back from MBNA, leaving me with even bigger interest bills and fees for late payments from MBNA.

What is going on? This is costing me a fortune in phone calls, letters, interest and nervous energy.

PK, London

The to-ing and fro-ing of your £8,000 payments would seem to be a comedy of errors. Halifax has looked into your problem and admits that you have not been well served. It blames bad luck, internal errors and your own intervention for the difficulties.

Halifax claims that one letter sent to a senior person was never received. To make matters worse, you were never too clear whose fault the cash tennis rally was.

But at least Halifax admits that it has not performed to an acceptable standard.It has arranged to refund all the interest charges during this period, and to send you £20 for your time and expenses. That ex-gratia payment should be at least £100.

 Got a problem? We want to hear about it. Get in touch with us here at Jobs & Money and we will try to help.

fields.headline: The other tube route
fields.trailText: Digby Jones, director-general of the CBI, clearly supports the government's plans for the tube sell-off (Bring in the private sector, March 9).
fields.body:
Digby Jones, director-general of the CBI, clearly supports the government's plans for the tube sell-off (Bring in the private sector, March 9). Sadly, he is mistaken in his belief that there is no detailed workable alternative capable of immediate implementation and at no risk to the UK taxpayer.

There is another option, which the Liberal Democrats, the Mayor of London and his transport commissioner, Bob Kiley, have been advocating for some time - to raise the money through bonds.

It is quite clear that raising money through bonds is an entirely workable solution to financing the investment needed for London's failing tube. Bonds were the success behind financing the crumbling New York subway. Moreover, a bonds issue would allow a unified management structure, thus avoiding the govern ment's potentially dangerous plans to split operations from infrastructure.
Lynne Featherstone
Liberal Democrat spokesperson on Transport, Greater London Authority

 Digby Jones cites the dome and the Jubilee line as examples of public sector cost overruns on big projects. There are many private sector counter examples, notably the west coast main line, where costs have soared from £2.3bn to £5.4bn. And because Railtrack cannot be allowed to go bust, guess who foots the bill?

Precisely the same will happen on the underground. Ultimately, you cannot genuinely privatise risk on a publicly funded project. All you do is pay extra to borrow the capital.
Christian Wolmar
London
xian@pro-net.co.uk

fields.headline: Acting up
fields.trailText: Interesting that when you fanfare Arts Council grants (After years of drought, money to finish the job, March 9) there's never a word about jobbing actors who feel we have been holding up the entire edifice for the past 20 years.
fields.body:
Interesting that when you fanfare Arts Council grants (After years of drought, money to finish the job, March 9) there's never a word about jobbing actors who feel we have been holding up the entire edifice for the past 20 years.

Last year, in Battersea, I played Mark Antony in Dryden's All For Love for £25 a week. Before that we premiered Jim Allen's Perdition at the Gate Theatre, again central London, for no fee at all - we got free bus passes for the run of the play.

The Arts Council money you fanfare is pathetically too little. The damage done to British drama over the Thatcher years and subsequently demands, not only cash, but a total revolution in political thinking about the status and value of the performing arts in national life.
Ian Flintoff
London IanFlintoff@aol.com

fields.headline: Partners against Aids
fields.trailText: Mark Haywood (People come before profit, March 5) described litigation between the Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Association and the South African government.
fields.body:
Mark Haywood (People come before profit, March 5) described litigation between the Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Association and the South African government. Firstly, Pfizer is not party to this lawsuit. In addition, the article referred to Pfizer's antifungal drug, Diflucan (fluconazole), and its use in the treatment of severe fungal infections in patients suffering from HIV and Aids.

Pfizer recognises that South Africa faces an Aids epidemic of tragic proportions. Already, estimates suggest that around 10% of the population have acquired HIV. Furthermore, one in four South African women between the ages of 20 and 29 are infected with the virus.

It was with this in mind that Pfizer Inc entered into negotiations with the South African Ministry of Health in April 2000. Working to gether with the South African government we developed the Diflucan Partnership Programme. Approved by the South African Minister of Health, Dr Manto Tshabalala-Msimang, on February 20 2001, this initiative will ensure that Diflucan is provided to those patients in need at no cost, for as long as they need it.

The Aids epidemic in South Africa is one of the single greatest healthcare challenges facing the world today. Any solution can only be achieved through partnership, political leaders, the medical fraternity, patient and advice groups and private industry working together.

To lay responsibility for this public health catastrophe at the door of the pharmaceutical industry is both misleading and naive.
Miranda Kavanagh
Pfizer, London

fields.headline: Mandelson's dog days
fields.trailText: There's no dispute that Peter Mandelson did make the telephone call in question, so why is he exonerated of all blame (Report gives Mandelson no way back, March 9)?
fields.body:
There's no dispute that Peter Mandelson did make the telephone call in question, so why is he exonerated of all blame (Report gives Mandelson no way back, March 9)? Surely he was using his influence inappropriately, to say the least, in view of the Hinduja brothers' contribution to the dome. But he forgot, so that's all right then.

Perhaps he should, like the rest of us who are getting old and forgetful, retire to spend more time with his dogs.
Eileen Noakes
Totnes, Devon
eileen.noakes@talk21.com

 We all know that Tony Blair, and indeed Jack Straw, need to be seen as being tough on offenders. However, if this is what Peter Mandelson gets for being innocent, it is difficult to imagine what they would have done to him for being guilty.
Rev John Gillibrand
Menai Bridge, Anglesey
Gillibrands@aol.com

 I have been a member of the Labour party for 37 years and I first wrote to Tony Blair in 1999 expressing concern at the way my party was developing and gave the arrogance of Peter Mandelson as just one example.

This was not, and never has been, acknowledged - although minor party minions were at pains to persuade me to stay in membership, since I had said that I was having to consider this very seriously. Obviously where I went wrong was in not signing the letter "MJ Hinduja" and including an invitation to a Diwali party.
Mick Williams
Stoke-on-Trent
MICK.WILLIAMS@GEO2.POPTEL.ORG.UK

webTitle: Cashpoints: Helping the aged ease pain of paying for healthcare.

fields.headline: Helping the aged ease pain of paying for healthcare
fields.standfirst: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: Help the Aged healthcare plan | Lloyds guide to the Euro | All-risk weather insurance
fields.body:
Charity Help the Aged is offering a healthcare plan that takes the financial sting out of everyday healthcare costs for older people. The scheme has no upper age limit for applicants and is tailored specifically with older people's needs in mind. The deal is designed to contribute towards the cost of a range of treatments including dentistry and eye care. The plan offers a more economical alternative for those who find the cost of private medical insurance prohibitive.

As well as insuring against the ex pected age-related ailments, the plan can contribute towards unexpected costs such as a stay in hospital, a specialist consultation, longer-term care such as home help or respite care and can also help pay for complementary medicine including physiotherapy, osteopathy, chiropractic treatment, acupuncture and homeopathy.

Applicants are not required to take a medical or complete a lengthy questionnaire. Cash benefits are paid tax-free, normally within three working days, directly to the claimant. The Healthcare Cash Plan from Help the Aged costs from just 20p a day. For further information call 08081-44-20000.

 Ahead of the demise of the 12 national currencies which are to be replaced by the euro on December 31, Lloyds TSB Bank has produced a timely guide about living with the new system. The free booklet comes with useful tips for travellers in Europe including using and getting cash, dealing with dual pricing, using UK-issued debit and credit cards and making payments in sterling in the Eurozone. Free copies of Keeping You Posted About the Euro are available from Lloyds TSB Branches.

 As we look forward to the balmy days of summer, anyone responsible for organising outdoor events, should sleep easier if they first take out an all-risk weather insurance policy. Specialist insurer Weather Direct writes policies to insure a range of outdoor events and activities including concerts, fetes and local sports gatherings. Cover can include abandonment or cancellation as well as reduced attendance due to bad weather.

The insurer uses meteorological data going back some 30 years to calculate the probability of rainfall at any time in any area by postcode. Claims are triggered after 10 continuous minutes of rainfall, involving no other complex calculations or measurements.

For details of premiums and cover contact Steve Warner of Weather Direct on 020-7426-2651.
