webTitle: The Budget: Odds are still against punters.

fields.headline: Odds are still against punters
fields.trailText: The widely expected abolition of betting duty in the Budget was heralded by most of the gambling industry as being good news for gamblers.
fields.body:
The widely expected abolition of betting duty in the Budget was heralded by most of the gambling industry as being good news for gamblers. Coral chief executive Bob Scott went as far as saying: "This is not just good news for punters and bookmakers, but also for the country."

In reality, though, the only people likely to benefit are the bookies as the tax saving is unlikely to be passed on to punters. At present 6.75% of any bet placed at an off course bookmaker has to be paid to the government. A myth that the tax is actually 9% - accepted by virtually every newspaper commenting on the Budget - has been encouraged to grow by bookmakers. On horse racing an additional 1.34% has to be paid to the horse racing levy.

Nine per cent, though, is the figure deducted from bets on all sports for "tax". Not surprisingly, this blatant rip off has led to the recent growth of offshore tax-free internet and telephone gambling services.

The 6.75% tax is not vastly different in amount or how it works to the 5% insurance premium tax. Unlike bookies, insurers seem able to quote their prices inclusive of tax, and certainly do not inflate the figure.

From January 2002 the 6.75% will be replaced by a 15% tax on bookies' gross profits. The table here shows how to work out what the bookies' profit will be.

The 25.8%, or just over one-quarter, is typical for many events. On horse racing it can be considerably higher. Chandlers were this week taking over 46% profit on their book for the 2000 Guineas in May. But it can be less for football - the same company was only taking 12% on the outcome of the Porto v Liverpool match on Thursday. The 15% tax will amount to about 4% of takings. Inevitably this sum will be recovered from punters. Victor Chandler, head of Chandlers, was alone among the industry leaders in being frank about this, saying after the Budget: "The tax changes look like a hollow victory for punters as they will continue to pay - only this time they won't realise it."

Many bookies will make their odds even shorter with 30%, rather than 25%, profit becoming the norm on many events. Others may simply continue making a deduction calling it "a levy" or service charge. At present big bookies usually make such a deduction when they take bets at sports grounds, even though no tax at all is payable on them. If odds shorten it is likely to be at the expense of the less sophisticated and generally poorer punter.

Off-shore betting will continue to flourish, as bookies will want to avoid the new tax just as much as they did the old. Such betting, though, is only available to people with credit or debit cards.

Those who gamble at betting shops have no choice but to accept the odds they are quoted. Because of the way odds are expressed, few will be able to calculate when they move still further in the bookies' favour. Many will naively believe they must be getting a better deal if they are not paying "tax".

Rather than tinkering with the way betting is taxed, the government might try to regulate it much more closely. It is certainly arguable that advertising odds without saying that a further deduction is to be made is a breach of the Consumer Protection Act which outlaws misleading price indications, yet the OFT have shied away from this issue. Even more fundamental is the way the big bookies almost invariably come up with similar odds and consequent profit margins. This suggests there may be little meaningful competition between them.

How the bookies always win

The easiest way to understand how events are priced is to look at odds in percentage terms. Evens means a horse has a 50% chance of winning. If every horse was given odds that equated to its true chance the total of all their prices would amount to 100%. However, odds are always shorter than the true price, so the total comes to well over 100%. The amount by which the percentage exceeds 100 is the bookies profit, sometimes referred to as the "over-round".

A typical range of odds for a five-horse race might be

Horse | <+>Odds | Percentage equivalent

Rolly | Evens | 50%

Bob | 2/1 | 33.3%

Lofty | 5/2 | 28.6%

Muck | 10/1 | 9.1%

Pilchard | 20/1 | 4.8%

The total of the percentages is 125.8% giving the bookie a profit or "overround" of 25.8% of the takings.

webTitle: Chief vet says no end to crisis in sight

fields.headline: Chief vet says no end to crisis in sight
fields.standfirst:
Farmers who traded outside official sales rings urged to come forward to help trace animals

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Farmers who traded outside official sales rings urged to come forward to help trace animals.
fields.body:
The foot and mouth outbreak will continue much longer than originally thought because sheep with links to infected sites may have been bought outside the official sales rings and are now untraceable and suffering from the disease.

Jim Scudamore, the government's chief vet, said farmers may have bought sheep without realising they were infected - the disease is difficult to spot in sheep - and without paperwork, making it hard to trace them. He urged farmers to come forward to allow their animals to be inspected by vets.

New outbreaks are being discovered because newborn lambs are dying of the disease, one of the most obvious signs that a flock is infected. Cattle are also developing the disease, having caught it from contact with sheep without the farmer realising his sheep have been infected.

Anyone who has traded sheep in or around any of the half a dozen markets known to have links to the disease is being asked to come forward. Some of these people may have committed criminal offences by not completing the necessary paperwork but their help is vital if the disease is to be contained, he said.

The disease already covers a much larger area of the country than in the 1967 epidemic, reflecting a huge change in farming methods. Although there were 2,364 farms involved in 1967, they were mostly confined to Welsh border areas and in six months never reached as far south as Devon or as far north as Cumbria.

Although the number of farms involved is fewer at this stage of the outbreak than in 1967, the number of animals to be killed - 100,000 - is much greater, reflecting the increased size of both holdings and flocks.

In the latest outbreak the disease was spread round the country in just days as dealers shipped sheep from market to market to make extra profits. Because of local abattoirs being replaced with larger specialist operations infected livestock have been transported much longer distances.

The infection had moved from Heddon-on-the-Wall in Northumberland to Essex as part of the pig trade, to Cumbria, Scotland, Northern Ireland and Devon, and as far east as Northampton as fat lambs were traded.

Mr Scudamore was more pessimistic yesterday than at any time since the start of the foot and mouth outbreak saying that he did not know when the number of cases would start to go down. He said: "The fact is we do not know where all the flocks incubating this disease are, or how many more there might be."

He said he was still sure the best way to stop a further spread was to continue movement restrictions on all farm animals. All the cases so far can be traced back to the original outbreak at Heddon-on-the-Wall. "If we suddenly get new cases in new parts of the country without links to these cases then we are in a much more serious situation," he said.

The continued increase in the number of cases means that the restrictions on the movement of animals would have to be extended beyond next Friday when they officially end, he said.

A new problem is the possibility that a small number of sheep become carriers. These are animals that have the disease and get better without the farmer noticing. These sheep are not normally infectious but if they are put in a stressful situation, for example loaded in a lorry and carried long distances, then they could pass on the disease. Sheep can be carriers for up to nine weeks after recovering from the infection.

To guard against new outbreaks among sheep that had not been detected with the disease, a regime of movement restrictions would have to be imposed.

Yesterday, Lady Hayman, the junior agriculture minister, agreed with farmers' leaders a limited movement of animals for welfare reasons. Cattle, pigs and sheep can now be moved across roads on farms for milking or to give birth. Where animals are on hills and need to be brought to shelter for lambing they can be moved up to three miles but both kinds of movement require a special licence.

The wider scheme for the collecting of animals from small farms to holding centres and then moving them on for slaughter has been postponed because of the dangers of spreading the disease and possible objections from the European Union, which had banned such movements on the continent.

Licences for moving animals from large holdings direct to slaughterhouses continue to be issued. Pig meat has reached 81% of normal supplies, beef 53% and lamb 25%. There are no shortages in the shops because the shortfall is being made up from foreign supplies.

Jim Scudamore, the government's chief vet, said farmers may have bought sheep without realising they were infected - the disease is difficult to spot in sheep - and without paperwork, making it hard to trace them. He urged farmers to come forward to allow their animals to be inspected by vets. New outbreaks are being discovered because newborn lambs are dying of the disease, one of the most obvious signs that a flock is infected. Cattle are also developing the disease, having caught it from contact with sheep without the farmer realising his sheep have been infected. Anyone who has traded sheep in or around any of the half a dozen markets known to have links to the disease is being asked to come forward. Some of these people may have committed criminal offences by not completing the necessary paperwork but their help is vital if the disease is to be contained, he said. The disease already covers a much larger area of the country than in the 1967 epidemic, reflecting a huge change in farming methods. Although there were 2,364 farms involved in 1967, they were mostly confined to Welsh border areas and in six months never reached as far south as Devon or as far north as Cumbria. Although the number of farms involved is fewer at this stage of the outbreak than in 1967, the number of animals to be killed - 100,000 - is much greater, reflecting the increased size of both holdings and flocks. In the latest outbreak the disease was spread round the country in just days as dealers shipped sheep from market to market to make extra profits. Because of local abattoirs being replaced with larger specialist operations infected livestock have been transported much longer distances. The infection had moved from Heddon-on-the-Wall in Northumberland to Essex as part of the pig trade, to Cumbria, Scotland, Northern Ireland and Devon, and as far east as Northampton as fat lambs were traded. Mr Scudamore was more pessimistic yesterday than at any time since the start of the foot and mouth outbreak saying that he did not know when the number of cases would start to go down. He said: "The fact is we do not know where all the flocks incubating this disease are, or how many more there might be." He said he was still sure the best way to stop a further spread was to continue movement restrictions on all farm animals. All the cases so far can be traced back to the original outbreak at Heddon-on-the-Wall. "If we suddenly get new cases in new parts of the country without links to these cases then we are in a much more serious situation," he said. The continued increase in the number of cases means that the restrictions on the movement of animals would have to be extended beyond next Friday when they officially end, he said. A new problem is the possibility that a small number of sheep become carriers. These are animals that have the disease and get better without the farmer noticing. These sheep are not normally infectious but if they are put in a stressful situation, for example loaded in a lorry and carried long distances, then they could pass on the disease. Sheep can be carriers for up to nine weeks after recovering from the infection. To guard against new outbreaks among sheep that had not been detected with the disease, a regime of movement restrictions would have to be imposed. Yesterday, Lady Hayman, the junior agriculture minister, agreed with farmers' leaders a limited movement of animals for welfare reasons. Cattle, pigs and sheep can now be moved across roads on farms for milking or to give birth. Where animals are on hills and need to be brought to shelter for lambing they can be moved up to three miles but both kinds of movement require a special licence. The wider scheme for the collecting of animals from small farms to holding centres and then moving them on for slaughter has been postponed because of the dangers of spreading the disease and possible objections from the European Union, which had banned such movements on the continent. Licences for moving animals from large holdings direct to slaughterhouses continue to be issued. Pig meat has reached 81% of normal supplies, beef 53% and lamb 25%. webTitle: Body of galleries chief found on beach

fields.headline: Body of galleries chief found on beach
fields.trailText: Police are investigating the mysterious death of Sir Richard Foster, director of National Museums and Galleries on Merseyside, whose body was found on a beach in Dorset.
fields.body:
Police are investigating the mysterious death of Sir Richard Foster, director of National Museums and Galleries on Merseyside, whose body was found on a beach in Dorset.

Detectives are not treating the death as suspicious but say they are unable to establish how the 59-year-old father of three died.

Sir Richard's body was found by a walker on the shore of the popular North beach in Swanage. A spokesman for Portland coastguard said: "We received a call from a member of the public yesterday morning saying that a body had been washed up on North beach. Initial examination and investigation suggested that no other person or vessels were involved."

A post-mortem examination is due today and it is in the hands of the coroner to establish whether Sir Richard's death was accidental. Formal identification was taking place late last night.

Tributes for the popular director came in from across the arts world. Chris Smith, the culture secretary, said he was shocked and saddened. "Richard ran one of the most important groups of museums in the country, and he was an extremely eloquent and effective champion for them."

Sir Richard led the team responsible for eight Merseyside galleries including the Walker Art Gallery, Liverpool Museum and the award-winning Conservation Centre. He was credited with leading Liverpool's museums through the chaos of local government changes in the 1980s to make the group of venues the first national museum in the provinces. He was considered one of the most popular and well respected gallery directors in Britain and was honoured in the millennium honours list 18 months ago.

After a distinguished 35-year career in the museum industry he planned to retire from his £80,000-a-year post in 2002. Born in Bournemouth, he was a keen yachtsman. He had travelled to London last weekend with his wife Lady Mary, who returned to their Wirral home on Tuesday, while her husband stayed on. When he failed to turn up for an appointment on Wednesday, she reported him missing.

David McDonnell, chairman of the trustees at the galleries, said: "We are all devastated at the news of Sir Richard's death. Our immediate thoughts are with his wife Mary and his three children. Not only will the staff of National Museums and Galleries on Merseyside miss him greatly, but the whole museums community today finds itself deprived of a great visionary."

Sir Nicholas Serota, director of the Tate, said: "Sir Richard Foster was much loved by his colleagues and was admired for his determination for his gentle humour combined with surprising modesty in the light of his achievements."

Neil McGregor, director of the National Gallery and a close friend, said: "Richard Foster was unquestionably the wisest museum director of his generation, and the one everybody turned to for advice. He was the only person to take a group of regional galleries through the tremendous turbulence of the collapse of local government and endow them with national status.

"He achieved this with as much modesty as charm and intelligence. He was a terrifically approachable and modest man. He was truly the servant of the institution, there was no ego there at all. He had the rare human skills to lead the museums through that period of great change without any disruption."

Eddie Klein, the lord mayor of Liverpool, said: "His loss on Merseyside is going to be absolutely enormous. He was extremely proud of the fact that he was the integral force in acquiring for Merseyside the biggest ever grant given to a conjunction of galleries outside London, £32m." Eight galleries in Liverpool were closed in sympathy yesterday.

Five months ago Lea Parkinson, 32, fell 150 feet to his death from the Lowry Centre in Salford Quays, Greater Manchester, where he was head of arts. He died 10 days before the centre was opened by the Queen. Police said that there were no suspicious circumstances.

webTitle: Lambs die as sheep farmers pay price of movement ban

fields.headline: Lambs die as sheep farmers pay price of movement ban
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: This morning at 5am, farmer Meirion Lloyd will have trekked four miles to pick his dead lambs out of pools of blood in the mud.
fields.body:
This morning at 5am, farmer Meirion Lloyd will have trekked four miles to pick his dead lambs out of pools of blood in the mud. Some might be hanging stillborn from their mothers. Others will have died from cold or starvation. Rain will be pounding their field in north Wales.

At this time of year, ewes should be in heated sheds and secluded fields for lambing, assisted by farmers and vets. But tens of thousands of uninfected ewes put out to graze in October have been stranded, miles from their farms, because of the ban on livestock movement. Some sheep only need to cross a road to reach safe lambing conditions, but cannot be moved. Ewes have been undernourished and exposed to the elements.

Thousands of newborn lambs are predicted to die in miserable conditions and vets and farmers have warned this is the most serious animal welfare issue of the foot and mouth crisis.

Yesterday the Ministry of Agriculture agreed to consider letting some farmers move pregnant ewes within their own land, issuing licences for movement between half a kilometre and five kilometres. The first should be issued next week.

But licences will not cover ewes which need to be moved between different farms. They will not save thousands of uninfected sheep belonging to upland farmers in Wales and Lancashire. In winter, hill farmers send their sheep to graze on lowland dairy farms hundreds of miles away in Yorkshire, Cheshire or Cumbria.

Ewes were due to be returned for lambing last week, but are giving birth on farms where staff have no experience of lambing.

On his farm near Mold, Mr Lloyd has 140 ewes in fields, stranded four miles from safety. He tries to visit them four times a day, removing the lamb carcasses. He faces losses of up to £30 a sheep and is unsure how long movement licence applications will take.

"I find it distressing watching lambs die when all they need is help we can't give them. I can't transport ewes to the vet and I can't pay for vets to come in. I try to be with the ewes as often I can during the day and night, but eventually you run out of puff. I feel guilty every time I go tramping back and forth. I feel guilty that another outbreak could spread just from my movement."

In Lancashire, sheep farmer Thomas Binns, based in Pendleton, near Clitheroe, cannot make a daily four hour round trip to South Yorkshire to tend to his pregnant ewes. He has 220 ewes spread over three counties. His business makes £1,000 profit a year, without affording him a salary. His resources are stretched to breaking point.

Mr Binns said: "The grazing season is over on dairy farms so there is no longer enough grazing grass for the ewes to eat, yet they are stuck there in the final stages of pregnancy. Although the farmers who own the land are doing their best, they do not have the skills to help.

"The ewes need nutrients and injections. Underfed, they will not be able to provide milk for lambs who will starve. Pregnancy toxemia could set in. Mortality rates will double. It is a desperate situation in which animal welfare is being seriously compromised."

Mr Binns said he wanted the government to allow sheep in unaffected areas like Yorkshire to be transported back to their farms. "There comes a point when we have to compromise to avoid an animal welfare disaster."

webTitle: Lesbian police sergeant cleared of trying to kill lover

fields.headline: Lesbian police sergeant cleared of trying to kill lover
fields.trailText: A police sergeant was yesterday acquitted of attempting to murder her girlfriend, an inspector.
fields.body:
A police sergeant was yesterday acquitted of attempting to murder her girlfriend, an inspector.

Tina Nash, 41, was warned by Judge Mark Dyer at Bristol crown court that she could still face prison after admitting causing actual bodily harm to Sara Glen. He adjourned sentencing until next month so that reports could be prepared.

During the eight day trial, the jury of seven men and five women heard how Nash strangled Miss Glen, 31, with her T-shirt on March 31 last year, tightening the ligature until her lover was unconscious. She then took a paracetamol overdose.

She said that she had become frantic and depressed because of Miss Glen's friendships with at least four other women, including Sergeant Katherine Willoughby. All three women are serving in the Hampshire force.

Miss Glen moved into Nash's home in Cowplain, near Portsmouth, shortly after the couple met in summer 1998. The following year, they began living at Miss Glen's new home at Bartley in the New Forest. But Nash became increasingly suspicious of her lover's friendships with other women.

The pair broke up briefly in January 2000 before continuing their relationship on an "on-off" basis.

But it was Miss Glen's relationship with Katherine Willoughby which caused the defendant the most despair. Nash and Sgt Willoughby had been in a two-year affair a decade before when both were involved in other relationships.

The defendant introduced her girlfriend and ex-lover and suggested that Miss Glen should help Miss Willoughby prepare promotion forms, but soon became convinced the pair were having an affair. Matters came to a head when Miss Glen admitted she had kissed Miss Willoughby in her van.

In court Miss Glen said Nash grabbed her round the throat and threw her against a wall accusing her of "shagging" Miss Willoughby in her van.

"She was just screaming really loud and shouting that she was going to kill me and kill herself and kill Katherine," Miss Glen said. Nash denied saying this.

The following night Nash arrived at Miss Glen's flat and the pair went to bed together. Nash claimed she had gone to the house to kill herself, telling the jury: "I had no wish to live anymore because my spirit was broken. I was filled with pain and just wanted to surround myself with sleep and wish the pain away." But before taking an overdose Nash wrapped her T-shirt round Miss Glen's throat and tightened it until she was unconscious.

The jury was told Nash refused to answer questions when interviewed by detectives, but said: "I'm very much in love with Sara and care for her deeply. I never wished to do her any harm."

Nash now faces internal disciplinary proceedings. Superintendent Paul Stickler, of the Hampshire force, said: "This was a particularly tragic case. Tina Nash was a thoroughly professional and competent officer."

Nash, who first joined the Hampshire force as a 16-year-old cadet, spent most of her career in the CID, including spells in a child protection unit. Detective Inspector Peter Swann, her supervising officer in one case, described her as one of the best detectives he had worked with.

Neither Miss Glen nor Miss Willoughby, who are now in a relationship, were in court for the verdict.

webTitle: Spice Girls deny rumours of split

fields.headline: Spice Girls deny rumours of split
fields.trailText: They were founded on hype and became the biggest band in the world, selling millions of albums and rubbing shoulders with Nelson Mandela and the Prince of Wales.
fields.body:
They were founded on hype and became the biggest band in the world, selling millions of albums and rubbing shoulders with Nelson Mandela and the Prince of Wales.

But yesterday the Spice Girls were seeking to dodge the headlines for once, denying rumours of a split after Melanie Chisholm said she wanted to work on her own.

"I don't intend to do any more work with the Spice Girls," she told Reuters news agency.

"Really, I've not been comfortable being in the Spice Girls for probably the last two years. It doesn't really feel that natural to me any more ... I've grown up, and I just feel that I want to do things my own way and not compromise."

But a spokesman for the band, Alan Edwards, said the comments referred to Mel's immediate future and that the group was still together. "What she said is that we've got no plans at the moment and it's been exaggerated.

"As everyone knows, the Spice Girls are pursuing their own solo projects but the Spice Girls still exists. It ain't over until it's over and it ain't over."

Chisholm was widely considered the band's strongest singer and has managed the most successful solo career, selling more than 2m copies of her debut album, Northern Star. Her departure would leave three Spice Girls: Victoria Beckham, Melanie Brown and Emma Bunton. The fifth member, Geri Halliwell, walked out in 1998.

The band shot to fame in 1996 with the release of their debut single Wannabe. But in recent years they have focused on solo careers and motherhood. They did virtually no promotional work for their third album Forever, which dropped out of the top 40 within weeks of its release last year.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Father punched baby to death
fields.body:
Father punched baby to death

A father who punched his five-month-old son to death on a railway platform and then tried to blame a group of youths was yesterday jailed for five years. Trevor McDonald, 25, of Whitley Bay, pleaded guilty to manslaughter at Newcastle crown court last month.

Bungle the bear in road rage case

Stanley Bates, 58, who played Bungle the bear in the TV series Rainbow, was yesterday bound over for 12 months by magistrates at Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk, after he appeared before them on a charge of assaulting Christine Marconi, 40, in a "road rage" incident.

More cinema tickets sold

Figures from the office for national statistics show British cinema admissions last year reached 137.1m, compared with 134m the year before. The highest grossing film was Toy Story 2, which took in £40m.

Apocalyptic expectations

A lifesize waxwork by Maurizio Cattelan of Pope John Paul II being poleaxed by a meteorite, a highlight of last year's Royal Academy Apocalypse exhibition in London, is set to fetch up to £430,000 at auction in New York in May.

Here today and soap tomorrow

A study carried out to mark the 200th anniversary of the first British census has revealed that there was a real Mrs E Sharples living in Coronation Street, Manchester, in 1861 - and that there was an Albert Square in east London, populated almost entirely by "prostitutes, sailors and brothel keepers".

webTitle: Eighteen more attacks linked to rail rapists

fields.headline: Eighteen more attacks linked to rail rapists
fields.trailText: Detectives are investigating 18 more sex attacks which could have been carried out by railway rapists John Duffy and David Mulcahy, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
Detectives are investigating 18 more sex attacks which could have been carried out by railway rapists John Duffy and David Mulcahy, it emerged last night.

The women have come forward since Mulcahy was convicted in February, largely on the evidence of his former partner in crime.

All of the possible victims come from London or Hertfordshire - the favoured areas for what the pair chillingly called "hunting" expeditions.

Detective Superintendent Andy Murphy, who led the investigation which ended in Mulcahy's conviction, is in charge of looking at the new cases and the victims will be interviewed in the next few weeks.

He said: "These women have found the confidence to come forward after seeing justice served in respect of Mulcahy. My team will be conducting inquiries to gather evidence and identify the offender or offenders involved in these new cases.

"It has taken a great deal of courage for them to come forward and they will be treated with respect and dealt with as sensitively as possible."

Mulcahy was convicted after Duffy, who was jailed in 1988 for a series of sex attacks and murders, finally named his partner to a prison psychologist. The news that more possible victims of the pair had come forward came as Duffy, 42, was sentenced for a string of attacks he admitted to the psychologist and later to police.

He is already serving life and has been told that he is one of only 23 prisoners who can never hope for release. Yesterday, though his counsel said it was academic, he was sentenced to another 12 years. He has now admitted 25 sex crimes including three murders between 1975 and 1986.

His decision to give evidence against his former boyhood friend Mulcahy won approval from the Recorder of London, Michael Hyam, when he sentenced him yesterday.

He said: "You chose to give evidence against Mulcahy. Your evidence, without doubt, formed the basis of the prosecution's case against him. Without your efforts it may be doubted whether the prosecution could have succeeded."

Mulcahy, 41, is serving three life sentences for murder and also received 24-year jail terms on each of seven rapes and 18 years each for five conspiracies to rape.

In 1997, when he had spent nearly 10 years in jail, he claims his memory returned. He began talking about them to psychologist Jennie Cutler and then to police.

He admitted every attack he remembered. Some were carried out alone but Duffy also named his childhood friend, David Mulcahy, as his partner in many.

The pair, who had met at school and lived in Hampstead, north London, had formed what was described during Mulcahy's trial as a "unique but wicked bond". They searched out lone women to rape, becoming more violent and finally killed.

"There is a lot of self-hate for what I have done," Duffy told the Old Bailey. "I feel a lot of guilt. I have raped and killed young ladies. I accept that. I am not trying to shift the blame. I did what I did." Yesterday he apologised to all his victims.

"His compelling evidence against Mulcahy in the witness box helped secure the conviction of a serial killer and a rapist.

"There is no doubt that the impact of the crimes of these two men was devastating. Our exhaustive inquiry has meant they will never be back on the streets offending again."

webTitle: Link 'discovered' between cluster of five CJD deaths

fields.headline: Link 'discovered' between cluster of five CJD deaths
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Health specialists investigating a cluster of five deaths from the human form of mad cow disease yesterday said they believed they had discovered a link between the cases.
fields.body:
Health specialists investigating a cluster of five deaths from the human form of mad cow disease yesterday said they believed they had discovered a link between the cases.

The conclusions by the team from Leicestershire health authority on the cluster, which is centred on the village of Queniborough, near Leicester, will not be released until they have been ratified by independent experts and until the families of victims are informed.

However, it is understood they do not contradict the findings of an interim report in November. This revealed that the investigation was concentrating on the preparation and selling of meat products during the 1980s. Other possibilities, such as the village being infected via the water supply, surgery, vaccines, work places or baby foods, had been discounted.

Residents will be told of the conclusions on March 21. Privately, some families of victims are concerned at the apparent delay between the link being discovered and the official publication of the report.

All five who died from variant CJD between August 1998 and October last year had lived in the Wreake and Soar valleys of Leicestershire. They did not have a common butcher.

Yesterday the man who has led the inquiry, Philip Monk, consultant in communicable disease control at Leicestershire health authority, said the inquiry was "virtually finished" but would not say what conclusions had been reached. He said the link was not obvious.

webTitle: The trial of the benign don

fields.headline: The trial of the benign don
fields.standfirst: Organised crime figures line up to testify in New York against one of the mafia's least flamboyant bosses, said to be the last of a dying breed
fields.trailText: Organised crime figures line up to testify in New York against one of the mafia's least flamboyant bosses, said to be the last of a dying breed.
fields.body:
Anthony Spero finally had a day out yesterday, but the 72-year-old pigeon-fancier would have preferred not to have spent it in a Brooklyn courtroom being tried for ordering three Mafia killings.

Mr Spero - said to be the number three, or consigliere, in one of New York's five crime families - has been under house arrest for almost two years, and is allowed out now only to go to federal court.

The benign-looking old man, who is alleged to have been everything from a soldier to the acting boss of the Bonanno crime family, is one of a dying breed.

A detective called the trial "one of the last of its kind," recalling the days when tales of turncoats, loansharking, gambling, rackets and revenge served cold were the common currency of the city's legal system.

Since then the families' influence has since waned, their leaders have dispersed, their membership has fallen, under the impact of a series of set backs, the biggest of which were the jailing of John "Dapper Don" Gotti, boss of the Gambino family, in 1992 and Vincent "The Chin" Gigante, five years later.

Gotti, also known as the Teflon Don and the most prominent gangster in the US since Al Capone, courted celebrity. Gigante, who acquired the soubriquet of The Oddfather, would wander Greenwich Village in a bathrobe, apparently intent on appearing too mad to be really bad.

Mr Spero, on the other hand, has no nickname. Grey-haired and not much more than 5ft (1.5m) tall, he confounds the mob mythology fashioned by popular culture. There is nothing about him of Tony Soprano's wise-guy brashness, none of the corrupt grandeur of the characters in Francis Ford Coppola's film The Godfather.

His bearing is closer to the anachronistic breed of mafia employed in director Jim Jarmusch's cult movie Ghost Dog. Indeed, the main character, a hitman played by Forest Whitaker, tends pigeons on a rooftop.

Mr Spero prefers cardigans and sausage sandwiches to designer suits and dinners in New York's finest steakhouses.

His chosen medium of communication with his mob underlings is said to have been meetings with fellow bird enthusiasts on top of the Big Apple car service, owned by his daughter Diana, in Brooklyn. They would then pass on his orders.

Asked what Mr Spero's favourite topics of conversation were, one witness told a bail hearing: "Baseball, football, women. Organised crime, mafia - anything like that has never come from his lips."

He is accused of ordering the killing of a drug dealer who threatened him in 1993 and, two years earlier, that of a small-time thief who made the mistake of breaking into his daughter's home and stealing a necklace with her name picked out in diamonds.

Alphonse "Little Al" D'Arco, a former crime boss who is testifying for the 10th time in a mob trial, told the court of his last meeting with Mr Spero.

"He went off in the speech that all rats, their families, women and children, should be murdered. I was shocked. In this life you don't interfere with personal family."

The Bonannos were the first crime family to be penetrated by the undercover FBI agent Joseph Pistone, who provided the kernel of the story for the film Donnie Brasco, starring Al Pacino.

"After that, they closed ranks," Jerry Capeci, author of several books on the mafia, said. "They've tried to operate like a secret society."

Joseph Massino is credited with that closing of the ranks, after he allegedly took control eight years ago.

"Joe Massino learned from the mistakes of other bosses who unwisely attracted attention to themselves," Lewis Schiliro, former assistant director of the FBI's New York office, said.

"He is the undisputed leader of the family, a low-key guy who avoids the spotlight, who has brought back discipline and order."

Mr Massino, 58, is a co-owner of the Casablanca restaurant in Queens, frequented by such stars as Hugh Grant, Liz Hurley and Johnny Depp, whose photographs are on the wall.

When Mr Pistone walked past Mr Massino to testify during his trial on racketeering and extortion charges in 1986, the restaurateur is said to have asked him: "Hey Donnie, who did you get to play me in the movie?"

Now Mr Massino says: "I did my time, I paid my dues. They can claim what they want, but it's not true. I don't believe there is such a thing as the mafia. A bunch of Italian guys goes out to eat and they say it's the mafia."

The Bonannos are now rated as second only to the Genovese family and considered unlikely to be severely damaged, even if Mr Spero is found guilty.

Daniel Castleman, of the Manhattan district attorney's office, said: "They are the only family with an undisputed leadership and without serious internal struggles."

That might be difficult for Mr Spero to accept when, on his outings from unfashionable Staten Island, he listens in court to at least a dozen organised crime figures giving evidence against him.

He was charged with nearly 20 others. All but Mr Spero have pleaded guilty, and several are expected to give evidence against him.

Mr Spero's lawyer, Gerald Shargel, told the court that the case against his client would rest on the word of self-confessed killers and drug peddlers. And, in any case, he said, "Not one witness is going to come in here and say 'I had a conversation with Anthony Spero about murder' or anything like that.'"

Listening to Mr Shargel was Dan Grimaldi, who plays the part of Patsy Parisi in the new series of The Sopranos.

"I'm hoping that the truth comes out and that he's found not guilty of these terrible allegations," the actor, whose sister is Mr Spero's girlfriend, said.

A family affair

The acting boss of the Luchese crime family, Steven Crea, 53, is facing charges of extracting millions of dollars from New York City construction schemes through bribery and rigged bids.

The Colombo family's boss, Carmine "The Snake" Persico , 67, is serving 139 years for murder and racketeering.

The head of the Gambino family, John Gotti, 59, is dying of throat cancer while serving life for murder and racketeering.

The Genovese family's boss, Vincent "The Chin" Gigante, 72, is serving 12 years for conspiracy to commit murder, racketeering and extortion.

The head of the Bonanno family, Joseph Massino, 57, owns restaurant and food businesses.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Fighting halts Guineau aid | Boy, 14, gets life for killing girl, 6 | Italians will vote on May 13 |  Spanish blast kills policeman | Swiss closer to legal cannabis
fields.body:
Fighting halts Guinea aid

The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has halted food distribution in southern Guinea after a rebel attack yesterday near the border with Sierra Leone and Liberia.

UNHCR aid workers are struggling to feed and evacuate up to 140,000 refugees who have been stranded for months by fighting.
Reuters, Conakry

Boy, 14, gets life for killing girl, 6

A boy of 14 who killed a girl of six was sentenced to life in prison by a Florida court yesterday.

Lionel Tate, who was 12 at the time, was convicted in January of first-degree murder. He was tried as an adult and received the mandatory term of life without parole.
Reuters, Fort Lauderdale

Italians will vote on May 13

Italy's general election was set yesterday for May 13, touching off what is expected to be a bitter fight between the centre-left, led by Francesco Rutelli, and the centre-right, led by the media baron Silvio Berlusconi.

Polls suggest that Mr Berlusconi, 64, who was prime minister for eight months in 1994, has a good chance of defeating Mr Rutelli, 46, a former mayor of Rome.
AP, Rome

Spanish blast kills policeman

A police officer was killed by a bomb in Hernani, northern Spain, yesterday as the Basque separatist group Eta responded to a police operation against the separatist Haika youth movement.

Haika declared yesterday a "day of battle" after 16 of its leaders were arrested. The police accuse Haika of promoting street violence and acting on Eta's orders.
Giles Tremlett, Madrid

Swiss closer to legal cannabis

The Swiss government endorsed a bill to legalise the use of cannabis and allow a limited number of "dope shops".

"Decriminalising the consumption of cannabis and the acts leading up to this takes account of social reality and unburdens police and the courts," it said.
Reuters, Berne

fields.headline: Thoroughbreds bolt
fields.trailText: A sign of the times? The British Bloodstock Agency, listed on Aim, has begun the process of going private.
fields.body:
A sign of the times? The British Bloodstock Agency, listed on Aim, has begun the process of going private.

According to its chairman, Major CR Philipson, a company "highly dependent on the contributions of senior individuals" is unsuited to the stock market when conditions are as they as are now.

The company was advised by Cazenove, that bluest of blue-blooded firms, to sell its British and Irish businesses leaving it with cash and a few properties.

The net asset value of the company, which buys and sells horses for wealthy individuals, is estimated to be about 94p, compared with the 80p closing price on Thursday, before the sales were announced. Yesterday, the shares ended 10p higher at 90p.

The directors intend to return £1.8m to shareholders after an egm later this month to approve the disposals.

fields.headline: Rightwing scandals turn Toulouse pink
fields.standfirst: Socialists poised to take conservative city, with help from a new popular force
fields.trailText: Socialists poised to take conservative city, with help from a new popular force.
fields.body:
On the wide, elegant and windswept expanse of La Place du Capitole in central Toulouse there is as much talk as anywhere in France about la vague rose (the pink wave) which the pollsters predict will roll across the country in Sunday's local elections.

"So will Toulouse fall to the left?" the local paper asks, a question being posed with equal urgency in other such conservative bastions as Lyon, and even in Paris, which has not been run by socialists since the Commune of 1871

"It's about time it did," Jean-Paul Tissot said forcefully from behind his charcuterie stall in the midweek market. "We need some fresh air. The left deserves a turn."

It may well get it. The Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, flew down last weekend to la ville rose - named after the colour of its bricks rather than its politics - to congratulate the mainstream left's candidate, François Simon, for planting "the seeds of doubt" in France's fourth-biggest city.

Dominique Baudis, a popular centre-right mayor, managed for 18 years to win the support of the city's moderate voters. But he is moving on to a top civil service job in Paris, and his chosen successor, Philippe Douste-Blazy, is by no means assured of taking over.

A national swing to the left and the capture of prominent centre-right strongholds such as Toulouse and Lyon would be a big boost to Mr Jospin's morale.

In particular, the almost certain Socialist victory in Paris will seriously set back the Gaullist president Jacques Chirac, barely a year before presidential and national assembly elections.

Five years ago France was split neatly down the middle, with right and left sharing roughly half of the 448 towns of more than 20,000 people.

This time the left seems likely to benefit from the scandals surrounding Mr Chirac's party, the RPR, and the bitter divisions and bickering that have made a mess of the right. Mid-term support for the Socialist-led government is also holding up unusually well.

"The advance of the left is essentially a national trend," Stephane Rozès, of the polling group CSA Opinion, said. "The economic and political picture favours the left, while there is little motivation for rightists to go out and vote given how divided their leaders are."

But here in Toulouse local politics remains a highly local affair. Mr Douste-Blazy's task has been made immeasurably more difficult, and Mr Simon's correspondingly easier, by the emergence of an alternative force on the local scene: a joy ous multicultural, post-Seattle caravan of musicians, social workers, students, immigrants, retirees and unemployed people with its roots in the city's rundown and troublesome northern suburbs.

Les Motivé-e-s have put on concerts and plays and run raucous neighbourhood meals and meetings in the name of "participatory democracy".

The movement, which began with militant youth workers angry at the way teenage immigrants were being excluded from French society, has spread to the disaffected left.

The latest polls give Les Motivé-e-s 12%-15% of the vote in Toulouse, more than enough to make them the kingmakers at city hall. If they decide to strike an alliance with the left, they could gain 16 or 17 councillors out of a total of 69.

"Toulouse is a wealthy city, the capital of the European aviation and aerospace industry, but it has a massive prob lem with social exclusion, with the integration of its immigrants," said Marie-Christine Etelin, a radical lawyer who is sixth on its list of candidates.

She pointed out that a big proportion of Toulouse's inhabitants are of immigrant origin, be they Spanish, Algerian, Moroccan or Italian.

It also has a strong radical tradition, having clutched to its rosy, brick-built heart thousands of anarcho-syndicalist Spaniards after the civil war.

"There are families who have been here for 40 years and still don't vote," said Ms Etelin, herself of Spanish extraction. "We believe they have to become citizens in the full sense of the term, really be given all their rights and responsibilities. It's the only way to achieve true integration."

To Salah Amakrone, who heads the group's list, the success of Les Motivé-e-s reflects Toulousains' refusal to accept the way politics is currently practised. "We have ensured that an awful lot of people will go out and vote who have never voted before ... That's a nice helping hand for democracy, isn't it?" he said.

Les Motivé-e-s will probably form a coalition with the mainstream left between the two rounds of voting, tomorrow and March 18, if that will defeat the right. But they will refuse executive posts on the council, aiming rather to act as a two-way channel of information between the town hall and the suburbs.

And while Mr Jospin seems likely to emerge as the overall winner tomorrow, he has taken good note of "the messages, the rejections, the anger, the hopes and the fears" revealed by Toulouse's unexpected support for Les Motivé-e-s. fields.bodyText: On the wide, elegant and windswept expanse of La Place du Capitole in central Toulouse there is as much talk as anywhere in France about la vague rose (the pink wave) which the pollsters predict will roll across the country in Sunday's local elections. "So will Toulouse fall to the left?" the local paper asks, a question being posed with equal urgency in other such conservative bastions as Lyon, and even in Paris, which has not been run by socialists since the Commune of 1871 "It's about time it did," Jean-Paul Tissot said forcefully from behind his charcuterie stall in the midweek market. "We need some fresh air. The left deserves a turn." It may well get it. The Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, flew down last weekend to la ville rose - named after the colour of its bricks rather than its politics - to congratulate the mainstream left's candidate, François Simon, for planting "the seeds of doubt" in France's fourth-biggest city. Dominique Baudis, a popular centre-right mayor, managed for 18 years to win the support of the city's moderate voters. But he is moving on to a top civil service job in Paris, and his chosen successor, Philippe Douste-Blazy, is by no means assured of taking over. A national swing to the left and the capture of prominent centre-right strongholds such as Toulouse and Lyon would be a big boost to Mr Jospin's morale. In particular, the almost certain Socialist victory in Paris will seriously set back the Gaullist president Jacques Chirac, barely a year before presidential and national assembly elections. Five years ago France was split neatly down the middle, with right and left sharing roughly half of the 448 towns of more than 20,000 people. This time the left seems likely to benefit from the scandals surrounding Mr Chirac's party, the RPR, and the bitter divisions and bickering that have made a mess of the right. Mid-term support for the Socialist-led government is also holding up unusually well. "The advance of the left is essentially a national trend," Stephane Rozès, of the polling group CSA Opinion, said. "The economic and political picture favours the left, while there is little motivation for rightists to go out and vote given how divided their leaders are." But here in Toulouse local politics remains a highly local affair. Mr Douste-Blazy's task has been made immeasurably more difficult, and Mr Simon's correspondingly easier, by the emergence of an alternative force on the local scene: a joy ous multicultural, post-Seattle caravan of musicians, social workers, students, immigrants, retirees and unemployed people with its roots in the city's rundown and troublesome northern suburbs. Les Motivé-e-s have put on concerts and plays and run raucous neighbourhood meals and meetings in the name of "participatory democracy". The movement, which began with militant youth workers angry at the way teenage immigrants were being excluded from French society, has spread to the disaffected left. The latest polls give Les Motivé-e-s 12%-15% of the vote in Toulouse, more than enough to make them the kingmakers at city hall. If they decide to strike an alliance with the left, they could gain 16 or 17 councillors out of a total of 69. "There are families who have been here for 40 years and still don't vote," said Ms Etelin, herself of Spanish extraction. "We believe they have to become citizens in the full sense of the term, really be given all their rights and responsibilities. It's the only way to achieve true integration." "We have ensured that an awful lot of people will go out and vote who have never voted before ... That's a nice helping hand for democracy, isn't it?" he said. Les Motivé-e-s will probably form a coalition with the mainstream left between the two rounds of voting, tomorrow and March 18, if that will defeat the right. For in the longer term it could be the whole bipolar tradition of mainstream French politics that is undermined.

fields.headline: At this price?  GUS
fields.trailText: Shares in Great Universal Stores slipped a shade yesterday, when an Italian fashion designer took his talents elsewhere.
fields.body:
Shares in Great Universal Stores slipped a shade yesterday, when an Italian fashion designer took his talents elsewhere.

They dropped 5p to 528p as analysts tried to decide whether the departure of Mr Menichetti from the group's Burberry fashion offshoot might delay the planned flotation of the business.

Burberry has undergone an amazing revival since the arrival of Mr Menichetti and chief executive Rose Marie Bravo three years ago.

When they arrived the business was famous for turning out old trenchcoats favoured by home counties' matrons and Japanese tourists. But under the guidance of Ms Bravo and Mr Menichetti the Burberry check has become a status symbol which adorns everything from bikinis to spike-heeled boots, and the business has become GUS's jewel. Its sales climbed 35% in the last quarter.

After much speculation the group, which owns Argos, traditional home-shopping catalogues and the Experian credit information business, recently confirmed it is planning a partial flotation, and analysts quickly decided it could be worth £1bn - or maybe even £2bn.

But in the fickle business of fashion, the designer rules.

Gucci prizes its chief designer Tom Ford so highly that it agreed to pay him like a pop star - with a $25m share deal.

Now that 36-year-old Mr Menichetti has put down his pencils - only a fortnight after star billing at London fashion week, it remains to be seen if Ms Bravo can fill the gap seamlessly.

An SG Securities analyst said his departure created uncertainty over the proposed IPO.

GUS has a breathing space. Luckily, as it turns out, it decided not to rush the IPO. It promised no further details until the summer and no float until next year.

That gives it plenty of time to find a new designer and assess whether the brand is still booming. The shares are a hold.

webTitle: Red Cross signs deal with Statoil

fields.headline: Red Cross signs deal with Statoil
fields.trailText: The Norwegian Red Cross insisted yesterday that a ground-breaking deal with Statoil, the state-owned oil company, would not compromise its independence.
fields.body:
The Norwegian Red Cross insisted yesterday that a ground-breaking deal with Statoil, the state-owned oil company, would not compromise its independence.

"Nobody can buy the Red Cross," said Sven Mollekleiv, general secretary of the Norwegian branch, who signed the agreement with Statoil.

Under the terms of the three-year deal, Statoil will give the Red Cross NKr2m (£155,000) a year and provide the non-governmental agency with facilities to allow it to promote its work.

In exchange the Norwegian Red Cross will use its international experience to help increase Statoil's awareness and knowledge about humanitarian issues in countries in which it operates.

The initiative comes as Europe's oil majors try to change their image under pressure from human rights campaigners, green activists and petrol price protesters.

BP last year gave itself a makeover, saying its initials now stood for "beyond petroleum" rather than British Petroleum. But at its annual meeting next month it faces a barrage of shareholder resolu tions calling on it not to drill in in the environmentally sensitive Arctic region and to pull out of a venture in China because of that country's occupation of Tibet.

Statoil, like Shell, has been criticised for its activities in Nigeria where foreign energy companies have been implicated in human rights abuses practised by the military.

Mr Mollekleiv said the deal would not place any restrictions on the Red Cross. "We will be critical of Statoil if they do something we don't like, something we think they should not do."

The Red Cross would never sign an agreement that placed restrictions on what it could do, how it could act or who it could help. "We feel comfortable [with the Statoil agreement], the International Red Cross feels comfortable."

Geir Westgaard, Statoil's vice-president in charge of country analysis and social responsibility said the Red Cross would be able to help Statoil "get a clearer understanding of the complexities of countries in which we are operating".

"It could be anything from cultural dos and don'ts to the challenges of operating in areas where there is conflict."

Statoil has issued proposals to sell a third of its shares.

fields.headline: Intel leads hi-tech rout
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The hi-tech sector was savaged again yesterday as another series of job losses and profit warnings were announced, led by the world's largest computer chip maker, Intel.
fields.body:
The hi-tech sector was savaged again yesterday as another series of job losses and profit warnings were announced, led by the world's largest computer chip maker, Intel.

On the anniversary of Nasdaq's internet-fuelled peak, hi-tech shares on both sides of the Atlantic were marked down heavily. In London, Bookham, the optical chip maker which cut 150 jobs earlier this week, closed the day 10% lower at 443p, Arm Holdings was off by the same amount at 373p and Cedar Group was 13% softer at 250p.

Intel added its name to a growing list of hi-tech businesses to report a weakening in demand. The statement, alongside reports that Cisco Systems is preparing to cut its workforce by 5%, some 2,500 jobs, ripped through the Nasdaq, which during the day fell to levels not seen for more than two years.

Concerns for the sector have caused the Nasdaq to fall precipitously, losing 59% of its value in the 12 months since it reached a record high of more than 5,000. The index had dropped by 4.5% to 2,069 points by early afternoon in New York.

The Techmark index in London which charts the progress of the domestic hi-tech sector closed 3% lower at 2308.7.

"When someone like Intel, who is sort of at the beginning of the food chain, says there is a real cutback in orders, it strikes some fear in the hearts of people," said one broker.

Intel shares fell 11%, to $29 after the world's leading computer chip maker warned late on Thursday night that first-quarter revenues would be roughly 25% below the previous quarter. The company said it intended to cut 5,000 jobs.

The warning was the third from Intel in recent months and blamed the downturn in the economy for dampening demand for personal computers. Weaker demand for PCs has had a knock-on effect on other areas such as networking, communications and server computers, the company said.

Microsoft shares slipped 5% to $56 after two separate downgrades on Wall Street, citing Intel's announcement as evidence of a slowdown in IT spending and weak demand for PCs and servers. Dell Computers fared worse, falling nearly 10% to $23.

Shares in Cisco, which makes the computer network ing equipment that powers the internet, also dropped almost 10% to $20. A spokesman for Cisco declined to comment on the reports of job losses which are expected in the wake of its failure to meet earnings targets for the first time in six years.

Alcatel demonstrated that mainland Europe has not escaped the downturn and warned that mobile handset sales had begun to fall away, although it maintained earlier forecasts for first-quarter and full-year turnover in its telecoms division this year.

Alcatel predicted a first-quarter operating loss at its mobile division and blamed excess stocks among clients. The company is implementing a cost-cutting programme and said healthier networking and optics businesses made up for the weaker handset sales. Alcatel shares closed 7% down at €42 (£25).

Other poorly performing stocks in London included Logica, marked down 7% to £14.33, Orchestream off 4% at 160p and Arc, 7% lower at 183p. Eidos also fell by 2% to 210p.

webTitle: Cricketing victory for Major in MCC election

fields.headline: Cricketing victory for Major in MCC election
fields.trailText: John Major has won one of the most important election victories of his life after a long and acrimonious battle for one of Britain's most coveted seats.
fields.body:
John Major has won one of the most important election victories of his life after a long and acrimonious battle for one of Britain's most coveted seats.

The former prime minister has gained a place on the elite committee of the MCC, the spiritual home of cricket.

Despite being invited to stand by MCC president Lord Alexander, the former chair man of NatWest Bank, there was vehement opposition.

Dr Nigel Knott, a campaigner for MCC reform, sent a letter to Mr Major demanding he withdraw due to a "conflict of interest" with his role as a president of Surrey Cricket Club. Mr Major's refusal prompted Dr Knott to run as a rival candidate.

But at the close of play a delighted Mr Major went home smiling.

fields.headline: Refulgent horns
fields.trailText: Refulgent horns
fields.body:
While I was away last week I saw a concert notice in the Times, assessing a performance which seems to have been almost perfect. But nothing is ever quite perfect, and the critic was on the lookout for flaws here and there. Were the horns, he inquired, a tad too refulgent?

I am far too old and weary to claim that this criticism has never been uttered before. Should I do so, someone would swiftly write in claiming to have a tape of some reheasal in the Queen's Hall in which the orchestra's leader could be heard inquiring of Sir Thomas Beecham: "Were the horns a bit too refulgent, your honour?" to which the great man answered: "A tad". But never from now on will I go to a concert without probing the horns for excessive refulgence. This one sentence has changed the whole pattern of Smallweed's life.

A season ticket-holder writes: Could this perhaps be the same critic who wrote one day this week in a report of a Man United match that goalkeeper Fabien Barthez "flaunted his florid resilience?"

Smallweed omnisciently replies: Perhaps. Next time I hear a great London orchestra, I shall be on the lookout for florid resilience too. If at any time I detect a moment of florid resilience on the part of refulgent horns, I shall leave the building immediately. I advise you to do the same.

Sir Peregrine Worsthorne was interviewed this week about the case of a London headmaster who bans from his school young people caught using four-letter words. This Worsthorne, they told us, was only the second person to use what I suppose we must call the F word on the BBC's airwaves, but he clearly disapproved of mere teenage groundlings doing the same. He saw it as a form of dumbing down, of the whole of society adopting the practice of what I think he described as the bottom class. This is odd, as I'd always believed that the upper classes swore quite as freely as the plebs, with only the middle clases keeping their language clean.

The oddest feature, however, was that Worsthorne described talk of this kind as something you heard on the top of a bus. I found it hard to grip the concept of Worsthorne on top of a bus, until I remembered that travelling pantheon, the number 94 from Piccadilly to Acton - surely the only bus on which such a fastidious fellow would deign to travel. Some time next week, shouldering aside such refulgent figures as George Steiner, Pierre Boulez, AS Byatt, JK Rowling and the late Isaiah Berlin, I shall force my way to the front of the upper deck in the hope of catching Sir P swearing away like billyo.

The entrepreneur JC Bamford, who died the other day, achieved something which, according to my (often imperfect) research, has been done by no other. An object became known across the civilised world by his initials. In his case, the thing was an earth mover, or as we now say, JCB. For writers and artists to be known simply by their initials is no rare thing.

I could if I chose, which I don't, cite GBS (George Bernard Shaw) or RLS (Robert Louis Stevenson). Some offices are known by their initials: PM, for example, meaning prime minister, LCJ (Lord Chief Justice) and MFH, master of foxhounds (though not, I hope for much longer); though curiously there seems to be no comparable shortform for the archbishop of Canterbury. In music, K means Köchel, who catalogued Mozart, and also a little confusingly, Kirkpatrick, who did the same for Scarlatti. Gilbert and Sullivan are habitually G&S, just as Marks and Spencer are M&S, while the drug M&B is a short form of May and Baker. But none of them got there unaided. Stretching a point one might also rope in JFK, which nowadays means not just President John F Kennedy but the airport named after him.

The nearest thing I can find to JCB is Ekco, a kind of radio set named after EK Cole, who made it. None of these in my judgment, however, quite emulates the achievement of JCB. What's more, he was born in Uttoxeter, which some readers may remember was first in Smallweed's list of places to visit this year.

Next week in Smallweed: A profile of Sir Dudley Uttoxeter Köchel Wörsthörne - inventor of the DUKW.

Is there anyone still alive, apart from Smallweed and Smallweed's friend Nick, who cherishes as warmly as we do the memory of a British movie of 1944 called Don't Take It To Heart? A tad refulgent, perhaps, but at least as we remember it did not descend to flaunting its florid resilience. I scan the listings regularly, but nobody seems to revive it. We remember the opening as if it were yesterday: a rickety-rackety bus roaring through the innocent countryside, an eccentric Frenchman in its driving seat steering with one erratic hand while eating an apple, and then the village in which it was set, in which everyone had the same surname, Bucket, except for the posh folk up at the hall who pronounced it Bucquet (like bouquet). This, by the way, was long before Hyacinth Bucket. There had, some local wiseacre warned us, been a certain amount of intermarriage: shot of a shop with a fascia reading: W Pail. Richard Greene, on his way to becoming Robin Hood, was the star, though according to my friend Nick, it also involved Claud Dampier and Edward Rigby as a very old butler. The writer-director was Jeffrey Dell, whose other writing credits included Sanders of the River (with Paul Robeson), Lucky Jim (1957) and Carleton-Browne of the FO, with Terry-Thomas and Peter Sellers (1959) which he also directed.

He also published a novel, a satire on the film industry, called Nobody Ordered Wolves. I hope it was as good as its title.

I find to my surprise that Dell was the second husband of Jill Craigie, preceding Michael Foot. It was Dell, then working for Alexander Korda, who awakened her interest in writing and directing for the cinema. He was born in 1904 and died, I think, in 1985. I still hope that one day the NFT will stage a Jeffrey Dell retrospective so I can go and see Don't Take It To Heart again; though I might at the very last moment decide not to go, in case it proved to be much less wonderful than my friend Nick and I have believed all these years that it was.

Smallweed@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Mr Not-so-clean
fields.trailText: March 10 2001, comment: The report on Mandelson seeks to cover up the real scandal of his behaviour, writes Richard Norton-Taylor.
fields.body:
Shortly before the Hammond report into the "dome cash-for-passports" scandal was published, political journalists were told Downing Street was concerned most over what it would say about the secret intelligence reports on Mr Hinduja, that lucky Indian millionaire now clutching his official maroon document following Mr Mandelson and Mr Straw's "helpful" efforts on his behalf.

Tony Blair need not have worried, if he really ever did. For the Home Office's own former chief lawyer has an answer, however implausible, to every uncomfortable incident he feels he has to record.

Unsurprisingly, Hammond concedes there was indeed "intelligence material" about the controversial and high-profile Indian businessmen brothers at the centre of allegations of corruption in a major arms deal. Disturbingly, he concedes that this MI6 intelligence which he acknowledges to be relevant, mysteriously escaped the attention of the Home Office, the agency responsible for granting citizenship.

Yet, astonishingly, he finishes up by suggesting that even if it had not, it would not have made any difference.

Downing Street is, of course, right to fear the MI6 material. Despite Hammond 's staggeringly complacent comments, it goes to the heart of the really crucial outstanding issue - the allegation that Mandelson is still lying in the impression he gives about what he knew at relevant times of those major bribery accusations against the Hindujas, while he was merrily taking their dome money and commending their passport applications.

The MI6 files also raise serious questions about the judgment of senior cabinet ministers, all of whom also regularly receive intelligence reports. Hammond conveniently ignores this.

With the masterfully calculated insouciance of someone well-versed in Whitehall culture, he says the Secret Intelligence Service - MI6 - accumulated "a certain amount of intelligence" on the Hindujas which it would "not be appropriate" to describe in detail. He concedes the material did "raise the possibility" that the Hindujas had been involved in "dubious practices" in some cases amounting to "illegal activities".

Yet none of this intelligence was passed to the Home Office. Why not? Because it was collected "in response to a request in a different context", says Hammond . Only beneath the surface does his report hint at another explanation - the Hinduja brothers were becoming so important to the dome project that both Home Office officials and Mandelson either ignored or played down possible MI5 and MI6 concerns .

MI5, explains Hammond , is concerned only with Britain's "national security" and allegations of corruption in India by prominent businessmen seeking British citizenship had nothing to do with that. But wouldn't the MI6 intelligence have been relevant to the test of "being of good character" enshrined in the British nationality act?

Certainly, says Hammond . Indeed, he goes further. Since it was such an "important and sensitive" question, the home secretary would have had to be consulted if the Home Office had ever seen the files. But it does not matter - the intelligence would "probably" not have made any difference because of its "speculative and inconclusive nature".

This is another artful choice of phrase. Hammond knows perfectly well MI6 reports never contain "conclusions" as such - they simply provide information, sometimes with references to the reliability of sources, for ministers to act on. This was the mistake made by Ann Widdecombe in January when, in an attempt to embarrass the government, she asked Hammond to investigate claims that MI6 advised that SP Hinduja's application for British nationality should be blocked.

Asked by Andrew Marr, the BBC's political editor in January whether he was aware of the Bofors case when he was inquiring about the Hindujas' British citizenship, Mandelson replied: "I didn't have any knowledge of that, no. All I know is that they volunteered to assist in the underwriting of the costs of that zone in the dome."

But Hammond himself now admits these intelligence reports were seen by Mandelson in October or November 1998, and that he went ahead regardless with the acceptance of pounds 1m of Hinduja sponsorship money. Mandelson recklessly decided to discount the danger of adverse publicity if the truth came out.

Behind the scenes another department, the Foreign Office, was, like MI6, under no illusions. In 1996, Caroline Elmes of the FO's south Asian department, told Andrew Walmsley, director of the Home Office's nationality division, about the Indian government's criminal investigation into the Bofors arms deal - a scandal which had featured prominently in media there for more than a decade. "Given the activism of the Indian courts," she warned, "it is conceivable that the case could come alight."

She gave a warning in language remarkably strong for the FO that "at the very least the Hinduja brothers can be said to have sailed close to the wind in building their business empire".

Ministers, as the Scott report into the "arms-to-Iraq" affair so amply demonstrated, seem to have little time for intelligence reports. In its latest annual report, the parliamentary intelligence and security committee noted that the cabinet committee on the intelligence services had not met since 1995.

Yet of course ministers did not in fact need any secret intelligence to know what the Hindujas were up to. Indian investigators became increasingly convinced that the brothers' request for British passports was linked to charges being drawn up there, and so would have concluded any assiduous reader of the newspapers.

The Hindujas were becoming notorious, as ministers in Britain feted them and they feted ministers. In November 1999, they invited the Blairs to a glittering Diwali party in London - in the conspicuous absence of senior diplomats from the Indian high commission.

None the less, when Mandelson last year personally approached Straw about yet a third Hinduja brother, Prakash, who wanted British citizenship, an official in the home secretary's private office emailed Walmsley saying the family business could benefit "UK interests" and Straw would like the case to be dealt with "helpfully".

Hammond asked the home secretary what he mean by "helpfully". It meant he wanted it dealt with "properly, as was his approach to all cases", Hammond records Straw's reply. "If it was right, within the rules, to exercise discretion in this case, then the Home Office should look to do so."

These knaves clearly think we're fools.

fields.headline: Acquittals all round
fields.standfirst:
Hammond's findings exude complacency

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: March 10, leader: Peter Mandelson will be pleased with the Hammond report. So will Keith Vaz and assorted Whitehall officials, all either exonerated or at least shown in the best possible light by the faithful Sir Anthony.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson will be pleased with the Hammond report. So will Keith Vaz and assorted Whitehall officials, all either exonerated or at least shown in the best possible light by the faithful Sir Anthony. They will value his findings - that Mr Mandelson did not deceive and that Mr Vaz's relationship with the Hinduja brothers was not "improper". Tony Blair, Jack Straw and Alastair Campbell have reasons to be less cheerful - but the real losers are the rest of us. For the Hammond report leaves as much of a muddle as it set out to clear up.

The headlines belong, of course, to Mr Mandelson. He had feared a stitch-up at the hands of a retired civil servant once attached to the Home Office, the department which had played such a crucial part in his fall. In fact Sir Anthony has cleared him, declaring his version of events "honestly held" and finding he never lobbied on behalf of the Hindujas. That puts him in the clear, removing the second official stain on his character (the first, from his resignation in December 1998, remains). He can now move on.

But Mr Mandelson's victory represents a defeat for Mr Blair. For if Sir Anthony has so effusively exonerated the former Northern Ireland secretary then why on earth did he lose his job? Mr Blair said yesterday that the inquiry's sole brief was to investigate claims of cash-for-passports corruption - not the rights and wrongs of Mr Mandelson's sacking. He is strictly right. Still, if this were a legal matter, Mr Mandelson could claim unfair dismissal by his previous employer and demand to be reinstated into his former job. But this is not law; this is politics. Cabinet appointment is a matter of prime ministerial pleasure: the whys and wherefores of late January matter less than the plain fact that Mr Mandelson lost the confidence of his patron. The forensics may be on Peter Mandelson's side, but the politics never were.

Which is not to say that Mr Blair is in the clear. On the contrary, the fact that Sir Anthony could not find hard evidence that might have justified a sacking - like a clear record of a phone call between the immigration minister, Mike O'Brien, and Mr Mandelson, which the latter always denied - reflects badly on the PM. For it shows that Mr Blair acted in haste, pan icked by the media drumbeat which demanded a resolution of the Mandelson muddle. Rather than investigating first, then passing verdict and sentence later, Mr Blair reversed the process.

The PM shoulders ultimate blame for that panic, but some of it also belongs to his chief press secretary. Sir Anthony makes clear that Alastair Campbell deepened the trouble in that fateful January week by straying beyond the form of words agreed with Mr Mandelson, so inviting a fresh round of media frenzy. It was he who let the news cycle drive events, rather than giving cooler judgment time to prevail. The party which mastered spin came to be mastered by it. That this happened is no surprise - not when we have a prime minister who has twice abased himself in grovelling articles written to placate the demands of the Sun. And who was the chief architect of New Labour's media-centred philosophy? Why, Peter Mandelson.

There are other losers. Jack Straw clearly let both Mr Mandelson and Number 10 believe there was firm evidence of that phonecall with Mr O'Brien when there was none. He also went on television all but declaring Mr Mandelson a liar. More damaging still is Sir Anthony's discovery that Mr Straw told aides he wanted Prakash Hinduja's application for British citizenship to be dealt with "helpfully". The home secretary insisted that "helpfully" implied no special treatment and merely meant "properly". Such a stretch of the language recalls David Willetts' "in want of advice" remark in the bad old days of Tory sleaze.

Yet Sir Anthony accepts it, just as he is untroubled to discover that there was damaging intelligence on the Hindujas which was never passed to the Home Office: he says it would not have made any difference to the final decision. That is typical of the report's complacency. It turns out to be a classic insiders' job, the cosy work of a civil servant who points no fingers and attaches responsibility to no one. Sir Anthony hears ten different versions of the same event and decides that every one is right. The result is to leave all players in this drama officially exonerated - but Whitehall itself exposed as the amateurish, back-covering world we had always feared.
