webTitle: Mandelson's fate sealed by Straw's intervention

fields.headline: How fate was sealed by Straw's intervention
fields.standfirst:
Blair emerges as ruthless, the home secretary as sharp, while cabinet secretary is seen as official who overstepped mark

Special report: Mandelson
fields.trailText: March 10: Blair emerges as ruthless, the home secretary as sharp, while cabinet secretary is seen as official who overstepped mark.
fields.body:
Tony Blair

When Peter Mandelson's links with the Hindujas suddenly blew into a crisis the prime minister must have been all too aware that his closest political ally may have been guilty of a lack of candour - as he had fatefully been over his Notting Hill home loan from Geoffrey Robinson.

Yesterday's report acquits the fallen Northern Ireland secretary of deceipt. "I do not believe Mr Mandelson has tried to deceive anyone during the course of these events," Sir Anthony Hammond concluded. Nor was there "evidence of an improper relationship" with the Hindujas.

Yet Mr Blair, at 47 just five months older than Mr Mandelson, forced his friend to resign all the same. If no one did anything wrong, why is Mr Mandelson's career apparently over, brutally ended by the man who owed him so much?

MPs will be asking each other that question this weekend. Mr Blair must already have asked himself. As of last night Downing St had no answer other than to try and move the media spotlight on.

Charitably Mr Mandelson speaks of "muddle" but panic must also feature in Mr Blair's role in the affair: the fear that a protracted fight with the media pack over a high-profile and controversial colleague would end in humiliation and defeat.

John Major had fought such battles and lost. New Labour would be tougher, as Ron Davies, the Welsh secretary, and Mr Mandelson himself had already learned. If a lesser minister, Keith Vaz, for instance, had been involved, there would have been less at stake. "Peter is different," No 10 knew.

As yesterday's report confirms, the prime minister came late to a drama which no one had realised would be fatal, though Jack Straw revealed better antennae than most.

Alerted to the crisis on January 22 Mr Blair left most of the inquiries to key aides, all unelected, Sir Richard Wilson, the cabinet secretary, Jonathan Powell, his chief of staff, and press secretary, Alastair Campbell. He was only directly approached by Mr Straw when Mr Mandelson went public - contradicting the No 10 line.

Since Sir Anthony did not ask to interview Mr Blair his views are not known. In any case the terms of his inquiry excluded the reasons for the resignation - a political matter, beyond a civil servant's reach, insiders explain.

But Sir Anthony does explain how: "Sir Richard had been called to see the prime minister in his flat shortly after 9am on Wednesday morning. There were five people (unidentified) already there as well as the prime minister, and Lord Irvine, (Lord Chancellor) arrived shortly afterwards ... "

Mr Blair reported Mr Straw's testimony, then left early for another meeting. At 10.30 he met Mr Mandelson to thrash out the story ahead of question time which both men faced later that afternoon.

As Sir Anthony blandly reports what followed "has been very widely reported.....(they) met and Mr Mandelson tendered his resignation". Mr Blair emerges as ruthless, but less than loyal. It is a day that will trouble him privately for years to come and politically in the months ahead.

Jack Straw

The home secretary emerges from the Hammond report in an unexpectedly robust role, reminiscent of his past reputation as a "have a go hero" tackling miscreants in his Blackburn constituency.

There is no known history of animosity between him and Mr Mandelson, though they are very different kinds of politicians and both potential rivals - sooner or later - for the post of foreign secretary. Mr Straw's have-a-go zeal will raise some MPs' eyebrows.

This time the alleged miscreant was Mr Mandelson whose supposed call to the office of Mr Straw's junior immigration minister, Mike O'Brien, triggered his second resignation.

Throughout the controversy Mr O'Brien was sure he had spoken directly to Mr Mandelson. But it was Mr Straw's direct interventions with Downing St which appear to have convinced Mr Blair that "Bobby" - as he called his old friend - was not being candid about his role in the Hinduja passport bid.

Mr Straw's interest was aroused by the need to answer a parliamentary question from the Lib Dem MP, Norman Baker, in December 2000. The two ministers finally talked directly on January 16 when Mr Straw - a stickler for protocol - insisted the answer must be "as accurate and complete as possible".

Mr Mandelson reluctantly agreed to be mentioned and Mr Straw later told Sir Anthony that he had also reminded him of the telephone call to Mr O'Brien. Mr Mandelson said the home secretary may have referred to "a general contact" - not specifically a phone call.

Mr Straw also recalled a second conversation, initiated by Mr Mandelson (who does not remember it) in the division lobby during a Commons vote. Again Mr Straw told Mr Mandelson that Mr O'Brien had "a clear recollection" of the phone call. "Did I (make it)?" Mr Mandelson allegedly replied.

After the Observer broke the passport/dome allegations on January 21, Downing St initially took the Mandelson line of "no direct contact," but the Home Office press office spoke of Mr Mandelson's "verbal inquiries".

Mr Straw spoke to Alastair Campbell before the press secretary changed his version at his daily briefing with reporters. That could have been the end of the matter. But that night - January 23 - Mr Mandelson went on TV to contradict the No 10 line and say he did not recall the O'Brien call.

Mr Straw rang Mr Blair directly to tell him what he knew. It was one of several calls in the final hours of the drama which helped seal Mr Mandelson's fate. Mr Blair told Sir Richard Wilson, the caninet secretary, and was consulted - by phone - during the impromptu "kangaroo court" next morning.

Within barely an hour Mr Mandelson was gone. Mr Straw, aged 54, is famously straight-forward, a great survivor in a difficult job. But if he becomes seen as Mandelson's chief assassin it will make him enemies as well as friends.

Sir Richard Wilson

Once it emerged that the cabinet secretary had done an impromptu investigation of the Hinduja passport affair the night before Mr Mandelson was sacked, he was marked as an official who had overstepped the mark. The fact that Sir Richard, 58, is a former permanent secretary at the Home Office, where Sir Anthony spent most of his career, fuelled suspicions among MPs, most of them not fans of Peter Mandelson, that a Home Office stitch-up loomed.

Rumours surfaced that Sir Richard had told Sir Anthony that his report had not recommended dismissal and that he had insisted that his letter to Mr Blair be published in the report - as it is, Annexe P.

Sir Richard's letter is revealing in that it acknowledges a "slippery slope" might exist - a trade-off between passports and financial help with the dome. That would be wrong, he wrote, though it would not be wrong to "pass on" a passport application - "adding a comment on the merits if he wishes".

The letter sets out the principles involved and says this was a "slippery slope" case, albeit one in which no one did anything wrong. It thus backs the crucial view - shared by Sir Anthony - that a phone call (if Mr Mandelson actually made it) does not constitute supporting a passport application or "making representations".

Sir Richard told the PM that there was "not a shred of evidence of impropriety" and proposes that "No 10 should not get too closely involved in this," merely stick to the agreed line. Nonetheless Sir Richard was present at the kangaroo court in Mr Blair's flat next morning. Mr Blair got rid of Mr Mandelson within two hours. Curious or what?

Mr Straw's have-a-go zeal will raise some MPs' eyebrows. This time the alleged miscreant was Mr Mandelson whose supposed call to the office of Mr Straw's junior immigration minister, Mike O'Brien, triggered his second resignation. Throughout the controversy Mr O'Brien was sure he had spoken directly to Mr Mandelson. But it was Mr Straw's direct interventions with Downing St which appear to have convinced Mr Blair that "Bobby" - as he called his old friend - was not being candid about his role in the Hinduja passport bid. Mr Straw's interest was aroused by the need to answer a parliamentary question from the Lib Dem MP, Norman Baker, in December 2000. The two ministers finally talked directly on January 16 when Mr Straw - a stickler for protocol - insisted the answer must be "as accurate and complete as possible". Mr Mandelson reluctantly agreed to be mentioned and Mr Straw later told Sir Anthony that he had also reminded him of the telephone call to Mr O'Brien. Mr Mandelson said the home secretary may have referred to "a general contact" - not specifically a phone call. Mr Straw also recalled a second conversation, initiated by Mr Mandelson (who does not remember it) in the division lobby during a Commons vote. Again Mr Straw told Mr Mandelson that Mr O'Brien had "a clear recollection" of the phone call. "Did I (make it)?" Mr Mandelson allegedly replied. After the Observer broke the passport/dome allegations on January 21, Downing St initially took the Mandelson line of "no direct contact," but the Home Office press office spoke of Mr Mandelson's "verbal inquiries". Mr Straw spoke to Alastair Campbell before the press secretary changed his version at his daily briefing with reporters. That could have been the end of the matter. But that night - January 23 - Mr Mandelson went on TV to contradict the No 10 line and say he did not recall the O'Brien call. Mr Straw rang Mr Blair directly to tell him what he knew. It was one of several calls in the final hours of the drama which helped seal Mr Mandelson's fate. Mr Blair told Sir Richard Wilson, the caninet secretary, and was consulted - by phone - during the impromptu "kangaroo court" next morning. Within barely an hour Mr Mandelson was gone. Mr Straw, aged 54, is famously straight-forward, a great survivor in a difficult job. But if he becomes seen as Mandelson's chief assassin it will make him enemies as well as friends. Sir Richard Wilson Once it emerged that the cabinet secretary had done an impromptu investigation of the Hinduja passport affair the night before Mr Mandelson was sacked, he was marked as an official who had overstepped the mark. The fact that Sir Richard, 58, is a former permanent secretary at the Home Office, where Sir Anthony spent most of his career, fuelled suspicions among MPs, most of them not fans of Peter Mandelson, that a Home Office stitch-up loomed. Rumours surfaced that Sir Richard had told Sir Anthony that his report had not recommended dismissal and that he had insisted that his letter to Mr Blair be published in the report - as it is, Annexe P. Sir Richard's letter is revealing in that it acknowledges a "slippery slope" might exist - a trade-off between passports and financial help with the dome. That would be wrong, he wrote, though it would not be wrong to "pass on" a passport application - "adding a comment on the merits if he wishes". The letter sets out the principles involved and says this was a "slippery slope" case, albeit one in which no one did anything wrong. It thus backs the crucial view - shared by Sir Anthony - that a phone call (if Mr Mandelson actually made it) does not constitute supporting a passport application or "making representations". Sir Richard told the PM that there was "not a shred of evidence of impropriety" and proposes that "No 10 should not get too closely involved in this," merely stick to the agreed line. Nonetheless Sir Richard was present at the kangaroo court in Mr Blair's flat next morning. Mr Blair got rid of Mr Mandelson within two hours. Curious or what? fields.headline: Aldridge's red-letter day
fields.trailText: Tranmere's manager tells Daniel Taylor what it means to face his lifelong love Liverpool.
fields.body:
John Aldridge was eight years old when he went to his first Liverpool match. He was so small, his father Bill stood him on a milk-crate so he could peer through the mass of heads in the paddock in front of Anfield's old Main Stand. Southampton were beaten 2-1 that January day in 1967, and the memories have stayed with him ever since: from the smell of Woodbines wafting across the vast old terraces, to his light-headed exaltation at hearing the Kop voice its approval for the first time.

"I always thought Anfield was a place more beautiful than heaven," he says. "Even when it was empty it used to send a shiver down my spine."

The same may not be said of Prenton Park but tomorrow, when Liverpool make the short hop to Birkenhead, the wave of anticipation engulfing Tranmere Rovers' modest abode promises to emulate the heady moments he savoured across the Mersey.

A few years ago the match might have been likened to a chess beginner sitting across the table from Garry Kasparov. But underestimating Tranmere has become a perilous business. Seven Premiership sides have fallen to the First Division men over the past two seasons, and the weight of expectation is such that Aldridge is finding it hard to sleep.

Ever since that awesome 4-3 comeback against Southampton 2 weeks ago the 42-year-old Tranmere manager has had a thankless task keeping his players focused on anything but tomorrow's match. He even threatened to fine anyone who uttered the L-word. But as a lifelong Liverpool fan, whose boyhood pilgrimage from Garston to Anfield was the highlight of alternate weeks and who went on to score 63 goals in 104 games in the famous red jersey, it has been impossible not to get caught up in the emotions himself.

"We must have seven or eight staunch Liverpool supporters in our squad," Aldridge says. "Andy Parkinson and Gareth Roberts both played with Michael Owen in the Liverpool youth team. My lad Paul is on the books here and whenever he gets the chance he follows Liverpool home and away. And then there's me: I've had some of the greatest moments of my life with that club."

It is difficult to pinpoint the greatest memory of all. Perhaps the league championship in 1987-88, or the following season's FA Cup. Yet Aldridge also recalls his farewell match, a September night in 1989 when Liverpool's last truly great team crushed Crystal Palace 9-0. He began the match on the bench but Kenny Dalglish sent him on in the last few minutes, specifically to take a penalty. Everyone knew he was leaving for Real Sociedad and it was to be his final goal beneath the Kop.

"That will stay with me forever," he says. "I was almost naked by the time I left the pitch; the boots, shirt and socks had all been thrown into the crowd. Afterwards, when I got into the dressing room, I just broke down."

Whatever tomorrow's outcome more tears will probably be shed, whether in anguish or, more likely, pride. Tranmere may languish at the foot of the First Division but the past 12 months have been the most illustrious in the club's history.

"Going around the Wirral, you see so many children in Tranmere shirts now," says the club's chairwoman Lorraine Rogers. "It's no longer just the red of Liverpool or the blue of Everton. A few years ago it was so unusual to see a [white] Tranmere shirt you would slow your car down to point one out. This season we've had our highest average crowd for at least 35 years, and so many more people are proud to be associated with this club."

Such has been the clamour for tickets for Liverpool's visit, the club have had to draft in temporary staff for their ticket office. The tie could have sold out two or three times over.

"Tickets went on general sale last Sunday," Rogers says, "and they were queuing up from 5am, three or four deep all the way around the ground. I suspect a lot of Tranmere fans started off as Reds and maybe under the surface are still slightly pink. Or Liverpool are their first club but they can't afford the tickets there, and Tranmere are more accessible. We certainly took a lot of Liverpool fans down to Wembley for last season's Worthington Cup final."

There is a feeling here that, a year ago, Tranmere did not get the credit they deserved, especially given that nine months earlier the club had been teetering on the brink of insolvency. In fact, their giantkilling exploits should go down as one of the great success stories of recent times. As well as Southampton, they have taken the scalps of Everton, Middlesbrough, Sunderland, West Ham, Coventry and Leeds over the past 18 months.

It is a peculiarity, therefore, that the bread and butter of First Division life has gone so stale of late. "Why that is I just don't know," Aldridge says. "We've become a great cup team but one that struggles in the league. I wish I was a psychoanalyst but I'm not and I don't understand it."

For now, though, the trials of the First Division's relegation skirmish can be forgotten. Rumours of an FA Cup in decline have clearly not reached these parts, and outside Prenton Park there are reminders everywhere that something special is in the offing - from scallies touting tickets in the car park, to the two white-haired ladies in the bakery round the corner debating who will score the goals, Paul Rideout or Stuart Barlow.

"I don't think anyone in the area is talking about anything else," Aldridge says. "Put simply, it's the biggest match in Prenton Park's history."

1999-2000

WC (2) Coventry (h) 5-1*

WC (5) Middlesbrough (h) 2-1

FAC (3) West Ham (h) 1-0

FAC (4) Sunderland (h) 1-0

2000-01

WC (3) Leeds (h) 3-2

FAC (4) Everton (a) 3-0

FAC (5 replay) Southampton (h) 4-3

*(6-4 on agg)

webTitle: Fifa force delay of Old Firm game

fields.headline: Fifa force delay of Old Firm game
fields.trailText: The date of the final Old Firm game of the Scottish Premier League season has been put back a week because of a clash with the World Cup qualifiers.
fields.body:
The date of the final Old Firm game of the Scottish Premier League season has been put back a week because of a clash with the World Cup qualifiers.

The SPL chief executive, Roger Mitchell, criticised Fifa, the sport's world governing body, for forcing the move, which follows the Dutch football association being granted permission to play a qualifier on a date set aside for friendlies only. Mitchell claimed Fifa were acting like "playground bullies" for forcing the switch. As a result, Celtic will now travel to Rangers on Sunday April 29, a week after the scheduled date of April 22.

Meanwhile, the Rangers manager Dick Advocaat is looking for a left-sided player after being snubbed by Everton's Stephen Hughes.

The Ibrox injury crisis has hit the left flank the hardest, robbing Rangers of Giovanni van Bronckhorst, Jorg Albertz, Arthur Numan and Neil McCann. Advocaat now wants to sign a replacement on loan for the rest of the season, but Hughes has made it clear he prefers a permanent move to West Ham.

The Ibrox club's new signing Marcus Gayle, who completed a £900,000 switch from Wimbledon on Thursday, will have to wait for his Rangers debut because he is ineligible to play at Dundee United in the Scottish Cup quarter-finals tomorrow. Van Bronckhorst will also have to watch the game instead of playing in it because he will not be risked. The Dutchman suffered a groin injury just minutes into his comeback game against Hearts last Saturday after being out since October.

There is little chance that Rangers' striker Michael Mols will be able to return in time to have a significant impact on the season, having undergone another operation on his reconstructed knee. The same applies to McCann, who is to have an operation on a groin problem.

Advocaat said: "Michael Mols is here now. It was a small operation, and they think it went quite well. We will have to wait but after an operation you always have to count six weeks. Maybe by then the season is over."

If they fail to win at Tannadice on Sunday it almost certainly will be.

webTitle: FA Cup overflows with intriguing potential

fields.headline: FA Cup overflows with intriguing potential
fields.trailText: Though the FA Cup now plays third fiddle to the Premier and Champions leagues in the public imagination, its engaging capacity for making heroes out of nonentities is undiminished.
fields.body:
If the first FA Cup final to be played at the Millennium stadium in Cardiff takes its cue from the Worthington Cup final there a fortnight ago the spectacle should be worthy of its setting.

Though no one would pretend the match between Liverpool and Birmingham City was a footballing classic, it was not short of incident and excitement. And if the shoot-out which saw the trophy go to Anfield was the false conclusion that settling a cup tie in this manner will always be, the accompanying suspense was real enough.

So it is encouraging to find that the season has produced FA Cup quarter-finals rich in potentially intriguing plots for the remainder of the tournament. This weekend, for example, Wycombe Wanderers can become the second team from the Second Division to reach the last four since the Premier League was formed, joining the six from the old Third Division who went as far.

Tranmere, who reached the fifth round in 1998 and the sixth last season, can now go one better to take the Cup a step closer to its first Nationwide finalist; likewise Blackburn, who are playing consistently well enough to cherish hopes of their first FA Cup final for 41 years.

If the final is to be elitist then the followers of Arsenal and Liverpool will be packing the roads and railways into Cardiff on May 12. Alternatively Leicester City look a reasonable bet, having reached three of the past five League Cup finals, while the thoughts of the romantics will surely lie with West Ham United, who never made Wembley yawn.

Nor, if it comes to that, did Tottenham, whose sixth-round tie at Upton Park tomorrow will be crucial to George Graham's chances of winning a few brownie points with Spurs' new owner. Tottenham's FA Cup successes of 1901, 1921, 1961, 1981 and 1991 are an omen of sorts. And in 1941 they did knock West Ham out of the wartime cup.

Should the law of sod apply both this weekend and in the semi-finals the wisdom of the Football Association's decision to switch the final to Cardiff until Wembley is rebuilt, always assuming this ever happens, will immediately be challenged by an all-London encounter between Arsenal and West Ham or Tottenham.

The strain this would put on the M4 motorway and the Severn Bridge toll booths does not bear thinking about and, since the trains are now about as reliable as taking a stagecoach across Monument Valley with Geronimo on the rampage, it is to be hoped that either the outcome of the quarter-finals or the semi-final draw rules out such a possibility.

It is not as if all-London FA Cup finals can be counted upon to produce riveting contests; few have done so to date. Far better surely for one of the capital's teams to be pitted against Leicester City or one of the northern sides.

The logic of form, comparative status and home advantage demands that tomorrow's draw will have to spare South Wales a London invasion. Arsenal and either West Ham or Spurs will surely be there along with Leicester and Liverpool.

Such an outcome, however, would be completely out of character with this season's competition, which more than most has managed to remind football that, although the FA Cup now plays third fiddle to the Premier and Champions leagues in the public imagination, its engaging capacity for making heroes out of nonentities is undiminished.

A whole sequence of surprises - including Dagenham and Redbridge and Kingstonian taking Charlton and Bristol City to replays, West Ham winning at Manchester United and Everton losing 3-0 at home to Tranmere - was overtaken by the earth-shaking events at Prenton Park when Tranmere beat Southampton 4-3 after trailing 3-0 at half-time.

That night the FA Cup finally came back from the dead and if Liverpool lose to John Aldridge's team tomorrow the old competition will again hold up its head in any company. It will be much the same should Blackburn win at Arsenal or Wycombe at Filbert Street.

A Blackburn win would appear to be the most likely upset. Graeme Souness's side are in form and Arsenal at present cannot be relied upon either to score goals or keep them out.

With West Ham hit by injuries the semi-finalists may well be Tottenham, Blackburn, Leicester and Liverpool. The South Wales traffic police might prefer a final between Tranmere and Wycombe but are likely to be disappointed.

fields.headline: Jansen plays confidence trick
fields.trailText: If Matt Jansen fails to penetrate the Arsenal defence this afternoon it will not be because of a lack of confidence. The 23-year-old striker has been handed the perfect stage to prove his self-proclaimed international credentials as Blackburn visit Highbury in pursuit of an FA Cup semi- final spot.
fields.body:
If Matt Jansen fails to penetrate the Arsenal defence this afternoon it will not be because of a lack of confidence. The 23-year-old striker has been handed the perfect stage to prove his self-proclaimed international credentials as Blackburn visit Highbury in pursuit of an FA Cup semi- final spot.

"The biggest difference between the First Division and the Premiership is that more football is played up there," he said. "Our league is more physical and you can't get the ball down so much, but I think the game against Arsenal will be a good football match between two good footballing sides and it will definitely suit my game.

"We have already been to Derby in the Cup and put five past them. While that is unlikely to happen at Highbury, who knows what we could achieve if we play to our top form? It is a two-horse race and in that situation you must have a chance."

Throughout his career Jansen has surprised many with his assured manner. In 1998 after a two-week trial at Old Trafford he turned down an opportunity to sign for Manchester United and moved to Crystal Palace instead, insisting he wanted first-team football. Palace paid Carlisle £1m for him but his presence could not prevent the Eagles plummeting out of the top flight. Brian Kidd then spent £4.1m taking Jansen back north and into the Premiership in February 1999 but the same thing happened.

Jansen says he was unfazed by the drop in status, and under the guidance of his manager Graeme Souness he has become one of the most feared strikers in the league. Indeed his partnership with another former Palace player, Marcus Bent, has been instrumental in lifting Rovers from a poor start to the season to within two points of an automatic promotion place, with two games in hand on second-placed Bolton Wanderers.

The former England Under-21 player has scored 15 goals this term and, as Sven-Goran Eriksson selected his first England squad this month, there was a strong feeling that he might have a place in it. But he was overlooked and he suggested it was because he was playing in the wrong league. He noted that Eriksson did not select any First Division players and said the only way to further his international career was to play in the Premiership. Hence he has been linked with Leeds, Newcastle, Tottenham and Rangers, and a move up a division, with or without Blackburn, seems inevitable.

Yet the England coach, and his trusty sidekick Tord Grip, know about Jansen's season's work so far. Eriksson was famously lined up to take the manager's post at Ewood Park after Ray Harford was sacked in 1996. Despite the Swede's failure to complete the deal, he and Grip have retained links with the club and have been kept aware of Jansen's progress in the side.

But there is a suggestion that, even though some of his on-field performances have been outstanding, Jansen lacks the composure and temperament to become a world-class striker. Even Souness earlier this year expressed doubts about his consistency. Not surprisingly the "exuberant youth" begs to differ from his manager. He believes he has matured both on and off the pitch as the season has developed and said: "The boss knows I disagree with him. He has accused me of over-playing at times and that did use to be a part of my game that I had to sort out. I feel that I have shaken that off this season, and playing with Mark Hughes has helped."

Despite disagreements about his own game, he certainly appears to be on-message with his manager regarding the importance of this afternoon's tie for the club. Souness has stated that, even if Blackburn make the final, the FA Cup will not be the priority this season. And their biggest fear for their visit to London appears to be that they may have to repeat the fixture in a fortnight's time. Just as the Tranmere manager John Aldridge banished the L-word before his side's FA Cup meeting with Liverpool tomorrow, Souness appears to have forbidden the R-word in his camp: replay.

Blackburn have already suffered fixture congestion from FA Cup replays with Derby and Bolton and any more draws might dent their highly promising surge for automatic promotion. Jansen said: "We want the game to be finished on the day and we will set out to do that. Promotion is a realistic target at the moment and we don't want to upset that.

"The gaffer has said that the league is far more important and he is right. We want to play in these sort of games week in, week out, and we can only do that in the Premier League."

fields.headline: On the spot but off the ball on Merseyside
fields.trailText: John Aldridge has been under intense media scrutiny in the build-up to tomorrow's FA Cup tie between Tranmere and Liverpool, but he was stumped by the first question put by a reporter at Thursday's press conference: "Forgive me for not doing my homework, but did you actually play in the Cup final against Wimbledon?" Aldridge kept his composure sufficiently to reply: "Yes. Next question."
fields.body:
John Aldridge has been under intense media scrutiny in the build-up to tomorrow's FA Cup tie between Tranmere and Liverpool, but he was stumped by the first question put by a reporter at Thursday's press conference: "Forgive me for not doing my homework, but did you actually play in the Cup final against Wimbledon?" Aldridge kept his composure sufficiently to reply: "Yes. Next question."

Bournemouth were not the first club to get an unwelcome surprise when they arrived at Rotherham for Tuesday's game. Having studied the home team's colours, they had carefully packed both their first-choice (red and black) and change strip (white shirts, black trim). As shown in the Football League handbook, Rotherham's shirts are also white - on the front. Unluckily for the Cherries, they are red on the back, an inspired piece of design which, if it was intended to demoralise opposing teams forced to wear borrowed kit, is clearly working.

The debate on the future ambience of the Tottenham High Road (burger joints or trendy cafes?) has reached fever pitch in the local press. Haringey councillor Reg Rice argues: "The fast-food outlets do very well on Spurs match days and football fans really help the local economy. At the weekend the High Road is really buzzing with people coming in for dancing and frolicking and whatnot." That's the George Graham effect for you.

Our search for the most inappropriate pre-match music continues. Reader Alex Chin-A-Fat claims that before Wimbledon's chilly FA Cup replay against Wycombe he distinctly heard the strains of Theme From A Summer Place in the background on the radio.

The new issue of Ipswich's Those Were The Days fanzine carries a refreshingly candid interview with Marcus Stewart, in which the leading scorer for the Horses (as Diary readers know them) is grilled about last year's play-offs. "Q: What were your thoughts when 2-0 down at Bolton in the first game? A: Umm, er, oh fuck!"

It's World Cup crunch time tomorrow as Ghana meet Nigeria, a clash both of local rivals and selection strategies. Whereas the Super Eagles squad is entirely foreign-based, Ghana's coach Jones Attuquayefio has left out all his overseas stars, "whose bluff indiscipline and outright buffoonery", says Accra's Daily Graphic, "have been a serious setback to the country's high international soccer image". Sounds all too familiar.

The Diary's ill-fated betting venture is over, thanks in part to Oxford United's completely unforeseeable resistance at Ashton Gate last week. Thanks to vipsoccer.com for the initial offer, though in our experience if you bet with them you'll end up losing all your money.

The French league is canvassing opinion on whether to enlarge from 18 clubs to 20. The fact that crowd-pullers such as Marseille, Lens and St Etienne are near the relegation zone is, of course, pure coincidence. Michel Platini, for one, is not convinced. "The idea is stupid. If you accept 20 clubs, why not 22 the next season and 24 the season after that? That way, no one would be relegated and everyone would be satisfied." Don't suggest it, Michel, not even as a joke.

Our favourite former ref, Michel Vautrot, is again in fine form in his column on Fifa's website. He recently enjoyed a referees' family seminar in Turkey (who wouldn't?) where the officials' wives were given "advice on diet and personal hygiene for their sporting husbands". Say what you like about Turkish refs, now at least they'll smell lovely.

webTitle: Transfer truce means Wenger could stay

fields.headline: Transfer truce means Wenger could stay
fields.trailText: Arsenal manager to consider a contract extension, as Anderton negotiates with Spurs.
fields.body:
Arsene Wenger, his fears allayed after the transfer-market conundrum was resolved earlier this week, has admitted that there is "no reason" why he should not extend his tenure as Arsenal's manager.

The Frenchman, who has been linked with positions at Barcelona and the Japanese national team, is contracted at Highbury until the end of next season. "No matter what happens I'm at Arsenal until 2002 and why not for longer?" he said yesterday. "There is no reason to change and no reason for me to leave."

Wenger had questioned whether he would remain in club management if a new transfer system was introduced which allowed players to hand in three months' notice and move on.

However he still has concerns over the compromise package hammered out earlier this week, though he accepts it is "workable" and that "the rules will lead to less stability than at present but more stability than we had feared".

Tottenham will open talks with Darren Anderton over an extension to his contract, which expires at the end of the season.

"We will be talking to Darren, he knows we will be offering him an extension, certainly beyond a one-year agreement," said David Pleat, the Spurs director of football. "We will be looking to sit down within the next 14 days to have deep and thorough talks."

Celtic's midfielder Neil Lennon will continue playing for Northern Ireland after considering his future after the sectarian abuse he received from fans during last week's friendly at Windsor Park. "Hopefully that's gone now and we can all get on with playing football," said Sammy McIlroy, his national manager.

Chesterfield's conduct has brought further condemnation from fellow league clubs. "We have received correspondence from Tranmere Rovers FC and Huddersfield Town FC in relation to non-payment of transfer fees," said John Nagle, a Football League spokesman.

Middlesbrough have sent the striker Andy Campbell on loan to Bolton Wanderers for a month. Viking Stavanger have threatened to bring the Norwegian FA into a dispute with Everton over a £230,000 payment which they claim was due when Thomas Myhre played his 75th game for the Merseysiders.

Raul has been suspended for a match and fined 20,000 Swiss francs (£8,000) for his 'handball' goal in Real Madrid's Champions League win against Leeds on Tuesday.

The Spanish striker will miss Wednesday's group match against Anderlecht for what Uefa described as "unsporting behaviour", although Real have already qualified for the quarter-finals.

Raul's action was not spotted by the match referee, Riszard Woljic, though he later apologised to the Leeds players.

"The action by Raul is against the fundamental principles of fair play," Uefa's chief executive Gerhard Aigner said last night.

However, the European game's ruling body decided not to punish Luis Figo or Claude Makelele for allegedly getting themselves booked deliberately, though Uefa will look into reviewing its system of suspensions.

England's Under-18 coach Martin Hunter has named a 21-man party to face Poland in the European Championships intermediary-round first leg at White Hart Lane on March 22.

Full squad : Bothroyd (Coventry), Clarke (Everton), Davis (Man Utd), Evans (Chelsea), Fallon (Barnsley), Halls (Arsenal), Hamshaw (Sheff Wed), Howarth (York), Jackson (Tottenham), Jagielka (Sheff Utd), Jenas (Nottm Forest), Jenkins (Wimbledon), Knight (Chelsea), McMaster (Leeds), Nolan (Bolton), Pennant (Arsenal), Richards (Blackburn), Reid (Rangers), Richardson (Leeds), Ricketts (Arsenal), Stewart (Leicester).

webTitle: Cup of cheer a welcome distraction for Peterhead

fields.headline: Cup of cheer a welcome distraction for Peterhead
fields.trailText: The prospect of a Scottish Cup semi-final beckons for the lowly Highlanders in their first season in the Scottish League.
fields.body:
Peterhead went to bed on Tuesday night facing, so far as football was concerned, mixed blessings. If only the town could claim even that economically. The football club, enjoying their debut season in the Scottish Football League, have been a rare ray of light in the north.

First Division Livingston had sprung a cup surprise by beating Aberdeen that night, but they had also denied Peterhead a local derby and all the passion and hard cash that entailed. The consolation is that Livingston are a division closer to Peterhead's new Third Division habitat. But since the West Lothian club are riding the crest of a wave at the top of the First Division, perhaps it is no consolation at all.

Nevertheless the prospect of a Third Division club making the semi-finals is heady stuff. The other quarter-final ties are all Scottish Premier League affairs but Peterhead's visit to Livingston means that one of the semi-final berths will be taken by a club outside the top 12. Both sides are in their first ever quarter-final.

It is because the SPL was expanded from 10 to 12 clubs that Peterhead and Elgin City made the journey from Highland League to Scottish Football League. Of the two newcomers, Peterhead have had a better time of it.

"It's not been too bad this season," says their chairman Roger Taylor. "But I don't want to stay in the Third Division. I am pleased; we have been feeling our way in the league and it looks like we are set to finish mid-table. It's a basis for improving the team for next season. Rome wasn't built in a day."

The part-timers, who this time last year were being beaten 2-0 by Buckie Thistle in the Highland League, are managed by the former Scotland, Leicester City and Everton midfielder Ian Wilson. He brings to the job his experience in Turkey and Japan as assistant to the much-travelled former Coventry manager Gordon Milne.

"It would have been a dream come true had it been Aberdeen, but we are now looking forward to Livingston," says Wilson. "It's important everyone tries to enjoy this fairytale run as much as possible.

"Livingston have Premier League-quality players; they will be as tough as Aberdeen would have been. It would be foolish for us to play any other way than we normally do, which is about controlling and passing the ball. We are not about launching the long ball. We'll stick to our principles. Sitting back and defending would be asking for trouble."

Taylor confesses to having followed Aberdeen home and away before being asked to get involved with the seaside town club, which became a plc in 1993, nine years after the club escaped bankruptcy thanks partly to the players volunteering to go a whole season without pay. A deal with a supermarket chain means they play in a new stadium which has boasted a second stand since January 27, an auspicious day in more ways than one.

It is unfair to say Peterhead's progress in the cup owes everything to one result. But after shocking First Division Morton 4-1 on January 27 they were the fortunate recipients of a bye to this round because of Airdrie's inability to muster a team. "I wouldn't say we are here under false pretences," says Taylor. "The Airdrie situation was not our problem and there is no one who would knock back a bye if offered."

Peterhead's best cup run was in the 1987-88 season when they lost a fourth-round second replay to Raith Rovers. In 1922-23 season they did meet Aberdeen in the cup but lost 13-0, the hammering caused by the players protesting at the club having agreed to switch the tie from their home turf to Aberdeen.

Taylor's Aberdeenshire accent resonates with the stoicism of a town battered not just by the North Sea. There has even been talk of Peterhead's famous prison being closed. Down by the harbour, trawlers idle as the fishing industry and politicians trade stances on conservation, the size of nets and quotas. "There is a buzz in the town and the town does need it. There have been some factory closures too, such as the Crosse Blackwell canned food plant.

"I am trying to be quite laid back about the trip to Livingston. We are going, it should be a good day and, were we to win, there will have still been bigger upsets in football."

webTitle: Doherty finds a fare way to fortune

fields.headline: Doherty finds a fare way to fortune
fields.trailText: Taxi rides give new impetus to versatile Spurs player who prefers to be in the back.
fields.body:
In football's world of flash cars and million-pound mansions Gary Doherty stands out. At 21 he may have played for the Republic of Ireland and become a regular at Tottenham but he left his parents' house only this week and the sleek motor will have to wait. "I can't drive," he says, "so there's not much point."

Instead a battered taxi was waiting to whisk him away from training yesterday and if he enjoyed the journey it would be no surprise. Taxis, it seems, have played a crucial role in transforming a player who was still awaiting his first Spurs start on Boxing Day into a key figure for tomorrow's FA Cup quarter-final at West Ham.

"I was taking the train from my parents' house in Luton to training earlier in the season, which probably affected my football," says Doherty, whose rapid rise is the more remarkable given that he was signed from the Second Division Hatters less than a year ago.

"I was getting up really early and having a two-hour trek on the train, which is not good for anybody. So I started taking taxis and, even though it cost more, my football started taking off from that point. Now that I've moved into my own place two minutes up the road it's easy."

Win a make-or-break game at Upton Park and the Spurs players may do well to leave in armoured cars. The 0-0 draw between the sides there on January 31 suggests a tight match and, whatever Chas and Dave think, Doherty is not counting on victory because the year ends in one.

"It's a bit of an annoying thing really because it's taken a lot of credit away from our performances," he says of the White Hart Lane superstition. "The comeback against Charlton was great but most people said it was bound to happen because of the year. If we win the FA Cup it's down to us having a good season."

It will, in no small way, be down to the versatile Doherty as well. Having scored the winner in the third round at Leyton Orient, he played a major part in transforming a 2-0 deficit into a 4-2 victory at the Valley. Operating in his less favoured centre-forward position, he started the comeback with a fine run and cross which forced Richard Rufus into an own-goal.

With Spurs underachieving in the league, he recognises the need to win this trophy. "We're a massive club so we should be in Europe," he says.

The good news for him is that he will be employed at the back tomorrow. His three international caps have come as a striker and he made his "nightmare" first Spurs start at Ipswich on December 30 up front, but the Spurs manager George Graham and the Republic coach Mick McCarthy see his future in defence.

"To play in the Premiership as a forward you have to be a really special player," Doherty says. "You have got to have a quick brain like Robbie Keane or be powerful like John Hartson or Mark Viduka, and I don't think I'm either of them at the moment. Centre-half comes easier to me and I feel I've got the attributes to become a more established Premiership player there."

Strong in the air and in the tackle but also neat on the floor, Doherty has proved the worth of Spurs' policy of buying young, lower division talent. Simon Davies, Matthew Etherington and Anthony Gardner show signs of doing likewise. Doherty appreciates he has come a long way fast.

"There's still a wow when I look at the players I'm playing against," he says. "There are no soft teams. Maybe in Division Two you go into a game against some sides and know it won't be as hard as others.

"In the Premiership it's a lot harder and a lot more physical but I've coped well so far and hopefully I can carry on. I think I've played 12 or 13 on the bounce now and I didn't expect to do that. I just wanted to be on the fringe of the team and maybe mount a good push next season."

Having exceeded expectations he hopes to make the Ireland squad for the World Cup qualifier against Cyprus this month. Part of the Ireland team, along with Keane, that won the Under-18 European Championship, Doherty's accent may be as Irish as Andy Townsend's but he was born in Donegal and moved to Luton aged six.

If he achieves as much as his boyhood idol Paul McGrath he will be happy. "He was always my main hero because of the World Cup and he was such a relaxed player," Doherty says. At 21 he may have played for the Republic of Ireland and become a regular at Tottenham but he left his parents' house only this week and the sleek motor will have to wait. "I can't drive," he says, "so there's not much point." Instead a battered taxi was waiting to whisk him away from training yesterday and if he enjoyed the journey it would be no surprise. Taxis, it seems, have played a crucial role in transforming a player who was still awaiting his first Spurs start on Boxing Day into a key figure for tomorrow's FA Cup quarter-final at West Ham. "I was taking the train from my parents' house in Luton to training earlier in the season, which probably affected my football," says Doherty, whose rapid rise is the more remarkable given that he was signed from the Second Division Hatters less than a year ago. "I was getting up really early and having a two-hour trek on the train, which is not good for anybody. fields.headline: New transfer recipe is not the real thing
fields.trailText: Remember what new-formula Coca-Cola tasted like? Thought not. It was introduced in 1988 because Coke executives were terrified by the sales advance made by Pepsi. Never mind that the original recipe had served the company for 100 years, tinkering was undertaken which resulted in a product almost, but crucially not quite, like the real thing.
fields.body:
Remember what new-formula Coca-Cola tasted like? Thought not. It was introduced in 1988 because Coke executives were terrified by the sales advance made by Pepsi. Never mind that the original recipe had served the company for 100 years, tinkering was undertaken which resulted in a product almost, but crucially not quite, like the real thing.

Thus has the European Commission come up with a new transfer system for football. After months of presentations, delegations and behind-the-scenes lobbying, the future emerged this week. A new recipe so impossibly foggy that mud has greater clarity. The Hammond report into the Mandelson case contains less obfuscation than these new guidelines. Or as Gordon Taylor, the chief executive of the Professional Footballers Association, puts it: "Filling in an income tax return is easy compared to trying to fathom this."

It goes something like this. In the old days, if a club wanted to buy a player from another club, the two parties would agree a fee and pay it. True, there were added complications involving motorway service stations, samovars crammed with cash and several weeks of speculative talk in the Sunday tabloids but, like Coke, the system did the job it was meant to do.

In future, under the new recipe, players will be allowed to move once a season provided they are over 23 but under 28, with the selling club receiving a compensation package arrived at by a formula yet to be worked out. Unless, of course, the player will be 29 after August 31 and plays for a "category one" band club, in which case the reparation will take account of the number of training years since the age of 12 - except if he was born on a Thursday, when the buying manager will jump out of the transfer window. I think I've got that right.

Oh, and in all cases, the compensation will be decided by a committee, providing plenty of lucrative work for blazers and bureaucrats. Which is, after all, the most important thing . . . "Football is a simple game," says Taylor. "Don't you think the rules should be simple?"

He has a point. Was there anyone reading the reports of the new deal in the papers this week who didn't lose the will to live by the final paragraph? There seems almost a deliberate attempt to make the conclusions as hard to understand as possible. Though one or two things do emerge from the fog: that there will still be cash compensation for movements between clubs, and that bigger clubs will be better compensated.

"Looking at this, I can't see it having a deflationary effect on the level of transfers," says Taylor. "There has been a lot of fuss for two years leading to not a lot of definition about where we are going to go. Even before the Bosman ruling we had tribunals at the end of the season deciding values, so I can't see much difference with this."

And if you wonder why there has been all the obfuscation, just look at who had the most to benefit from keeping the new rules as ambiguous as possible: the big clubs. If the transfer system had been scrapped as the European Commission originally intended, they would have been the ones to suffer. True, there was much spin from them about smaller clubs losing their livelihoods, yet such altruism is rarely shown when it comes to divvying up the television money.

No, they had most to lose because they counted players as financial assets. So through their lobbying agency, Uefa, they put pressure on the commission to retain some sort of monetary value on the movement of players. Anxious to be seen to be doing something, the commission dressed up the same old monetary exchange in as arcane a formula as it could manage, in the hope that no-one would notice it had caved in.

Which leaves the players no better off than they were under the old, semi-feudal system, still counted as commodities and still without the freedom of moving their labour most of us enjoy. So what is Taylor, who is also the chairman of Fifpro, the international players union, going to do about the new treaty for football?

"That's a very good question," he tells me, "and one much easier to ask than to answer. There's so much detail here, it's far from clear. So the first thing I'm going to do about it is take the report home and study it carefully." Looks like a fun weekend ahead.

And if you're wondering what ever happened to new-recipe Coke, it was abandoned after less than six months in production. No one could quite see the point of it. The old recipe might have rotted your teeth, but at least you knew where you were.

Time for Old Trafford to stand up and be counted

"There is a serious possibility of an accident and the council cannot afford to turn a blind eye." So says Barry Brotherton of Stretford council, explaining why he may be forced to close parts of Old Trafford because the ground breaches health and safety regulations.

The cause of the potential accident? Fans standing during matches. As dangerous acts go, I wasn't aware standing was up there with leaping from 20-storey tower blocks or swallowing razor blades. People seem to get by without damage, say, while standing at bus stops. Or in the queue at Stretford town hall waiting to pay their council tax.

Standing is something most of us manage to perform several times a day without doing ourselves long term injury. Apart of course from Darren Anderton. Indeed, since Old Trafford became an all-seater stadium seven years ago, several thousand occupants of the sections behind the goals have stood throughout matches without any pain except in the necks of those who might prefer to sit down.

As an experiment in safe terracing - light years from the fenced-in death-traps of Hillsborough - it has been clear-cut. But the local council reckons safety has been so compromised that it is prepared to close down a section accommodating as many as 5,000 season-ticket holders.

In which case, as there is nowhere else to put them with every other seat taken, they will effectively be banned from the stadium. You wonder if Stretford council's safety officers have considered the implications of that. If I were them, I would be consulting my lawyer.

Stan, an enigma wrapped up in self parody

The most depressing thing about growing old is the way time accelerates, eventually to breakneck speed. But no one's chronology has headed off at quite the warp factor of that of Stan Collymore, who this week announced himself a pensioner at 30.

Stan's modus operandi throughout his career was this: he would become disenchanted with his lot at a club, fall out with the manager or team mates then agitate for a move. Another team would come in, hoping they might be the ones to unlock his majestic skills. On arrival at the new club he would announce he had come home, slag off his old employers and play a blinder on his debut.

But Stan trouble would soon reappear; before long he would be back at the beginning, disenchanted again. As he got older, the gap between the two points on the Collymore employment graph grew ever closer, from a couple of years at Liverpool to a couple of weeks at Real Oviedo.

Magnificently, in Spain he even missed out the inconvenience of actually having to start a match, moving from making extravagant claims about the hospitality of his new employers to retiring, with only three games as a sub in between. But you couldn't accuse him of hiding his intentions. A fortnight ago he said he wanted to end his career in Spain. It was just that nobody realised he meant 10 days later. If only he could have played football with the same consistency he showed for self-parody, the man might have been an England stalwart.

The word "enigma" was used more than once in the obituaries of his career that littered the papers this week. But none of the send-offs were as succinct as a comment Alan Smith, the Crystal Palace manager, once made about the player he coached in his youth. "In the end, I don't think he was in love with football," said Smith. That was probably what it was about all along.

fields.headline: Hallé/Nagano
fields.standfirst:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
****
fields.trailText:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
****
fields.body:
If Schoenberg's music has at last found a place in audiences' hearts, his tone-poem Verklärte Nacht can take a lot of the credit. His astute decision to arrange his stringent 1902 sextet for string orchestra in 1917 is a major reason why: the effect was to soften its raw intensity with a luxuriant warmth and richness that serves it well.

Even in this form, though, its often exposed textures can be unforgiving, and anything less than total control shows. The arrangement has its full-blooded moments, but Schoenberg retained some of the sextet's immediacy by keeping his textures thin and soloistic. Kent Nagano's restrained approach exacerbated the fragility of these moments rather more than felt comfortable, and this was especially noticeable in the gentle off-beat pizzicato passage after the sudden move to D major, which felt oddly lifeless.

Although it was refreshing to hear the secondary parts in far sharper relief than usual, the effect was slightly disruptive, mainly because they tended to sound garbled. With more rehearsal time, Nagano could probably have got the performance he wanted; as it was, it sounded like work in progress.

Any performance of Schubert's Fifth Symphony stands or falls on the quality of the wind playing. Brought to life, each phrase radiates joy and vitality; flattened out, the whole work simply dies on its feet. It was an ideal showcase for the Hallé wind, who played superbly; even when not playing, they could be seen swaying happily from side to side.

The whole work sounded as effortless as only a really well-crafted performance can. Corners were turned with a grace that does not come by itself - the transition from minuet to trio was especially well done - and the trio itself was miraculous.

Composed a mere 13 years before Verklärte Nacht, Richard Strauss's Tod und Verklärung was clearly Schoenberg's model. The two works share the same close relationship to a programme, the same oppressive, brooding opening mood, the same sudden passionate surges, and the same striving for the light: D major for Schoenberg, C major for Strauss. All of its colours, from the muted death scenes to the gloriously expansive transfiguration theme, were vividly painted.

Dying was, Strauss confided in 1949, exactly as he had composed it 60 years earlier: if this performance was anything to go by, we can all die happy.

fields.headline: LSO/ Belohlavek
fields.standfirst:
Barbican, London
****
fields.body:
One of the points of a festival like the London Symphony Orchestra's Bohemian Spring is to combine music that is familiar with works that are much less well known. If Czech music generally means Smetana, Dvorak and Janacek, this series promises a wider perspective. Those three composers certainly bulk large in the concerts, but there is also space for Suk, Novak, and even Martinu. Josef Suk's brooding Asrael Symphony comes next month, but his early Scherzo Fantastique opened Thursday's concert, conducted by Jiri Belohlavek.

In all these composers there is something essentially and identifiably Czech, passed on from generation to generation, while imported elements were grafted on: for Dvorak it was the classicism of Brahms, for Martinu, 50 years later, it was the French tradition. At the very beginning of the 20th century Suk was naturally indebted to his teacher, Dvorak, but in the 1903 Scherzo - which is a much more expansive work than its title suggests - the bold, imaginative use of orchestral colour shows clearly that he knew Richard Strauss's symphonic poems, and even perhaps Debussy's early orchestral works too. Belohlavek was adept at bringing out those tints, but equally assured in his moulding of the long, sinuous melodies, and glittering woodwind evocations of nature in its central section.

The LSO clearly likes working with Belohlavek - they recognise his seriousness and unfussy musical insights, and respond accordingly. Together, they provided a highly energised platform for Dvorak's Violin Concerto by Sarah Chang that was never content just to sing out the work's reservoir of good tunes, but dug deep to find something much harder edged. Chang's very fast vibrato lent urgency to every phrase, even in the slow movement, while the cross-rhythms of the finale were musically and physically stamped out. She seemed in a hurry, almost impatient.

Anyone lucky enough to hear Belohlavek's impassioned conducting of Jenufa at Glyndebourne last summer will know the sureness of his grasp of Janacek's dramatic architecture. He applied it here to the orchestral ballad The Fiddler's Child, making sure each gesture painted this portrait of rural poverty in ever finer detail, and brought the Sinfonietta steadily and compellingly to its star-spangled conclusion. He always pointed up new things, showing that the inner movements are just as rewarding as the famous framing fanfares.

webTitle: Risk and return: Can Japan make the numbers add up?

fields.headline: Can Japan make the numbers add up?
fields.standfirst: Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: Japan may rank as one of the world's largest economies and retain the third most valuable stock market after the US and euroland, but these days investing in the country hardly registers with retail investors.
fields.body:
Japan may rank as one of the world's largest economies and retain the third most valuable stock market after the US and euroland, but these days investing in the country hardly registers with retail investors.

After 10 years of recession, the economy and the stock market are yet again slipping back. The Nikkei stock market index is at a 15-year low and the economy splutters on without ever firing into life with growth figures at less than 1%.

Last week two of the biggest and most highly rated funds that target Japanese firms have dropped back after the Nikkei index followed the Dow and Nasdaq downwards. The Atlantis Japan Growth and Schroder Japan Growth saw their funds slump by 28% and 11% in just seven days, according to Standard & Poor's online funds service www.funds-sp.com.

Picking at random one week in the year is hardly a recipe for successful long-term investment strategies, but these kinds of falls are indicative of the pain felt by many investors. There are winners, which is good to know when £7bn in UK retail money remains locked up in Japan trusts.

Over the past three years the average Japan unit trust is up 40% compared to the average UK All Companies Trust, which has increased just 27%. Three years, however, is the best period for Japan funds. After the Asian crisis of 1997-98, the markets recovered strongly and much of the growth registered by Japan funds goes back to a mini stock market boom in 1999. Still, some advisers reckon investors should pay more heed to the three-year figures than the the past 10 years or the past 10 days.

"There are still lots of negative things about the Japanese economy," says Jason Hollands of financial adviser BestInvest. "But there are some very attractively priced stocks. Many are companies that are listed in Japan, yet are global companies that rank as market leaders."

Companies like Sony have risen on the back of the Nasdaq and have now followed the market's trajectory downward. Mr Hollands reckons that Sony and other big company stocks are now significantly undervalued.

Michael Wood-Martin, Japan fund manager at Henderson Investors, has just returned from a two-week trip to the country. "Things are still pretty gloomy and sentiment [among investors] is poor. The Nikkei has been stuck in the trading range of 12,000 to 17,000 and can't seem to make any sustained progress." He believes the current drop in share prices, coming on the back of a prolonged slump, will lead to demands for change.

"We might be getting to a crescendo in bear sentiment and the politicians will be forced to do something dramatic to reverse the trend. It is difficult to say it will definitely happen on a certain date, but it looks like it is coming. They have brought in reforms before that have cheered the market for a while, and reforms this time might do the same."

Like the markets in London and New York, Japan has seen a huge fall in the value of its technology sector. webTitle: The Budget: Tax rule  may start new brain drain

fields.headline: Tax rule  may start new brain drain
fields.standfirst:
The brightest array of high tech experts may leave the country if a High Court ruling goes against them

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: The brightest array of high tech experts may leave the country if a High Court ruling goes against them.
fields.body:
Next week a band of computer experts will trudge along to the High Court in London to contest a tax rule which they say leaves them paying tax at more than 50p in the £1.

They say the new rule - known as IR35 - has forced the country's brightest talent to leave in their thousands for the continent and the US rather than pay excessive amounts of tax.

Computer programmers, software developers and other IT specialists who supply their skills to big companies are at the heart of Britain's technology boom. Without them, they argue, Tony Blair's dream of a nation full of energetic, independent techno wizards driving the economy forward will to be an interesting idea and not much else. Many of them hoped the Chancellor would scrap the rule in the Budget this week, but it seems there was never any intention on the government's part to step away from next week's confrontation.

The Professional Contractors Group represents a large slice of disgruntled computer specialists who are caught by the tax rule. Gareth Williams, the group's chairman, says he was disappointed that almost two years of concerted lobbying had failed to change the government's mind.

"The government has been universally condemned for introducing this misconceived measure. This Budget gave the Chancellor the last opportunity to right the wrong before the PCG's legal action," he says. "There is little point in him making token gestures towards small businesses when many of those small businesses will have either closed or moved overseas." The contractors' group keeps a running list on its website of members that have already left the country. A glance at the list shows that most have gone to places with favourable tax schemes. Holland is a top destination as is the US and Germany.

Anywhere between 50,000 and 100,000 IT people could be affected by IR35. The rules are devised to stop what Inland Revenue officials had come to see as a widespread tax scam. The Revenue claims that during the mid-90s it began to see large numbers of people who provided services, set up limited companies that employed one or two others.

A limited company was better than self-employment for several reasons, but mainly to save on National Insurance payments. If the income of the company was in the region of £50,000, the usually male employee would be paid £4,000-£5,000 tax-free (roughly equivalent to their personal allowance entitlement). Another £4,000-£5,000 would be paid to their non-working wife.

Meanwhile large amounts of domestic costs along with business costs like new computers, software and training would be charged as expenses, depressing the amount of taxable income. The difference would be paid out in dividends, which are eligible for income tax but not National Insurance.

In this way, someone with a large income could use a limited company to their advantage. The Revenue says a PAYE employee earning £50,000 would pay, on average, 35% of their income in tax while the computer contractor sitting next to them was paying 21% of their income in tax.

John Birt, the former BBC director general, made the perfectly legal practice famous when it was discovered that he was not a BBC employee despite taking on the top job but, instead, used a limited company that charged his services by the hour.

A senior Revenue official told Jobs & Money that computer contractors and other business people in the service industry were encouraged by accountants to use limited companies to avoid paying tax. The Revenue believed it was losing millions in unpaid class one National Insurance contributions as the computer industry grew and the ranks of contractors swelled.

IR35 says contractors and other workers must behave like self-employed people and work for several employers. Long projects for one employer will mean they are employed by the client. If they manage to fit the self-employment rules, the contractor's company is prevented from retaining company profits for investment, which depresses taxable income. National Insurance will be applied to the companies' income and expenses must be limited to 5% of income.

But the PCG denies that its members used limited companies as a tax avoidance device. It says clients who bring in contractors want them to work under the umbrella of a limited company, which must take responsibility for any mistakes. If the contractor were self-employed, the client would be liable.

The contractor will often employ people to help develop software and work on projects, which is easier to manage and with more legal safeguards in a limited company arrangement.

And it says there is no justi fication for comparing contractors with employees. They qualify for sick leave, holiday pay, pensions, share options and a degree of job security.

Even if they had an equivalent status, under IR35, contractors will pay much more tax than employees without any of the benefits, it claims.

The Revenue official said: "Ministers do not accept that people who work in the IT in dustry are a special case. The government is very keen to support the IT industry, but not by allowing a certain class of people to pay tax in a different way to other employees."

IR35 helpline: 0845-303-3535 or www.inlandrevenue. gov.uk/ir35

Also leaflet IR2003, Supplying Services - How to Calculate the Deemed Payment

fields.headline: Jazz's casual charmer
fields.standfirst:
Bill Charlap
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London
***
fields.trailText:
Bill Charlap

Pizza Express Jazz Club, London
***
fields.body:
You wouldn't go to a Bill Charlap gig expecting to hear the jazz world turned upside down. The axiom that jazz is about the player and not the repertoire can sometimes be harder to demonstrate when the luggage of the mainstream repertoire is as heavy as it is with him. But the New Yorker brings a casual and reticent charm and a compellingly fragile fluency to his handling of some of the most exhaustively-mined keyboard materials in jazz.

On his opening night, Charlap and his musicians initially seemed to be teetering on the edge of the soporific, as is always the risk with an undemonstrative, lounge-piano manner, but the initial caution was soon thrown to the music's winds. From This Moment On exhibited Charlap's easy grace, but the group sounded tentative. Harold Arlen's I've Got the World on a String suggested a general loosening of collars, and Vivvie's Waltz (an original written for the pianist's daughter), with its mix of an emphatic lower-register riff and a feathery, diaphanous principal melody, was positively impulsive.

Charlap's dynamic sense is very subtle and his touch remarkably gentle even at speed, so his double-time lines on this piece soon began to exhibit the mercurial mobility and sparkle that have made him so much in demand with celebrated leaders.

A trademark of his is the deceptively suspended ending, and several of his pieces concluded with devious codas, suddenly preoccupied arpeggios, and dangling silences abruptly resolved in a single theatrically-struck chord.

Charlap's local partners played at first as if anxious not to crowd the leader, and young bassist Mark Hodgson suggested a poise and security all over the register that was only made frustrating by his modesty with the volume control. Drummer Stephen Keogh, reserved at first, eventually hurled himself into a delightful display of uptempo hustling with the brushes on Five Brothers - a bebop sprint Charlap had borrowed from a recording with the late Gerry Mulligan. It triggered the pianist into a surging display of seamless runs and Red Garland-like block chords that ought to have sounded frantic but were as relaxed as a leisurely stroll.

Charlap's unassuming persona added considerable warmth. He even name-checked his high-school piano teacher Jack Riley and gave a thoughtful exposition of a wistful, entirely creditable Riley composition. By the time they got to Dave Frishberg's mixed-tempo Love Rolls On, everyone sounded as if they'd been enjoying this kind of musical conversation for years.

 Last performance tonight. Box office: 020-7439 8722.

fields.headline: Abbey feels unwanted
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Investors lost the Abbey habit yesterday as the recent bid premium in Abbey National ebbed away. After a 25p fall on Thursday, the shares lost yet another chunk of their value yesterday as the clever arbitrageurs became increasingly convinced that the competition authorities would not let Lloyds TSB's £19bn bid go ahead.
fields.body:
Investors lost the Abbey habit yesterday as the recent bid premium in Abbey National ebbed away. After a 25p fall on Thursday, the shares lost yet another chunk of their value yesterday as the clever arbitrageurs became increasingly convinced that the competition authorities would not let Lloyds TSB's £19bn bid go ahead.

The shares in the former building society were down almost 5% by the end of the day at £10.90 while the pain suffered by its suitor, Lloyds TSB, was slightly less, off 2% at £6.45.

According to the market talk, it was a day of unwinding positions in Abbey, that occurring a day after the event which caused the concern: publication of the precise reasons why the office of fair trading had recommended that a full-scale competition com mission investigation was necessary.

The outcome of the investigation, which has barely begun, is unlikely to be announced until at least mid-July. The decision is, however, all but known as far the market is concerned. Only time will tell whether the pessimism about Lloyds' advances being derailed will prove to be true.

Abbey was one of a number of stocks to be savaged yesterday. While the reasons for its fall appeared to be stock-specific, the rout in other sectors of the market, particularly anything hi-tech, was far more a function of a general malaise.

ARM Holdings suffered a 37.5p drop to 331.5p, apparently on the back of the woes of the US chip maker Intel, which made negative comments overnight about the state of the semiconductor market. Arc International was also lower at 171p, down 13p, while Autonomy, relegated from the FTSE 100 index earlier this week, fell yet again, by 45p to £13.09.

The Techmark index was down more than 3% at 2,308, while the blue chip FTSE 100 index slid back into territory below the once-sacred 6,000 level at 5,917, down 85 points or almost 1.5%, on the day. It would need only a further 1% drop in the index next week for last week's closing number of 5,858 -a two-year low -to be eclipsed.

Confusion about the health of the all-important US economy appeared to do little to help sentiment, on top of the fresh anxieties in the technology sector following Intel's bleak warning which exacerbating the fright inflicted by Yahoo! late on Wednesday.

Accordingly, it was telecoms and technology stocks that did most of the damage to the FTSE 100. Colt Telecom , for instance, fell 84p to £12.24 while BT , still seeking support from its long-suffering investors, lost 33p to 555p.

Bookham, down 49p to 444p, attracted attention because of a £10m profit appar ently made by venture capitalist Jon Moulton, who nearly bought Rover.

One of the stocks in the main index to endin higher territory was Shire Pharmaceuticals , in the throes of an intricately structured merger with BioChem Pharma of Canada. The odd trading strategies adopted by the arbitrageurs and hedge funds, detailed here this week, were cited for a reversal of its recent slide. The shares gained 51p to £11.71.

Well outside the FTSE 100, Convergent Communications jumped 8p to 24p after promising investors good news in the coming two years. Bakery chain Greggs hit a new high during the day of £31.19 after its profits rose 22%.

But, most of the tales involved woe rather than joy with pubs chain JD Wetherspoon warning of slowing sales - the reward for which was a 56.5p fall to 347.5p.

Industrial materials firm Scapa's profits warning resulted in a 25p fall to 100p while aborted merger talks between software companies Orbital and KMS forced their shares lower initially, although by the end of the day Orbital was up 3p at 48.5p with KMS down 8.5p at 29p.

webTitle: Business: FSA warns against hedge fund Isas

fields.headline: FSA warns against hedge fund Isas
fields.standfirst:
Watchdog tries to minimise risk on two fronts
Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Watchdog tries to minimise risk on two fronts.
fields.body:
The financial services authority warned yesterday that people should be wary of a new type of individual savings account that invites small investors to put money into hedge funds, traditionally the preserve of the very rich.

A number of fund management firms have introduced or are planning "hedge fund Isas" to attract investors after technology funds' fall from favour.

Last month Deutsche Bank introduced its Guernsey-registered Xavex HedgeFirst fund for investors with as little as £7,000, bringing it within Isa investment limits.

Jupiter plans to launch a product in the spring, while funds from Credit Suisse First Boston and Henderson will open this month.

Hedge funds are traditionally private partnerships used by wealthy individuals and banks to achieve very high returns, often by making use of complex financial tools such as derivatives and arbitrage to bet on market movements.

Some experts say hedge funds will become this year's top investment story. The FSA yesterday urged investors to "think twice" before putting money into "exotic" Isas.

"The FSA is concerned that the rush to take out Isas before the end of the tax year might blind consumers to the risks involved with certain complex products that offer the potential for a high return but often mean a higher risk to capital," a spokeswoman said.

Isas that invest in hedge funds or use derivatives linked to the performance of a complex hedge fund index "are often not suitable for your core investment for the year, particularly if this represents a high proportion of your total savings. They can be difficult to understand, and the costs and charges may not be clear."

She added that some of the funds are registered outside the UK and so individuals may not be covered by British complaints and compensation schemes if things go wrong.

A ban on selling hedge funds to small investors is being legitimately sidestepped by offering "funds of hedge funds".

 A new breed of sophisticated financial contracts could pose a threat to the financial system because users do not fully understand them, according to David Clementi, deputy governor of the Bank of England.

The arcane products, known as credit risk derivatives, are used to trade the creditworthiness of companies and are growing in popularity.

The risk of problems is particularly acute at times of economic uncertainty, such as now.

In an unusually explicit warning, Mr Clementi said the use of credit derivatives, particularly credit default - effectively credit protection policies - raised several concerns.

Not only could credit derivatives be used to spread risk but they could also be used to concentrate it, he said. A bank's shareholders, creditors and regulator might not be able to understand its risk exposure.
