Isas that invest in hedge funds or use derivatives linked to the performance of a complex hedge fund index "are often not suitable for your core investment for the year, particularly if this represents a high proportion of your total savings. They can be difficult to understand, and the costs and charges may not be clear." She added that some of the funds are registered outside the UK and so individuals may not be covered by British complaints and compensation schemes if things go wrong. A ban on selling hedge funds to small investors is being legitimately sidestepped by offering "funds of hedge funds".  A new breed of sophisticated financial contracts could pose a threat to the financial system because users do not fully understand them, according to David Clementi, deputy governor of the Bank of England. The arcane products, known as credit risk derivatives, are used to trade the creditworthiness of companies and are growing in popularity. The risk of problems is particularly acute at times of economic uncertainty, such as now. In an unusually explicit warning, Mr Clementi said the use of credit derivatives, particularly credit default - effectively credit protection policies - raised several concerns. Not only could credit derivatives be used to spread risk but they could also be used to concentrate it, he said. A bank's shareholders, creditors and regulator might not be able to understand its risk exposure.

webTitle: Art review:  I Am Making Art

fields.headline: Rough and ready video art
fields.standfirst:
I Am Making Art
Anthony Wilkinson Gallery, London
****
fields.trailText:
I Am Making Art
Anthony Wilkinson Gallery, London
****
fields.body:
Today video art is fully aestheticised, rivalling cinema in its glossy production values and projected scale. Back in the early 1970s it was another story, as this time capsule of a show demonstrates. Then, video meant a black-and-white monitor, a shoddily-made tape and a frankly baffled audience. Yet the early American video resurrected here is more dramatic than any current efforts.

These videos are contemporary with the paranoid cinema of Pakula, Coppola and Scorsese, and share its terrible introspection. Poor John Baldessari, who, in his mid-30s, burned all his paintings, is here on a tape recorded in 1971, putting on a performance so pathetic, so ludicrous, you want to pat him on the back and say, yes, you're an artist, now please go away. "I am making art," he says, over and over again for 18 minutes, while adopting peculiar convoluted gestures in his clingy nylon top. It would be funny for a couple of seconds as a TV sketch, but there's no let-up. It goes on, becoming more and more desperate. You feel you are intruding on someone's despair.

Or you can watch Vito Acconci pacing around his apartment as he gives a low, creepy voiceover about how you, his next lover, will be completely different from her, from all the others, who made him feel empty inside, made him feel he was wasting time, whom he had to shake just to get a reaction, yes you'll be different, you'll understand.

American art had always teetered on solipsism because it was a romantic art, and the self-obsessed, desperate isolation of these artists is a re-staging of the grand western individualism of Jackson Pollock. This is explicit in a video in which Paul McCarthy smears paint over his body and drags himself across the floor in a hilarious, sincere, terminal re-enactment of action painting. Could anyone make a connection any more? Joan Jonas, in her 1972 piece Duet, has two people reduced to howling like dogs from different sides of a TV screen.

This is America in the 1970s, where the great romantic wave finally broke in self-mockery and neurosis. You think of the music and movies of that time, the evocative melancholy, and here it all seems frightening again.

 Until April 8. Details: 020-8980 2662.

fields.headline: The Big Funk
fields.standfirst:
Arches Theatre, Glasgow
****
fields.trailText:
Arches Theatre, Glasgow
****
fields.body:
"You have no idea what it means to be single these days," Jill tells her new friend, Fifi, who is dressed up like a Christmas-tree fairy. Jill refers to a man she doesn't know smearing her all over with Vaseline - he brings a vat of the stuff to their first date - and the fact that she let him do it. Fifi has other things on her mind, though, having just found out that she's pregnant with twins and that they are due the next day.

This is a typical exchange in John Patrick Shanley's play about thirtysomething angst. Sound like a well-trodden path? Well, Shanley goes off the beaten track and then some to produce an oddball charmer - like Friends set in a self-help manual on acid. The plot is incidental, but colourful: Fifi and her husband, Oscar, a circus knife-thrower, come to terms with impending parenthood; Jill meets Oscar's friend Austen, whose mission in life is to make sad women happy. He wipes the Vaseline away in a moment of kooky delight - Jill in a full tub of water, Dean Martin on the stereo (operated by a rubber duck) and a pair of maracas on the go.

But beneath the surface strangeness this is a meaning-of-life drama at a time when all of us are saturated with advice on how to find that meaning. It is angst as only the post-therapy generation can do it - each character introduces themselves by talking about the dysfunction in their family background, the lack of love, the excess of it. "Let me tell you about me," says Omar, speaking for them all. Whether the play is ultimately a surreal parody of this culture - and there are some terrifically funny moments - or another aspect of it isn't really clear.

Austen speaks directly to the audience at the end, naked and holding a mirror for us to see ourselves anew in. He's full of empowering lines about feeling the big funk, the big fear, and doing it anyway.

This deadly serious mood is undermined by the glorious psychedelia of the set, the great lines ("I feel like I've been through the scumbag Olympics"), some sparkling performances (especially Selina Boyack as Jill, edgy and greasy at the same time), and the glorious self-help-speak of a dinner-party scene.

It turns out Jill likes having grease smeared on her because her father used to put butter on her nose at the dinner table. "Grease is not love," Austen tells her, as if it's a mantra she can take with her. There is one for all of us here in this strange, rather lovely, and gently funky play.

 Until March 23. Box office: 0901 022 0300.

webTitle: Risk and return: It's back to the future

fields.headline: It's back to the future
fields.standfirst:
Small investors should beware those fund managers who point to performance figures dating from 1996, warns Tony Levene

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Small investors should beware those fund managers who point to performance figures dating from 1996, warns Tony Levene.
fields.body:
Remember 1996? Hardly a vintage year. Politics at home were dominated by the last months of the John Major government and seemingly non-stop sleaze. And two of the memorable cultural events of that year - for all the wrong reasons - were Demi Moore's Striptease and Pamela Anderson's Barb Wire.

But if all those are events best forgotten, the investment fund industry has no intention of letting anyone ignore 1996. Quoting five year performance figures - now dating back to 1996 - is a favourite way of attracting the attention of potential investors.

Past performance figures scream out from virtually every unit trust advert. But three and five-year figures can be dominated by a few clever purchases years ago - often when a fund was smaller and more nimble.

The £532m ABN-Amro UK Growth was third in the 209- strong UK All Companies sector over the past five years, and an even more creditable second over three years. The performance has received acres of praise. The fund features highly in the paid-for mentions in the IFA Isa Guides.

Chelsea Financial Services, for instance, say "it is one of the top performing UK Growth Funds over almost all time periods. Indeed, had you invested £7,000 in this fund at launch, your investment would now be worth well over £100,000."

The ABN advert says: "Many are asking how our UK Growth Fund performs so well. By pinpointing areas of promising growth, and producing a performance that is impossible to ignore."

But more recent performance has also been impossible to ignore. Over the past year, it has slumped to 277th out of the 292 trusts now in the sector with a unit price that has been slipping since last August.

While, arguably, it is a good time to buy a trust after it has taken a knocking, investor psychology - as assessed by marketing departments - suggests most savers only plunge into equity-based funds after a long run of apparent gains. So they want the assurance of past success.

The recent fall from grace of the ABN-Amro fund is ignored in the Chelsea publication - admittedly based on figures now some months old.

ABN Amro is not alone in this top to near bottom performance - others include Dresdner RCM UK Growth, Dresdner RCM Mid Cap, Jupiter UK Special Situations, Liontrust First Growth and Norwich UK Growth.

Look through most unit trust adverts and winning past performance has pride of place - there is little on what the trust will do or how it will cope with changing market conditions.

Yet the small print tag that "past performance is not necessarily a guide to the future" is not just a measure of legal protection. It is a proven fact. Back in 1987, statisticians at Exeter University concluded that "past unit trust performance is less reliable an indicator of the future than trying to predict tonight's greyhound winners by using last night's successful trap numbers".

And last summer, the Financial Services Authority published research which took the same line - albeit without the dog track comparison. The watchdog said: "Retail investors cannot increase their chance of choosing a fund that will perform well in the future by picking one that has performed well in the past."

The only straw of comfort was that past performance can help weed out the very worst funds.

Researcher Mark Rhodes says: "A number have examined whether past performance repeats. Where there is any repetition, it is more likely to occur in smaller, poorly performing funds."

Past performance figures are not the only area where consumers need to read adverts with special care. Other potential problems include:

Use of quartiles. These are akin to the divisions of a football league. First quartile includes the relegation zone of the Premiership, while second quartile includes funds around the average mark.

Inappropriate comparisons. Some trusts are favourably compared with building society accounts, ignoring the safety and ease of access of the latter. Others are graded against an unsuitable benchmark - a world fund with currency risks might be lined up against the UK All Share index.

Choice of rivals. Companies select five or ten competitors which have fared less well and compare themselves against them. This can ignore more successful trusts from other managers.

Fund growth. Performance figures may be based on a time when a fund was small and able to take big bets on the market knowing that, if it failed, it could disappear, while success would bring headlines.

Change of manager or strategy. Some funds survive this well - others do not. But fund management companies which attract customers on the back of one manager's talents rarely bother to tell unitholders of any change.

Headline promises. A year ago, the then CGU (now Norwich Union) Monthly Income Plus advertised "a consistent monthly income to keep you going" and a level "which is both high and stable". Income and capital values both fell.

fields.headline: Flexibility sought
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Flexible rules to gauge the solvency of insurance companies are to be introduced by the Financial Services Authority in an attempt to modernise the way the industry is regulated.
fields.body:
Flexible rules to gauge the solvency of insurance companies are to be introduced by the Financial Services Authority in an attempt to modernise the way the industry is regulated.

While the new regime, which will start in two years' time, is not a direct result of Equitable Life's troubles, the more flexible approach may help to speed up a response to any other insurers developing similar problems.

Sir Howard Davies, chairman of the FSA, said: "We propose to require that all insurance companies in the future make their own assessment - on reasonable assumptions - as to the capital and other financial resources they need in order to adequately meet the risks and uncertainties of their business."

Under the current regime neither the regulator or the insurer are given any leeway.

Sir Howard intends to allow insurance companies to make assessments of their risk for insurance claims and expenses in a more sophisticated way. He wants insurance companies to identify adverse scenarios which may alter their expectations for claims by policyholders.

The companies will also be asked to have sufficient financial resources to cope with adverse scenarios.

Sir Howard said the new regime would be simpler than in the past

fields.headline: Spine-chilling Gothic horror
fields.standfirst:
Unheimlich Spine
Riverside Studios, London
***
fields.trailText:
Unheimlich Spine
Riverside Studios, London
***
fields.body:
Theatre increasingly seems to feed off movies. And in Unheimlich Spine director-deviser David Glass takes his inspiration from a cult 1959 horror film, The Tingler, directed by William Castle. The weirdly wonderful, if still evolving, result is a strange mix of Gothic flesh-creeper, camp send-up and celebration of the infinite diversity of human life.

The MacGuffin - the unlikely premise for the spiralling plot - is an obsessive scientist's discovery of a parasite that takes possession of the human backbone and is the source of all fear. The mad prof enlists the help of the bizarre Bobby Bangs, who projects cinema titles onto a blank screen and allows audiences to imagine the film, and who delivers his apparently dead, deaf-mute wife, Close-up Alice, to the doctor for surgical experiment. The removal of her "unhomely spine" leads to her resuscitation, confrontation with her own fear and, ultimately, to her, and everyone else's, regeneration.

The plot may be tosh, but not, as I feared, sadistic tosh. Indeed, what strikes one is Glass's mixture of spiritual benignity and theatrical inventiveness. He clearly believes we have nothing to fear except fear itself and that we need to conquer our irrational terrors. But he also mixes live action, video projections and film music - much of it from Bernard Herrmann's scores for Psycho and Vertigo - with considerable skill. The operation on Alice, suspended at one point in a giant sling behind a whirling glass screen, has a particularly nightmarish effectiveness.

Admittedly there are elements at which I jib: most of all the implication that deaf-mutes can somehow find their faculties restored by shock-therapy. But, for a show much possessed by death, there is a strong life-affirming element, symbolised by the final video projection of a human embryo to a kitsch rendition of Stranger in Paradise.

Kathryn Hunter also brings her customary prodigious inventiveness to Close-up Alice: looking for her missing dog she acquires an all-fours canine desperation, and when her seemingly dead body is transported in a jerky car her limbs take on a flailing independence. Sophie Partridge, who has trained with the Graeae Company, lends Alice's embodied fear a paradoxical angelic sweetness and there is robust support from Amit Lahav as the wild-haired scientist, Therese Bradley as his cabaret-singer wife and Richard Clews as the constantly erect Bobby Bangs. A peculiar evening but one that sees life through a Glass kindly.

 Until March 18. Box office: 020-8237 1111.

webTitle: The Budget: Bank accounts for the homeless

fields.headline: Bank accounts for homeless
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: The Bank of Scotland and The Big Issue magazine have joined forces to launch Britain's first banking service for the homeless.
fields.body:
The Bank of Scotland and The Big Issue magazine have joined forces to launch Britain's first banking service for the homeless.

The scheme, based at the magazine's Scottish head office in Glasgow, has signed up 56 customers and expects to run 200 similar accounts by the end of the year. It offers people previously shunned by financial institutions their own banking facility as they struggle to leave the streets.

Bank of Scotland chief executive Peter Burt said: "By offering people a basic banking service we are providing one of the key factors Scotland's homeless have asked for in their attempts to reintegrate themselves into our society and our economy."

Elsewhere, hole-in-the-wall cash machine outfit Link is close to clinching a deal with the Post Office to connect its 18,000 branches to almost all of the UK's banks and building societies. The move will provide a massive fillip to creating a "universal bank" for the 4m people without a bank account or access to other financial services. The Universal Bank project was launched last year as part of the government's drive to encourage people on low incomes to open bank accounts.

Meanwhile, Yorkshire Bank has launched an investment scheme that aims to raise money for the children's charity NSPCC. For every saver who invests at least £2,000 in its Charity Bond the bank will donate £5 to the charity.

And for fiftysomething investors seeking regular guaranteed income, Birmingham Midshires, has launched a savings bond paying 5.75% before tax (4.6% clear of tax) fixed for five years on a minimum deposit of £1,000.

But National Savings has cut the interest rates on its Isa accounts to 6% while Safeway has trimmed the returns on its Isa accounts to 5.95%.

webTitle: Europe tops advisers' tips for Isas

fields.headline: Europe tops advisers' tips for Isas
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Independent financial advisers (IFAs) are plumping for Europe as this year's top Isa tip.
fields.body:
Independent financial advisers (IFAs) are plumping for Europe as this year's top Isa tip.

A Fidelity poll showed that 77% of advisers are currently recommending European funds to clients. They feature significantly in Isa guides.

Fidelity itself has seen European ISAs move up from 6% of total sales last year to 12% this year.

Yet one of the acclaimed top flight funds - Invesco GT European Growth - has slumped from top to bottom over the past year.

Sixth in its sector over five years, it has collapsed to last of 104 over the past year according to Standard & Poor's statistics. It is down some 45% over the past year - around three times the average decline in European funds. This trust was heavily marketed by discount IFAs a year ago.

But there is no indication of that fall in recent advertising which boasts of three, five and ten year figures under the heading "performance worth applauding".

Nor is the manager's commentary on the website much help. It says: "European bourses were particularly weak in February" and lists falls in some tech stocks.

But it remains decidedly upbeat. "Our medium-term outlook is bullish. European economic growth is robust and inflation should remain low in an historical context. We will continue to focus on fast-growing firms with pricing power, earnings visibility, strong business models and a clear competitive advantage," it adds.

Other managers continue to wave the European flag. Schroders tips "Europe as a haven for 2001", expecting it to avoid the US economic growth standstill.

And Credit Suisse expects Europe to outperform both the US and the UK.

"European equities will deliver respectable returns over the year," it says.
fields.bodyText: Independent financial advisers (IFAs) are plumping for Europe as this year's top Isa tip. A Fidelity poll showed that 77% of advisers are currently recommending European funds to clients. They feature significantly in Isa guides. Fidelity itself has seen European ISAs move up from 6% of total sales last year to 12% this year. Yet one of the acclaimed top flight funds - Invesco GT European Growth - has slumped from top to bottom over the past year. Sixth in its sector over five years, it has collapsed to last of 104 over the past year according to Standard & Poor's statistics. It is down some 45% over the past year - around three times the average decline in European funds. This trust was heavily marketed by discount IFAs a year ago. But there is no indication of that fall in recent advertising which boasts of three, five and ten year figures under the heading "performance worth applauding". Nor is the manager's commentary on the website much help. It says: "European bourses were particularly weak in February" and lists falls in some tech stocks. But it remains decidedly upbeat. "Our medium-term outlook is bullish. European economic growth is robust and inflation should remain low in an historical context. We will continue to focus on fast-growing firms with pricing power, earnings visibility, strong business models and a clear competitive advantage," it adds. Other managers continue to wave the European flag. Schroders tips "Europe as a haven for 2001", expecting it to avoid the US economic growth standstill. And Credit Suisse expects Europe to outperform both the US and the UK. "European equities will deliver respectable returns over the year," it says.

fields.headline: Puccini's visions of hell
fields.standfirst:
Il Trittico
London Coliseum
****
fields.trailText:
Il Trittico
London Coliseum
****
fields.body:
In 1900, when Puccini first mooted the idea of Il Trittico - a "triptych" of one-act operas - his intention was to model the work on the three sections of Dante's Divine Comedy. However, by the time Trittico hit the stage, 18 years later, things had changed somewhat. Hell and purgatory remained: the first of the three operas, Il Tabarro, deals with a deterministic emotional inferno played out in a setting of almost Zola-esque drabness; the second, Suor Angelica, blends torment, salvation and moral questioning. But the final opera portrays a world far from heavenly. Gianni Schicchi is a bitter comedy on the nature of human venality, populated by, arguably, the most obnoxious line-up of characters ever assembled on the operatic stage.

Patrick Mason's ENO production, now on its first revival, doesn't quite get the ambiguous emotional balance right. Gianni Schicchi is, to a certain extent, its weak link, despite a charismatic, forceful and gleefully witty performance in the title role from Andrew Shore. Mason shies away from the opera's inherent nastiness, veering towards slapstick and gaudy caricature. His insights are only intermittently telling. Schicchi's daughter Lauretta, usually played as a romantic drip, is shown to be as manipulative as the rest of the crew. At the end of the opera she calmly prepares to consummate her passion for Rinuccio in the bed of the deceased Donati, whose lucre everyone has been intent on grabbing.

However, the tone doesn't always cohere, and Mason seems much happier with the other two operas. Angelica's convent, a breezeblock structure stalked by stroppy wardresses, is as much a prison as a place of spiritual refuge. Mason updates Tabarro to the years following the first world war, presenting a gallery of compassionately observed, damaged people who play out their tragedy in a smoky landscape that turns a hellish red.

Il Tabarro is very much the high point, boasting an outstanding performance from Peter Coleman-Wright as Michele. Animalistic, sexual and dangerous, he tracks Cheryl Barker's sluttish yet sympathetic Giorgetta with a painful intensity. As Giorgetta's lover, Bonaventura Bottone suggests a certain emotional vapidity, a telling weakness of will. Barker, in radiant voice throughout, returns in part two as a nerve-shredding Angelica, with a performance guaranteed to move you to tears. Anne-Marie Owens is less than ideally vicious as her implacable, persecuting aunt.

Despite some overdone antics, the ensemble that swirls round Shore's Schicchi is exceptional. In the pit, Noel Davies gets to the heart of each opera, contrasting perfectly Tabarro's brooding darkness with Angelica's chromatic, modal mystery and Schicchi's razor-sharp clarity. It is a flawed evening, though the best of it is unquestionably tremendous.

 In rep until April 7. Box office: 020-7632 8300.

webTitle: Debt: Battle to stay in the black

fields.headline: Battle to stay in the black
fields.standfirst:
Millions of people are in the red. Now £1m is being invested to stem the problem. Liz Stuart reports

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Millions of people are in the red. Now £1m is being invested to stem the problem. Liz Stuart reports.
fields.body:
The economy may be doing well, but the personal financial situation of many people in this country is dire. The average person in the UK now owes £2,000, not including mortgage debts.

The National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux says it has seen an increase of nearly 40% in the number of people knocking on its doors, and the National Debtline, a freephone advice service, says 4% of callers owe more than £50,000.

More worrying still, according to research from the Bank of Scotland, one-third of people in debt do not admit they are in difficulty.

While the package of measures aimed at helping low income families announced in this week's budget will ease the fiscal burden for some, others are already too entrenched in debt and turn to private debt management organisations whose consumer contracts are currently under the scrutiny of the Office of Fair Trading.

The government, however, which has already commissioned a task force to examine the problem of debt, has this week said it will inject £1m into advice centres, in a bid to stem the problem, matching money raised by the Money Advice Trust (Mat) from banks and other lenders.

Kim Howells, consumer affairs minister, says: "I want to enable consumers, if they have debt problems, to be able to access high quality free advice when they want it."

The extra funding from the government will go to create two new National Debtline call centres, in Perth and Cornwall, and to expand the present centre in Birmingham, which can only respond to a fifth of the 140,000 call attempts made a year.

"We find that 80% of cases can be dealt with over the phone and then followed up by sending material in the post. Around 20% of people need to go on to have face to face counselling," says Alan Jarvis, director of the Mat, which works in conjunction with the National Debtline.

He adds that Scotland will have its own service for the first time, following findings that just 6% of calls to the midlands-based centre come from north of the border. "Celts want their own line. They want to hear a Scottish voice on the end of the phone," he adds.

So what should you do if you are one of the thousands of people troubled by the amount of money you owe? Rodger McArthur, managing director of personal banking at the Bank of Scotland says: "If you find you can't cope with the level of debt you have accrued, don't ignore the problem by burying your head in the sand.

"But consumers should only talk to reputable high street lenders and established organisations such as the Citizens Advice Bureau; they should avoid debt management companies which promise to consolidate debts and dramatically reduce monthly payments.

"By taking this route, people are only increasing the length of their repayment period and the level of indebtedness, and will also be charged commission for the privilege. This is not the quick fix it appears."

This month's issue of Moneywise magazine offers these additional pieces of advice for people in debt:

Talk to your creditors if you are having problems - don't just stop making repayments.

Don't just pay the creditors who shout the loudest. Your mortgage, rent, council tax, child maintenance and utilities should take priority.

Only offer to pay off debts at a rate you can stick to. With good intentions, it can be easy to be panicked into offering more than you can afford.

Pay off debt first rather than trying to save large amounts - £3,000 of debt can negate £10,000 of savings.

It adds that you should be wary of borrowing four or five times your income to buy a house as, if interest rates rise, keeping up mortgage repayments will be very difficult.

The main reason UK adults take on extra debt is to buy a car and to finance home improvements, followed by buying Christmas presents and a holiday.

If you are concerned about your debts, you can contact the following helplines free of charge: CCCD 0800-138-1111; National Debtline 0808-808-4000.

webTitle: Home truths: Help for flat owners who take control

fields.headline: Help for flat owners who take control
fields.standfirst:
Leaseholders can soon free themselves from tyrant freeholders; many already manage their blocks. Elizabeth Langton reports

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Leaseholders can soon free themselves from tyrant freeholders; many already manage their blocks. Elizabeth Langton reports.
fields.body:
Widespread changes to the laws that govern the ownership of flats and leasehold houses are currently making their way through parliament.

Under one of the most radical changes in the bill, leaseholders will be able to set up companies to take control of the management of their block, in some cases wresting it from cowboy landlords.

The Co-op bank, which views the new form of ownership as a co-operative venture, launched a service last week to support home owners in their new management role. The bank will offer insurance services and even loans to groups of flat owners who need to carry out urgent repairs of the shared property.

The government hopes the Commonhold and Leasehold Reform Bill, published in December, will free thousands of flat owners from the tyranny of crooked freeholders with the introduction of a new form of tenure called commonhold.

The problems faced by leaseholders are well documented. Flat owners have been bullied and intimidated into coughing up for inflated service charges or pay maintenance bills for work that was never carried out.

A lease is also a depreciating asset: the longer a person lives in the property, the less the lease is worth on the market.

Under commonhold, people living in flats and other multi-unit developments will own units individually and be members of a "commonhold association" which owns and manages the common parts of the building used by all the residents.

It will also be easier for leaseholders to buy their freehold or take over the management of the block without purchasing the freehold, if that's what they'd prefer.

Not all leaseholders are at the mercy of a freeholder. Many existing flat owners are already running their blocks through Residents Management Companies (RMCs) where residents also own individual leases and collectively own and take responsibility for the common parts.

Ray Walker, a housing and leasehold expert, argues that the RMCs are co-operatives and should be supported by the co-operative movement. In a report, New Deals for Leaseholders, prepared with Co-op bank, he identifies ways in which the movement can help RMCs and future Commonhold Associations thrive.

RMCs are effectively co-ops of leaseholders that own the freehold of their own block, says Mr Walker. There are currently between 43,000 and 48,000 such organisations. And if the Commonhold and Leasehold Reform Bill becomes law, RMCs will become the biggest form of direct co-operative endeavour in the country, he adds.

In recognition of its status, Mr Walker says the Co-op bank will become the first bank to provide finance (subject to the usual checks) for RMCs. It will lend money to groups of leaseholders who want to buy the freehold from their landlord, a process known as enfranchisement. Secondly, there will also be loans on offer for groups to take up when major work is needed on common parts, such as when a lift fails and its sinking fund won't stretch to cover the cost of the repairs.

It will also lend money to cover financial shortfalls when there are short-term liquidity problems. The bank will look upon the ground rent and service or maintenance charges that leaseholders pay to the RMC as security for the loan.

In addition, the bank has drawn up an insurance package to meet the needs of the RMCs and directors' liabilities.

While there is a great deal of support for changes that pass the power from unscrupulous freeholders to leaseholders who own the flats, few see commonhold as a panacea. Residents who want to manage themselves still have to deal with problems of financial management, says Mr Walker.

These include how to ensure transparency in the running of a block. RMCs will also have to grapple with how to ensure leaseholders don't fall into arrears with charges and how to ensure funds are available to cover running costs if some flat owners pay late.

Leaseholders will need all the support they can get, says Mr Walker. "For most, it will be the first time they have become involved in running a company." There is a danger that the neighbours who volunteer to run the RMC could be worse than the freeholder the leaseholders dumped. As Walker's report says, in some circumstances self-management might "substitute one form of tyranny for another for some residents" as the leaseholders take on directorships and exercise their new power.

To keep personality clashes out of the business of running a block, most groups of leaseholders will want to employ a managing agent. Those living in units of just two or three flats might decide they could do the job themselves.

But even those who do employ a managing agent will need to wrestle with company law, taking policy decisions such as whether to replace a roof or mend it and monitoring the performance of the managing agent, argues Mr Walker.

The Campaign for Residential Leasehold Reform (Carl), is sceptical that many home owners will be willing to take on the responsibility of running their blocks under the proposed measures, because the Commonhold Associations will be subjected to company law and dealing with the complexities of the law will be a huge turn-off. Also, they will not be prepared to subject themselves to the heavy penalties which company law imposes when rules are misunderstood, adds Carl.

But the government is convinced that leaseholders will embrace the new opportunities regardless of the rules and regulations that will surround the new forms of ownership. The Co-operative movement, too, is seizing the opportunity to help home owners take control of their own lives.
